HEADLINE: Embracing la Nouvelle Economie;
String of Big Deals Elevates France in Europe and World

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 27

 BODY:
When Thierry Desmarest joined the French oil company Total as an exploration expert 19 years ago, most of Total's shareholders were French -- including the French state, with a 35 percent stake -- and most of its profit was made in France. Its far larger domestic rival, Elf Aquitaine, was mainly a Government fief run by bureaucrats.
Mr. Desmarest, now the chairman at 53, mused in a recent conversation that it would be "difficult to imagine" Total contemplating a merger with Elf back then. 
 Today both companies are publicly owned, and about 65 percent of Total's shareholders and 51 percent of Elf's are not French. Earlier this year, Total took the brash step of merging with the big Belgian group Petrofina to become Total Fina and is now locked in a brawl to acquire Elf Aquitaine. If Mr. Desmarest succeeds, and he is convinced he will by the end of the year, the combined Elf and Total Fina will still be only half the size of new giants taking shape, like the Mobil-Exxon combination, but it will dwarf many European rivals.
"Things can change rapidly," Mr. Desmarest said, seated in his office here with a view of Elf's black glass headquarters tower.
Indeed, in the last two years, France has moved to shake up and slim down its corporate world more thoroughly and quickly than many had thought possible. And in the process, it is simultaneously creating a kind of fortress within Europe even as it reaches aggressively beyond its borders into the global economy.
France has gone through periods of wrenching restructuring in the past. In the 1980's, heavy industries like steel and coal, as well as financial services like insurance, were reorganized, and tens of thousands of jobs were shed.
But while those changes, which were aimed at overcoming a chronic bloat that was smothering the economy, required France to go through a decade of pain, there are tentative signs that the latest wave of overhauling will produce a much faster payoff.
France has become a darling of foreign investors, and the Paris bourse has surged by 50 percent in two years, against an average of 44 percent for the top 300 European companies.
Growth prospects are brighter than in a long time. This year, the economy is expected to grow 2.5 percent, and though that is less than last year's 3.3 percent because of the downturn in emerging markets, the Government expects as much as 3 percent in 2000. Last year's growth produced a windfall of tax revenues, which were $6 billion higher than anticipated in this year's first half, prompting discussion of possible tax relief.
There is even some relief on the job front. Though unemployment, at 11.5 percent, remains stubbornly high, in this year's second quarter private-sector jobs rose by 266,000, or nearly 2 percent, over 1998. The feeling, however tenuous, that things are getting better has helped transform the gloom that shrouded France in the mid-1990's into a new consumer confidence.
And there is little sign that the corporate reshuffling will let up soon.
In banking, an unsuccessful $37 billion hostile bid by Banque Nationale de Paris for two domestic rivals, Societe Generale and Paribas, ended with the takeover of Paribas, a strong investment bank, by the far larger Banque Nationale, creating what will be the third-largest bank in Europe after Deutsche Bank, the German banking giant, and UBS of Switzerland. The takeover will reshape the banking landscape in ways that could favor future consolidation beyond France.
Emboldened by the changes, French corporations are entering new and inventive alliances.
Earlier this month, the big aluminum group Pechiney joined Alcan of Canada and Alusuisse Lonza of Switzerland to form a behemoth to challenge the pre-eminence of Alcoa.
Earlier, the chemical giant Rhone-Poulenc agreed to a $23 billion merger of its drug operations with those of Hoechst in Germany.
And as French companies reorganize, they are flexing their muscles abroad. Americans were struck in recent months by the struggle of two French giants, Vivendi and Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux, for control of the growing American market for water services. In March, Vivendi, once a stodgy utility called Generale des Eaux, made the biggest French acquisition ever in the United States when it paid almost $8 billion for the United States Filter Corporation. Not to be outdone, Lyonnaise des Eaux has spent more than $6 billion on similar acquisitions.
"There's no other way but to follow the rules of the game as it's played now," said Eric Barthalon, chief economist at Paribas. Change is much in evidence at Paribas itself after the takeover by Banque Nationale. Yet Mr. Barthalon senses spirits rising.
In 1997, when he returned to Paris after spending two years at Paribas's offices in London, "it was a nightmare," he recalled. Paris was crushed by gloom, particularly among the young, who felt little chance of upward mobility. Talented graduates emigrated to Britain or the United States, finding work in Silicon Valley or at London brokerage firms. "This has pretty much changed over the last two years," he said. "Good people don't have to go abroad for jobs."
Partly, the shake-up is the work of a new type of French-bred corporate raider. Bernard Arnault, the chairman of LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, has consolidated the fashion and perfume businesses. Earlier this year, the billionaire Francois Pinault bought a large stake in Gucci, the Italian fashion group, in hopes of creating a rival luxury goods conglomerate.
More often, graduates of the elite French training schools are learning to play by the new rules.
Claude Bebear, chairman of the big AXA insurance group, got a degree from the Ecole Polytechnique. But with results below those that would have qualified him for top Government jobs, Mr. Bebear went to work at a sleepy insurance company in Normandy. In the past, he would never have made it to the top of French society. But Mr. Bebear, now 63, had a strong sense of opportunity, picking up acquisitions at opportune moments. The turning point in his career came in 1991, when AXA paid $1 billion for a majority stake in the Equitable Insurance Company. Today, AXA's stake is worth 15 times that.
In 1996, Mr. Bebear went further, acquiring Union des Assurances de Paris, a big French insurer the Government had sold off two years earlier. But Mr. Bebear's real influence comes from AXA's role as one of France's, and the world's, largest asset managers. AXA is the biggest shareholder in Elf Aquitaine and owns substantial shares of Banque Nationale and Paribas. "He is a fabulous manager, but he has a vision," said Elie Cohen, a leading French economist. He added that Mr. Bebear, who is an avid big-game hunter, brings the same instinct to his business decision-making. "He knows that if you have to kill, you have to kill immediately."
Consolidation is also being driven by the Government's push the last two years to sell big shares of more than a score of huge enterprises, including banks, industrial companies, and insurance. Though the state still holds large stakes in companies like Renault, Air France and France Telecom, the Government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, despite its Socialist heritage, has sold assets worth more than $30 billion to private shareholders. Many of these assets have gone to British and American investment funds, which become involved with the way the businesses are run, demanding good returns on investment and sound long-term strategies.
Total was one of the pioneers. In 1991, the company listed its shares on the New York Stock Exchange, starting a flood of investment from institutional investors.
And the trend toward an international shareholder base continues. The arrival of the euro is encouraging European investors to diversify geographically. "What strikes me much more now," Mr. Desmarest said, "is the arrival in the last year of new shareholders from Germany, the Netherlands."
But if the private sector is getting back into shape, overstaffed Government operations pose even greater challenges for Mr. Jospin. Government spending, much of it on railways, postal service and medical care, account for 54 percent of the economy, against 40 percent in Britain. More than 25 percent of the workers in France are employed by government compared with 14 percent in Britain.
To reduce unemployment, the Government has resorted to an immensely costly make-work program that created 174,000 jobs.
Mr. Jospin's immediate challenge, advisers say, is getting a handle on pensions and health spending. With more than two years before national elections, Mr. Jospin wants to start debate on reducing the gap between Government pensions, which reach as much as 85 percent of final salary, and those in private business, where they are about 50 percent. To cut medical costs, the Government wants to consolidate the public hospital system.
Despite union resistance to changes in the traditional public sector, labor leaders support Mr. Jospin in his bid to speed financial and industrial privatization.
Jean-Christophe Le Duigou of the executive board of the C.G.T., the big labor federation that grew out of the Communist labor movement, accepts the Government's retreat from the business of running businesses, arguing that the public sector had "reached its limits both industrially and financially."
And he acknowledges that the private sector is creating jobs, even if many of them are considered temporary or part-time employment. Last year, hours lost through private-sector strikes were the fewest ever in postwar France. What his union now wants is for the Government to help by improving education and pouring more state money into industrial research. Fingering a cellular phone on his desk, he asks, "Why should this be made by Nokia or Motorola -- not in France?"
His union is conciliatory in part because Mr. Jospin delivered on a pledge to enact legislation cutting the workweek from 39 hours, to 35. The idea, based on a popular notion of the labor market as a pie of fixed size, is that if the slices are cut smaller, there are more slices for everyone.
Mr. Le Duigou acknowledges that the 35-hour week has not automatically created jobs. Still, he says, the new law is delivering benefits because it forces labor, business, and the Government to sit together and discuss ways to ease the dislocation caused by corporate restructuring.
Business grudgingly swallowed the 35-hour week, negotiating in exchange a union commitment to more flexibility. In exchange for fewer hours, business won the right to more overtime, weekend and night work, increasing the productivity of factories that operate on high- and low-production cycles, and can now run nonstop in periods of high demand.
Total Fina is an example. The 35-hour week, Mr. Desmarest says, means the company "will try to achieve a level of productivity gains to compensate" for lost hours. Total Fina should benefit from greater flexibility at its robot division; the unit supplies the auto industry, which has seasonal and cyclical demand.
Still, Mr. Desmarest added, he would have preferred a different approach. "At the end of the day," he said, "I am not at all convinced this will create jobs."

The stock market is up smartly, economic growth has recently been robust, unemployment is beginning to shrink and consumers, while not overly optimistic, are feeling better about their prospects than they have in years.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Another Low-Price Offer For Long-Distance Callers
Undercutting the telecommunications giants, IDT, a small company based in Hackensack, N.J., plans to begin offering domestic long-distance calls for 5 cents a minute at any time with a flat monthly fee of $3.95.
The offer comes a day after AT&T said that it would offer consumers domestic long-distance calls for 7 cents a minute with a $5.95 monthly fee, intensifying a price war with MCI Worldcom, Sprint and other companies in the $80 billion long-distance industry. Page C6. 

Apple Introduces Faster Macintosh
Steven P. Jobs, the interim chief executive of Apple Computer, introduced the latest, most powerful Macintosh, describing it as a supercomputer for the desktop. The new Macs were not expected until next year, but Mr. Jobs said shipments of them had begun. Investors signaled their approval by sending the company's shares up $3.1875, to $65.25. C2.
 
Trying to expand into a new personal computer market, Intel will announce processors today that are capable of powering the devices that route data through corporate networks and the Internet. C3.
 
Dow Falls, but Nasdaq Posts Gains
Stock prices declined after a purchasing managers report heightened fears that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates again. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 84.85 points, to 10,829.28. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.61 points, to 1,320.41. But the Nasdaq composite index, thanks to strength in technology stocks, gained 26.66 points, or 1 percent, to 2,739.35. C6.
 
Calpers to Invest in Hedge Funds
The California Public Employees' Retirement System, seeking to enhance its investment return, plans to put up to $11 billion in hedge funds and what it called other aggressive "hybrid" investments. C2.
 
Mexico Not Spending Oil Profits
Despite a jump in petroleum prices, Mexico will reap only enough of a windfall to stabilize its accounts this year and plans no spending sprees, Energy Minister Luis Tellez said. Although Mexico has earned $1.3 billion more from petroleum exports than budget planners anticipated, Mr. Tellez said, the Government is taking a sober view of the upturn in its oil fortunes. C4.
 
Japan Struggling With Public Debt
Japan has some of the worst public accounts in the industrialized world. The debt situation is so precarious that as talk of new stimulus plans heats up, there are growing doubts about how long Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi can continue to spend furiously in hopes of reviving the economy. A1.
 
Manufacturing Growth Reported
A survey of the nation's purchasing managers, inadvertently released a day early, showed that the manufacturing sector continued to grow in August. Manufacturers paid higher prices for goods and materials, and employment continued to gain. C6.
 
Kaufman & Broad in Irregular Loss
The home builder Kaufman & Broad said that it had lost $18.1 million from unauthorized mortgage trading by an employee. C2.
 
Shares of European Retailers Soar
The planned merger of the French retailers Carrefour and Promodes sent the shares of other leading European food retailers sharply higher as investors and analysts wagered on the companies' chances of merging or being acquired. C4.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As Economies Revive Abroad, Dollar Falls vs. Key Currencies

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The United States dollar has begun to slide against the Japanese yen and the European single currency, as investors turn their attention to reviving economies in Asia and Europe.
The dollar fell yesterday below 110 yen, the second time it has done so since autumn 1996. In January, it briefly pierced the 110 yen level before rebounding. Against the euro, which was introduced in January, the dollar is falling after a 15 percent rise that ended in July. 
 Though the American economy continues to expand, growth slowed in the second quarter. And some analysts and investors are saying they expect higher interest rates to prove a further drag on the dollar this year.
At the same time, Asian economies, many of which fell into recession after the currency turmoil of 1997, show signs of life, and these countries' stock markets have soared in 1999. Optimism is being heard about the economic prospects of European countries, too. So the potential for growth in the near term may be just as good or better elsewhere than in the United States, many are saying, and this is causing dollars to flow out of American investments and into foreign markets.
"Over the past year or so, the dollar has leveled off, and we are in an environment now in which the dollar should start a moderate slide," said James McCormick, currency strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities. "It's not a question of a weaker dollar. It's a stronger rest of the world."
The euro rose yesterday to a value of $1.0578, from $1.0471 on Monday. Mr. McCormick said he expects the euro to rise further, and the dollar to fall, to a rate of $1.12 by the end of the year, while the yen could move to 105, a dollar decline of 4.2 percent from current levels.
A weaker dollar means that prices of imported goods will rise, increasing inflationary pressure. It also makes travel abroad more expensive for Americans. But analysts note that a falling dollar also has positive effects. It would make American goods more competitive abroad, which could aid economic growth here and help American manufacturers recover from a slump induced by the global financial crisis that began in 1997. More exports, combined with a slowdown in imports, would also help reduce a ballooning American trade deficit.
Whether this weaker dollar is a policy problem for the Clinton Administration is not yet clear. The former Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, had supported a strong dollar, in part because it helped restrain inflation. His successor, Lawrence H. Summers, says he is supportive of that policy, but some analysts wonder if he is as committed as Mr. Rubin.
The Federal Reserve will be looking at the dollar, too, with an eye toward any inflationary pressure. But other factors, including consumer spending that is being fed by a strong stock market and gains in home values, are a bigger concern. The central bank traditionally has paid close attention to the dollar only if it is considered drastically out of line with where it should be or if it fluctuates so rapidly as to risk destabilizing other financial markets.
The big move against the dollar this year has come from the Japanese yen, which is up 11.8 percent since early July. In trading yesterday, the yen settled at 109.59 to the dollar, up from 110.73 on Monday.
Most of the move this year has been caused by the rush of foreign investors into Japanese stocks as they bet that a turnaround in the Japanese economy will improve corporate performance and push a long-depressed stock market higher. So far they have been right, with the benchmark Nikkei index up more than 30 percent in dollar terms.
Mr. McCormick said that foreigners had made about $54 billion in net purchases of Japanese stocks so far in 1999, compared with $17 billion in all 1998. To buy the stock, foreigners sell their local currency and buy yen, pushing up the yen's value.
Though the weakening dollar may not be regarded as unalloyed trouble for the United States, economists say it could become difficult for Japan. As the yen strengthens, Japanese goods become more costly abroad. And if this cuts into sales by Japanese companies, the long-sought economic recovery there could run into trouble.
For this reason, Japan tried to slow the rise of the yen by intervening in the currency market to sell yen six times in June and July. But last month, Japanese officials indicated that they were abandoning this policy, at least for now. That shift opened the door for the yen to move below 110. One reason Tokyo relented is that intervention, without the participation of the United States, is unlikely to work. In addition, officials are hoping that their economy is on the rebound, which would make the rise in the yen less worrisome.
A test will come on Sept. 10, when Tokyo releases data on growth for the quarter that just ended. If the data are strong enough to confirm that the recovery signaled in the first quarter is continuing, worries about the yen's rally could subside. Comments from Japanese officials yesterday indicated that the growth outlook was still positive.
But now that the yen is below 110, currency traders will be on the lookout for any sign that Japanese policy makers are ready to intervene again. Investors are showing some signs of concern, too.
As for the euro, since mid-July when there were the first sure signs of a turnaround in the German economy, it has risen 4.4 percent. But it is still down 9.3 percent against the dollar for the year. The relative strength of the dollar against the euro and some other major currencies suggests that there is no serious dollar swoon in the making now.
Still, the Federal Reserve's vigilance against inflation is not helping the currency. By moving to increase short-term interest rates, the Fed aims to slow growth here before the economy overheats to a point that prices and wages spiral upward. Though higher interest rates can sometimes support a currency, they are negative for the dollar in this case because investors are betting that a slowdown here will make American investments a little less attractive.
The threat of a further rate increase by the Fed when it meets in October, and comments about rising asset prices made last Friday by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, also put downward pressure on stock prices this week as foreign investors fled the market and, with that, the currency.

HEADLINE: Keyes Draws the Few, but Devoted

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
As he wanders the nation prophesying a political apocalypse, Alan L. Keyes, the staunchly conservative radio talk show host, is the invisible man in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination.
He gets few cameras at his events. Political analysts tend to forget him in their prognostications. Polls show him receiving 1 percent of the vote or less. And when the Log Cabin Republicans, a homosexual group, issued a news release recently criticizing culturally conservative candidates for intolerance, Mr. Keyes did not even merit a mention. 
 But to his small yet devoted cadre of followers, Mr. Keyes is the best-kept secret of the campaign. To them, Mr. Keyes, a former Reagan Administration diplomat with a Harvard Ph.D., has something his fellow conservatives lack: mesmerizing oratorical skills twinned with a messianic vision.
And therein lies the heart of the Keyes for President campaign. With little money, name recognition, organization or governing experience, Mr. Keyes is running on his powerful voice, breathlessly wooing far-right voters with Boschian word pictures of schools that are "places of death," taxpayers who are "enchained slaves" and children who have fallen into a "howling moral void."
Though he is given little chance of winning -- he finished seventh of nine candidates in the Iowa straw poll -- winning is not what he promises his followers. What he offers is the chance to feel morally correct on Election Day.
"The conclusion I've reached is that no one is doing what I believe needs to be done," Mr. Keyes said in a recent interview, speaking of the moral issues. "If I were satisfied that anyone else was addressing it, I would not run."
His campaign chairman in South Carolina, Hal W. Stevenson, said, "If you only care about your chances of winning, you don't back a guy like Alan. You back him because you like what you hear. You'll feel better when the election is over."
Mr. Keyes did win the Alabama Republican straw poll last Saturday, but other than Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, who finished second, he was the only candidate who competed.
Indeed, at a time when several Republican candidates, including the front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, are trying to play down divisive issues like abortion and gay rights, Mr. Keyes provides an eloquently uncomfortable reminder that, to some dedicated conservatives, ideological purity matters more than victory in November 2000.
"I think there is a struggle going on in the party," said Mr. Keyes, 49, who also ran for President in 1996. "It's a struggle between the Money-is-God Republicans and the God-is-God Republicans."
On the stump, Mr. Keyes aims the sharpest barbs at Mr. Bush, whom he considers a tepid-tongued pragmatist. In Greenville, S.C., recently, he mocked Mr. Bush's slogan of "compassionate conservatism," saying, "You don't prove you are compassionate by talking about it." He accused Mr. Bush of exploiting moral issues, "without being seriously committed to facing the moral challenges." And he ridiculed the Texan for saying he would not demand that all his nominees to the Federal bench share his opposition to abortion.
"Is it true we need leaders who will be vague in their response to the most compelling moral issues we face as a people?" Mr. Keyes, who is black, asked the virtually all-white crowd in Greenville. "No!" many of them responded.
Though his campaign has received little media attention, Mr. Keyes has consistently drawn hundreds of people to his "Renewing America" speeches in South Carolina, Iowa and New Hampshire. Marietta Kaiser, 72, of Greenville, walked out a convert. "He's a breath of fresh air," she said after Mr. Keyes's appearance in mid-August. "We've heard the cliches of the other candidates, and they just don't move the spirit."
But his against-all-odds campaign has drawn questions from some rivals and analysts, who suggest that he is using the race trying to draw attention to his speaking-for-hire business and to gain listeners for his radio program, which until recently was syndicated to about 75 stations in more than 43 states.
In 1997 and 1998, Mr. Keyes gave about 20 paid speeches a year, typically to corporations or college groups, charging $12,000 to $15,000 for each, his aides said.
But the aides scoffed at the assertion that he profits from running for office. They said that he suspended the radio show during the campaign and has scaled back his paid speaking engagements to about 15 this year. They added that most of his speeches are given free to benefit pregnancy counseling centers and anti-abortion groups.
Other critics have asked whether he is living off his campaign account, as he did in his losing 1992 Senate race in Maryland when he paid himself more than $8,000 a month from campaign donations. Though the practice was legal, it prompted criticism even from Republicans.
Mr. Keyes says he is not drawing a salary from his campaign fund, which had raised $1.9 million as of June 30 and had $172,497 on hand. But he argues that the practice is legitimate and that his critics are "wealthy oligarchs."
In private, Mr. Keyes cuts a different figure from the acid-tongued talk show performer who has amazed even the most combative hosts with his ability to shout them down. With his goatee and newly trim build -- he has lost 70 pounds in two years -- he can come across as a genial academic. An opera buff, he confesses to relaxing with westerns and action films or "Star Trek" reruns.
Mr. Keyes, the youngest of five children, is the son of a career Army officer who moved the family repeatedly through Italy and the United States. Reared a Roman Catholic, Mr. Keyes attended parochial schools for much of his youth, though he graduated from a public high school in San Antonio.
In high school, he was already demonstrating his powerful speaking skills, winning the American Legion's national oratorical competition and getting elected president of the Legion's Boys Nation, the first black to do so.
Though his parents were Democrats who admired John F. Kennedy, Mr. Keyes became a Republican in the late 1960's while attending Cornell University, where he viewed Vietnam War protesters as repugnantly anti-American. He transferred to Harvard, where he went on to earn a doctorate in government.
While serving as a State Department official in India during the Reagan Administration, he met Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, who later called him "one of the most dramatically articulate people" she had ever met. After she became chief United States delegate to the United Nations, Ms. Kirkpatrick made Mr. Keyes the Ambassador to the United Nations Economic and Social Council. Mr. Reagan later appointed him Assistant Secretary of State for international organizations.
In India, Mr. Keyes also met his wife, Jocelyn Marcel Keyes, who is Indian. They have three children and live in Maryland.
Mr. Keyes's speeches are aural spectacles, part revivalist sermons, part Oprah. With a microphone on his lapel, he wanders through the audience, talking -- sometimes in a whisper, sometimes in a shout -- for an hour or more without notes, weaving images of an America going to hell in a high-speed handbasket.
He argues that a collective loss of faith in God's authority has caused a panoply of social ills, from the breakdown of "marriage-based families" to the Columbine High School shootings to failing schools to "immoral" military interventions abroad, including in Kosovo.
Without God in their lives or their politics, Americans are allowing an authoritarian central government to tax and regulate them into submission, he says. Likening Americans to a frog that sits calmly in a pot while the water gets hotter, he argues that Americans are passively watching their freedoms erode.
"We're past medium rare and headed toward well done," Mr. Keyes said in Greenville.
Not surprisingly, he prescribes strong medicine. He would eliminate the income tax and finance the Government on tariffs, duties and excise taxes. He would end welfare and outlaw abortion. He has floated the idea of public paddling of parents who abandon their children.
But in private conversation, Mr. Keyes reveals more nuanced views. And that makes for some paradoxes.
Though he ridicules targeted tax cuts as "marionette strings," he also endorses federally subsidized mortgages for families and tax breaks for banks that invest in poor neighborhoods. And while he warns that "perpetual war" is a means by which totalitarian governments control their citizens, he is not an isolationist, having strongly supported America's involvement in Vietnam, Cambodia, Grenada and Kuwait.
There are interesting nuances in Mr. Keyes's views on race as well. He is an ardent opponent of affirmative action and other race-based social programs. But he also speaks about the need to address urban poverty through private investment, and has often lambasted the Republicans for not recruiting more blacks.
"The Republicans vacillate between trying to buy off black voters with programs, trying to out-Democrat the Democrats, and just writing them off," he said in an interview.
Indeed, Mr. Keyes says, his revulsion for slavery has intensified his conservatism, not weakened it. As a teen-ager, he voraciously read books about slavery, weeping while he wondered why more slaves did not revolt. Lincoln became his hero. Even his stump-speech language -- "We need to strike off our chains," is a favorite phrase -- is drawn from the peculiar institution.
"I always wondered, why didn't people resist to the point of fighting and dying?" Mr. Keyes said. "Why would human beings let themselves be oppressed, when they could have said, 'give me liberty or give me death,' and gone out in a blaze of resistance?"

HEADLINE: Why Not Let Them Eat Big Macs?;
Safety Isn't the Point

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "New Trade Threat for U.S. Farmers" (front page, Aug. 29): Whether or not genetically engineered food is grown in an ecologically sound manner or is safe for consumption is beside the point. What should worry us is the fact that a very small number of transnational corporations like Cargill and Monsanto are coming to dominate the world's food production and distribution systems. 
 Those of us who do not wish to be a part of the grossly overconsumptive global market economy look forward to building strong, diverse local communities and economies that are ecologically sound and socially just. We know that a system in which a handful of transnational corporations control food production and distribution at the expense of human rights and ecological conservation has no place in our lives.
 
JOSHUA MINER
Oakland, Calif., Aug. 29, 1999

HEADLINE: Haiti Still Needs Help From U.S.

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While the headline of Bob Shacochis's "Only Haiti Can Save Haiti" (Op-Ed, Aug. 30) is true, it may also be misleading. 
 Although Haiti's economy can be characterized as little merchants and their unmoving pyramids of oranges and mangoes, it is also true that some heroes (in the form of American alternative investors) have created microbanks for these small merchants to diversify and grow. Other inconspicuous heroes have brought 500 Cuban doctors into the country to aid in health care. Many Haitians are working at reforestation and literacy.
Haitians need continuing partnerships with outsiders willing to take risks to help them build an economy. For the United States to recall its small military presence sends the wrong message to Haitian elites who believe that only fascism can save Haiti. Sadly, they seem to have support from many in our Congress.
LARRY CASTAGNOLA
West Haven, Conn., Aug. 30, 1999
 
The writer is the director of a nonprofit group that finances the education of Haitian children.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;

BYLINE: AP

Aspiring small-business owners or those who are struggling with their finances can enroll in the Entrepreneurial Training Institute program, sponsored by the New Jersey Development Authority for Small Businesses, Minorities' and Women's Enterprises.
The eight-session program will begin in September at 10 locations throughout the state: Elizabeth, Irvington, Jersey City, Lakewood, Long Branch, Mount Laurel, Newark, Pleasantville, Trenton and Vineland. 
 Each of the weekly three-hour evening sessions will be led by area bankers and representatives from local community development organizations. Students will develop business plans, marketing plans and financial statements.
The course, including textbooks, costs $225. To register, call (609) 292-9279 or send an E-mail to cld@njeda.com.

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 2; Circuits 

LENGTH: 2174 words

HEADLINE: Click Here for the Ivory Tower

BYLINE: By LISA GUERNSEY 

 BODY:
FOR almost as long as students have been going to college, educators have been trying to bring college home to them. More than 100 years ago at Cornell University, professors traveled to rural areas on horseback to teach farmers about the latest agricultural research. Correspondence courses have been available for decades, first through the mail and then through television and video.
But the development of the Internet has created new excitement around what has become known as distance learning. This summer a start-up company called Unext.com (www.unext.com), based in Deerfield, Ill., announced a venture that is one of the most ambitious yet: delivering executive training and, eventually, a full M.B.A. program over the Internet. This summer, Unext.com (pronounced you-next) christened its virtual school Cardean University after a Roman goddess, Cardea, who could "open what is shut and shut what is open," in the words of a company press release. 
 The plan attracted attention not only because one of the initial investors was the former junk-bond king, Michael R. Milken, but because of the five prestigious institutions the company had brought on board -- the University of Chicago, Columbia University, Carnegie Mellon University, Stanford University and the London School of Economics and Political Science -- a veritable all-star team of elite universities.
The plan is for Unext.com to produce, market and distribute the courses -- as well as hire a corps of employees to serve as mentors and E-mail correspondents for Cardean's students. The universities will provide the curriculum and the impressive credentials, without risking their endowments on untried technology. Some of them have projected that their own campuses will each earn at least $20 million in royalties from Unext.com within five to eight years.
"This is a way to embark on distance education by using what others bring to it," said John Preis, associate dean for finance and administration at Columbia University's School of Business. "We think this is a home run." Distance learning, it seems, has come of age.
But has it? Since the dawn of the Web in the mid-1990's, the concept of earning degrees entirely on line has become a rallying point for university presidents, politicians and profit-seekers alike. Yet while millions of people are diving into on-line shopping malls and chat rooms, virtual universities have been something of a bust.
"I think it's going to be the joke of the 21st century," said Carole S. Fungaroli, an adjunct professor in English at Georgetown University who is writing a book about the value of university degrees. "I don't see anything that these people are offering that you can't get better on campus."
Western Governors University, a venture started by 17 states and Guam, opened its on-line doors to much fanfare last year but has enrolled only 120 students, far below its projections. California Virtual University, a project initiated by the California Board of Regents in 1997, folded this spring, citing financial problems. Many other virtual university projects have appeared to be nothing more than on-line catalogues of courses that can be taken for credit only by students who are already on campus.
One place the distance education concept has been successful is Wall Street, where analysts' reports are thick with data on the rapidly growing adult-student market. The Apollo Group, the company that runs the University of Phoenix, an accredited institution that offers on-line degrees, has seen its stock soar more than 1,500 percent since 1994. Apollo, which also operates other educational programs, now has a market capitalization of $1.7 billion.
Administrators at the universities that have signed up with Unext.com readily admit that the possibility of becoming part-owners of a publicly traded Internet company is a part of Unext.com's attraction. "I was less interested in the income stream than in the market capitalization of Unext.com," Meyer Feldberg, dean of the Columbia University School of Business, told The Wall Street Journal. "The huge upside essentially is the value of the equity in the I.P.O."
There have been other concerns raised about Unext.com. The management of the company is made up of several Chicago professors, including John P. Gould, a former dean of the university's Graduate School of Business, and two Nobel laureates, Gary Becker and Merton H. Miller. Several other members of the Chicago faculty have publicly raised questions about conflicts of interest. Whose interests will be served, the company's or the institutions that need to protect their good names and academic integrity?
The entrepreneur behind Unext.com is Andrew M. Rosenfield, a business consultant and University of Chicago alumnus who was running Lexecon, a company that employed many of the same people who are now involved in Unext.com. In the last decade, he has also served as a part-time law professor and trustee for the university, remaining immersed in the culture of an institution known not only for breeding free-market intellectuals but also for being strongly resistant to change.
In the mid-1990's, Mr. Rosenfield started thinking about about creating an Internet-based education company that would be both a radical departure and a continuation of the values of his alma mater. He wanted to create an on-line environment that would be "the technological equivalent of the small break-out session or the evening at the coffee shop, where students really teach each other." He also wanted to reach students outside the United States who wanted access to education delivered by American universities but who could not travel to get it.
He mulled over the idea with Dr. Becker -- his former professor and now longtime friend, who had won his Nobel prize for his theories about human capital. The two brainstormed over lunch at the University of Chicago's faculty club and while watching Chicago Bulls games.
The first investor for the company, which was founded in December 1997, was Knowledge Universe, a company owned in part by Mr. Milken. His involvement stirred gossip throughout the higher-education community last year, when Mr. Rosenfield started to shop his idea around to select universities. By the time Mr. Rosenfield signed up his first partner -- Columbia University, in March 1999 -- the contracts included the condition that Mr. Milken's investment would never exceed a 20 percent ownership stake and that he would have no voting rights.
In the last four months, four more universities have signed on; the last was Carnegie Mellon, which struck a deal in July. Other universities, like Cornell, were approached by Unext.com to be pioneering members but declined. Cornell has already developed its own distance-education technology, said Jonathon D. Levy, executive director of Cornell's distance-education office.
Critics say that the partnership could damage the universities' academic credibility. The quality associated with getting a degree from these schools cannot be replicated on the Internet, said John K. Wilson, an outspoken graduate student at the University of Chicago who has written columns accusing administrators of jumping in blindly with "dollar signs in their eyes."
University administrators have responded vaguely to questions about how much the deals may be worth. Mr. Preis, at Columbia University, confirmed reports that his institution expected to make at least $20 million in five to eight years. Other university administrators said they expected the same return.
But Unext.com would not confirm the $20 million figure. "That's the universities' expectation," said Edwin Eisendrath, the spokesman for Unext.com. Mr. Eisendrath added that not every university had signed the same deal. He would not elaborate.
Within the business faculties themselves, the reaction to the announced deals has ranged from approval to confusion. Administrators at some of the participating schools have pleaded ignorance about exactly what the deal means and who will be affected. At the University of Chicago, a committee was formed to talk about Unext.com before the deal was signed, but at Columbia University, most professors had not heard of the proposal before they awoke to an announcement of the deal.
In Carnegie Mellon's case, a Chicago public relations firm sent out an announcement about the university's involvement before the university's press office had a chance to see the release and fix a large error. The announcement said Carnegie Mellon would offer courses in E-commerce courses through Unext.com, but the dean of the Graduate School of Industrial Administration, Douglas M. Dunn, said it had no plans to do so. The university, Dr. Dunn said, is still negotiating over exactly which courses Carnegie Mellon will help create.
Meanwhile, some professors are wondering what involvement with Unext.com will mean to their scholarly reputations, the coin of the realm in the academic world. Robert Connolly, a professor in the Kenan-Flagler Business School at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, has worked with another distance-education company, called University Access, to create several economics courses using the Web and videotape. The experience, he said, has improved his teaching skills but hurt his standing in his department.
"I can't get people in my own school to talk to me about it," Mr. Connolly said. Colleagues who have been willing to acknowledge his distance-education work expect that his research -- a professor's ticket to tenure -- must be suffering, he said. "They look at it and say, 'If you are spending time on that, that takes time away from your research and publishing.' "
The American Association of University Professors has also asked questions about teaching quality in distance education courses. Last spring, when an on-line university called Jones International University became the first completely Internet-based school to gain accreditation, the association wrote a letter of protest to the accrediting agency. The letter cited "major worries about the denigration of quality" that could come with on-line education.
Most distance-education courses are not cheap either. The Caliber Learning Network, a company based in Baltimore, persuaded three universities -- the University of Pennsylvania, Johns Hopkins University and the University of Southern California -- to join it in offering business courses via satellite television and the Internet. Tuition is high; students who take the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton Direct program pay $2,500 each for six-week courses.
Most of the students can afford to attend, said Alison Pierce, Wharton Direct's director, because they are already in upper-income brackets and the companies for which they work pick up most of the tab.
While Unext.com expects to benefit from companies' tuition-reimbursement programs as well, it will offer lower tuition prices, Mr. Rosenfield said. The company has not yet set its prices, but the cost of an Internet-based education, he said, should not be more than that of attending schools in person.
Still, critics ask, what will a degree from Cardean University be worth? Dr. Fungaroli has called such on-line programs "a new version of a trade school."
And students who enroll in M.B.A. programs from Stanford or the University of Chicago, Mr. Wilson argued, are doing so to build networks of contacts. "There is a real question about whether the 'good old boys' network' can be created in the same way it is created in elite business schools," he said.
But International Business Machines, Unext.Com's first customer, is willing to give the concept a try as a way to encourage their employees to learn without losing them to on-campus business schools. I.B.M. will offer its employees a finance course this year. It is also a partner in the Unext.com venture; the courses are being delivered through Lotus Learning Space, software developed by Lotus, an I.B.M. subsidiary.
Mr. Rosenfield admits that Unext.com does not plan to offer a full M.B.A. on line for years. Until then, the company will focus on executive training. Unext.com is not being structured to attempt to compete with what universities are already offering on campus, Mr. Rosenfield said.
In fact, Mr. Rosenfield himself calls on-campus education the best way to learn. "For people who have the ability to attend facilities-based schools, we recommend it," he said. But, he asked, why not also attempt to create a worthwhile experience for people who cannot attend those schools?
"They will not have direct interaction," he continued, "but what they will have is the wisdom of professors and pieces of their knowledge that are captured and scalable. And they will have supporting resources and mentors who are their guides."
So would Mr. Rosenfield take these courses? "Absolutely," he said. "The days when you ended your education at college, or graduate school, are truly over."

HEADLINE: Finding Fashion And History On the Edges;
Museums Look Again At Their Picture Frames

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
In a hushed gallery at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, Elizabeth Easton, the curator of European paintings, and Jared Bark, the founder of Bark Frameworks in SoHo, were huddled around a Sisley landscape. The talk was not about the painting, but of its Louis XV-style reproduction gilt frame festooned with intricately carved flowers, swags and shells. "Look how the frame overpowers the painting," said Ms. Easton. "It's just too Louie-Schmooie."
Dissatisfied with the frames on many of the pictures in their collections, museum curators from Brooklyn to Kansas City, Mo., are caught up in a flurry of costly reframing projects. At the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City the curator of European paintings has spent $500,000 to reframe 75 paintings. The National Gallery of Art in Washington paid $60,000 to put a 17th-century walnut frame on Rembrandt's "Man in Oriental Costume," the most it has ever paid for a frame. And at the Art Institute of Chicago curators do a special "before and after" presentation to encourage benefactors to support the cost of reframing paintings. 
 Increasingly, as museums across the country expand, works that have languished in storage are being re-evaluated. Economic considerations underlie some of the activity. In today's robust art market, curators can no longer afford to buy paintings as often as they once could, so they try to make the best of what they have. Sometimes a painting brought back into view has a frame deemed hopelessly out of fashion; or a painting, framed to enhance a donor's decor, just doesn't work in a museum. But scholarship also plays a role. In recent years curators armed with new information about how artworks were originally framed are becoming fussier about authenticity
So now, in addition to raising money for exhibitions, acquisitions and expansions, curators are also trying to convince donors that the right frame, which can cost tens of thousands of dollars, is not just window dressing.
"Framing has always been a business," said Keith Christiansen, a curator of European painting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. "But now there's big money in it." Like the price of all antiques, those of frames from the 17th through 19th centuries have escalated in the last decade. The most expensive and hardest to find are the simple, hand-carved 17th-century frames that curators covet.
In London, at the Bond Street gallery of Paul Mitchell, frames of all ages, sizes and styles line every available inch of wall. Mr. Mitchell's business is booming largely because of work from American museums. "It's a ripple effect," Mr. Mitchell said. "Once a curator changes a frame on one picture he wants to keep going." And when one curator learns that a colleague at a competing museum is reframing a collection, he suddenly wants to do the same.
In art history books, pictures are shown, but rarely their frames, Mr. Mitchell said. "Famous paintings are catalogued from head to toe, but about their frames you know nothing," he said. "That's because art history books only show the picture. They don't show the frame." Some artists have had definite ideas about how their works should be framed, but this information is also rarely documented.
So framers like Mr. Mitchell compiled their own historical references. He has systematically photographed pictures in their frames and created an archive of more than 40,000 paintings from museums, private collections, exhibitions and auctions worldwide. He also uses computer imaging to show clients how one painting might look with different frames.
"Few paintings have withstood the ravages of time in their original frame," he said. "Generally Old Masters have been divorced from their frames, either because of change of ownership, transport (it's easier to ship a painting without its frame) or changing tastes in interior decoration."
Every artistic movement has produced its own style of frame. The earliest frames, from the Renaissance, were merely protective edges for religious paintings and were extensions of the painting. The conception of frames as separate from the painting began in Italy during the 16th century. By the 19th century frame making had become a growth industry as the new middle class framed everything from paintings to lithographs.
At the National Gallery of Art in Washington, a frame committee of four museum staff members -- David Bull, a senior consultant in the conservation department; Philip Conisbee, senior curator of European paintings; Mark Leithauser, chief of design, and Alan Shestack, deputy director and chief curator -- was formed 10 years ago to reduce the chances of choices based purely on personal taste.
"Before we change a frame all of us have to agree," Mr. Bull said. Since 1990 the National Gallery has reframed some 200 paintings and plans to do 200 more.
Because it is so large, the museum has a growing computer database that consists of some 3,000 frames in its collection. Along with images and detailed descriptions of each frame are conservators' reports. "We look within our own collection first whenever we decide to reframe something," Mr. Conisbee said.
When the committee members decided to find a new frame for Degas's "Three Dancers," for instance, they discovered the perfect one in their storeroom. It was designed by Degas and was originally on the painting, which had been badly reframed by a dealer by the time it came to the museum in the 1940's. Luckily the original frame accompanied the painting. Because museum policy is never to throw out a frame, conservators were able to restore the more restrained Degas frame.
"We don't get rid of frames just in case 50 years from now people think we've made a mistake," Mr. Leithauser said. "This way they can easily change something."
For Dutch Old Masters, reframing can be a challenge because large 17th-century frames rarely exist. "In the 19th century dealers and collectors took off the original 17th-century black frames believing they were too somber and devoid of decoration," Mr. Leithauser said. "If you were a collector with a Rembrandt, you wanted a frame that said, 'I am a Rembrandt.' The older frames were therefore scrapped or burned."
For van Eyck's "Annunciation," which is 36 1/2 inches by just over 14 3/8 inches, the committee studied the original frames that they found on paintings by the same artist. One in the National Gallery of Art in London became the basis for a reproduction.
But the gallery was able to find a perfect match for Rembrandt's "Man in Oriental Costume," a 17th-century frame costing $60,000 from Guttman Frames. It replaced the overpowering gold frame that was on the painting when the museum acquired it. The men have no regrets. "Compared to what the painting is worth, it's cheap," Mr. Bull said.
In the early 1980's, before frames increased in price, Roger Ward, the curator of European art at the Nelson-Atkins Museum, made a list of the 20 most difficult to frame paintings in his collection. "The price I paid then for a period frame couldn't even pay for a reproduction now," he said.
The Nelson-Atkins was one of the first museums to comprehensively reframe major portions of its Old Masters and European art collection.
Mr. Ward said that 60 of his paintings now wear antique frames.
One of his prized paintings, Caravaggio's "St. John the Baptist," had been framed in a spindly 18th-century tapestry molding that had been cobbled together. Mr. Ward found a 16th-century Italian altarpiece frame that was appropriate to the scale and color of the painting.
"Since this was originally stuck in a stone altar, this frame is as close to the original as I could get," he said. When he bought the frame in 1987 it cost just over $26,000. "It would cost a lot more now," he said.
Mr. Ward said he realized that he is luckier than most museum curators: "I had sympathetic trustees and a sympathetic director. I have an endowment for my department, which includes expenses for things such as frames, so I don't have to find a donor for every frame I want to buy."
At the Art Institute of Chicago, curators have been evaluating the need to reframe gallery by gallery. With financial help from the museum's Old Masters Society, a group of about 400 people, and from the institute's director, curators have raised $125,000 for the Dutch and Flemish galleries and are raising another $225,000 for reframing major works in the mid-19th-century galleries.
The "before and after" presentations at the museum have persuaded potential donors to help. To illustrate the difference an appropriate frame can make, curators take Corot's "Interrupted Reading," an image of a woman looking up from her book. First they show the painting in its original 17th-century Italian frame, which had been stripped and painted a dull brown, presumably to match the painting's background. Then they replace that frame with an 1870 Louis XIII-revival-style frame from Wiggins in London.
"It restores the balance between the background and the flesh tones in the figure," said Gloria Groom, a curator in the museum's department of European paintings. "This is a frame the artist would have put on the painting for an exhibition in a salon in the second half of the 19th century."
The museum started to think about reframing nearly 10 years ago, with the exhibition "Monet in the 90's." "When we put paintings of similar subjects together we could actually see what was historically and esthetically pleasing," Ms. Groom said. Some of the original frames on works the museum borrowed, she said, opened curators' eyes. "Ninety-nine percent of the time we try to figure out what the artist put the picture in himself," she added.
The reframing project has been "a consciousness-raising exercise," said Douglas Druick, the senior curator of European paintings at the Art Institute of Chicago. "A lot of the Dutch paintings that had entered the collection at the same time were suffering under the weight of the robber-baron frame."
Curators don't always have the luxury of spending years seeking the right period frame when they make changes gallery by gallery. The Chicago museum has often had reproductions made. Of the six Monet haystack paintings in their collection, two have their original frames. The others have frames made by Mr. Mitchell, all different but all based on the classical vocabulary of the Louis XVI style.
The museum's star painting, Seurat's "Sunday Afternoon on la Grande Jatte," still doesn't have a frame that satisfies curators. They consider it too big, too round and too white. "We feel we need to revisit this," Ms. Groom said.
While the designers who made the frame in 1989 took the shape from the artist's rendition (Seurat is famous for his impossible-to-match white frames), what they considered historically correct then does not do justice to the painting. "Historically correct doesn't always work," Ms. Groom said. "It's difficult to age white because there's a patina you can't get. We just have to keep experimenting."
What may be considered historically accurate and what an artist would have wanted are not always what the public likes. In 1986 curators at the Baltimore Museum of Art removed the ornately carved wood-and-cast-plaster frames from the fabled collection of Matisses that had belonged to Dr. Claribel Cone, a Baltimore pathologist, and her sister, Etta Cone, who bequeathed their collection to the museum.
They replaced the Cones' elaborate frames with simple strip frames and stored the originals. Scholars applauded the museum's boldness, but some visitors criticized the move.
Last year, when Doreen Bolger became the museum's new director, one of her first decisions was to restore the Cone sisters' frames. "We know that Matisse made comments about not liking elaborate frames, but there have been strong feelings in Baltimore that the Cones' frames should go back on the Matisses," she said. "When I first saw them in strip frames I wanted to see the paintings in the more traditional frames."
Archival pictures of the artist's studio show that Matisse put his paintings in flat-edged strip frames, and in a letter that he wrote in 1916 he said he was "very opposed to frames and particularly heavy frames that surround the paintings with a yellow color, stopping all expansion."
He continued, "A modern painting has no need for a frame: it should have a simple border at most."
So who is right? "We have to acknowledge changes in tastes and no doubt tastes will change again; it's cyclical," Ms. Bolger said. "Framing is definitely subject to interpretation."
 
A Waning Passion For Gilt
One reason museums are saddled with frames that do not do justice to their paintings is that many of the world's most famous dealers during the last two centuries -- figures like Joseph Duveen and Paul Durand-Ruel -- put paintings in imposing gilt frames to impress their nouveau-riche clients.
The scroll-shaped corners of a Durand-Ruel frame, for example, can be instantly identified by any seasoned curator. Their flourishes served a purpose. When a painting looked more impressive framed in heavy gilt, it could command a higher price. Ornately carved gilt frames were also used to tame what were considered wild Impressionist paintings, and they went well with the fine 18th-century French furniture that was the decorating trend of the moment.
By the late 19th and early 20th centuries, however, artists became involved in framing. Whistler refused to allow anyone to design his frames and made simple ones himself. Some Impressionists, particularly Pissarro and Degas, put their pictures in plain white, gray, yellow and even purple frames of their own design. And post-Impressionist artists like Seurat, van Gogh and Gauguin made frames that in colors that complemented their paintings.
Today there are no rules for what makes an appropriate frame, although curators are mindful of a painting's history.

HEADLINE: TURF;
Once Dross, Now Dream: Wrecks Are Suddenly Hot

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
A FEW years ago, agents say, the smallish two-bedroom apartment overlooking Sutton Place South, with a sidelong glance at the East River, would have been priced at around $475,000 -- and labeled a wreck. The worn linoleum in its dark Pullman kitchen was starting to crack; the grout in the bathroom was falling out. Wind whistled through the old window sashes.
This year, the apartment, up for sale, was labeled, primly and elegantly, in estate condition. The asking price: $895,000. It sold immediately, with at least six bidders. 
 In New York's real estate market, the whopping discount for the handyman's special has gone the way of the $500 sublet. "People always expected a big reduction for an apartment that needed work, and they got it," said Peter R. Marra, the president of William B. May Real Estate. "But now, there's virtually no differential. Appraisers consider square footage, views, building. Condition is not even an issue."
Just this week, a very large Fifth Avenue apartment came on the market, this one also in raggedy condition: crammed with tired furniture, covered with wallpaper hung 40 years ago, with a kitchen decked out in old painted cabinets -- and a terrace strewn with pots of dead ivy.
"It just looked and smelled old," Mr. Marra said. "We priced it just as if it were in very good condition, very aggressively: around $3 million."
Sometimes, a wreck brings even more money than an apartment that has been totally renovated -- especially if it is in a prewar building, and if the original wainscoting and moldings are intact.
And while brokers say that paying premiums for Cinderella apartments is most prevalent along the Gold Coast of Fifth and Park Avenues, and within the grande dames of Central Park West, the phenomenon is not confined to the boulevards.
IN Murray Hill, for example, Laura Enman, 33, a garment district saleswoman, just paid $202,000 for a one-bedroom apartment at 136 East 36th Street, a prewar building that is showing its age. (The last one-bedroom that sold in the building -- this one in really good shape -- went for $175,000.)
The moldings in Ms. Enman's apartment are so obscured with glopped-on paint that it's hard to see that they are moldings; the floor was long ago painted a strange shade of beige, which has rubbed off in places, and the fireplace (yes, there is a working fireplace) was repaired by some overworked handyman who slapped gray mortar over the brick -- and left it like that.
"I love that it's a fixer-upper," Ms. Enman said, as she riffled through her very first mail delivery, surrounded by cardboard boxes. "This way, I'll be in charge of the renovation. I'm not paying for someone else's taste. My father's going to come here and teach me how to strip woodwork."
Ms. Enman knows that she paid more than she would have a few years ago. And she knows that her place is in worse condition than others that have recently sold for less. "But I wanted this apartment," she said. "I didn't want to lose it."
Ms. Enman was infatuated with its charm. And that is why apartments that only a few years ago would have been knocked down in price have been rediscovered: the charm of the old (and shabby).
That and a general shortage of good apartments -- in any condition.
Right now, there are waiting lists for apartments with large rooms, views, fireplaces and moldings. When one comes on the market, the eight or nine or 90 people who didn't get the last such property that came up will be back bidding on it. Which is another reason that a wreck may go for more money than a place that's in pristine condition: bidders don't want to lose out a second time.
"So what if they then pay hundreds of thousands of dollars more to renovate?" said Barbara Corcoran, the chairwoman of the real estate company that bears her name. "This market is defined by the moment. It's inconsequential, a moot point, what an apartment went for yesterday, whether or not it was fixed up."
In the recession of the early 1990's, she said, the fixer-uppers were a bargain, priced way below what they would be worth if renovated. "People didn't have the confidence that if they invested money to fix them up, they'd ever get their money back," she said, adding that today is different.
Still, there are those who shake their heads at the prices. Two years ago, Ann Keenes bought a large classic six (two bedrooms, formal dining room, living room, kitchen and maid's room) in an Old World building on West End Avenue in the 90's. She paid $560,000 -- and thought she overpaid. The apartment was what she calls, without blushing, a wreck.
Now, an apartment with the same configuration, but one floor down, where the river views are a little less spectacular, is for sale, in the same condition. The asking price is $825,000. "I just can't imagine that it's worth that much money," Ms. Keenes said.
Oh, but it is -- or well may be. Unrenovated apartments, once the dregs, have now risen to the top layer of the marketplace. As one fervent agent said: "We once called them problems. Now we herald them as opportunities."
So, it figures that agents are out beating the bushes for untouched gems. And where better to look for an estate-condition apartment than in an estate?
"We basically have a whole team that looks at estate lists -- people who've actually died and are not coming back, not some guy moving to Florida," Mr. Marra said.
Do the real estate salesmen wine and dine these lawyers? Not exactly, because lawyers don't have the power they once had to dictate to heirs which agents to hire.
"But they can usually recommend two or three firms," Mr. Marra said, "and obviously we, along with every other company in town, want to be one of those three."
So, with all the agents angling, and would-be buyers bidding, are there any bargains left? Probably not. Two young women got what may have been the last one.
Catherine and Edith Kuhnle, aspiring singers known as Cat and Edie, ages 25 and 29 respectively, just bought a three-bedroom Park Avenue wreck for -- you're not going to believe this -- less than $150,000.
The apartment had the right location -- in a fine building on Park in the 80's -- but as Stephen Perlo, the agent, said, "it was unconventionally located within the building."
"It was down three steps off the lobby, past the superintendent's apartment," he said, adding that it was sort of a dark hole. "A lot of people who looked at it just couldn't deal with that." And those who could, he continued, "wouldn't have a chance of passing the board."
Enter the Kuhnle sisters, whose father lives in Washington and is politically connected, Mr. Perlo said.
"And the president of the board is Susan Thomases," he said. Ms. Thomases, a lawyer, is a longtime friend of the President and the First Lady.
Some people have all the luck.

HEADLINE: A Key Index Says Economy Is Continuing To Perk Along

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
In another sign that the nation's economy continues to grow at a brisk pace, a key barometer of future activity rose three-tenths of a percent in July, the same rate as in the prior two months, the Conference Board reported yesterday.
The Index of Leading Economic Indicators has registered gains in 9 of the last 10 months. 
 There are concerns that rising interest rates could slow growth later this year, said Ken Goldstein, an economist for the Conference Board, a business-sponsored research group.
"But over all, strength in manufacturing conditions and a robust labor market more than offset the negative contribution of higher interest rates," he said in releasing the figures.
The results for July, which were slightly better than expected, reinforce Tuesday's economic data that showed that the manufacturing economy grew in August.
"Eight of the 10 leading indicators posted increases, underscoring the continuing strength of the current economic expansion," Mr. Goldstein said. "The two key drivers of this latest increase were manufacturing and the labor market."
The economic expansion, now in its ninth year, is, however, showing some signs of cooling, including a report yesterday of a decline in construction spending.
Home building and other construction spending was surprisingly weak in July, according to the report yesterday from the Commerce Department in Washington.
Construction spending fell half a percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $695.7 billion. In June, construction spending fell slightly, according to revised figures.
July's decrease was the opposite of what many analysts had expected. They were forecasting that spending would actually go up between three-tenths of a percent and six-tenths of a percent.
Home building and other construction -- driven by low mortgage rates -- were key contributing factors to the strong economic growth in the early part of the year.
But the Federal Reserve has raised key interest rates twice this summer, and that makes buying a home more expensive.
Rising mortgage rates took a bite out of the housing market in July. Existing-home sales fell 3.9 percent, while sales of new homes rose a slight one-tenth of a percent but still reached the second-highest level ever.
Consumers are feeling a little less confident about economic and job prospects, in part because of the rise in interest rates. The consumer confidence index fell for a second consecutive month in August, according to a Conference Board report Tuesday.
The leading indicators are calculated from a base of 100, set in 1992. First calculated in the late 1960's, the index is periodically fine-tuned and

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Subaru isn't tampering with success; it's just going to do what it has been doing -- only bigger.

BYLINE: By Courtney Kane 

 BODY:
SUBARU is rolling out the largest advertising campaign in its history, but don't expect to see a new cast of characters or any other drastic changes to its existing theme. Instead, the company is sticking by an old adage: "If it ain't broke, don't fix it."
Paul Hogan of "Crocodile Dundee" fame continues as Subaru's spokesman in the integrated campaign from Subaru's agency of six years, Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex., and the campaign continues to emphasize safety and performance features, including all-wheel-drive technology. Subaru, however, is doubling the amount of broadcast and print placements and backing the ads with $70 million to $80 million to push its revamped Legacy line and its 2000 Forester model. 
 "Subaru understands who they are," said David Lyon, group account director at Temerlin McClain, a unit of True North Communications. He added, "That's why you see consistency, focus, continuity, and you see the courage to stay with what's working."
Clive Chajet, chairman of Chajet Consultancy, a brand and corporate image company in New York, agrees that sticking to a similar format seems to be the right formula for the Subaru of America unit of Fuji Heavy Industries of Japan. "Given the intensity of the noise level of automobile advertising, essentially the only way they are breaking through the clutter is staying with what they already have," he said.
In the latest campaign for the company's redesigned Legacy models, which include the Outback wagon, the Outback sedan and the Legacy GT, the overall slogan is still, "The beauty of all-wheel drive."
Most of the nine new television commercials, which began running nationally last month, are for the Outback models. In one spot for the Outback sedan, a sleek black car is shown cruising through a city and passing imagery of the Australian Outback, including a woman walking a kangaroo on a leash, crocodiles in potholes and a herd of sheep crossing the street at a crosswalk. Mr. Hogan steps out of his Subaru and says, "My kind of town."
A spot for the Outback Sport vehicle, which is aimed at younger consumers, shows Mr. Hogan tagging along with his nephew en route to an outdoor concert. The two drive on a dirt road through a variety of obstacles to demonstrate the car's performance and horsepower. As they reach their destination, passing tattooed fellow concertgoers, the nephew says, "This might not be your type of crowd, Uncle," to find Mr. Hogan already body surfing in the mosh pit. The Outback tag line is, "The world's first sport utility wagon."
A third commercial to demonstrate the traction and control of all-wheel-drive technology has Mr. Hogan in the classic Subaru chase scenario in the jungle. Two other spots for the Forester emphasize its carlike handling and that it is easier to climb into than other sport utility vehicles. The Forester slogan is, "Sport utility tough, car easy." And another commercial, showcases the entire line of Subaru's all-wheel- drive vehicles.
"I don't think anyone would look at the work and say there is a significant departure from what we have done," Mr. Lyon said, "though we have done some things differently to call attention to the fact that we have a new car."
Mr. Hogan, who has been in the Subaru campaign for five years "represents everything we want to say about this car -- that it's rugged, it's adventurous, it can provide the driver with a lot of confidence and that it's fun," Mr. Lyon said.
Still, he added, "We had to find a way to use Paul a little differently to make sure that we signal news that we have a new car this year."
Bill Cyphers, vice president for marketing at Subaru in Cherry Hill, N.J., said the company's sales figures were argument enough for continuing with the current theme. "We've had three wonderful years back to back -- each year is better than the last," he said. "And this past year was our best sales year in over 10 years."
Over the last six years, Subaru said that sales in the United States had grown more than 50 percent. As of July, Subaru had sold 85,478 cars this year, up 8 percent, from the corresponding period a year earlier.
"Mr. Hogan continues to work for us. The type of ads that we do continue to work, and we are targeting those people with the active life style who have a high propensity to buy our cars," Mr. Cyphers said.
Most Subaru buyers are college-educated, make approximately $75,000 annually and enjoy an active life style involving canoeing, hiking and skiing, Mr. Cyphers said.
Mr. Lyon added that Subaru was also trying to win over consumers who had become disillusioned with sport utility vehicles, which are essentially light trucks and have poor fuel economy.
As Subaru has brought itself back from a string of declining sales ending in the early 1990's, it has grown from a marketer of niche products like front- and four-wheel-drive vehicles that were positioned as cheap and reliable to a full-line producer of mainstream offerings like upscale all-wheel-drive sedans, sports utility wagons and the Forester sport utility vehicle.
The print portion of the campaign gives readers glimpses into the active, outdoor-oriented life styles of Subaru owners. Six ads began appearing in the August issues of publications including Automobile, National Geographic, Outside, People, Southern Living, Smithsonian and Time. All the ads refer consumers to a refurbished Subaru corporate Web site, subaru.com or to a special site designed to showcase the new line, 2000.subaru.com. In addition to search engines like Yahoo, Subaru interactive banner ads have been placed on sites like Autobytel and Carpoint.

HEADLINE: Savings and Loans Had Strong Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
The United States savings and loan industry earned $2.12 billion in the second quarter of 1999, bolstered by a strong economy and a vibrant housing sector, the Office of Thrift Supervision said today.
The earnings were the industry's best on record for any second quarter, rising from $2.06 billion in the first three months of 1999 and $2.10 billion in the second quarter of 1998. 
 Despite rising interest rates, mortgage originations remained strong, the office said. New mortgages handled by savings banks reached $79.2 billion, up from $77.4 billion in the first quarter and $78.6 billion a year earlier.
Reduced overhead and higher retail fee income also contributed to the strong performance.
Return on average assets for the industry, a key measure of profitability, rose to 1.01 percent in the second quarter from 1.00 percent in the first quarter. Return on average equity rose to 12.44 percent from 12.29 percent.
Asset quality also continued to improve, the office said. Troubled assets fell to $5.5 billion, or 0.65 percent of the total, the lowest level since the agency began tracking them in 1990. The number of problem savings banks also declined to 10, less than 1 percent of the total number of institutions, from 14 in the first quarter.
Rates of overdue loans fell for all major loan types in the second quarter. On single-family mortgage loans, the overdue rate fell to 0.78 percent of all such loans from 0.84 percent in the prior quarter. Overdue consumer loans dropped to 0.72 percent from 0.82 percent.
