HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices on Treasuries Continue Retreat on Fears of Rate Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday for the fourth time in five days on concern the economy's strength and prospects for faster inflation might prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for a third time this year.
"It's still not clear to people that the Fed is done" raising rates after doing so in June and last week, said David Jallits, who helps oversee $5 billion at Strategic Fixed Income in Arlington, Va. "Until that happens, bonds will continue to struggle." 
 Mr. Jallits has been buying money market securities, the safest fixed-income investments. Strategic has not held so much cash-equivalent debt since 1994, when the Fed began a series of seven rate increases.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond declined 7/32, to 100 21/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.08 percent from 6.06 percent on Tuesday.
William Stevens, portfolio manager at Montgomery Asset Management L.L.C. in San Francisco, expects bond yields to rise as high as 6.5 percent by the end of the year. Mr. Stevens, who invests $1.8 billion of debt, currently is favoring 10-year notes over bonds.
Treasuries came under pressure Tuesday after a report showed manufacturing activity rose for a seventh month. Also, an index of prices paid by manufacturers, an inflation barometer, climbed to the highest level in more than four years.
Since Thursday, reports on new- home sales, income, spending and manufacturing have shown no slowdown in the economy's ninth year of expansion, fueling concern that the growth will lead to inflation and cause further Fed rate increases. Friday's jobs release -- which will probably show that the unemployment rate tied a 30-year low in August -- is expected to provide further evidence of strength.
"The U.S. is growing too strongly for its own good," said Gerard Lyons, global head of Treasury research at Standard Chartered Bank in London. "I'm expecting one more rate hike this year" and more early next year, he said.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
A Legacy of Conscience From Milton Rogovin

BYLINE: By VERLYN KLINKENBORG 

 BODY:
Three weeks ago an air-conditioned truck pulled up to Milton Rogovin's house in Buffalo and carted away his entire archive of photographic negatives, contact sheets and prints -- a lifetime of work. When artists allude to posterity, they often do so only half-believing in it, but this was posterity's actual moving van, come to carry Mr. Rogovin's archive to the Library of Congress.
The day must have seemed strange in many respects, not least in the faint but still discernible irony that hung over it. Mr. Rogovin's career as a professional photographer began only after he refused to testify before the House Un-American Activities Committee, a refusal that diminished his livelihood as an optometrist. "They already had enough stool pigeons," Mr. Rogovin says. "They didn't need me." 
 That was in 1957. The next year Mr. Rogovin was asked by a friend to photograph storefront churches in a black section of Buffalo, a neighborhood Mr. Rogovin already knew well as a voting-rights activist. The result was a series of photographs capturing the pathos, religious and otherwise, of that urban communion. Since then Mr. Rogovin, who will turn 90 in late December, has devoted himself to a photography of implicit activism, to portraits of working men and women, of the rural and urban poor in America and abroad. In a sense Mr. Rogovin has continued on his own the project of the Farm Security Administration, the 1930's sponsor of some of the most remarkable photographic work of this century. His subject is not the Great Depression but the chronic depression that still shapes the lives of the working poor and unemployed.
Two of Mr. Rogovin's most striking photographic series rely on the transformations that place and time bring about. In "Working People," Mr. Rogovin photographed his subjects at work, dressed in the armor of heavy industry, and at home, dressed however they chose. Labor transfigures, but so does leisure, and it is a little alarming to notice how much more sharply defined Mr. Rogovin's subjects seem in hard hats and shop aprons than in coats and ties and Sunday dresses. But nothing transfigures like the years going by. Three times in the past quarter-century, Mr. Rogovin went to Buffalo's Lower West Side and photographed the same people in settings of their own choosing. The result is a book called "Triptychs," as pure a witnessing of time's movement, and the ways in which poverty coarsens that movement, as there is.
If it made sense, during the Depression, to send photographers out into the countryside to chronicle the "ill housed, ill clothed, and ill fed," it makes equal sense to acknowledge, as Mr. Rogovin's portraits do, that for many people those conditions have never changed. An art raised upon that sad fact can sustain itself in esthetic terms without falsely ennobling or falsely degrading the people who stare at us still from these pictures. There is true collaboration in Milton Rogovin's photographs, a conspiring of artist and subject, and that is a legacy of conscience worth preserving. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
With LightTouch, Trade Chief Takes Over

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Mike Moore of New Zealand began his first day as leader of the World Trade Organization today with a reminder of some nettlesome issues he faces as the top global trade arbitrator.
White placards with such slogans as "God Is Dead; the W.T.O. Has Replaced Him," waved by a small but voluble band of demonstrators, greeted him as he arrived in a chauffeur-driven black Lexus. 
 "That's a bit flattering I would have to say," Mr. Moore remarked of the placards' sentiment. The protesters represent groups that have increasingly criticized the trade organization as having too much power. They are threatening to disrupt global trade talks in Seattle late in November, which is scheduled as Mr. Moore's initial challenge as Director General. According to his count, he has 11 weeks to pull together a workable agenda on an array of complex issues.
Mr. Moore's congeniality and breezily informal style may help smooth over disagreements among the 134 often-fractious member nations on issues as diverse as cuts in farm subsidies, taxation of electronic commerce, market access to financial services like banking and insurance, and tariffs on industrial goods.
Looming as particularly contentious is whether to include genetically modified food on the trade talk agenda, in light of the dispute between the United States and the European Union over whether barring American hormone-treated beef from the Continental market violates global trading rules.
"Whether we like it or not, these are issues the public is concerned about," Mr. Moore said.
Some trade experts say they think he will have a second full-time job mending fences with envoys from developing countries who supported his rival for Director General, Deputy Prime Minister Supachai Panitchpakdi of Thailand.
The 10-month contest escalated into a clash of wills with delegates of many nations expressing resentment of Mr. Moore's support from the United States. This was particularly true among nations that contend they have not benefited from trade liberalization and suspect the United States of having tried to undermine Mr. Supachai's candidacy.
In July, a compromise was struck in which both men will serve three-year terms, with Mr. Moore going first. "It's been a lot of drama and theater," the new trade chief said, "but it will be forgotten in six months because the real issues are so enormous."
Mr. Moore, 50, has spent much of his career in New Zealand, where he was most recently opposition spokesman for trade and foreign affairs. He worked briefly for the printers' union but mostly served in Government posts. In 1990, he was briefly New Zealand's Prime Minister. "I was there such a short time it made Gerald Ford look like Franklin Roosevelt," Mr. Moore remarked.
Jovial one-liners aside, he is well aware that he faces a tough task in figuring out how the trade organization presents itself to a public that is increasingly aware and suspicious of centralized power over trade.
Criticism over the lack of openness erupted last year when the organization brushed aside American safeguards for endangered sea turtles caught in shrimpers' nets. Such environmental or conservation measures are at odds with the views of many emerging economies, which have resisted opening their commerce to outside scrutiny.
"We have to recognize that many nongovernmental organizations have enormous influence," Mr. Moore said, "so we have to engage them and show a more human face.
"If you've got something to hide, the best way is to give out 5,000 sheets of paper and dare people to find it," he said jokingly.
At the same time, he has repeatedly emphasized that the trade organization is driven by its members' needs. To bring more smaller economies into the fold -- about 30 countries are too poor to have diplomats in Geneva -- Mr. Moore plans to help them better protect their trading interests.
"The W.T.O. now doesn't look like the real world," he said. "It looks too rich and clubby, so we have to work on that." That includes admitting Russia and China to the group, he said.
However, the trappings of his new job -- a six-figure salary, an entertainment allowance, the luxury car and a spectacular view of Lake Geneva -- obviously fit the upscale model, although Mr. Moore says he is too down-to-earth to have his head turned by such perks. A worry, he said, is that he does not speak French -- something considered tantamount to sin in Geneva circles.
Aside from that, how will he know if he has been successful? "If I manage to offend everybody, then I'm doing a good job," he said.

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Memo Appears to Oppose a Type ofPension Conversion

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
Cash-balance pension plans have drawn heavy criticism lately because they often reduce the pensions of older workers. In fact, a memo written by an Internal Revenue Service district director one year ago -- and released Tuesday by a member of Congress -- stated that one cash-balance pension plan may violate age-discrimination laws.
Cash-balance pension plans have become popular with employers because they are cheaper and can offer better benefits to young workers unlikely to spend their career in one place. 
 But middle-aged employees at a number of companies that have converted to cash-balance plans have complained about benefit reductions that they say can take away up to 50 percent of the value of their pensions. In response, some lawmakers in Washington have sought to stop cash-balance conversions through legislation or action by Federal agencies.
Traditional pension-plan benefits are typically calculated using the number of years an employee was at a company and final pay, so most of the value of the pension is based on years late in a person's career. Under cash-balance plans, companies contribute a percentage of an employee's pay to an account every year, and then guarantee that money will grow at a certain interest rate, such as the yield on a Treasury bill. At retirement, that account is the pension.
The September 1998 I.R.S. memo, released Tuesday by Representative Bernard Sanders, a Vermont Independent and critic of cash-balance plans, could fuel efforts to slow cash-balance conversions. In the memo, the I.R.S. district director in Cincinnati, C. Ashley Bullard, told I.R.S. officials in Washington that one company's cash-balance plan may not comply with age-discrimination rules because the "plan's benefit-accrual rate decreases as a participant attains each additional year of age."
Mr. Sanders said in a statement, "This memo bears out what I and others have been saying: If the rate of accrual goes down as workers get older, then the plan violates the law."
Mr. Bullard declined to comment yesterday. A spokesman for the I.R.S., Don Roberts, said the memo merely reflected internal agency debate about a pension plan at one specific company. He declined to say whether the I.R.S. had made any formal decision relating to the plan. In the memo, he said, regional I.R.S. officials were seeking guidance from the national office about the one plan, and the document did not necessarily reflect the position of Mr. Bullard. It "is not precedent-setting and may not be cited as a broad statement" of I.R.S. policy, he said.
I.R.S. officials are also working on a response to a letter from some members of Congress about whether cash-balance plans violate age-discrimination or other rules.
The name of the company that was the subject of the memo was blacked out, but according to people close to the matter, it refers to the Onan Corporation, a subsidiary of the Cummins Engine Company based in Fridley, Minn.
As previously reported, the I.R.S., in a filing in a lawsuit in United States Tax Court, has taken the position that an Onan pension plan should be stripped of its tax-exempt status because of the way it converted to a type of cash-balance plan. If the judge in that case agrees with the I.R.S., Onan will be given the opportunity to correct any problems with the plan. Cummins said Wednesday that the company had not received confirmation that Onan was the subject of the I.R.S. memo, and that the agency had not raised age discrimination in the tax court case. "Onan does not believe there can be age discrimination when everyone who makes the same amount, no matter what age, gets the same company contribution each year," said the spokeswoman, Marya M. Rose.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Why all the fuss over pint-sized Ecuador? Brady bonds.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
HAS the looming possibility that Ecuador will default on its foreign debts provoked an excessive amount of hand-wringing? At first glance, it surely appears so. Ecuador produces less output in a year -- about $15 billion -- than the United States produces in a day. The financial travails of such a pint-sized economy would not ordinarily threaten anyone beyond its own borders.
Yet the Treasury Department and International Monetary Fund remain fixated on Ecuador's problems for reasons that go beyond the ordinary duty to help out a distressed country. This week Ecuador became the first country to skip interest payments on Brady bonds -- bonds issued by Mexico, Ecuador and other Latin countries during the debt crisis of the late 1980's and 1990's. 
 Ecuador has a month to make interest payments before its Brady bonds are technically in default. But if it does default, some analysts worry that the Brady bonds issued by other debtor countries will also be tarnished, scaring investors away.
So, will Ecuador's potential default contaminate financial markets in Latin America and beyond? The debate is lively.
"Probably not," said Albert Fishlow of Violy, Byorum & Partners, a New York investment firm. "Ecuador's debt problem is understood to be far worse than that of other countries in the region."
But Gary Hufbauer of the Institute for International Economics warned that if the International Monetary Fund did not handle the situation carefully, Ecuador's problem could soon become Brazil's, Argentina's and even sub-Saharan Africa's.
By the late 1980's, Mexico, Ecuador and several other Latin American countries had borrowed from foreign banks far beyond their capacity to repay. The solution, spearheaded by Nicholas F. Brady, who was Treasury Secretary in the Bush Administration, was to replace the bank loans with Brady bonds.
The Brady bonds helped debtors and creditors. Ecuador came out ahead because the banks agreed to knock down the value of its debt payments by about 40 percent. The banks came out ahead because Ecuador and other debtor countries put up collateral to guarantee repayment of the principal and some interest payments.
By eliminating some of the debt overload and creating a security that could be easily traded, Brady bonds made it possible for Mexico, Ecuador and others to re-enter foreign capital markets, a necessary step to reviving aising their depressed economies.
But floods and a plunge in the price of oil, a key export, rocked Ecuador's finances last year. Political paralysis has prevented Ecuador from closing a huge deficit by raising taxes or by ending expensive subsidies for gasoline and other consumer products.
Mr. Fishlow said that Ecuador's debt was perhaps three times, compared with the size of its economy, that of its neighbors. Its foreign debt exceeds $13 billion, of which about $6 billion is in Brady bonds. According to Lehman Brothers, the country spends over 30 percent of its budget on interest payments. Few experts believe that Ecuador can repay all of its debt.
The International Monetary Fund and Ecuador have been negotiating a bailout package that is expected to provide about $400 million in direct aid and release another $800 million from other international institutions. The fund will require Ecuador to reduce its deficit. The fund also expects Ecuador to negotiate debt relief from its private creditors -- a new direction for the I.M.F. intended to insulate it from criticism that the money it would pump into Ecuador would flow right back out to pay off private creditors.
But David Roberts, international economist for Banc of America Securities, warned that current holders of Brady bonds were the wrong target for the fund's new policy toward private creditors. "The banks that originally took Brady bonds in exchange for existing loans already wrote down the value of their loans," he said. "If the fund becomes cavalier toward current holders of Brady bonds, it threatens to drive the right type of foreign lenders out of Latin America." If the fund encourages Ecuador to default, he warned, "it will create a legal mess."
Mr. Hufbauer agreed: "Brady bonds helped countries pull themselves out of depression. The Brady's were thought of as superior debt, protected by collateral and a firm resolve to repay in full. For the fund to appear to be forcing Ecuador to default on these loans could make it impossible to use this device again."
Mr. Hufbauer acknowledged that Ecuador could not pay all its debts and must seek relief. What worried him was the possible role of the fund in insisting on default on the Brady bonds.
Michael Hood of J. P. Morgan disagreed, warning, "Do not sanctify Brady debt." It trades like other debt, he said, and its holders need to provide some debt relief.
In the end, the debate is not so much about Ecuador as about the fund's role in forcing further losses on the holders of Brady bonds. Why, some economists ask, should those who helped save Latin America be treated as villains? Because, says the other side, they are among the only sacrificial lambs available.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Applications to Medical Schools Decline for Second Straight Year

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
The number of applications to medical schools dropped nearly 5 percent last year, continuing a decline that began in 1997 after an all-time high in 1996, according to a study published yesterday in the Journal of the American Medical Association.
The author of the study and others in the field said the decline could be cyclical because applications tended to dip in prosperous times when students had more options for high-paying careers. 
 Other factors may include a more difficult job market for medical school graduates, and complaints by doctors of excessive paperwork and a loss of autonomy brought on by the growth of managed care.
Applications peaked in 1996 when 46,968 people applied for about 16,200 openings at the 125 medical schools accredited by the American Medical Association, the study reported.
Since then, applications have dropped about 12 percent, to 41,004 last year. Figures for 1999 are not yet available, but Barbara Barzansky, the principal researcher of the study and director of medical schools services for the medical association, said applications in May were down 2,000 from May 1998.
Since 1996, the number of applications from minorities -- blacks, American Indians, Mexican-Americans and Puerto Ricans -- has also declined, about 12.8 percent, Dr. Barzansky said.
The data have spurred speculation over how to explain the decline. Dr. Barzansky said a decline in the number of doctors was not likely because medical schools were still drawing two or three applicants per available slot and there was no indication the quality of candidates was declining, since grade point averages and medical college admission test scores had remained about the same.
But, she said, the dip in minority applicants raised some concern because it comes amid an aggressive recruiting effort by medical schools. One explanation could be reverberations from affirmative action debates, leading some minority students to believe there are fewer openings at the schools, she said.
If the decline continued, it could have broader implications. "Students who are from minority groups are more likely to serve minority groups," Dr. Barzansky said. "In addition, there is a feeling a diverse student body is considered a good learning experience for everybody."
Andrew Frantz, the associate dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University, said there were slightly more than 3,000 applicants for 150 spots last year at his college, a decline of more than a 1,000 since 1996.
Dr. Frantz noted that applications also rose and then fell during the 1970's and 1980's, usually in stride with the condition of the economy.
Jordon Cohen, president of the American Association of Medical Colleges, agreed that the economy might explain the decline but also blamed the growth of managed care.
Susan Pisano, a spokeswoman for the American Association of Health Plans, a trade group in Washington representing 1,000 managed-care organizations, said blaming managed care was "too simplistic."
"There is a transition going on from the old system to the new system," Ms. Pisano said, "and I think people who want medicine as a career will not be daunted by the challenges."
She suggested an oversupply of doctors as a factor. The Journal of the American Medical Association reported last year that one quarter of doctors who recently completed residency training reported difficulty in finding employment.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Details on Russia's Use of Aid

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration said today that it wants assurances that international financial aid already sent to Russia has not been lost to corruption, but stopped short of calling for a halt in future loans to Moscow from the International Monetary Fund.
Seeking to defend the Administration's policy of supporting aid to Russia -- and to defuse an issue that could have political ramifications for Vice President Al Gore -- Treasury Department officials and John D. Podesta, the White House chief of staff, said the Administration wanted to be certain that no money loaned to Russia by the fund had been moved surreptitiously out of the country. They were responding to reports of money laundering in which billions of dollars were sent by Russians through the Bank of New York. 
 "We want to make sure that the I.M.F. money is going to reform-oriented projects," Mr. Podesta said today in an appearance at the National Press Club. "The I.M.F., in its latest lending, has instituted additional safeguards, but we want an accounting of the ways the I.M.F. money has been spent."
Previous investigations of monetary fund loans to Russia have found no evidence that the money had been misused, and Justice Department officials have told their counterparts at the Treasury Department that they have no evidence that the money-laundering investigation involves the proceeds of I.M.F. loans. Officials at the fund repeated today that they have no evidence of any misuse of loans to Russia.
"Let's wait and see what the facts are," Mr. Podesta said.
But it is unclear how much new evidence the Administration hopes to assemble about the matter. Officials at the fund said they have not undertaken new studies of how Russia has used past loan proceeds since news of the money-laundering investigation broke on Aug. 19.
Still, the monetary fund has had some serious problems with Russia, including questions about whether the Russian central bank used transactions with an offshore affiliate known as Fimaco to deceive the fund about the country's financial condition. The fund is now waiting for a follow-up report on the Fimaco case from the accounting firm of PriceWaterhouseCoopers that looks at the central bank and its affiliates in Britain, France and Germany.
At the same time, the I.M.F. is conducting its routine review of its current lending agreement, which was signed in July.
Russia is eligible for $4.5 billion in loans from the fund over the next year and a half, of which $640 million was disbursed as a first installment in July. The next installment, probably of roughly the same size, is scheduled to be released in the next several months. Like the first installment, the next one is intended to help repay previous loans, and will simply be transferred from one fund account to another without entering the Russian banking system. Russia already owes the fund about $16 billion.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said in an interview published today by USA Today that the "United States will not support disbursement" of the next loan installment to Russia from the monetary fund "without adequate safeguards to assure that any funds disbursed are used properly."
Treasury officials said Mr. Summers was not implying -- as the headline on the USA Today story suggested -- that the United States was ready to block the next loan installment.
It would be "premature to make any judgments as to whether Russia will meet the conditions" for the loan, said Michelle Smith, a Treasury spokeswoman. The statements suggested that the Administration wanted to express concern about the possibility that the international aid had been misappropriated without changing its policy toward Moscow as Russia struggles to continue its rocky transformation towards democratic capitalism.
Federal investigators are looking into the movement of at least $4.2 billion from Russia through the Bank of New York over the past 18 months. However, some investigators estimate that as much as $10 billion may have flowed through the bank.
Investigators say the money may have come from a combination of organized crime, corporate embezzlement and political graft. Given the amounts of money involved, there has been speculation that some of it might have come from international aid packages, of which the loans from the fund are the largest component. Despite the lack of hard evidence, Republicans in Congress have used the case to raise questions about the Administration's policy of granting aid to Russia, and to renew attacks on the monetary fund as inefficient and perhaps unnecessary.
Mr. Podesta defended the Administration's Russia policy today, citing progress on arms control, defining Russia's role in Europe and starting to build a system of democratic capitalism. "We've made some progress," Mr. Podesta said. "We've had some problems. We're aware of the allegations of corruption."
In Moscow today, Russian officials denounced reports that they might have misused the international aid. Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov said the reports came from people "who do not want our country to take on its role in the world as a great power."
Alexander Livshits, Russia's Ambassador to the Group of 8 industrial nations, said the previous studies by the monetary fund and PriceWaterhouseCoopers showed no misuse of money and that he did "not understand this game."
Part of the problem in resolving the questions lies with the way the monetary fund operates. Until now, money lent by the fund to Russia has typically gone into the Russian central bank. Although agreements between the fund and its borrowers include economic benchmarks that the country must meet to qualify for further aid, they do not specify precisely how the money is to be used.
In practice, the money becomes intermingled with the borrowing country's other foreign currency reserves, making it all but impossible to trace where any particular dollar or euro or ruble might go.
"By and and large it goes to the central banks, and it's their money to use appropriately," said William Murray, a fund spokesman. "We do not earmark -- we don't say, of this $1 billion, $600 million has to go to pension subsidies. We don't track individual transactions."

HEADLINE: Among 14 Charter Proposals: Delaying Special Election for Mayoral Vacancies

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Charter Revision Commission decided yesterday to put 14 proposed changes before New York City's voters on the November ballot but said that its most contentious initiative -- creating a special election to fill mayoral vacancies -- would not take effect until January 2002 if approved.
In proposing a delayed implementation of the special election, the panel veered from what had appeared to be its main objective: thwarting the mayoral ambitions of Mark Green, the Public Advocate, should Mr. Giuliani, who is considering a run for United States Senate, leave office early. 
 The 14 proposed Charter changes, which will appear on the ballot as a single-question referendum, include imposing a cap on city spending increases, creating permanent city commissions to fight organized crime and protect human rights, and making gun-free zones within 1,000 feet of schools.
At its final public meeting in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon, the 15-member commission voted with minimal discussion or disagreement to include all 14 of its final recommendations on the ballot as a single question, which it forwarded to the City Clerk in time to meet today's deadline.
Randy M. Mastro, the chairman of the commission, said the proposals were substantive and important changes that "would do so much good for our city in the future." He expressed confidence that voters would approve the referendum.
But critics, including Mr. Green and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, continued to denounce the proposals yesterday as unwarranted and ill-conceived, and urged voters to reject them. Mr. Green, however, did praise the decision on special elections that would allow him to succeed Mr. Giuliani.
"This is a huge victory for New Yorkers who really care about fairness and democracy," he said. "The Mayor and the commission withdrew this foolish proposal to change this succession midterm not because they saw the light, but because they felt the heat of a broad civic-labor-elected official coalition standing united in opposition."
It was at Mr. Mastro's urging yesterday that the commission voted to include the special election proposal on the ballot this year, but to delay its implementation until 2002. If the referendum is approved, all of the other changes will take effect at the start of next year.
"I have searched my soul about this issue, and I have reached a conclusion we should delay the effective date of this proposal," Mr. Mastro said about the special election. "Concerns have been raised about this one proposal that have overshadowed the importance of our total body of work."
Recently, Giuliani administration officials had hinted that the panel would take this step, but Mr. Mastro's remarks were striking nonetheless because the Mayor, when he appointed the commission in June, had strongly hinted that his goal was to impede the advancement of Mr. Green, a political enemy.
By law, any Charter Revision Commission must consider the entire Charter, not just specific parts of it, and Mr. Giuliani's panel quickly developed a list of about 40 proposals. In a quick series of public meetings and hearings over the summer, that list was narrowed to 14 specific changes.
Critics accused Mr. Giuliani of appointing a commission stacked with supporters, led by Mr. Mastro, who is one of Mr. Giuliani's former deputy mayors, and of developing the other proposed Charter changes as cover for the effort to settle a political vendetta with Mr. Green.
Under the Charter's current provisions, the Public Advocate automatically finishes the term of any mayor who leaves office early.
Mr. Mastro said the criticism had distorted public perception and yesterday urged delaying the special elections.
Privately, however, advisors to Mr. Giuliani have said that they came to the conclusion that the Mayor, a Republican, had little to gain by Mr. Green's demise and, in fact, having Mr. Green in office might help the chances of a Republican candidate for Mayor in 2001.
Opponents of the Charter revision process, including a number of elected officials, good-government groups and labor unions, said yesterday that they would continue to oppose the ballot referendum.
Some of the changes, like making the Administration for Children's Services a permanent agency under the Charter, are merely technical and could be done by City Council legislation, critics have said.
Other changes, like the imposition of a cap on city spending tied to the rate of inflation, are seen by critics as efforts to restrict the Council's powers in favor of the Mayor.
"Based on the fact that much of the attention was focused on succession and not on the other proposals, we urge voters to reject the Charter recommendations," said Michael Clendenin, a spokesman for Speaker Vallone. "There hasn't been that much public debate or dialogue over the summer."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Malaysia EndsMost Controls On Investment

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Taking a major stride back into the world's financial mainstream, the Malaysian Government lifted a steep tax on the repatriation of foreign capital today.
The move is expected to uncork a stream of capital out of Malaysia, as overseas fund managers withdraw money that had been effectively locked in the country since the Government imposed sweeping capital controls last September. 
 Still, several analysts said they expected the outflow to be on the order of $1 billion to $2 billion, far smaller than earlier forecasts of $6 billion to $7 billion. As a result, the long-awaited easing of restrictions caused little commotion in stock prices here, which declined less than 2 percent -- an ordinary fluctuation in an emerging market.
Malaysia was also buoyed by new statistics reaffirming that its economy was in the midst of a remarkable recovery. The Government reported that the trade surplus rose to $1.52 billion in July, a 46 percent increase over the period last year, on the strength of surging exports.
"There are some unreconstructed enemies of Malaysia," said P. K. Basu, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in Singapore. "But most of the people I talk to are eager to invest in the country again."
Malaysia's decision last year to impose controls made it a maverick among Asia's economically stricken nations. While most of its neighbors adhered to the International Monetary Fund's prescription of open markets and high interest rates, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad turned his back on the West, even laying the blame for Asian ills on foreign currency traders.
Dr. Mahathir had relaxed the controls once before. In February, he replaced a moratorium on removing foreign money with an exit tax that penalized investors for withdrawing it in less than a year.
Malaysia has not lifted all capital controls: its currency, the ringgit, remains nonconvertible outside the country, with an exchange rate fixed to the United States dollar. Also, while investors no longer have to pay a penalty for withdrawing money, they will still be taxed on their gains.
As with the exit tax, the capital-gains tax is graduated to encourage investors to leave their money in Malaysia as long as possible. Profits on investments held for less than a year will be taxed at 30 percent; with investments held for more than a year, the rate will be 10 percent.
"I don't think too many people have capital gains on their Malaysian investments, but for those that do, it's a factor," said Bill Kaye, senior managing director of the Pacific Group, a Hong Kong hedge fund.
On the face of it, Malaysia's experience would seem to vindicate the 73-year-old Dr. Mahathir, who drew worldwide opprobrium when he imposed the controls last September. He said they were necessary to protect Malaysia from the destructive ebbs and flows of foreign capital that had plunged the country into recession and ignited a regionwide crisis.
Critics here and in the United States predicted that Dr. Mahathir would turn a nation that depended on trade into a pariah. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter removed Malaysia from its influential Asian emerging markets stock index. And foreign portfolio investment all but evaporated.
"Malaysia has chosen to become a heretic, a pariah if you like," Dr. Mahathir said in a speech then.
He further alienated investors and others by ousting and imprisoning his protege, Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim. Mr. Anwar, who received a six-year prison term for what his defenders say were politically motivated corruption charges and is now being tried on accusations of sodomy, had advocated a more open financial policy.
As Malaysia has gradually loosened the capital controls, it has won back some of the skeptics. Last month, Morgan Stanley reinstated it on its index, effective next February. And prominent economists, including Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, noted that the controls had some beneficial effects.
By fixing its currency at a relatively low rate of 3.8 ringgit to the dollar, Malaysia made its exports extremely competitive. Its booming trade in computers and peripherals is the major reason its economic output swung from negative statistics to 4.1 percent growth in the second quarter.
"The pegged exchange rate is the key to Malaysia's export success," Mr. Basu of Credit Suisse said. "The predictability of the exchange rate allowed exporters and foreign direct investors to plan." He said the new rules could still put off investors. The capital-gains tax will make it difficult for fund managers to value their portfolios since they cannot calculate their profits beforehand.
Mr. Kaye is among those who refuse to put money back into Malaysia. "Who wants to be told the terms on which you can or cannot invest?" he said. "They're putting themselves at an enormous competitive disadvantage."
Indeed, Malaysia has attracted less foreign investment than South Korea or Thailand, even though its economy has rebounded at least as strongly as those countries have. But Mr. Basu said it was a sign of Malaysia's strengths that it attracted more than $1 billion in foreign money between March and July -- a period when it was not included in Morgan Stanley's stock index. He added that it would be a few weeks before experts could judge the magnitude of the capital exodus from Malaysia.
Dr. Mahathir, however, said to reporters today that he was confident the Government could withstand the outflows, which he estimated at $3 billion to $4 billion. It has accumulated $32 billion in reserves and is running a large current-account surplus, the broadest measure of trade. With exports booming, economists said that at least for now, Malaysia does not really need foreign money.

YESTERDAY -- Controls are eased again, when a repatriation tax on foreign capital is lifted.

HEADLINE: Clinton Eager to Veto Tax Cut, Aide Says

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
The White House chief of staff today urged the Republican majority in Congress to send President Clinton its $792 billion tax cut bill so that he could promptly veto it.
Congress passed the tax measure early last month, but lawmakers have refrained from forwarding it to the White House, where it faces certain rejection. During the current Congressional recess, Republicans have been stumping across the country for their tax plan, hoping to generate public support. The President and his aides have taken every opportunity to criticize the proposal as an unwarranted windfall for the rich and a threat to the booming American economy. 
 John D. Podesta, the White House chief of staff, pleaded with the Republican leadership this morning to release the bill "so we don't have to keep fooling around with the phony debate."
"We intend to veto it," Mr. Podesta said in an appearance at the National Press Club. "So send it down to us so that we can veto it and then move forward, putting first things first and seeing whether we can find some bipartisan agreement on these other major budget questions."
Mr. Clinton and members of Congress have been out of Washington for the last two weeks and there has been no movement on this year's tax-and-spending debate beyond the occasional rhetorical salvo like the one fired this morning by Mr. Podesta. Congressional officials said today that the leadership would send the tax-cut bill to the White House by the middle of this month.
The White House is clearly spoiling for the fight over taxes and spending to resume. Polling and political experience have convinced the President and his advisers that they hold the high ground of public opinion in the looming struggle.
Mr. Clinton has argued that projected Federal budget surpluses should not be given away in the form of tax cuts but rather "invested" in education, technology, the environment and an expansion of Medicare benefits, including prescription-drug coverage for the elderly.
The ordinarily camera-shy Mr. Podesta took advantage of a relatively news-free week in Washington by venturing out of his West Wing office to attend a crowded news conference at the press club. In his prepared remarks, he complained about Republican plans to pay for their tax cut in part through what he called "devastating" reductions in the Clinton Administration's proposed Federal spending for research and technology.
"This is a 19th-century budget for a 21st-century economy," Mr. Podesta said of the Republican spending plan. "One has to wonder whether the people designing these budgets spent too much time watching Fred Flintstone and not enough time watching the Jetsons."
Mr. Podesta said Congress had cut the Administration's request for civilian research and development spending by $1.8 billion from roughly $38 billion, and had cut $1 billion from the Administration's proposed $13.6 billion for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Republicans also blocked a proposed $200 million increase in financing for the National Science Foundation, he complained.
Until now, American science and technology have enjoyed strong bipartisan support in Washington, Mr. Podesta said.
"But this year, the Republican-led Congress -- to make room for their risky tax plan -- is playing politics with science and technology funding," he continued. "They have proposed deep cuts in many important research programs. And in so doing, they are threatening the potential progress of innovation in America."
Elizabeth Morra, spokeswoman for the House Appropriations Committee, said the White House was indulging in the luxury of sniping from the sidelines while Congressional appropriators tried to devise a budget beneath stringent spending limits decreed in the 1997 balanced-budget agreement.
"Every week another Cabinet officer or White House official complains about some part of the budget we've underfunded," Ms. Morra said. "We've done the best we can to prioritize spending under very tight caps."
She said the Administration's budget submission last January included $42 billion in tax increases and user-fee increases that Congress rejected, money that is not available for new spending on research, technology or anything else.
She said many of the research accounts that were cut were in the appropriations bill for the Departments of Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development that also includes money for NASA, the National Science Foundation and the Environmental Protection Agency.
Ms. Morra said a majority of the committee's members decided to increase spending on veterans' health programs substantially, requiring offsetting reductions in research programs.
"It's about prioritizing," she added.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Rose Sharply In August

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 1

 BODY:
In a sign that strong consumer spending continued to power the American economy last month, many auto makers announced today that their sales soared in August, with the biggest growth occurring for some of the most expensive models with the highest profits.
DaimlerChrysler A.G. said that its Chrysler, Dodge, Plymouth, Jeep and Mercedes-Benz brands had their best August ever, together climbing 9.6 percent from already brisk sales in August 1998. Honda Motor reported that its sales had climbed 10.5 percent in August from a year earlier, to the highest level ever for any month, while Toyota Motor reported its best August ever in the United States with a 2.8 percent increase. 
 General Motors said that its sales jumped 63.4 percent. But its sales in August of last year were severely depressed because a 54-day strike had just ended and dealerships had not yet been restocked with popular models.
Auto executives and dealers were jubilant about the strength of the market last month. "It was unbelievable, it was as hot as Texas," said Alan B. Helfman, a Chrysler, Plymouth and Jeep dealer in Houston.
Monthly sales of new automobiles have long been an important barometer of the economy's health, because they account for 4 percent of the nation's economic output and because auto makers disclose sales immediately at the start of the next month. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, made his reputation as an economic consultant while working for the steel and auto industries in the 1950's and 1960's. He has watched auto sales closely ever since, although noting that the auto industry's role in the economy has diminished somewhat over the years.
Lyle E. Gramley, a former Federal Reserve Board governor and now a consulting economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said the soaring sales increased the chances that the central bank would raise short-term interest rates at the next meeting of its interest-rate policy committee on Oct. 5, particularly if other economic indicators showed the same strength as the August auto sales.
While the minutes of recent committee meetings show that the Fed keeps expecting consumers to become satiated with big-ticket purchases and slow their spending, Mr. Gramley said, "These auto sales say it is not happening."
In another indication of economic strength, the Conference Board, a New York business group, said today that the Index of Leading Economic Indicators had shown an increase of three-tenths of a percent in July. But the Commerce Department announced separately that construction spending was surprisingly weak in July, which could mean that the Federal Reserve's two small interest-rate increases this summer are starting to hurt the housing market.
But the rate increases seem to be having little effect on the auto market. "Demand has exceeded our expectations and everyone else's in the industry," said Paul Ballew, G.M.'s general director of industry and market analysis.
Jamie Jameson, DaimlerChrysler's vice president for sales and marketing operations, said that the pace of sales actually increased after the Fed's most recent increase in short-term rates, on Aug. 24. "We closed 3 or 4 percent higher than we had forecasted in the middle of the month," he said. "There are a lot of people who have made a lot of money in the stock market, and it seems like they're cashing it out."
DaimlerChrysler also raised its forecast for auto sales next year, predicting today that sales would be a very strong 16 million vehicles, including heavy trucks. That would be a little less than this year, which is on course for a record 17.2 million vehicles, according to DaimlerChrysler.
Sport utility vehicles sold best last month, followed by pickup trucks, with cars and minivans trailing. Auto makers and dealers make their biggest profits on sport utility vehicles because demand has outstripped supply, allowing many models to be sold at full retail price with little discounting.
The introduction of new designs has increased competition in the market for midsize sport utility vehicles. But with DaimlerChrysler offering lower-cost leases on the Jeep Grand Cherokee this summer, sales shot up last month to the highest level ever, the company said.
Mr. Helfman said that while his dealership stocked a dozen models of cars, minivans and sport utility vehicles, just one model, the Jeep Grand Cherokee, accounted for 100 of the 210 vehicles sold last month. If Chrysler, Plymouth or Jeep built an even larger sport utility vehicle, the size of a Ford Expedition, it would sell extremely well, too, he added.
"If we had a big one, there'd be another 30 or 40 sales -- man, we'd be eating caviar down here," he said.
Ford Motor is scheduled to release its sales figures on Thursday. Auto analysts predict that it will show only a small gain from a year ago, when Ford dealerships profited from the lack of inventory at rival G.M. dealerships. Without Ford's sales, auto makers' market shares cannot be calculated precisely. Mr. Ballew said that G.M.'s share should be "pretty close" to 30 percent, the company's target.
Nissan Motor, which has been struggling, reported a 7.7 percent drop in sales last month from a year ago. But Subaru, a unit of Fuji Heavy Industries, announced that August was its best month in 12 years, with a 9.1 percent improvement from last year, while Mitsubishi Motors said that its sales had jumped 42.8 percent. Volkswagen, which has been riding the popularity of the New Beetle and the midsize Passat sedan and wagon, posted a 33.8 percent increase in August sales.

HEADLINE: Serbs Driven From Kosovo Live Crowded and in Want

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: KURSUMLIJA, Serbia, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Srbislav Bisercic, a competent, bluff and imposing figure who always wore a pistol when he ran the Podujevo municipal administration in Kosovo, is now a broken man, ashamed to be in a jobless exile and hunting for a cheap apartment.
"Yes, I'm depressed," he said. "How could I not be? I left everything down there, everything, my flat, my house, 20 acres of land, my cattle, pigs and tractor." 
 Stopped on the street, Mr. Bisercic is all smiles at first, but his mood quickly darkens, and at one point his eyes become red and wet.
"My biggest problem is being jobless, not having work," he said. "I get my salary, late like everyone else, but I don't know what the state will do with us, since they haven't made it possible for us to go back" home to Kosovo.
Kursumlija, a southern Serbian town of 14,000 people just 15 miles north of Podujevo, is now struggling to absorb 7,000 displaced Serbs from Kosovo.
With the school year starting, Serbs who had been living in Kursumlija's schools are being moved to a tattered local cultural center; thousands more live with host families or relatives or in any apartment they can find.
"Eighty percent of Podujevo's Serbs are looking for a flat here," Mr. Bisercic said. Most Kosovo Serbs are getting only 60 percent of their regular salaries from a state with a severe shortage of cash, its industry smashed by NATO bombs and 10 years of sanctions.
"Everyone is depressed," said Milivoje Mihajlovic, a Serbian journalist from Pristina whose parents now live here. "My wife says, 'I dream every night, and my dreams are in Pristina.' And I'm the same. I spent my whole life, 40 years there, and psychologically that's the biggest problem. Everyone asks everyone else, 'When can we go back?' "
Mr. Bisercic, humiliated and distraught, vows to return to Kosovo soon. Mr. Mihajlovic knows better. "It will take years, if ever, for the pressure to go out of Kosovo," he said. "Everyone needs to calm down, the Serbs and the Albanians." And both need to find less aggressive leaders, he conceded.
According to Vesna Petkovic of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, by last Friday 133,737 displaced Serbs and Gypsies from Kosovo were registered in Serbia, having left Kosovo since February, but the agency estimates the true total was 173,000.
In all of Yugoslavia, including Montenegro, 157,259 people were registered as displaced, and the total was estimated at 196,500.
With 500,000 to 700,000 other Serbs displaced from Bosnia and Croatia, Yugoslavia has more refugees and displaced people than any other country in Europe.
The policies and nationalist wars of Slobodan Milosevic have been the prime source of the refugee burden, which the United Nations refugee agency is working to relieve. This year, it will spend some $60 million to help those in Yugoslavia.
Mira Nikolic, Deputy Minister of the Yugoslav Ministry for Refugees, Displaced Persons and Humanitarian Affairs, said in a telephone interview that the refugees "need almost everything: food, shelter, beds, blankets, hygiene products -- it's better to ask what don't they need." She said that the agency was providing important help, but the biggest problem now would be fuel for heating in the winter.
Host families, with whom some 85 percent of the displaced are living, cannot afford the burden, Ms. Nikolic said, so Belgrade is looking more toward collective housing. The United Nations is ready to help prepare buildings for the winter with construction material, beds and heating fuel.
Ms. Nikolic and Ms. Petkovic agreed that Belgrade's policies toward the Kosovo Serbs had softened. At the beginning, they were urged to return immediately to Kosovo, and Belgrade refused to register them or let them enroll their children in local schools. That has changed, with nearly all students registered for school, but the displaced are encouraged to live near Kosovo and are actively discouraged from trying to settle in Belgrade, where they would be more visible.
Kursumlija is a pleasant but isolated town in the middle of an agricultural area. There is one large company, Drvni Kombinat, making wood products, but salaries average only 200 dinars a month, or $20 at the official rate of exchange. A beer at a cafe costs 50 cents, a sixth of the price in Belgrade. There is no cellular telephone service as there is in bigger towns.
At the shops, people buy 200 grams, or 7 ounces, of meat at a time. "If you buy a kilo," or 2.2 pounds, Mr. Mihajlovic said, "they think you're a millionaire."
If anything, the influx of Kosovo Serbs has pushed up prices a little here, especially for housing, and because the new arrivals are generally better educated they are often seen as a threat to the jobs of the locals.
In the small main square, surrounded by parking, there are many cars with license plates indicating that they are from Pristina and Podujevo and Pec and Prizren.
"I'm lost," said Caslav Bojovic, 44, who was the principal of a school for 367 children in Podujevo. "I feel terrible. I don't know who I am, where I'm going, what I'll do tomorrow."
"We are 'temporarily dislocated people,' " he said bitterly, "and no one cares very much for us, and there is no chance to go back."
He shrugged and said: "We all feel like this. Whatever I had was in my work of 20 years, and it's gone. I was on good terms with my Albanian neighbors. That hurts me, because my neighbors call me and say I should not come back, and I know they are right."
Still, he is angry that Kosovo's Albanians are driving out Serbs, no matter the provocation by others, under the eyes of NATO. "Why don't they indict Thaci as a war criminal?" he demanded, referring to Hashim Thaci, the leader of the Kosovo Liberation Army.
Mr. Bojovic is now looking for a building here to try to reopen his school, and says the local authorities are open to the idea. "I can't leave the kids," he said. "And we need to work."
Down the street, at the shabby Evropa Restaurant, the Kosovo Serbs line up, shamefaced, for a free lunch organized by the local Holy Trinity Church, with help from Belgrade and international organizations like the World Food Program. A section of the restaurant is set aside for the refugees, and Radovan Rajovic, the chef, provides a balanced meal, usually a meat and vegetable stew of some kind, salad and bread. Today, the choice was paprikash, a Hungarian-style veal stew that actually had chunks of veal.
The restaurant serves 1,000 meals a day to the Kosovo Serbs in a program that began Aug. 16, said Radoje Milanovic, the restaurant manager.
Registered refugees have cards that entitle them to the meal, and their names are checked off. But 80 percent take the food away with them rather than sit and eat in a group, Mr. Milanovic said. As they leave, their heads are down.
"I wouldn't come at first, but we have to eat," said a woman in her 50's who asked to remain anonymous. "Of course I'm ashamed."
Mr. Bisercic, the Podujevo official, had insisted that he would stay in Podujevo. But in the end, he left, on June 21, 11 days after Yugoslav forces pulled out in long columns from the city, creating a vacuum that NATO forces did not move in to fill.
"Those Serbs who stayed there are dead," Mr. Bisercic said. "I took three of the last out with me." United Nations officials in Kosovo confirm that only three Serbs remain in all of Podujevo, women too old and alone to leave.
Mr. Bisercic faults NATO for the vacuum of power, but he also considers the Belgrade Government erred in allowing one. "They should not have signed anything until they filled the territory with international forces," he said.
But asked if he blamed President Milosevic, Mr. Bisercic bristled, even more upset. "I voted for Milosevic," he said. "Don't touch me there."
Velisa Malevic, 37, was head of the Podujevo tax police. On the square, wearing shorts and flip-flops and a two-day beard, he said he and his mother and brother and their families -- 14 people -- had all moved here, where his wife was born. In Podujevo, they had two houses and an apartment, with 10 acres. But the apartment has been taken by Albanians and the two houses burned, he said.
"I get a salary but I'm not working," Mr. Malevic said. "That's the worst thing."
He said he dreamed about his life before. "It's the biggest wish in my life to go back." He laughed, then said sardonically of Kosovo's new rulers, "I believe in the United Nations and the United States."
He, like the others, insists that the Albanians of Podujevo were his finest friends and that he protected them as best he could. "The K.L.A. attacked the Serbs, and the Serbs defended themselves with guns, and then NATO came and disarmed the Serbs but not the Albanians, and that's the whole story," Mr. Malevic said.
When told how ridiculous his version would seem to an Albanian whose family was murdered by Serbs or who was driven out of Kosovo by force, Mr. Malevic laughed bitterly. "The Albanians are no angels," he said. "You in the West will find out soon enough."
His wife, Sladjana, worked at the Fagar factory in Podujevo. Here, she is back to being dependent on her father while trying to care for three young children. "I feel ashamed," she said. "It's very unpleasant."
She said the people from Kosovo were overwhelming the town. "The people here are more kind to us, since I was born here," she said. "But they are very distant with the others."
She buried her nose in the hair of her son, Lazar, 4, named after the Prince who led the Serbs in the famous battle of Kosovo in 1389. She lifted red eyes and said softly, "We had everything, and now it belongs to someone else."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Line Forming (Wealthy Bidders Only) for Jets

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Shhh. The Jets are being sold. The new buyer probably won't be chosen soon, perhaps not until the end of the season. But in the quiet fashion that was the hallmark of the team's late owner, Leon Hess, his estate is receiving interest from at least 10 suitors, including Charles F. Dolan, the Cablevision chairman; John McMullen, the Devils' owner, and Ronald Lauder, the cosmetics heir.
Last week, bidders deemed to be sufficiently wealthy received a confidential prospectus written by Goldman, Sachs & Co., the estate's investment adviser, that outlines the myriad reasons the Jets are an attractive investment. 
 The team is very likely to fetch at least $500 million, despite its lack of a revenue-rich stadium, a sweetheart lease at Giants Stadium or the possibility of playing in a new stadium until 2009. A strict financial analysis might yield a much lower price, but the temptation of buying a rejuvenated, New York market football team led by Bill Parcells (even though he may step down as coach after this season) will very likely push the price into the stratosphere.
"The analysis doesn't sustain the numbers being talked about," said one person who has received the prospectus, noting the revenues currently generated at Giants Stadium do not buttress a purchase of a half-billion dollars.
The record price for a sports team is the $800 million paid earlier this year for the Washington Redskins by a group led by Daniel Snyder. But Snyder will have the advantage of a flood of cash from the facility formerly known as Jack Kent Cooke Stadium, which is entering its third season of operations.
If the Jets' prospectus is similar to the one issued late last year to sell the Redskins, and another distributed in 1993 to sell the New England Patriots, it will paint an exceptionally rosy portrait of a rare, maybe once-in-a-lifetime chance to join an elite business club of only 31 members.
"Opportunities to acquire professional sports franchises in general are limited," the Redskins' prospectus boasted, "and the opportunity to own an N.F.L. franchise of the reputation and caliber of the Washington Redskins is truly unique." It added that ownership lets one "become a prominent and influential member of the local and national political and business communities."
"Future appreciation potential," said the Patriots' document. And it pointed out that "season ticket sales increased 37 percent following the announcement of Parcells as coach."
Suitors will undoubtedly read about Jets' franchise history (but probably not about the Rich Kotite era), the National Football League's popularity (with charts), analyses of its collective bargaining agreement and its network television contracts, and several years of team financial statements. One person who read the Jets' prospectus said it mentions the prospect of a new stadium in the Jets' future sometime after the team's Giants Stadium lease expires in 2008, but does not indicate who would pay for it.
"If an owner can handle the short-term cash needs, in the long term, it will be a marvelous investment once he's in a new stadium," said Marc Ganis, the president of Sportscorp Ltd., a consulting firm. "Plus, it would provide a platform of influence in New York second only to owning the Yankees."
Stadium finances were crucial to those looking to buy the Cleveland Browns last year. But before suitors could examine the prospectus, they show their determination by paying the league a $150,000 fee, only half of it refundable.
"That's how they weeded out people," said Bart Wolstein, a Cleveland real-estate developer.
"We got an accurate picture from the book, where the stadium was the real impact," he said, noting the team would keep nearly all the revenues coming into the Browns' new stadium. "We knew what to expect, but in the end I wasn't interested; the whole thing was overvalued."
Al Lerner eventually paid $530 million.
The Patriots' prospectus was so optimistic that it did not mention the team's 2-14 record in 1992, but included a chart comparing its rebuilding program to the one initiated by the 1989 Dallas Cowboys, who recorded a 1-15 record in their first season owned by Jerry Jones and coached by Jimmy Johnson.
The star of the New England prospectus was Parcells, who was entering his first season of coaching the Patriots when the document was issued. His biography was the longest in the prospectus.
"With a stated goal of taking the Patriots to the Super Bowl," it said, "Parcells has put together a talented coaching staff of 11, 10 of whom are new to the team and eight of whom previously coached for the Giants."
Parcells took the Patriots to the Super Bowl in 1997 -- the prospectus didn't promise he would win it -- and his value to the Jets is so enormous that he could have been the cover boy of his current team's sale document.
The Redskins' prospectus, prepared by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, featured one undisputed star: Jack Kent Cooke Stadium, with revenues from its league-high 80,116 seats, 208 luxury suites, 1,506 loge seats and 14,959 club seats; the George Preston Marshall Lower Level, the Sammy Baugh Press Level, the Vince Lombardi Lower Suite Level and the George Allen Upper Suite Level; and the chance to sell the stadium name for millions of dollars for the 2000 season. With the Cooke name off the building, it is temporarily Redskins Stadium.
Stadium revenues and league economics built on broad revenue-sharing help power team sales. Teams like the Redskins, Browns and others that own stadiums or have leases allowing them to swallow nearly all the cash flow usually offer the best reasons for making enormous investments. The 31 teams equally share all network TV revenues and all money from NFL Properties, NFL Films and NFL Enterprises. Visiting teams receive 40 percent of gate receipts from each game.
The Redskins' prospectus describes several years of annual network TV payments for each team ($58.1 million this season, rising to $90.3 million in 2005) and per-team income from NFL Properties ($4.5 million in 1997).
For the 1998 season, the Redskins' combined team and stadium revenues were estimated in the prospectus to reach $141.2 million, with earnings before interest and taxes of $45.6 million. Ticket sales, and luxury box and club seat leases, concessions, parking and advertising expected to total $70.5 million. Last season, the Jets reaped only $22.2 million from the same areas.
When the Patriots were sold, the former owner, James Orthwein, did not own the stadium. In 1992, the team generated $48 million in revenues -- $33.2 million alone from TV and radio -- and posted a $10.6 million loss.
Robert K. Kraft, who bought the team, already owned the stadium and saw the value of purchasing the team for $158 million.
The Hess estate will benefit from selling a New York team that is considered a favorite to win its conference championship with the retirement of quarterback John Elway from Denver. There is no guarantee it will sell for $500 million -- a price is not likely to be mentioned in the prospectus -- but there will be no shortage of those peeking under the team's hood.
Dolan, who bid on the Browns and the Redskins, has the Jets' prospectus. So does McMullen. A spokesman for the real-estate developer Samuel LeFrak, and his son, Richard, said, "They are very interested and talks are going on."
An executive close to Lauder said he has made one inquiry about participating in buying the Jets and expects to make more.
One person reportedly interested is the Las Vegas billionaire, Kirk Kerkorian, who controls Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and MGM Grand. Kerkorian, 81, has the resources, but his casino ownership would put him at odds with the N.F.L.'s blanket prohibition against owner involvement in casinos. "Sports books are a loss leader for the casinos," said Eugene Christiansen, a gaming analyst at Christiansen/Cummings Associates, who added, "Football is by far the biggest sport for casino sports books."
If Kerkorian seriously pursues the Jets, he would have to present a structure in which his ownership is clearly separated from the casinos, or put in the name of his two children, said Greg Aiello, a league spokesman.

HEADLINE: In Panama's New Dawn, Woman Takes Over

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: PANAMA, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Mireya Moscoso, a schoolteacher's daughter who grew up in rural poverty, was sworn in today as Panama's President, the first woman to lead the nation. She will also become the first Panamanian President to lead a completely sovereign country once the United States withdraws its remaining troops and completes its handover of the Panama Canal on Dec. 31.
Those twin themes flavored her inaugural address, in which she repeatedly urged the Panamanian people to join her in eliminating poverty and corruption and in reviving the civic and moral spirit of the nation. 
 "At this moment," she said, "when we are about to end the century and our nation ends a historic era with the departure of a foreign presence, when we are ready with pride and dignity to usher in the new millennium with our sovereignty fully rescued, it is I, the first woman, who has received the trust of the Panamanian people.
"We begin to make real the hopes of thousands of Panamanian women over the centuries who, through generations of history, have nourished the hope that our society recognize their ability and merit, and share with all the men of this country the great responsibility of leading the nation."
Accompanied by her young son, Ricardito, she entered the National Stadium and raised her arms in a symbolic embrace of the cheering, flag-waving crowd of thousands of Panamanians from throughout the country.
The site was a gesture to the populist pillars of her Arnulfista Party, which was named after her late husband, Dr. Arnulfo Arias, who was elected and removed from the presidency three times.
Although her father was a teacher, her political education came during her marriage to Dr. Arias, a legendary -- and somewhat eccentric -- nationalist whose own beliefs included fascist and mystical leanings. She has often invoked his memory in her speeches, and her address today was filled with poignant references.
"Today is the beginning of the period of government he never had a chance to fulfill for the benefit of the poor and marginalized of Panama," she said. "How much I wish my mother and father and Dr. Arnulfo Arias were sitting in front watching this historic day. But I know they are in heaven blessing us and saying 'Mireya, keep on and fulfill the work I could not finish.' "
While the audience included heads of state and diplomats, notably absent was the man she defeated in last May's election, President Ernesto Perez Balladares, who left the Presidential Palace even before the inauguration.
The slight was the final skirmish in a summer-long battle marked by moves that could hobble his successor's administration, like packing the Supreme Court with his political allies and appointing associates from his Revolutionary Democratic Party to Civil Service posts.
President Moscoso, 53, leads the nation into its most important period as it takes over the canal and some $4 billion in surrounding property. Although the canal is a $700 million operation, it is not a windfall because much of that money goes back into operations.
Several companies have invested in tourism and other projects, but there have been suggestions that the United States should provide more help.
"We haven't tried to support them with a package of trade and investment incentives that will insure the transfer of facilities and land be done smoothly," said Bob Pastor, a political scientist at Emory University and former member of the National Security Council.
President Moscoso vowed to run the canal efficiently and safely, projecting an international image of stability. And she reminded citizens of their new relationship with the canal and of the challenges and opportunities of Panamanian ownership.
"On Dec. 31, at 12 noon, we will once and for all attain our true independence," she said. "From then on, we will have to go on a new path, one where we will have to provide all the elements of a national identity."
Her supporters have high expectations because of her promises to create jobs, ease poverty and deliver better social services.
In a country where more than a third of the population is in poverty, many voters became suspicious of government after her predecessor's policies of privatization and open markets resulted in little they could see, except for miles of new highways. Balladares left behind an unemployment rate of about 14 percent, $7 billion in debt and little cash to pay for Ms. Moscoso's platform.
Some foreign diplomats said she has only vaguely explained how she will translate her intense grass-roots appeal into a workable social and political program.
"She's very good at retail politics, in sensing the mood in a crowd," one said. "But don't talk to her about big policy details. She goes blank."
President Moscoso has said she will not privatize any more state-run enterprises, though few remain. She has also said she wants to raise tariffs to help farmers devastated by imports, but her ability to do so is limited by Panama's membership in the World Trade Organization.
She has suggested dipping into a $1.7 billion fund generated by her predecessor's sale of state industries, but her slim majority in the legislature may not prove strong enough to accomplish this.
While viewed as having the most pro-American administration in decades, the President has chosen a Cabinet of relatively young professionals with little government experience.
And they have been hampered by the departing administration's almost total lack of cooperation in any transition meetings.
But Roberto Eisenmann, an informal adviser on social issues, said she was focused on the task ahead and aware of the risks.
"A few months ago, when the euphoria of her victory was still present, I was in a meeting with people who were talking about the difficulties of governing with an strong opposition in the Assembly," Mr. Eisenmann said in an interview on Tuesday. "A loyal supporter stood up and said, 'Dona Mireya, remember you have the people!'
"With a serenity that was really remarkable she said: 'I have the people today. I could lose it tomorrow if we don't dedicate ourselves and work for the people.' "
