HEADLINE: A Step to End Newark's Chapter in High-Rise Public Housing Projects

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Built in 1959, the seven hulking 13-story brick buildings that are the Stella Wright Homes stand as a forlorn monument to another era of urban renewal. It was a time, said Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, when the nation was warring with itself over the impulse to integrate the poor and the impulse to isolate them.
Mr. Cuomo came here today to announce a $35 million grant to tear down the Stella Wright Homes -- Newark's last remaining high-rise public housing complex -- and help redevelop the site with town houses for low- and moderate-income residents. 
 Projects like Stella Wright, Mr. Cuomo said, were examples of the temporary triumph of occasional efforts since the first public housing was built in 1937 to isolate the poor from the rest of society.
"When public housing makes the statement of exclusion and isolation, President Clinton has said, 'Tear it down and don't repaint it, put in new windows or new fences,' " Mr. Cuomo said. "It had the wrong intent from the beginning and should be replaced with smaller, low-rise, low-density places where people want to live."
The announcement of the grant was applauded by Mayor Sharpe James as well as by tenants groups that have taken the city to court over conditions at Stella Wright and delays in building new public housing.
Mr. James has often been criticized for pushing harder for downtown development like the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and the city's new minor league baseball stadium than for housing and neighborhood redevelopment. Today he called the Department of Housing and Urban Development grant "a great gift" that confirmed that "we have not forgotten the neighborhoods."
It most likely will be years, though, before Stella Wright is razed and replaced. City officials have yet to arrange over $100 million in financing to build the town houses or to schedule demolition of Stella Wright, where more than a third of the 1,179 apartments now are vacant.
While encouraged by today's announcement, Dave Weiner, a local labor leader who is secretary of the Newark Coalition for Low Income Housing, noted that plans announced by the city in 1994 to build housing at another site remained just that, plans.
"We like this program," Mr. Weiner said, "but our experience is that the Newark Housing Authority is always behind in construction." Last year his group persuaded a Federal judge to order the authority to hire a construction manager in an effort to speed up new construction and renovation of existing housing, which currently has a waiting list of more than 9,000 names.
Robert Graham, acting executive director of the authority, said the cost of rehabilitating Stella Wright to Federal standards has been estimated at $95 million. Stella Wright is plagued by broken elevators, trash-strewn stairwells and fortresslike fencing.
The site of the nation's longest rent strike among public housing residents, it is symbolic of tenant activism as well as the problems of the so-called vertical ghettos of towering projects. The rent strike, from 1970 to 1974, ended only after a Federal court forced both sides to compromise.
But today the officials looked ahead. Under the current plans, the complex's 764 occupied two-, three-, four-, and five-bedroom apartments will be replaced with 755 town houses of various sizes. About 300 will be rented as public housing and 284 sold to moderate-income families. The remaining 167 will be rented at fair market rates. Some of the money awarded today will be used to help obtain $119 million in private and other public funds for the redevelopment effort.
Five parks, two community centers as well as child care facilities are planned for the area around the redevelopment.
The grant, part of a program called Hope VI, also includes money to train and find jobs for about 345 residents of public housing and help prepare 500 young people for employment.
Atlantic City also received a $35 million award, which will go to demolish the 214 apartments in the Shore Park/Shore Terrace public housing development and help replace it with 600 town houses, 386 of which will be sold at the market rate. The HUD funds are intended to attract $154 million in other public and private funds.
Mr. Cuomo said that because the economy was so strong, the private capital needed for the redevelopment efforts in both cities was likely to be more readily available.
As he sketched out how public housing philosophy has evolved, the Secretary expressed fear that the current Republican-controlled Congress, with its plans for using budget surpluses to grant large tax cuts, would again force exclusion of the poor.
For one thing, he said, those proposals would give most of the surplus to those on the top 1 percent of the income ladder. But they would also cut $1.6 billion from HUD's budget for programs like the one announced today. For New Jersey that would mean a $50 million annual loss in HUD funds and for New York State it would mean a $200 million cut.
"This is a battle for the nation's soul," Mr. Cuomo said, referring to the fight over how to allocate the budget surpluses.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
New Jersey Economy Described as Robust

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New Jersey's already strong economy will add even more muscle over the next year, according to a report released yesterday by economists who advise Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.
The Governor's Council of Economic Advisers, releasing a midyear report, upgraded an already rosy outlook for the economy. The group said all sectors of the economy were going strong. 
 Most economists gave Mrs. Whitman high marks for managing the good times, but said that outside forces, like the national economy, were the biggest reasons for New Jersey's success. Unemployment remains under 5 percent, state employers are on track to add up to 65,000 jobs this year, and prime office space is being gobbled up.
Joseph Seneca, a Rutgers University economist who heads the council, said even the long-troubled manufacturing sector was showing signs of stability.
"It's the best economy in a generation," Mr. Seneca said.
The economic advisers said New Jersey's gross state product, which measures goods and services produced in the state, would rise by 5 percent this year. The group also upgraded estimates on retail sales, personal income and consumer spending.
The council's early projections for 2000, however, show slower growth. Mr. Seneca said the state and national economies faced a problem born of their own success: low unemployment rates are producing a shortage of skilled workers. He said this might be one force that could slow the growth.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Investors Seek Bargains Despite Worries About Fed

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks finished higher yesterday as bargain hunting overshadowed interest-rate jitters in advance of fresh statistics on the tight American job market.
Halting a four-session skid that had lopped nearly 500 points from last week's record level, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 108.60 points, or 1 percent, to 10,937.88, paced by a 211/16 -point jump in I.B.M., which has benefited this week from new contracts with Cisco Systems. 
 The Nasdaq composite index and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also climbed. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 11.45 points, or four-tenths of a percent, to 2,750.80. It is now up 25.45 percent for the year.
The S.& P. 500-stock index rose 10.66 points, or eight-tenths of a percent, to 1,331.07.
"It's really hard to identify sustainable trends in a week like this," said Timothy E. Woolston, a portfolio manager at Boston Advisors. "Everybody's waiting for the numbers," mainly the job report for August, which will be announced Friday, but also the Labor Department's tally today of first-time applications last week for unemployment insurance. Factory orders will also be revealed today for July.
Timothy E. O'Grady, senior portfolio manager at First Capital Group in Philadelphia, said, "Inflation is still a potential issue, an item to contend with."
An initial belief that the Federal Reserve's Aug. 24 credit-tightening might be its final one of the year has been undermined, most recently by Tuesday's survey of corporate buyers who reported paying markedly higher prices last month.
Higher interest rates make stocks less competitive with bonds and make corporate borrowing more expensive and, for some, more difficult. Rates were narrowly mixed yesterday, edging up for longer-maturity bonds while money rates eased.
Drug stocks and those of paper and forest products companies made some of the day's biggest gains, the latter helped by upgrading at Paine Webber.
International Paper, one of 23 Dow blue chips to advance, rose 1 9/16, to 48 5/8, while Willamette Industries was up 3 1/2, to 43 1/8, and Fort James, Westvaco, Champion and Weyerhaeuser each rose more than a point. Georgia Pacific, now up 46 percent so far this year, climbed 15/16, to 42 5/16.
Among the drug makers, Warner-Lambert jumped 2 1/4, to 68 5/8, and Merck, Bristol-Myers and Schering-Plough posted gains of more than a point.
Retailing stocks, beaten up of late, rebounded slightly in most cases though J. C. Penney surged 1 7/8, to 38 1/8, while Sears lost 5/16, to 37 3/16.
The Standard & Poor's 500 advanced 10.66 points, or 0.8 percent, with AT&T, up 2 3/8, to 47 3/8, making the biggest contribution. I.B.M. had the next largest gain followed by General Electric, up 1 3/8, to 113 11/16. Intel was another sizable gainer, up 1 1/4, to 83 7/16, after the company introduced a new line of networking chips.
On the other hand, Qualcomm, the cellular company, was a significant drag, falling 23 1/2, to 168 11/16, after an analyst at Everen Securities warned of an earnings shortfall after meeting with management.
Juniper Networks was another casualty, sliding 24 3/4, to 180 1/4, after registering 5.75 million shares for a secondary offering, more than half from company officials.
MMC Networks was battered for a second day, losing 4 1/8, to 26 3/4, on top of a 38 percent drop Tuesday after I.B.M. said it would no longer make products using MMC chips.
Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange was 697.1 million, with 1,715 advancing issues and 1,288 declines. New 52-week lows swamped new highs, however, 97 to 25.
Major European markets closed about one-half percent to 1 percent higher but the best overseas gains were 2.1 percent in Tokyo and 3.2 percent in Sao Paulo.

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
Chinese Glass As Stepchild

BYLINE: By Wendy Moonan

 BODY:
Antique Chinese glass is a stepchild in the family of Chinese decorative arts. There are only a handful of scholarly books on the subject, and few American museums have high-quality Chinese glass collections. (The outstanding exceptions are the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston and the Corning Museum of Glass in upstate New York.) Much more attention is paid to Chinese painting, calligraphy and ceramics from ancient times through the Ming Dynasty (A.D. 1368 to 1644).
"Lack of knowledge has made people afraid to touch Chinese glass," said Mostafa Hassan, owner of a Manhattan gallery, Imperial Oriental Art. Mr. Hassan, a former specialist at Christie's, sells pink, amber, turquoise and "mutton fat" white examples of 18th- and 19th-century Chinese glass in his gallery, at 790 Madison Avenue, near 67th Street. 
 The market for Chinese glass has had dramatic ups and downs. In the early 1980's it was relatively inexpensive because there was little demand for it. By the end of the 1980's the market heated up and the prices for the finest examples increased dramatically. The stepchild status persists, however. As James B. Godfrey, a Sotheby's specialist, said, "Glass can be a whimsical market."
A few years ago two scholars, Claudia Brown and Donald Rabiner, tried to explain the prejudice against post-Ming Chinese glass. In "Clear as Crystal, Red as Flame: Later Chinese Glass," a catalogue for a 1990 exhibition at the China Institute in America, they wrote, "Particular disdain has long been reserved for 'late' Chinese art, that is, works of the Qing Dynasty (1644-1911)."
Ms. Brown, curator of Asian art at the Phoenix Art Museum, and Mr. Rabiner, an art history professor at Arizona State University who died in 1992, explained: "The obvious merits of Qing-period jade, enamel, lacquer and glass were sadly obscured by the belief that 'late' is but a euphemism for decadent, representing at best the triumph of technique over good design, and more commonly bearing witness to a notable decline in workmanship."
A coming show at Alvin Lo Oriental Art Limited, a gallery at 5 East 57th Street in Manhattan, may challenge such attitudes. Mr. Lo, whose father, P. C. Lu, was a renowned Hong Kong dealer, has been collecting glass for 15 years. On Sept. 14 he is opening an exhibition titled "18th Century: The Golden Age of Peking Glass," which includes 18 pieces, ranging from monochrome examples in egg yolk yellow, ruby red and opaline green with simple shapes (what is called "scholar's taste") to highly decorative pieces with multicolored glass overlays.
The Lo exhibition is timed to coincide with Asia Week in New York, a major period of sales of Oriental antiques. The Doyle sale is on Sept. 13. The "Art of Pacific Asia" show runs from Sept. 15 through 18. Sotheby's sale is on Sept. 15 and includes several pieces of later Chinese glass. Lot 10, for example, is a pair of 19th-century yellow jars with covers.
"Jars with covers always seem popular with people, because they like the shape," Mr. Godfrey said. "What is also compelling is the color. Yellow is the most sought after because it is the color associated with the Chinese Imperial household."
One lot at Sotheby's is a brush washer. Mr. Godfrey called it "a typical scholar's object, in that it is more subtle, simple and less complex." The estimates for the glass range from $2,000 to $10,000.
Christie's "Fine Chinese Furniture, Ceramics and Works of Art" sale on Sept. 16 will have little glass, except for a handful of small bottles.
Mr. Lo uses the popular term Peking glass because people associate Chinese glass with the Imperial Palace workshop and the commercial glass houses of Beijing. In fact the Chinese have made glass since about 700 B.C. It is just that glass apparently did not rate royal patronage until 300 years ago.
In 1696 the second Emperor of the Qing Dynasty, Kangxi (1662-1722), established a glass house within the palace workshops, apparently after learning that a German missionary in Beijing, Kilian Stumpf (1655-1720), knew how to construct kilns, formulate glass batches and work the materials into forms.
The founding of the imperial workshop was "an event that would profoundly affect the history of Chinese glass for at least a century," Ms. Brown and Mr. Rabiner wrote. "Imperial patronage greatly increased the status of this material, whose principal function had long been the economical imitation of jade and other hard stones."
The palace workshops grew productive and glass became very fashionable, both inside the court and out. Mr. Stumpf's influence over the forms the glass took was short-lived. As Ms. Brown and Mr. Rabiner wrote in the Phoenix Art Museum catalogue for the 1987 show "Chinese Glass of the Qing Dynasty: 1644-1911": "However much technical assistance the European craftsmen may have lent, few surviving pieces of Chinese glass owe a discernible debt to European styles." What happened in fact was just the opposite. By the time of the Qianlong Empire (1736-1795), the Chinese were making glass in the shapes of traditional Chinese pots, vases, dragon-handled cups, even statues of horses.
"Glassmaking had long encompassed the imitation of hard stones," the catalogue continues, "but now, working side by side with lacquerers, enamelers and jade craftsmen, glassmen took inspiration from other crafts."
In the Lo exhibition, there are a pair of opaque green glass cups decorated with bas relief carvings of lotus leaves, birds, and flowering branches. Mr. Lo said that the carved glass cups were made to imitate carved jadeite. "Jadeite was always very expensive; it was a precious material," Mr. Lo said. "Peking glass was made to look like jade, lapis lazuli, turquoise and rose quartz. It imitated rubies, sapphires and emeralds."
Collecting Chinese glass can be a tricky enterprise. "I don't sell it because it's so easy to copy," said Ralph Chait, a veteran Manhattan dealer in Chinese art.
Mr. Lo concurred. "You have to buy from a reputable source," he said. "Some of the marks on glass are very deceiving. They could be from the imperial glass works, but they could also be marks added in the 20th century. To make matters worse, there are genuine pieces that have no marks. You have to have a basic understanding of what pieces would have been marked, and which would not."
Mr. Lo warned that there are fakes on the market. "In the early 1980's, when I started dealing in 18th-century glass, prices were so low that it wasn't worth faking," he said. "When prices shot up in the late 1980's, I began to see decorative pieces with marks that shouldn't have had any marks. The Chinese do a very good job at imitating old Peking glass."
Mr. Lo's prices range from $8,500 to $150,000 (for an unusual pair of glass horses). The show is to continue through Sept. 24.

HEADLINE: Don't Jettison Russia Just Yet

BYLINE: By Boris Nemtsov and Ian Bremmer; Boris Nemtsov is a former First Deputy Prime Minister of Russia. Ian Bremmer is a senior fellow at the World Policy Institute and president of Eurasia Group.

 BODY:
With the year 2000 bringing presidential elections in both the United States and Russia, the emerging scandal over the possible laundering of billions of dollars from Russia through the Bank of New York has, predictably, already prompted a politically tinged search for scapegoats. And in both countries, the leading culprits are the same -- the Democrats and the "democrats."
In Russia, President Boris Yeltsin's administration, through inept governance and suspected corruption, has managed to give reform a bad name. The opposition, frustrated in its efforts to break Mr. Yeltsin's power, has taken to blaming "democrats" and their accomplices in the West for the country's many troubles. 
 In the United States, the problem is different, but the tactic of the opposition is the same. A strong economy, victory in Kosovo and the nagging suspicion that Monicagate may have helped more than hurt the Democrats have left the Republicans in a quandary: how to set upon the Clinton record without seeming priggish, pharisaical and small? The answer of the moment seems to be to focus on the Administration's fascination with and support for a limping Russia, particularly the prominent role of Vice President Al Gore.
Is this the end of the entente between the United States and Russia? Should the West continue to provide aid? Won't International Monetary Fund dollars end up in the hands of Russian mobsters?
Before we write off the relationship, we should remember that the Russian economy is moving very slowly to a free market. The billions of dollars that have left Russia in the past decade will never come back if Western governments bury their heads in the sand, and they will come back only if and when Russia becomes an integrated part of the global economy.
Western governments should recognize this and focus spending where it can make the greatest difference. The West could finance institutional support through Western nongovernmental organizations -- NGO's -- and multinational corporations operating in Russia, keeping money out of the hands of the corrupt elite while providing the intellectual and physical infrastructure of a market-based economy. The I.M.F. could take the money earmarked for defending the ruble and use it to finance a micro-loan program aimed at building a middle class, creating a tax base so that the Government can meet it debt obligations (finally putting the horse in front of the cart). Russia's Soviet-era debt could and should be forgiven.
But at the same time, there must be accountability. The I.M.F. has made clear that it hasn't the ability to follow money once it goes overseas. The American and Russian intelligence communities should form a joint investigative body to track Western money -- through Russia, through the West and through offshore sources.
Yuri Skuratov, who was dismissed as Russian Prosecutor General earlier this year after pressing an investigation of Mr. Yeltsin's inner circle, has said that the Russians will not cooperate in such an effort. Certainly there is little reason for President Yeltsin to initiate it. But if an official proposal comes to Moscow from the Clinton Administration, it would be politically difficult for Mr. Yeltsin to say no.
The investigation now under way in the United States will, it is hoped, determine where the money that went through the Bank of New York came from. Our theory is that Russia's ill-fated treasury bills -- the G.K.O.'s -- will account for much of it.
The bills were canceled after the fiscal crisis in August 1998, but convertibility continued for several months. Russia's elites knew that they needed to get their money out fast, and as insiders they knew exactly what to do. Insider trading is deplorable, especially given its compounding effect on the long list of ills brought upon Russia's economy by its oligarchs. But there is a big difference between the politically savvy flight of capital and money laundering. Russia simply doesn't have the institutions in place to regulate these transactions properly. This should be a priority for the future.
All of this is very different from the allegations of corruption involving those in and around the Yeltsin family. Here America's role must be carefully balanced. The United States has been remiss by supporting the first democratically elected head of the Russian state instead of the processes and institutions of democracy. The corruption allegations surrounding the Yeltsin family should be discussed frankly and with vigilance. This does not mean Russian reform is at an end.
We should keep our heads about us. Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, has stated that in its initial scrutiny of the Bank of New York case, the I.M.F. has found no indication that loan money was involved. Russia's relationship with the West is much more important than presidential politics in either country. Let's not blame the D/democrats for that. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Refinancing Helps Co-op Despite Penalty Payment

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
Windsor Park, a robust 1,822-unit co-op apartment complex in Bayside, Queens, has embarked on an aggressive refinancing plan to free cash to make improvements and bring long-term financial stability to the enclave of 20 six-story red-brick buildings.
Last month, the co-op, set on 46 acres along 73d Avenue and Bell Boulevard, arranged with its lender, the Republic National Bank, to refinance its underlying mortgage, increasing it to $40 million from $29 million for 15 years. At the same time, the co-op locked in an interest rate of 7.07 percent, down from the 8.43 percent it now pays, days before rates moved upward. The new loan is to close in two weeks, said Robert P. Corso Jr., director of the mortgage brokerage division at Insignia Residential Group, which manages Windsor Park and represented the co-op in the refinancing. 
 Mr. Corso said the new loan would give the co-op enough money to pay off an existing $4.5 million construction loan, invest $3.5 million more to complete a continuing renovation program and establish a $300,000 reserve fund. But crucial to the refinancing, he said, is that it will let the co-op shift into the new loan a $2.7 million prepayment penalty for retiring the old balloon mortgage three years before it was to expire. Making the prepayment penalty a part of the new mortgage will allow the co-op to amortize that payment over 30 years, minimizing the financial impact on the corporation.
Windsor Park, which has one- to three-bedroom apartments of 650 to 1,400 square feet, is late to the refinancing trend. Many co-ops have already refinanced to take advantage of lower interest rates, which are still reasonable though they have risen a full percentage point since last November, said Ellen Bitton, president of the Park Avenue Mortgage Group, a Manhattan mortgage broker. The refinancing market is not as strong as it was in the last two years, but it is still active, she added.
Greg Carlson, president of the Federation of New York Cooperatives, said that some co-ops like Windsor Park that faced large prepayment penalties had hesitated to plunge into refinancing. "Sometimes it pays for them to refinance and take advantage of lower rates, but sometimes it simply doesn't," he said.
Lawrence R. Vitelli, senior vice president of the Insignia Residential Group, added, "Boards do not always readily see the benefit in paying a large sum of money today for a lower rate tomorrow."
He said that for Windsor Park, which wanted to complete a renovation program it started three years ago, the debate was whether to raise the needed funds for the work through a special assessment on shareholders, take out another construction loan at a high interest rate or refinance. What persuaded the board to refinance, Mr. Vitelli added, is that the new underlying mortgage, the result of three months of negotiations, is structured so it will not significantly increase the co-op's $12 million annual operating budget.
Meanwhile, he said, the monthly maintenance costs that co-op owners pay, which range from $325 to $930, will remain unchanged, and the owners will get a onetime tax deduction for their pro rata share of the prepayment penalty. For example, the tax reduction on a typical 1,200-square-foot, two-bedroom apartment will be $1,700, he said.
"It's an insurance policy," Larry Kinitsky, president of the co-op board at Windsor Park, said of the new loan. As part of the co-op's long-term strategic plan, the stability of a 15-year low-interest-rate mortgage coupled with the added improvements "will keep Windsor Park ahead of the financial curve and take it where it needs to be to remain competitive," he said. And it will also help increase the value and marketability of the apartments for unit owners, he said.
Windsor Park was converted from a rental to a co-op in 1986. Since then, even when the residential market fizzled in the late 1980's, it remained a financially viable upper-middle-income co-op where residents own 80 percent of the apartments. Of the remaining 20 percent of the units, which are owned by a Manhattan investment group, most are rented for $600 to $1,750 a month.
Still, owners watched the prices of their units plummet by up to 50 percent at the nadir of the recession in the early 1990's, with little upward movement through the first half of this decade, as the co-op market outside the plusher Manhattan neighborhoods remained dormant. But as the overall housing market has improved, prices for co-ops in Queens have risen by about 5 percent a year for the last five years, said Mr. Carlson, the president of the co-op federation, who also heads a real estate brokerage bearing his name in Forest Hills, Queens.
While sales have picked up, prices in many co-op buildings have not yet rebounded to where they were at the time of conversion, he said. "But in some of the better buildings in the better neighborhoods, units are selling for close to their original prices and in a few instances exceeding them," he added.
At Windsor Park, two-bedroom units that sold for an average of $75,000 two years ago are now selling for $115,000, Mr. Vitelli said. The added hope of the refinancing and, in turn, the renovation program, he said, is that those prices will rise 15 to 20 percent more, bringing the value of the units back to at least their original prices.
The $3.5 million renovation program calls for completing capital improvements, like installing new heating systems and roofs, as well as making cosmetic upgrades to the complex. They include refurbishing the lobbies and hallways in the buildings as well as enhancing the landscaping of the grounds of the community, whose amenities include outdoor swimming pools and tennis courts, which have already been improved. The work will take place over the next 18 months, Mr. Kinitsky, the board president, said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
HSBC's Deal For Republic To Be Delayed

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
HSBC Holdings P.L.C. said today that its pending $10.3 billion acquisition of the Republic New York Corporation would be delayed because of an investigation of Republic's securities unit.
United States and Japanese officials are investigating whether the securities unit inflated the net asset value of an investment fund owned by large institutional investors in Japan, The Wall Street Journal reported today. 
 Republic, the holding company for the Republic National Bank of New York, declined to comment on the investigation. In a statement, it said that it was cooperating with investigators and that it had suspended the chief executive of the unit, James Edward Sweeney. Republic also said that it had replaced the manager of the futures department.
HSBC, which announced on May 10 that it would pay $72 a share for Republic, said in a statement today that it hoped to close the deal but that "as a result of this investigation, it may take longer than originally anticipated to complete the regulatory process."
HSBC, Britain's largest bank, said it was waiting for more details from Republic and investigators before completing the deal.
"Everyone wants to know what kind of exposure is involved and if it is material and all of the rest," said Richard Beck, a spokesman for HSBC in London. "We have to wait for Republic to update us with new information."
Shares of Republic fell 10.4 percent, or $7.185, to $62.1875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. In London, shares of HSBC fell 2.6 percent, to 7.46, or $12.03.
Analysts said they expected that the purchase would be completed but were concerned that it might drag on for several months. The two companies had hoped to complete the deal by the end of this month.
"It's unlucky timing for HSBC," said Simon Samuels, a banking analyst with Salomon Smith Barney in London. Indeed, earlier this week, talks between HSBC and the South Korean Government for HSBC to take control of Seoulbank fell apart.
Despite the problems that Republic might face, "the industrial logic of the deal is very compelling," Mr. Samuels added.
"It is likely that it will delay the deal but not scuttle it," he said.
The investigation stems from an inspection by Japanese regulators of a Tokyo office that is affiliated with a client of Republic's securities unit. Though Republic did not identify the client, Bloomberg News said today that the client was Princeton Economics International, a New Jersey company. Princeton Economics owns Cresvale International Ltd., which specializes in brokering and underwriting equities and bonds in Japan.
In May, Japanese regulators made an unannounced audit of Cresvale's Tokyo operations as part of a wider scrutiny of foreign securities firms.
Officials at Princeton Economics could not be reached for comment.
The chairman of Princeton Economics is Martin Armstrong, who is one of the largest individual traders of silver futures on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange. He is also involved in currency hedging in Asia.
Mr. Sweeney, who headed the Republic securities unit, had had previous run-ins with regulators. In February, he agreed to pay the Securities and Exchange Commission a $25,000 fine over accusations that the unit had paid rebates to an investment advisory firm. In settling with the S.E.C., the Republic unit and Mr. Sweeney neither admitted nor denied the allegations.

HEADLINE: Ford Reports Surprisingly Strong Sales For August

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 2

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that its sales in August were even higher than expected, making last month the best August ever for auto sales in the United States and the best month in the 1990's after adjusting for seasonal variations in demand.
Ford posted an 8.1 percent increase in sales compared with the period a year earlier. Car sales leaped 19.2 percent, with the introduction of new models and the purchase of Volvo's car business. Sales of light trucks -- sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans -- climbed seven-tenths of a percent. 
 The rise in light-truck sales was particularly surprising because Ford sold an large number of light trucks in August 1998, when a strike against General Motors just ended.
Ward's Auto Info Bank, a market research service in Southfield, Mich., calculated that the seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales in August was 17.76 million cars and light trucks. That made August sales the fourth-highest ever in seasonally adjusted terms, only trailing September 1986, September 1985 and December 1986. The expiration in the mid-1980's of tax deductions for certain car loan expenses produced a brief but unsustainable spike in sales as consumers raced to take advantage of the old rules.
August is traditionally a slow month in the auto industry. The actual number of automobiles sold in August this year was fewer than in May or June, but the seasonal adjustments for the May and June sales made those numbers look weaker than last month's sales.
Auto executives attribute the brisk sales to rising household incomes, soaring stock and real estate prices, low unemployment, strong consumer confidence, fairly flat prices for new autos and the introduction of innovative vehicles like the Lexus RX-300, which is a cross between a car and a sport utility vehicle.
Some auto analysts have expressed concern that rebates and other incentives may be contributing considerably to the boom in sales. But that view is beginning to shift.
"I'm beginning to believe there's something more structural going on," as rising incomes outpace increases in vehicle prices, making automobiles more affordable, said John Casesa, an auto analyst at Merrill Lynch. "I don't get the impression incentives changed a lot from July to August."
Sport utility vehicle sales reached their highest level ever in August, according to Ward's. "Consumer demand for S.U.V.'s has outpaced every other segment every year of this decade, and we believe this trend will continue," said Robert Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing, sales and service.
The acquisition in March of Volvo Cars accounted for less than half of Ford's improvement in car sales. Even without the acquisition, Ford's car sales rose 12.57 percent compared with those in the month a year earlier; if Volvo is counted in both years, car sales rose 12.47 percent. The introduction of the Lincoln LS and Jaguar S-Type sports sedans this summer and the earlier introduction of the completely redesigned Mercury Cougar have helped Ford, as have lower prices on the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable sedans.
DaimlerChrysler, G.M., Toyota, Honda, VW and several smaller auto makers all announced robust August sales on Wednesday; Nissan posted slightly lower sales. G.M.'s car and light truck market share in August was 29.8 percent, barely falling short of the company's goal of a minimum of 30 percent.
Today, BMW said that, like Ford, it had enjoyed its best August ever. BMW's sales jumped 31.5 percent compared with those in the month a year earlier.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Continues Its Retreat, Falling Another 95 Points

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Stock prices resumed their late-summer swoon yesterday, under the cloud of a hyperactive economy and nervousness over whether the Federal Reserve will decide to raise short-term interest rates again to keep inflation at bay.
Bracing for the Government's report today on the August job market, traders had to contend with word that the automotive industry sold cars and trucks last month at the fastest pace since December 1986 and with a warning by Edward Kelley, a Federal Reserve policy maker, that it was "premature" to rule out a third rate increase. 
 What is more Government reports that manufacturing orders rose by a rapid 2.1 percent last month, jobless claims stayed below the key 300,000 level, and that growth of productivity in the second quarter slowed to an annual rate of six-tenths of a percent depicted a growing economy with a risk of inflation ahead.
 "The compass continues to point in one direction," said Jeffrey M. Applegate, chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers. "People are increasingly worried that the Fed is not on hold."
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 94.67 points, or 0.87 percent, to 10,843.21, nearly erasing Wednesday's rally and making it five losing sessions out of six since it set a record at 11,326.04 on Aug. 25.
The Dow's decline was in line with an 11.96 point, or 0.9 percent, drop in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index, which closed at 1,319.11. The Nasdaq composite did a little better, losing six-tenths of 1 percent, or 16.56 points to close at 2,734.24, even through it is heavily weighted with expensive high-technology stocks that are especially sensitive to rates.
"Interest rates going up puts a lot of burden on price-earnings multiples" and on financial stocks, said Paul McManus, research director at Independence Investment Associates in Boston.
J. P. Morgan, down 3 11/16, to 125 15/16, and American Express, down 3 1/8 to 135 7/8, placed first and third, respectively, in contributing to the skid in the Dow industrials. Sears, Roebuck, which slumped 3 11/16 to 33 1/2 after warning of a profits shortfall, was the second-biggest drag.
While 20 of the Dow's 30 stocks fell, these three issues accounted for 55 percent of the total drop. Analysts attributed a late rebound in the Dow, which had been down as much as 205 points at one stage, to traders covering short positions, which represent the sales of borrowed stocks, and to the activation of buy programs.
On the New York Stock Exchange, an unusually high total of 2,078 issues declined, while 874 advanced, a ragged performance that added to the general sense of market deterioration. Stocks making new 52-week lows, moreover, outnumbered those making new highs by more than five to one -- 118 to 22.
At the same time, analysts noted that activity remained on the light side, with 687.14 million shares changing hands on the Big Board, compared with 697.1 million during Wednesday's rally.
Other retailing stocks were hit along with Sears yesterday, reflecting fears of higher rates and a slowdown of torrid consumer spending. Dayton Hudson fell 1 5/8, to 56 5/8, J. C. Penney 1 11/16, to 36 7/16, and Best Buy 10 1/2, to 61 7/16, after personal-computer promotions failed to lift the company's quarterly sales as high as many had hoped. Wal-Mart, one of the few merchants to buck the trend, rose 1 1/16, to 45 11/16.
Republic New York tumbled 7 3/16, to 62 3/16, after disclosing governmental investigations of a client that in turn prompted HSBC Holdings to say this might delay its takeover of Republic.
Technology stocks were caught in the general downdraft but few of the losses were big. Rambus, however, slid 4 3/4, to 90 1/2, after Intel said it would use a less expensive competing memory-chip technology in response to demand by computer makers. Intel gained 1 7/8, to 85 5/16 to make the biggest positive impact on the S.& P. 500.
Stocks in major European markets fell by 1.25 to 2.5 percent, while Japan fell about 1 percent. Brazil's Bovespa, however, advanced nine-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Challenges for Boeing After Union Approves Pact

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
The Boeing Company's largest union voted overwhelmingly Wednesday night to accept a three-year contract, averting a strike that would have dealt a blow to Boeing's efforts to recover from a financial downturn.
Of the votes cast by members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 44,300 of Boeing's 207,000 employees, 86 percent, or 26,842, were for the contract. A simple majority was required for passage. 
 Both the union and the company hailed the results, which headed off what would have been the third walkout by the machinists in the last 10 years. "With this contract, the company and the union must move forward together to capture productivity gains and significantly improve the company's financial performance and growth," said Peter Conte, a Boeing spokesman.
That Boeing still faces large challenges was made evident yesterday, when the company announced that it was taking a $225 million charge in the third quarter after losing crucial campaigns to sell the F-15 jet fighter to Greece and Israel.
Earlier this year, Boeing announced a $45 million charge and layoffs of 7,000 workers in St. Louis after Greece chose the F-16 made by the Lockheed Martin Corporation over the F-15. The company said that the additional charge reflected money it had invested in parts for 24 fighters it hoped to sell to Israel, which also chose to buy the F-16 instead.
Boeing said in a statement that "there is a limited near-term market" for the F-15, though it hopes that the United States Air Force will order some this year, keeping the production line active for possible future sales.
The company also said that the latest charge and the new labor contract, which the company and the union said would make the machinists the best-paid workers in the aerospace industry, would not affect the existing estimates of future profits.
Analysts were uncertain whether the charge, which amounts to 17 cents a share, meant that they should lower their earnings estimates for this year, which average $2 a share, according to First Call.
"It could be that what Boeing is telling us is that somewhere else in the company there is another $225 million that we didn't tell you about," said Joseph F. Campbell, a managing director at Lehman Brothers.
Boeing has exceeded Wall Street expectations in each of the last two quarters. But those expectations are much diminished in the wake of production turmoil that began two years ago at Boeing's flagship passenger jet division. That has resulted in lackluster profits for the company at a time when demand for its jets has been at a record high.
Boeing plans to deliver a record 620 commercial airplanes this year but promises profit margins of just 5 percent on projected revenue of $58 billion. Some analysts and investors think that Philip M. Condit, Boeing's chairman, felt he had little choice but to give the machinists what they wanted because a strike would have disrupted the company's delicate financial recovery.
"This is a company that has come off a two-year disaster and doesn't want to upset Wall Street expectations," said Steve Binder, an aerospace analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York.
The new contract raises hourly wages for machinists nearly 16 percent over three years, to an average of $24.35 an hour. The contract also raises retirement benefits 25 percent and contains a one-time 10 percent bonus that amounts to an average of $4,400 a worker.
In addition, Boeing abandoned an attempt to introduce weekend shifts that would have reduced overtime payments, and it failed to get the union to agree to have its members help shoulder the cost of health insurance. The company also agreed not to lay off any workers as a result of a decision to contract out some work to other manufacturers.
Analysts and investors were not too concerned about the increased wages, a large portion of which will be passed on to Boeing's airline customers in the form of escalation clauses in their sales contracts. But they worried that by giving in to the union on the issue of weekend work and subcontracting, Mr. Condit had forsaken two important tools the company needed to increase its efficiency as he has promised to do.
"On the surface this pact seems to limit Boeing's ability to achieve large productivity gains," Mr. Binder said.
The union, on the other hand, had exactly the opposite concerns. While the leaders strongly endorsed the new contract, which Boeing submitted early on Saturday, they were disappointed that they did not get more firm job guarantees from the company.
An opposition faction within the union picked up on that theme and campaigned against ratification, complaining that the negotiators did not secure strong enough guarantees of job security and did not win cost-of-living increases for retirees.
But in the end, most union members thought that the offer was the best deal they were going to get without enduring a costly walkout.

HEADLINE: Data on Jobs And Factories Raise Fears Of Inflation

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
The nation's factories are humming and jobs appear to be plentiful, new Government data released today showed, adding to investor fears that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again.
Reports on manufacturing orders, jobless claims and productivity depicted the economy as growing at a solid clip but led some economists to warn of potential higher inflation. 
 Orders for factory-made goods rose by 2.1 percent in July, the fastest pace this year, the Commerce Department said. The Labor Department reported that new claims for unemployment benefits stayed below the key 300,000 level for the sixth consecutive week, signaling a strong job market.
Separately, though, the Labor Department said the growth of worker productivity, which is considered crucial to holding down inflation in a strong economy, slowed abruptly in the second quarter while labor costs shot up.
"The picture that is forming about the economy is that growth is going to remain strong and that we may have already seen the best news on inflation," said Mark Vitner, an economist at First Union Bank in Charlotte, N.C. "In that kind of environment, it is likely that interest rates are going to increase."
Although the manufacturing orders and productivity numbers were viewed as rather backward-looking reports with the third quarter already nearing completion, they contributed to sell-offs on Wall Street yesterday. Another important factor was a Fed official's interview with the wire service Market News Service Inc. The official, Edward W. Kelley Jr., a Fed governor, was quoted as saying it was premature to assume that the Fed would wait until next year to raise interest rates again.
The Commerce Department's report on factory orders was the latest in a string of reports indicating that the manufacturing sector is on the mend after taking a severe beating in the last couple of years because of export-related problems.
"Manufacturing has gone from being at the back end of economic growth toward the front end," said Stuart Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh.
The Labor Department's productivity report showed that output per worker hour outside the farm sector rose at a revised annual rate of just six-tenths of a percent in the April-June quarter. The department had previously estimated growth at 1.3 percent. The second quarter's rate was much weaker than the 3.6 percent productivity growth rate recorded in the first quarter.
Rising productivity can help keep inflation low by allowing businesses to increase their output of goods and services without having to incur higher labor costs.
Over the last few years, productivity has been strong, but the second quarter was an exception to that trend. As a consequence, unit-labor costs in that quarter rose 4.5 percent, the fastest increase in more than five years. In the first quarter, labor costs rose eight-tenths of a percent. Most economists expect productivity, which can be volatile from quarter to quarter, to bounce back.

HEADLINE: Labor Day Drivers to Pay More for Gas Than in '98

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
As Americans indulge in the last great driving binge of summer, they are paying an average of 22 cents a gallon more for gasoline than they were around Labor Day of 1998, the Department of Energy says.
The average retail price for regular unleaded gasoline was $1.23 cents a gallon as of Monday, compared with $1.01 on Aug. 31, 1998, the department's Energy Information Administration said on Wednesday. 
 Gasoline prices, which as recently as February were at an average of 90 to 92 cents a gallon, have risen 12 cents a gallon since June. The increases are being felt everywhere, although for a variety of reasons gasoline continues to be most expensive in the Far West and least expensive in the Southeast.
The American Automobile Association said that as of last week the average per-gallon price for unleaded gasoline in New Jersey was $1.17, compared with $1.32 in New York State and $1.37 in Connecticut.
In any event, the higher prices are not keeping people at home -- the Automobile Association expects nearly 35 million Americans to travel 100 or more miles this weekend -- but they have produced grumblings at the pump.
"They know that we have to use our cars, have to get to work," Daniella Gobert complained the other day as she gassed her 1985 Oldsmobile in San Francisco, where the price of regular unleaded has soared to more than $1.50 a gallon and the premium price is flirting with $2. "I don't believe we're getting gas for cheap, if that's what they're saying."
By "they," Ms. Gobert and legions of fellow complainers mean the big oil companies. And, yes, the oil industry says gasoline is still a bargain.
To Mike Libbey, a spokesman for Chevron U.S.A., the complaints reflect two misconceptions. "One is that gasoline prices are high," Mr. Libbey said, "and the other is that we control all that. If we controlled them, they'd stay up. But they go up, and they go down."
The Automobile Association said the average price for self-service regular unleaded gasoline has simply returned to its levels of August 1996 and August 1997. The Automobile Association gets its data from the Oil Price Information Service newsletter, whose figures, because of sampling methods and timing, were slightly different from the Energy Department's. The association said the average increase from a year ago was about 18 cents.
Discrepancies notwithstanding, the trend is unmistakable, and people who work in or follow the oil industry offered several reasons. For one, prices often rise before a summer holiday, when demand goes up. More important, the 11 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed on March 23 to cut the production of crude oil by 3 percent effective April 1. And the cartel persuaded Norway, Mexico, Oman and Russian, four oil exporters that do not belong to O.P.E.C., to go along.
The O.P.E.C. countries were reacting to an abundance of crude oil that had driven down prices. Last December, American refiners paid just under $10 a barrel for crude oil, the lowest price price since the Great Depression when adjusted for inflation, according to Ron Planting, an American Petroleum Institute expert on gasoline-price fluctuations.
By June, United States refiners were paying $16 a barrel. The effect was being passed along the fuel chain, to American drivers. Now, crude oil sells for about $20 a barrel.
There has been grumbling even in Georgia where, despite the price upsurge, self-service unleaded gasoline cost only $1.09 a gallon in late August, the lowest average price in the country. "I don't like it," said Gregg Richey, who was gassing up in Atlanta. "Gas is a major expense in Atlanta, where you're commuting long distances."
One reason why Georgia has low prices is its tax of only 7.5 cents a gallon, the lowest state levy in the country. New Jersey's state tax on gasoline is 14.5 cents a gallon, New York's is 29.8 cents and Connecticut's is 32 cents, the highest in the country. (The Federal tax is 18.4 cents.)
California's state gasoline tax is 18 cents a gallon, and there is an additional sales tax of 7 cents a gallon. Californians pay some of the highest prices anywhere: $1.55 a gallon for self-service regular unleaded, according to the Automobile Association. Only Oregon, which has a state tax of 24 cents and like New Jersey does not allow self-service, had a higher average per-gallon price in late August, $1.56.
California's strict air-quality rules, which demand cleaner-burning gasoline that costs more to refine, also keep prices high.
Thomas F. Hogarty, an adjunct professor of economics at Virginia Technical Institute who has studied the petroleum industry for many years, said Asia's renewed economic prosperity, and the greater oil consumption that goes with it, have pushed up crude oil prices. So have several recent refinery fires and pipeline accidents in the Far West, which curtailed supplies in the region and reduced the oil available to other areas.
The American Petroleum Institute and the oil companies insist that gasoline is inexpensive compared with the price of the many others things people need. The Consumer Price Index supports their argument.
According to the index, the cost of a wide range of goods and services used in everyday life rose by two-thirds from a base period of 1982-84 to July 1999. In other words, a shopping basket of goods that cost $100 about 15 years ago would have cost $166.70 in July. But the price of gasoline was only 1.9 percent higher in actual dollars than it was about 15 years ago. The same amount of gasoline that cost $10 then would have cost $10.19 in July 1999.
Professor Hogarty thinks prices will remain fairly stable and could even decline again, as they typically do after a big travel holiday. Historically, he said, O.P.E.C. has had trouble keeping discipline among its members, some of whom (Iran, Iraq, Kuwait) have warred upon one another. If individual members cheat and produce more oil, there could be another glut.
On the other hand, he said, another war in the Middle East could send prices skyrocketing, or perhaps something closer to home: "God forbid a huge hurricane should hit some refineries along the Gulf Coast."

HEADLINE: Retailers Report Strong August Sales, but Sears Spoils Mood

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
Attracted by trendy fashion items like inflatable dorm room furniture and embroidered blue jeans, back-to-school shoppers helped propel retailers to another strong month in August.
Sales in stores open at least a year, a crucial industry measurement, rose 5.1 percent in August, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index. While strong, the growth was a little slower than the torrid pace of the first half of this year. Analysts said the numbers indicated the beginning of a consumer slowdown, but nothing severe. "We have gone from a boom to what you might describe as the next notch down," said Richard Burner, chief United States economist with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "But the fundamentals are still very good." 
 George Strachan, vice president for retail investment research with Goldman, Sachs & Company, agreed with that view. "Right now, we are running among the best results in 20 years if you take out last year's exceptional numbers," he said. "The consumer is still very healthy."
Despite the overall good news, shares of most retailers ended the day down, largely driven by unexpected bad news from Sears, Roebuck & Company. The retailer reported August sales rose one-tenth of 1 percent, but also said yesterday that it was lowering earnings expectations for the third quarter to a range of 63 cents to 67 cents a share. Analysts had expected Sears to earn 82 cents a share, according to a survey by the First Call Corporation. Shares of Sears fell $3.6875, to a 52-week low of $33.50.
The company, based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., attributed the decline in earnings to softness in apparel sales and lower-than-expected margins because of heavy price- cutting. "We are selling a lot of merchandise, but not at full price," a spokeswoman for Sears, Peggy Palter, said. "Even new products were coming in and being promoted very quickly."
Analysts said the problems at Sears were not a reflection of a slowing economy, but a confirmation of the company's longstanding problems. The lowered estimate was announced in conjunction with a shake-up of top management.
Alan J. Lacy, who is president of Sears Credit, will also oversee the company's home services and E-commerce businesses. Julian C. Day, who has been chief financial officer since March, was named to the newly created position of executive vice president and chief operating officer responsible for finance as well as logistics and information technology. Mr. Lacy and Mr. Day will join Arthur C. Martinez, the Sears chairman and chief executive, in a newly formed office of the chief executive.
Also, Robert L. Mettler, the head of merchandising, resigned.
Several other department stores also fared poorly in August. The J. C. Penney Company reported that sales in stores open a year declined 3.2 percent, a slide that was greater than anticipated. Similarly, Mervyn's, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, had a slightly larger-than-expected decline in sales.
The discounters, which have done well throughout the yearlong shopping boom, seemed to get even stronger as the rest of the retail sector pulled back a bit. "The dichotomy just got exacerbated for August," said Jeff Feiner, a retail analyst with Lehman Brothers. "The consumer recognizes that in the price-value equation, value just got more important."
Wal-Mart Stores posted a substantial 8.7 percent gain, on top of a very strong 7.6 percent increase in sales in August 1998. At Target, the discount unit that accounts for more than 75 percent of Dayton Hudson sales, sales climbed 6.9 percent, propelling the parent company's sales up 4.9 percent.
Susan Eich, a Dayton Hudson spokeswoman, said the fashionable discounter had done particularly well in some home furnishings, like the Furry Cousin It Lamp, for the college-bound set, but that sales for younger children were still to come. "Ten years ago, a mom would do one big trip," Ms. Eich said. "Now a lot of parents are waiting until their kids are in school and seeing what other children are wearing."
Quick-and-easy fashion statements were also on the minds of consumers. Specialty chains did well this month.The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation was up 9 percent in August. American Eagle Outfitters Inc. rose 24 percent, on top of a 28.4 percent sales gain in August 1998.
In what is turning out to be the turnaround story of the year, Limited Inc., whose subsidiaries include Express, Lane Bryant and Lerner and which owns 80 percent of Intimate Brands, parent of Victoria's Secret, posted an impressive company-wide gain of 12 percent.
The real disappointment in the specialty store category came from Gap Inc. Although the company posted respectable sales growth of 8 percent, that number was powered by explosive returns at its Banana Republic and Old Navy divisions. Gap stores, which account for some 40 percent to 45 percent of the parent's revenue, actually had declines in sales of as much as 7 percent, while sales jumped by as much as 17 percent at Banana Republic and 19 percent at Old Navy.
"The weakness was in the Gap core business of basics," said Warren Hashagen, senior vice president for international finance. "The fashion business was stronger than expected, but we just did not have enough merchandise." He said Gap was working on "adjusting the assortment" for the rest of the season.
Shares of Gap have been down in recent months, but analysts are confident the chain will work through its problems and they have great faith in the track record of its chief executive, Millard S. Drexler. "I give management the benefit of the doubt because the Gap has been most adept at creating and re-creating brands," said Maura Hunter Byrne, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Jets Pare Uncertainties to Just One Spot

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Sept. 2

 BODY:
Measurably stronger than they were a year ago, the Jets go into their final preseason game against the Minnesota Vikings on Friday night ready to show off the offense and defense that will start the season against the New England Patriots on Sept. 12.
But there is an interesting difference between this Jets lineup and the one from last year's exhibition finale against the Chicago Bears. While the 1999 Jets seem to have everything in place on the starting unit, last year's backup quarterback was better. 
 Remember? It was Vinny Testaverde. Glenn Foley was the starter. On Friday night, Rick Mirer will get a long opportunity to impress Coach Bill Parcells, who is now looking for a backup to Testaverde. Mirer could play almost a full half in his competition against Ray Lucas.
Except for positions farther down the depth chart, though, and the vagaries of injury, the Jets have rarely been so strong as the exhibition season draws to a close.
Against the Bears a year ago, Parcells was still not sure about his rookie free safety, Kevin Williams. Indeed, Williams did not last as a starter, and three players manned the position. Now the former Pro Bowler Steve Atwater is there.
At left guard a year ago, Parcells had his weekly second-guessing about the journeyman Todd Burger. Every week, he virtually threatened Burger with unemployment. Even during the final week of preseason, Parcells shifted Burger to right guard. Finally, when the season came to a close, Burger was let go.
Now an inexperienced left tackle, Kerry Jenkins, is at left guard. He is, however, a significantly more athletic and bigger player.
There was yet another player Parcells was unclear about last summer: place-kicker John Hall. Parcells brought in Brett Conway to challenge him, but Hall won the job, and his place-kicking improved during the season. Last Saturday against the Giants, though, he missed an extra point, prompting Parcells to say that a kicker should go through an entire year without missing an extra point.
Still, the strong-footed Hall will remain, unless Parcells completely loses confidence in him.
Friday night's Meadowlands fans will, however, see a shift in defense compared with last year.
Then, Pepper Johnson was the middle linebacker, and James Farrior and Mo Lewis manned the outside spots in a three-man alignment. The recently arrived Bryan Cox was not yet ready to become a major member of the team. When he did, his presence helped persuade the Jets to switch to a four-linebacker alignment.
That is in place now. Cox is on the inside, where his relative lack of speed is not a handicap. And while Marvin Jones -- who did not play last year because of knee surgery -- may be out Friday night with a sprained ankle, he should be back for the opener. Farrior will share an outside spot with Roman Phifer while Lewis is back in the position where he earned a spot in the Pro Bowl.
All the first-stringers will play at least a half against the Vikings, the highest-scoring team in National Football League history last season. Will next week's difficult opening games affect the way players are used or the play-calling against Minnesota?
The Jets play a rare home opener against the Patriots, while the Vikings visit the team that upset them in the National Conference championship game, the Atlanta Falcons.
Parcells has said that the Jets have not unveiled much of the offense they will take into the regular season. And with Mirer performing in two dozen plays after being a Jet less than two weeks, it is unlikely there will be much variety from the backup quarterback.
Even during Lucas's 4-for-4 passing in a smart 14-play drive against the Giants, he was not called upon to display the wide range of the offense. So despite being in such good shape, the Jets remain with a loaded question: Everyone knows their offense is outstanding, but would it be that good with Mirer or Lucas running the show?
A year ago, it didn't seem to matter as much. Foley had had a good preseason and Testaverde was sharp as well.
 
EXTRA POINTS
Both teams' coaches yield nothing in preseason. BILL PARCELLS's 44-16 won-lost mark with the Giants, the Patriots and the Jets is believed to be the best exhibition mark of any coach with 10 years in the league. DENNIS GREEN's Vikings are 23-11 since he took over in 1992. Both teams are 2-1 this year. . . . Clubs will cut their rosters from 65 to 53 by Monday. Parcells is still wondering about injured players he has not seen enough of: wide receiver CHRIS BRAZZLE, linebacker CASEY DAILEY and F-back BLAKE SPENCE. Any veteran who is on the roster for the opening game has to be paid for the entire season if he is cut. Thus, the emotional tug-of-war between Coach Parcells and General Manager Parcells continues into the weekend and beyond.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Time to Hold All Umpires Accountable

BYLINE: By Jack Curry

 BODY:
The four men strolled onto the field at Yankee Stadium, three clad in red shirts and one wearing a blue shirt, looking as anonymous as beer vendors. They toiled for almost four hours, were in proper position, performed as if they cared and were consistent. Besides Paul O'Neill's routine outburst, no one complained about the umpires, which is what should happen every day.
It is unfortunate that 22 major league umpires stopped working yesterday because it is unfortunate whenever anyone loses his job. There are emotional stories from suddenly unemployed people about sick family members, mortgage payments and children's tuition, whether they are umpires who resigned, truck drivers who angered the boss, or waiters who were laid off because their restaurant failed. No one revels in anyone else's plight. 
 But there is a positive that could and should emerge from the silly labor strategy that resulted in one-third of the umpires being released. The umpires have been humbled. They learned in an emphatic manner that they are not the Ken Griffey Jr.'s of their profession. They can be replaced.
"There are a smattering of guys who have the attitude, 'You can't do that to me,' " Joe Torre admitted before yesterday's game. "I don't like that. Any time you think you're bigger than the game, you're not good for the game."
It would be worthwhile if baseball instituted an evaluation system in which umpires were judged and held accountable for their work, like almost every employee in America. Sandy Alderson, the executive vice president for baseball operations, wants all umpires to be monitored as one group by Major League Baseball next season.
There should be no more laziness on shots sprayed around the park, no more inconsistencies on the strike zone, no more baiting of players by moving toward them to invite confrontation, and no more Tony Gwynn-like physiques. If these changes are made, the umpires will enhance their reputations and the game. The game is what matters, on the field, where the Yankees pounded the Athletics, 9-3, yesterday.
"My goal long term has been for baseball to have a group of umpires who are well respected for training, expertise and integrity," Alderson said. "We want our umpires to be regarded as the best officials in the world. Right now, that's not the way they're perceived."
Perception often becomes reality. While it is unfair to characterize all umpires as inferior, all it takes is one umpire's incompetence for an entire crew to be branded. If one ump does not run into the outfield on a sinking liner inches off the grass, all four look sluggish.
"If you're not going to care about it, take it home," Andy Pettitte said flatly. "It's too bad it affected people's livelihoods. But if anything good comes out of this, maybe it'll be an evaluation system. All we're asking for is effort."
Richie Phillips, the embattled head of the umpires' union, has said that baseball does not care about the game because it accepted the resignations of umpires with more than 20 years of experience. That is an easy remark for a desperate man to utter, but it is untrue.
Alderson cares. He thinks umpires should be supervised more strictly, wants to include off-season training and educational seminars as part of their job, and feels the mandated rotation of umpires in the post-season should be replaced by selection on merit. If an umpire is ineffective, Alderson believes, baseball should be permitted to dismiss him, just as in other jobs.
Baseball is trying to develop a computerized simulator that would enable umpires to practice calling strikes the way they are defined in the rule book. That sounds more appealing than the current behavior of some umpires who, one baseball official said, work just a few games each spring at their own discretion and then jump behind the plate rusty in April.
"One of the things I hope we can change is the image of the umpire," John Hirschbeck, one of the umpires who led the anti-Phillips faction, said recently. "The fans need to know we care about getting calls right and hustling on every play."
One umpire told an American League player that umpires who spend 10 years in the minors are like players who do the same and are not talented enough to be promoted. That is highly questionable, because there was little turnover among major league umpires before these resignations. But the umpire insisted his view was accurate and said all of the best umps were already in the majors. So the player asked, "How would we know?" The umpire had no answer.
O'Neill said he felt sorry for the departing umpires, and Mark McGwire was cognizant enough of Frank Pulli's last game on Wednesday night that he flipped him a game ball. It is a difficult period for some, but it is also an important period for baseball to improve the umpiring situation forever and make the game better.
"My feeling is umpires should be held to the same scrutiny as the rest of us," Torre said. "Managers don't do their job, they get fired. Players don't do their job, they go to the minors. Umpires don't do their job, I don't know what happens. I'd like it to be the same. Everybody put in a day's work."

HEADLINE: Bank of New York Dismisses Second Employee in Laundering Case

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER

 BODY:
The Bank of New York said yesterday that it had dismissed a second employee involved in its investigation into possible money laundering at the bank.
The employee, Svetlana Kudryav tsev, was discharged for failing to cooperate with the bank's internal investigation into the suspected money laundering, a person close to the inquiry said. The bank refused to elaborate on the ouster. 
 Ms. Kudryavtsev joined the bank in 1994 and was an international bank associate in the Eastern European division in New York, a low level position akin to an administrative assistant, the person close to the investigation said. Ms. Kudryavtsev could not be reached for comment.
She was discharged six days after the bank ousted a vice president in the Eastern European division, Lucy Edwards. Ms. Edwards, who worked in London, was dismissed for "gross misconduct," said a person with direct knowledge of the dismissal, including the falsification of bank records, failure to cooperate with investigators and for never telling the bank that she was married to Peter Berlin.
Mr. Berlin had opened accounts at the bank in the name of a company called Benex. Federal investigators say at least $4.2 billion, and perhaps up to $10 billion, was channeled through Benex accounts at the bank over 18 months starting some time early last year.
Although little is known about Mr. Berlin, investigators say they believe that the money came from criminal activities, political graft and corporate embezzlement in Russia and that it was being laundered for figures in organized crime in Russia. Some of the money was also probably capital flight, Russian executives and American law-enforcement authorities said, secreted out of the country last year, when Russia faced a grave financial crisis and its banks and currency collapsed.
Press reports have speculated that some of the money may have been diverted from loans by the International Monetary Fund or from food-aid programs. But the I.M.F. and the United States Government said they had no hard evidence of that.
Mr. Berlin and his wife, who was born Lydmila Pritzker and emigrated to the United States from Russia more than 20 years ago, lived in the in the New York area until a few years ago, when the bank transferred Ms. Edwards to London.
Neither the bank nor any employees, including the two who were dismissed, have been charged with wrongdoing by legal authorities. According to Reuters, Ms. Edwards issued a statement yesterday through her lawyer in London in which she "strenuously denied" the allegations on which the bank based her ouster. The statement said that Ms. Edwards was "pursuing the remedies available against the bank, and we have notified the bank accordingly."
The statement did not say what the allegations were, and neither has the bank. A lawyer in New York for both Ms. Edwards and her husband, T. Barry Kingham, told Reuters, "Both Peter and Lucy firmly deny any wrongdoing."
Sorting out the exact sources of the money and the extent to which its movement violated any laws will take many months, perhaps years, American officials said. Layers of companies were used to disguise the origins and destinations of the money, and many of the companies were registered in places like the Isle of Man in the Irish Sea and Antigua, which have strict bank-secrecy laws and few disclosure requirements.
American law-enforcement officials said the only hope that they had of eventually getting to the bottom of the activity at the bank was with the full cooperation of the Russian Government.
Another senior bank officer whom investigators say they are looking at closely is Natasha Gurfinkel Kagalovsky, who was in charge of the Eastern European division in New York and worked closely with Ms. Edwards. The bank suspended Ms. Kagalovsky, with pay, after the allegations of money laundering became public on Aug. 19.
Ms. Kagalovsky and her husband, Konstantin Kagalovsky, a prominent Russian businessman, have denied wrongdoing. She and her husband own a condominium on East 47th Street in Manhattan. Contrary to earlier reports, the apartment has a mortgage, her husband, said last week in an interview in Moscow.
