HEADLINE: A Vast Fortune, Liberal Views, a Political Dream

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
From the moment he began thinking about running for the United States Senate from New Jersey, Jon S. Corzine, the former chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, has been attacked by his rivals as too rich to identify with workers, too suburban to care about the urban poor, too Wall Street to understand small-business owners on Main Street.
But in recent weeks, as his campaign for the Democratic nomination has started taking shape, Mr. Corzine has been vigorously promoting himself as a rich but humble guy who can appeal to the party's core constituencies: women, blacks and union workers. 
 Indeed, the positions Mr. Corzine has begun laying out would place him solidly in the liberal wing of his party, roughly the same ideological ground held by his main Democratic competitor, former Gov. Jim Florio, and the man he wants to replace, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who is retiring next year at the end of his third term.
In a lengthy interview last week, Mr. Corzine, of Summit, said he would make health care, education and gun control his priorities in the Senate, and he offered strong liberal prescriptions for each: universal health care; heavy Federal investment in public schools to increase teacher salaries and reduce class sizes, and requiring all gun owners to be licensed and all guns to be registered.
"If we can do it for cars, we should be able to do it with guns," he said.
Mr. Corzine (the last syllable rhymes with "pine"), who is estimated to be worth more than $300 million, said he opposes the Republican plan to cut taxes by $792 billion over 10 years, adding that he sees no reason to reduce either capital gains or estate taxes.
He also made clear that he supports two fundamental positions of the party's liberal wing, the unabridged right to an abortion and protecting affirmative action. He said he opposes the death penalty, though he considers tough mandatory sentences to be good policy.
And while the former investment banker said he would not support repealing the North American Free Trade Act, as labor unions have demanded, he staked out a strong pro-labor position on the minimum wage. Not only would he increase it now, but automatically raise it in the future whenever inflation rose by a certain amount.
"I don't think there should be a political debate every year over whether it should go up," he said.
It is, of course, essential for a political newcomer like Mr. Corzine, 52, who has never run for office before, to establish his credibility with the Democratic Party's core constituencies, who tend to be more liberal than voters in general.
But Mr. Corzine's efforts to stake out strong liberal positions now could pose problems for him if he wins the primary and goes on to face the likely Republican nominee, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. In a general election, he will have to appeal to more centrist and even conservative voters, many of whom may strongly object to his positions on tax cuts, abortion and gun control.
In the interview at his downtown Newark headquarters, Mr. Corzine paused at the description of him as liberal. "I don't look at myself that way," he said. "I call it progressive."
But he said that he has been spending much time meeting with Democratic officials and labor leaders, trying to assure them that he is not some haughty "Wall Street mogul" who is trying to buy the election. As his aides say, he is trying to show that he is more Gray Davis -- the plain vanilla Democrat who was elected governor of California last year -- than Al Checchi, a multimillionaire businessman who spent some $40 million of his own money in losing the same race.
"People expect somebody in pinstripes with an element of arrogance," he said. "I've tried to show I'm sincere about wanting this."
But Mr. Corzine has made clear that he will spend as much of his own fortune as necessary to be competitive. (He is a lukewarm supporter of the Democratic proposals for campaign finance reform, saying the real way to reduce the influence of money on politics is to give candidates free time on television to publicize their positions on issues.)
Already, he has retained several well-known, and high-priced, Democratic consultants, including Robert Shrum to handle the news media, and Doug Schoen to do his polling. He has rented an entire floor in a Newark office building, though he currently has only enough workers to fill a small part of it. And he has vowed to raise at least $100,000 to help the Democrats retake the State Assembly.
Still, with his low-key, soft-spoken manner, Mr. Corzine does not fit the stereotypes of either a rich banker or a slick politician, which may help him bond with individual voters in small group settings. But it is not clear whether his laid-back style will be effective on television or before large groups.
It is also not clear how well Mr. Corzine will handle the stress of running against a rough-and-tumble politician like Mr. Florio.
Reporters have already begun receiving anonymous letters accusing Mr. Corzine of dodging the draft, not voting in some elections and causing thousands of workers to be laid off by engineering mergers and acquisitions.
"I think the most important thing for me to try to do is distinguish myself by holding the high ground," Mr. Corzine said. "On the other hand, if people are trying to throw knock-out punches and hit below the waist, I am going to behave differently."
Mr. Corzine said he thinks Mr. Florio's supporters have already delivered some low blows, particularly by accusing him of joining the Marine Corps Reserve to avoid fighting in Vietnam.
Mr. Corzine said that he did not want to go through the draft because it would have forced him to leave his wife for two years, just after they had moved to Los Angeles, where he was attending graduate school. Joining the Reserve allowed him to live at home, though it also required a longer commitment of six years.
But Mr. Corzine said he objects to being branded a draft dodger because he signed up fully believing that he might be sent to war, and was prepared to fight if called.
"I don't know why anyone would join the Marine Corps to get out of anything," he said. "I was not a big fan of the Vietnam War. But it was never a question of whether I had a responsibility to serve. And that's what has been implied."
Asked how he would differentiate himself from Mr. Florio, Mr. Corzine said he would be a more collegial and less negative leader. "I believe in leadership with a positive vision of what I believe," he said.
Mrs. Whitman, he said, will be vulnerable on several issues, including high property taxes, high auto insurance rates and racial profiling by state troopers. Mr. Corzine has criticized both Mr. Florio and Mrs. Whitman for not doing more to stop that police practice.
He also questioned Mrs. Whitman's consistency. "I wonder how clear she is on some of the fundamental issues," he said. "I see a stepping back from the pro-choice movement. I see uncertainty with regards to how we handle gun violence."
Asked if he would make Mr. Florio's unpopular decision to raise taxes in 1990 an issue in the primary, Mr. Corzine said no. "I don't want to debate 1990 economic policy when the year 2000 economic policy is what matters," he said.
"In fact, my greatest fear is that a Whitman-Florio debate would be about history," he continued. "I don't think we need that. We need a debate about a rapidly changing society."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
$25 Million to Lure Technology Business

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

 BODY:
New York City will create a $25 million fund to invest in start-up technology companies as an incentive for them to come to the city, city officials said yesterday.
Telecommunications, biotechnology, Internet and software companies seeking first-round investments will be eligible for $100,000 to $1.5 million of financing, the city said. The investments will be structured as equity, debt or a combination of the two. 
 The administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani expects the fund to draw technology companies to New York, boosting the city's revenue and creating jobs for residents.
The city's Economic Development Corporation will review proposals and select the companies to receive financing. The investments will be approved by a seven-member board delegated by the Mayor and the City Council.

HEADLINE: Unsettling the Art World for a Living;
A Critic Resurrects Beauty as a Standard, and Finds It in Unexpected Places

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS

 BODY:
The physical boundaries of Dave Hickey's world are clear enough. He lives in a nondescript apartment complex improbably called Country Club Towers, wedged in a triangle made by the Las Vegas Country Club, the Las Vegas Convention Center and the World Trade Center Hotel and Casino, a low-rent gambling hall with a line of faux Grecian statues in the front. He has a sunshine-to-neon, skyline-to-mountain view of that singular slice of the American landscape, the Las Vegas Strip.
But the parameters of Mr. Hickey's intellectual universe seem limitless. His gentle, nicotine-laced drawl drifts effortlessly from Rembrandt to Norman Rockwell, from Jackson Pollock to "Perry Mason," from Willie Nelson to Andy Warhol and back around to Robert Mitchum. He's a writer who learned to make prose by listening to the "long, lapidary lines" of Chet Baker's jazz trumpet, and he's a former Nashville songwriter and musician who once copied out the first 50 pages of "The Great Gatsby" "just to see what it looked like to have good writing come out of your typewriter." 
 In his 59 years he has owned one art gallery and run another, been an editor at Art in America and The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, played in a band with Janis Joplin, dropped acid, snorted cocaine, swallowed speed and written short stories about dying old cowpunchers and mystic young gamblers. And now, as a tenured professor of art criticism and theory at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, he is a smiling eminence terrible of the art world, enrapturing admirers with his impassioned defense of beauty and beauty alone as an inherently valid way of judging art without the imprimatur of official authority -- and infuriating all manner of official authority for roughly the same reason.
"You can kind of divide the art world into those people who find that art's closest analogy is with literature and those who find its closest analogy is with music," said Mr. Hickey, a pink, portly figure in black sweater, pants and boots, emitting periodic pleural chuckles between the plumes of nonstop Marlboro Lights at his dining table one weekday morning. "And people like myself, who find it to have been with music, have been radically out of fashion for many years. You know, people are concerned with 'what it means.' I'm much more concerned with what it does." Or as he put it at another point: "I'm not interested in the intentions of artists; I'm interested in consequences."
"The cultural world is divided into those people who look at Raphael as if it's graffiti, and those who look at graffiti as if it's Raphael, and I prefer the latter," he said. "That is, if I address pop culture, I try to bring the full equipment of disciplined criticism. I'm willing to take it seriously." He added: "Having been around both worlds, I really never have found any moral distinctions. The distinction is the audiences they attract."
That attitude has not always won favor with his colleagues in the rarefied world of art academe, who have derided him as Satan and worse for questioning the received canonical wisdom of high art by veering happily into the cul-de-sacs of pop culture. But Mr. Hickey's iconoclasm and the sheer range of his polymath's perception have endeared him to legions of admirers, who have helped make his most recent book, "Air Guitar: Essays on Art and Democracy" (Art Issues Press, 1997), a phenomenal success for its genre, with more than 20,000 copies sold. "Dave is the smartest person I've ever known," said his friend Christopher Knight, the Los Angeles Times art critic. "I'll say that without qualification." Then why has he so incensed some peers? Mr. Hickey's critics variously disdain his insistence that pop culture and high culture equally deserve critical inquiry, take umbrage at what they see as his unfair attacks on the academic establishment and admittedly envy his graceful prose style. But perhaps the crux of the criticism is that by trumpeting beauty as a theoretically objective and spontaneous universal gauge of art, Mr. Hickey is a retrograde.
Like John Ruskin and other Victorians, he chooses to overlook the view that beauty may be merely what the ruling economic and social elites say it is. In the process, his adversaries argue, he substitutes his own bad-boy outsider judgments for those of narrow-minded art professionals.
Amelia Jones, an associate professor of art history at the University of California, Riverside, calls such hubris unforgivable. "With the revival of an abstract notion of beauty, we return not only to Ruskin," she said, "but also by implication to the imperialist and exclusionary logic of cultural value that gave Ruskin and his contemporaries their social authority as arbiters of taste." Ms. Jones, the author or editor of several books on 20th-century art, was writing in a recent issue of X-tra, a Los Angeles-based art journal.
Similar intellectual debates bubble in fields from law to philosophy, and as Mr. Knight said of the anti-Hickey voices, "if Dave's right, they're way wrong.
"There is a huge academic industry that is predicated on all kinds of things that Dave opposes and does not believe in, like the whole politically correct routine of the last 10 years," Mr. Knight added. "That is something that drives Dave crazy, and a lot of his writing has been about trying to pull the rug out from under those ideas of academic norms. As Dave says, art is about the specificity of experience, and governments are about establishing norms which exclude."
Mr. Hickey's latest heresy -- though one endorsed by a roster of other art heavies -- is his celebratory essay on Norman Rockwell in the catalogue for an exhibition of the artist's work organized by the Norman Rockwell Museum at Stockbridge in Massachusetts and the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. It opens at the High on Nov. 6 and is scheduled to wind up two years later at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan. In his optimistic essay, "The Kids Are All Right," Mr. Hickey parses Rockwell's "After the Prom," a highly formalized portrait of teen-agers on a date after World War II. In the canvas a smiling soda jerk sniffs the girl's gardenia corsage, and a grizzled Air Force veteran on the next stool casts a wry glance.
Mr. Hickey compares Rockwell's skills of composition to those of artists like Fragonard and David, and he discerns a spirit of tolerance and permissiveness in pictures more often seen as confining. He imagines, for instance, the prom couple grown up -- his chronological contemporaries -- "sitting around the campfire in some commune in New Mexico trying to recapture the golden glow of that night at the soda fountain."
"The interesting thing from a theoretical point of view about Rockwell is that in the history of artists' reputations, artists gain a kind of public vogue and then they're institutionalized, and the work goes into museums and it goes into books and the reputation survives there," Mr. Hickey said by way of explaining his own appreciation for "an exquisite maker of pictures."
"Now Rockwell never achieved that level of institutionalization, but for 30, 40 years after his prime, he still remains a creature in the public's imagination, you know, profoundly influential. The opening scene of every science-fiction movie in the world is a Rockwell scene. If you look at 'Independence Day' or anything like that, it's like, 'Here's Norman Rockwell and heeeere come the aliens!' Spielberg couldn't exist without Rockwell."
Mr. Hickey's own life has not been Rockwellian. He grew up bouncing between Texas and California, the son of a man who made his living setting up distribution warehouses for General Motors but loved to play jazz saxophone and clarinet. He committed suicide when his son was 11. His mother was a Marxist economics professor at Texas Christian University and "a part-time rapacious entrepreneur" who ran a family flower shop. Young Dave attended 13 grammar schools, left home early and entered Southern Methodist University in Dallas at age 15, majoring in engineering "principally because the engineering school was across the street from the Kappa Sig house and it was extremely convenient."
After earning an undergraduate degree in English from Texas Christian, he enrolled as a graduate student in linguistics at the University of Texas at Austin for much of the 1960's. "What I was doing was telling myself that I was a serious graduate student and what I was really doing was not being drafted," he says now. "The day that I turned 26 and was ineligible for the draft, I was totally amazed at the way my enthusiasm for an academic career seemed to dissolve." He and his first wife, Mary Jane Taylor, opened a gallery in Austin called A Clean Well-Lighted Place, representing young contemporary artists. He eventually he wound up in Manhattan, managing the Reese Palley Gallery in SoHo.
About a decade ago -- many late nights, freelance articles and a couple of relationships later -- he traded his vagabond life for health insurance as a faculty member at Nevada and marriage to Libby Lumpkin, an art scholar who recently stepped down as curator of Stephen A. Wynn's new collection at the Bellagio casino and hotel in Las Vegas. She is to join her husband on the university faculty next year. Mr. Hickey says he chose Las Vegas because he could eat at all hours of the night and he finds release in its lingering frontier air, describing it gleefully as "Dodge City built by Jews and Italians."
He is less thrilled with academic bureaucracy, acknowledging that he has been unable to fulfill his dream of having "some guy come up to me and say, 'Tony Two Fingers Tattaglia, dean of fine arts!' " Instead, he says, "Universities are universities."
It is clear that Mr. Hickey does not suffer fools, and for all his roguish charm in conversation, he leaves little doubt that he would be hard to live with.
"He's an incredibly interesting person to edit," said Gary Kornblau, his friend and editor at Art Issues. "I wouldn't call it easy." Mr. Hickey says his pet peeve is the "growing hegemony of the presumption that there needs to be consensus" in the world of high art.
"Being an art critic is one of the few professions in which one is actually paid for one's eccentricity, and paid to be disagreeable," he said. "In other words, if two art critics agree, there's no real reason for one of them to be there." He is galled by the idea "that there's a right-thinking world in art," adding, "I mean, most of us get into art to get out of that world."
He said: "I'm not a public servant. The presumption that you're a public servant and therefore you have certain obligations -- I mean, I'm an art critic, you know. I certainly strive to be elusive. And in a sense, the fact that you're doing this article means that my effectiveness is waning, simply because the curve has caught up with me."

HEADLINE: Labor Goes to Capitalism's Citadel, and the Sky Doesn't Fall

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
The head of a movement that has often been the nemesis of business -- the labor movement -- did an unlikely thing in an unlikely place yesterday. He rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange.
Why did John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., put aside thoughts of class struggle and enter the hallowed halls of capitalism? 
 "We like to do what's counterintuitive," said Denise Mitchell, the communications director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.. "We've been delivering a lot of messages to corporate America about improving wages, health care and pensions, and we've also delivered messages about ways that all of us can cooperate more. We thought we might as well be where they are, if we're going to get their attention."
Some traders joked that perhaps Mr. Sweeney ought to be invited back to ring the opening bell every day because the stock market had a big day yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average soaring 235.24 points, or 2.17 percent.
The idea to invite Mr. Sweeney came from Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, who has long believed in building bridges to many segments of the community. One reason he invited Mr. Sweeney, union and exchange officials said, was that the 600 runners, clerks and reporters of stock trades at the exchange are unionized. They are members of Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employees International Union, and not surprisingly, the union's president, Michael Goodwin, stood with Mr. Sweeney as he rang the bell.
They were enthusiastically applauded by the many union members working on the exchange floor. Afterward Mr. Sweeney and Mr. Goodwin toured the floor with Mr. Grasso, who was once a member of Local 153.
"I felt a little unusual being there," Mr. Goodwin said. "It's the first time in history that an American labor leader rang the opening bell. It's because Dick Grasso and the New York Stock Exchange have a new respect for the labor movement due to the movement's resurgence under John Sweeney."
But a stock exchange spokesman had a simpler explanation. "We did this in honor of Labor Day," the spokesman said, adding that Mr. Grasso was also mindful of the billions of dollars in pension funds controlled by labor unions.
One reason that stocks soared, however, did not exactly delight Mr. Sweeney: the Labor Department reported yesterday that job growth had slowed.
"That was the unfortunate part," said Mr. Goodwin, whose view of the news, as befits a labor leader, differed sharply from the interpretation prevailing on Wall Street. Many investors were heartened by the job slowdown on the theory that as a result, the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates again this year in an effort to slow the economy.

HEADLINE: Moving-Madness Holiday In Nation's College Capital

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Every year, right around now, Boston finds its capillaries badly clogged by the bright, orange-striped bulks of what residents believe must be the greatest convergence of U-Hauls in the country.
At least one rental truck, driven by a heedless student, inevitably smashes its top into one of the low-clearance underpasses that booby trap roads along the Charles River. 
 "When the first one hits, we say, 'They're back!' " said Gary Larivee, president of the U-Haul Company of Massachusetts.
And the long-suffering neighbors of the city's nearly 90,000 students -- who give Boston its youthful intellectual flavor and make up almost one-sixth of its population -- are reminded yet again of why it is not only a blessing but also sometimes a curse to live in the college capital of the country.
Sometimes, said Eva Webster, a neighborhood advocate in the South Brighton section of Boston, a pocket of particularly heavy student presence, "it feels like it's some kind of sci-fi movie where everyone over the age of 25 is dead."
Until Labor Day weekend is over, only foolhardy motorists venture into student-filled neighborhoods like Allston-Brighton, Kenmore Square and the Fenway, and the nearby cities of Cambridge and Somerville, or those who do not mind sitting patiently as sweating young people empty the back maws of Ryder and Penske and Budget trucks. The drivers must also be ready to skirt the curb-side mounds of crumbling sofas, dead plants, beer-stained carpets and folded cardboard boxes.
"It's really like a swarm of bees coming in," said James Cahill, director of the code-enforcement police, who watch for trash violations. "And they do their thing and all of a sudden it's over. It's just an amazing influx in such a short span of time."
The city tries hard to maintain control. It shifts virtually all of its garbage code-enforcers to student neighborhoods around now, and has been issuing $300 tickets right and left, perhaps 100 a day, to landlords who let their trash get out of hand.
Mayor Thomas M. Menino warned landlords this week about trash disposal, declaring: "Every year, we welcome back the students to the city of Boston. But I don't want their return to be a nightmare for the people who live in the neighborhoods."
Too late, some in the neighborhoods say. The Allston-Brighton area, where an estimated 15,000 students live in four square miles, gets to looking like "a hurricane scene, with none of the houses destroyed but with debris everywhere," said Paul Berkeley, president of the Allston Civic Association.
True, it will mostly pass in a week or so. But this time of the year, despite all the rosy appeal of the fresh, excited faces flooding town, also serves to highlight the problems that such a giant student population poses for a city, problems serious enough to merit a University-Community Relations Committee on the Boston City Council.
When the committee held a public meeting several months ago, said Brian Honan, its chairman, about 300 people came, compared with the usual 5 or 10 on other issues.
The total student population in Boston is estimated at 135,000, but some students do not live in the city itself; in the greater Boston area, students number approximately 250,000.
Boston proper has 32 colleges and universities, which generate an estimated $3.1 billion a year in spending. There are 33 more colleges in the suburbs.
"The students are really a double-edged sword in our neighborhood," Mr. Honan said of Allston-Brighton. "They shop and use the goods and services, so they provide an economic backbone with the tremendous buying power they have. But oftentimes their schedules do not necessarily jibe with those of people who have to get up at 6:30 in the morning to get to an office downtown."
The tension goes beyond schedules. The real estate market in Boston is blazing, and students' willingness to live like sardines and pool their rent money helps drive prices up. Their very numbers, too, increase demand and raise prices.
Then there is the problem of their transience: they have a reputation for being indifferent toward neighborhood esthetics and good relations, at least, compared with long-term residents, and their density can create garbage and parking problems. Transience also means less interest in pressuring City Hall for physical improvements.
"We have all the symptoms of extreme gentrification with nothing to show for it," said Ms. Webster, head of the Aberdeen and Reservoir Civic Association. "We are gentrified in terms of price, minus the usual quality of life."
As local institutions like Boston University and Boston College have grown over recent years, the city has been pressing them to build more housing for their undergraduate students. The results have been mixed. Boston University is completing a dormitory for more than 800 students; Harvard has just promised 288 new apartments for its graduate students, and other building plans are in the works. But universities tend to get more excited about adding new academic buildings than dormitories.
When they are asked to build housing, Mr. Honan said, "the typical response is that we're landlocked or don't have any more places to build buildings."
"But then we turn around," he said, "and they're building science buildings, academic buildings, new pools and gyms and stadiums."
City officials do say that the colleges' efforts to rein in bad student behavior off-campus have noticeably improved in recent years. Many issue instructions about everything from trash to late-night noise. The police, too, have learned the trick of arresting a few disorderly students at the start of the school year, and getting the message across, the officials say.
Of course, from the students' point of view, moving day is no picnic, either.
"Getting a U-Haul in this town was like the worst experience I've ever had," said Chris Lucca, a senior at Wentworth Institute of Technology. "You call to get one, and they tell you they're booked up two months in advance."
Other students reported that truck rental clerks simply laughed when they called this week.
Moving can get a bit, er, boisterous, too.
At times, Mr. Cahill of the code-enforcement police said, "you'll find things hanging in trees -- newspaper or clothing -- when they're cleaning out an apartment, but that's few and far between."
As for the apartment he was vacating the other day, Chip Baskerville, a Boston College student, said: "It's destroyed. There's like four different kinds of cereal on the floor."

HEADLINE: Judge Stanley Weigel, 93, Dies; Acted to Improve Prisons

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Stanley Alexander Weigel, a retired Federal judge who had ordered California to improve living conditions in prisons and, earlier in his career, had defended professors dismissed for refusing to take a loyalty oath, died on Wednesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 93.
Mr. Weigel was considered a tough judge with a short fuse, but he was also known for his independence and his courage to render decisions regardless of their popularity. 
 He began his career in 1928 in San Francisco, handling antitrust cases. But in 1949 he took on a civil liberties case that many other lawyers had shunned because of its political implications.
Thirty-one professors had been dismissed by the University of California for refusing to sign a loyalty pledge. Mr. Weigel sued the university on behalf of the professors and won their reinstatement with back pay in 1952 when the California Supreme Court declared that a loyalty oath violated the State Constitution.
About that time, Mr. Weigel became friends with Pierre Salinger, the journalist and confidant of the Kennedy family. After Senator John F. Kennedy was elected President in 1960, Mr. Salinger took Mr. Weigel to meet Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, who was screening candidates for judicial appointments.
Mr. Weigel, who had served on the national committee of the American Civil Liberties Union. was a registered Republican.
In 1962, President Kennedy appointed Mr. Weigel to the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.
One case over which Judge Weigel presided began in the early 1970's when inmates in the maximum-security units at the aging San Quentin and Folsom prisons sued, claiming that living conditions were inhumane. The case would continue until 1984 when Judge Weigel ordered the State of California to make improvements.
The judge was also known for his leniency in sentencing draft resisters during the Vietnam War. While other judges would often send those convicted of dodging the draft to prison, Judge Weigel would routinely sentence them to community service or probation.
Stanley Weigel was born in Helena, Mont. He graduated from Stanford University in 1926 and from Stanford Law School two years later. He practiced law for two years before becoming a partner in the firm of Landels, Weigel & Ripley, now Landels Ripley & Diamond, representing corporations in antitrust issues.
Mr. Weigel also served two years as a lieutenant in the Navy in World War II.
Another highly charged issue before Judge Weigel grew out of the eviction of tenants whose homes stood in the way of the Yerba Buena urban renewal project proposed by the San Francisco Redevelopment Agency.
In 1970, Judge Weigel blocked the replacement of the low-income apartments with hotels and tourist attractions.
He ruled that the developers had not done enough to find replacement housing for the displaced tenants, a decision that dismayed much of San Francisco's political and business community. In 1973, Judge Weigel worked out a settlement in which the tenants were provided new homes.
Judge Weigel reached senior status in 1982 but continued to hear cases until two years ago.
He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Anne Kauffman Weigel; a daughter, Susan Weigel Pasternak, of Cambridge, Mass., and four grandchildren.
In a 1995 interview with The Recorder, a legal newspaper in San Francisco, Judge Weigel related how the Salinger-Kennedy connection landed him in Robert Kennedy's office and on the bench.
"Robert Kennedy was wearing a turtleneck sweater and had a football and threw it at me as I walked in the door, and I caught it," he recalled. "That's how I became a Federal judge."

HEADLINE: Indifferent to a Planet in Pain

BYLINE: By Bill McKibben; Bill McKibben is the author of "The End of Nature," which will be reissued this month in an updated 10th-anniversary edition.

DATELINE: JOHNSBURG, N.Y.

 BODY:
As the hot sun sets on this long, odd summer, you might try staring into the nighttime sky. Several times in the last few months, observers in the lower 48 have seen "noctilucent clouds," which develop about 50 miles above the earth's surface -- clouds so high that they reflect the sun's rays long after nightfall.
They're spectacular -- and they're also out of place. These odd clouds belong in far northern and southern latitudes, but global warming seems to be driving them toward the Equator. The same carbon dioxide that warms the lower atmosphere cools the next layer -- the mesosphere -- causing the clouds to form. 
 Sightings as far south as Colorado are a big event, according to Gary Thomas, a professor at the University of Colorado's Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics. "While they are a beautiful phenomenon," Professor Thomas told National Geographic's on-line magazine, "these clouds may be a message from Mother Nature that we are upsetting the equilibrium of the atmosphere."
Ten years ago, global warming was a strong hypothesis. Now, after a decade of intensive research, scientists around the world have formed an ironclad consensus that we are heating the planet. Almost daily some new piece of evidence appears; the weekly editions of the journals Science and Nature make "The Blair Witch Project" look like "The Baby-Sitters Club." Forget the piddling drought and heat wave that withered lawns and fields across the Northeast this summer. Consider the real news:
Spring comes a week earlier across the Northern Hemisphere than it did just 30 years ago. Severe rainstorms have grown by almost 20 percent, precisely what you'd expect on a planet where warmer air can carry more water vapor. A Navy sonar survey conducted this summer shows that the Arctic ice sheet is in many places 40 inches thinner than its normal 10 feet. Warmer waters have bleached coral reefs around the globe. Glaciers are melting. Sea levels are rising.
The question is not what we should do. Though it's far too late to prevent global warming, it takes no special insight to deduce the policies that would slow it down. Stiff increases in the price of fossil fuels would quickly bring a new generation of renewable energy technologies to the fore. Raising fuel-economy standards for cars and trucks would end the trend to ever-bigger sport utility vehicles. And focused diplomacy and foreign aid could keep developing nations from sliding into our bad habits.
No, the question is why we've done so little. In 1992, President George Bush promised the world that the United States would emit no more carbon dioxide in 2000 than it had in 1990. The Clinton Administration instead watched with little apparent concern as our emissions surged more than 10 percent. Congress refuses even to consider the baby step represented by the 1997 Kyoto accords, which would return us to 1990 levels by 2010. The issue barely even crops up in the Presidential campaigns.
The reason, I think, is that we don't yet feel viscerally the wrongness of what we're doing -- not just the very rational fears about what it will be like to live in a superheated world but, even more, the simple shock that we've grown so large we can dominate everything. Earthquakes and volcanoes are the only "natural disasters" left. Everything that happens above the surface comes at least in part from us, from our appetites and our economies.
I used to wonder why my parents' generation had been so blind to the wrongness of segregation; they were people of good conscience, so why had inertia ruled for so long? Now I think I understand better. It took the emotional shock of seeing police dogs rip the flesh of protesters for white people to really understand the day-to-day corrosiveness of Jim Crow.
We need that same gut understanding of our environmental situation if we are to take the giant steps we must take soon. Go outside: try to understand that the sun beating down, the rain pouring down, the wind blowing by are all now human artifacts. We don't live on the planet we were born on. We live on a new, poorer, simpler planet, and we continue to impoverish it with every ounce of oil and pound of coal that we burn.
In retrospect it will be clear. A hundred years from now, people may well remember the 1990's not as the decade of the Internet's spread or the Dow's ascension but as the years when global temperatures began spiking upward -- as the years when rain and wind and ice and sea water began irrefutably to reflect the power and heedlessness of our species. But how bad it will get depends on how deeply and how quickly we can feel.
It depends on whether we're still capable of shock. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Ostrich That Roared;
Did Malaysia, Its Head in the Sand, Duck the Asian Crisis?

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 3

 BODY:
If you had not visited this city of dreamy minarets and dazzling skyscrapers before last week, you might wonder whether the Asian crisis ever happened.
On Tuesday, Malaysia's leaders dedicated the Petronas Twin Towers, a futuristic colossus that is the world's tallest building. As fireworks blazed and laser beams pierced the night skies, the Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, declared, "We need something to express our towering ambition." 
 Malaysia did suffer a humbling economic collapse, of course, as the half-empty towers attest. But with the country now showing signs of a robust recovery, Dr. Mahathir is exuding victory and vindication.
Unlike its neighbors, Malaysia chose to fend off the Asian typhoon by boarding up its windows. Drawing the wrath of the free-market West, it imposed sweeping controls on its capital markets -- suspending offshore trading in its currency and locking foreign capital in the country for a year.
Dr. Mahathir says the moves protected Malaysia from the predations of foreign currency traders. Without controls, he says, the traders would have caused wild swings in the currency, which could have decimated the economy and ignited social unrest in this multiracial society. Business people here initially balked, but most now rally around the Prime Minister.
"We did not implode as a society; there were no mass riots on the streets, as in Indonesia," said Francis Yeoh, an ethnic Chinese tycoon who is one of Malaysia's richest men. "It is not half-vindication, it is full vindication."
On Wednesday, Malaysia relaxed its rules on the repatriation of capital. Now, as foreign investors weigh whether to pour money back into Malaysia, Dr. Mahathir's policy is getting another hearing. Economists, fund managers, business people and even officials at the International Monetary Fund acknowledge that Dr. Mahathir appears to have won his risky gamble.
To be sure, most economists and policy makers still view capital controls with deep skepticism. They say that shutting off markets and freezing currencies can strangle investment and cause damaging distortions.
Hubert Neiss, director of Asia-Pacific operations at the I.M.F., said at a seminar in Tokyo this week that Malaysia's recovery had little to do with the controls. But he also said Malaysia should not be condemned for the move.
Other economists say Dr. Mahathir has proved that controls can be useful in dire situations.
"There was always a case for capital controls in principle during a crisis," said Paul Krugman, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who wrote an influential article defending controls in Fortune magazine on the eve of Malaysia's announcement.
"The argument was that they were impractical -- that they would inevitably screw up the real economy," he said. "What Malaysia has shown is that they are actually more workable than everyone claimed."
Certainly, Malaysia's performance has confounded skeptics, who predicted the controls would deplete reserves and stop the economy in its tracks. After contracting 6.7 percent last year, Malaysia's gross domestic product rose 4.1 percent in the second quarter. The country's reserves, far from diminishing, have shot up 60 percent, to $32 billion, since August 1998.
"If you do not like or trust statistics, just visit the shops and restaurants," said a defiant Dr. Mahathir in a speech here this week. "Only, give yourself a little extra time -- because I am afraid the traffic jams have come back."
The Prime Minister also noted that relatively little capital has flowed out of the country since the controls were relaxed -- defying those who had said that Malaysia would be hit by wholesale capital flight on Sept. 1.
Critics say, however, that his arguments have a few holes. Thailand and Korea are rebounding even more quickly than Malaysia, despite having left their markets open and allowing their currencies to fluctuate. And while billions of dollars of foreign capital have not stampeded out of the country, that is partly because most of it had fled before Malaysia imposed the controls.
So the question remains: Was Malaysia smart or lucky?
"They got lucky because they put the controls on just as pressure lifted off the other regional currencies," said David N. Devine, a director at Overlook, an investment fund based in Hong Kong.
If the currencies in Thailand, Korea and Indonesia had continued to fall after Malaysia had imposed its controls, Mr. Devine said, Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, would have been overvalued. Such a situation would have undercut the country's exports and created a black market in ringgit.
In fact, the opposite happened. Because the Thai baht and the Indonesian rupiah rose while the ringgit was fixed to the United States dollar at 3.8 to the dollar, Malaysia's currency became relatively cheap. That made Malaysia's exports -- led by computers and peripherals -- extremely competitive.
"The country's exports were plummeting until August 1998," said P. K. Basu, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in Singapore. "They stabilized in August and started roaring in September."
Critics said Malaysia had permanently alienated foreign funds -- the same people who bankrolled its economic development by pouring money into the country for much of the 1990's. And there are some investors who say they plan to steer clear of Malaysia, regardless of its newly relaxed rules.
"Essentially, you've got a Government that makes its own rules," said Henry Lee, the managing director of Hendale Asia, an investment fund in Hong Kong. "We've exited because we see a lot of problems there."
But an informal survey of regional money managers in Asia indicates that more people may think like Mr. Devine of Overlook. He said he would put money back in Malaysia, provided he could earn a decent return. "My view is that the investment community has a short memory," he said.
In any event, it is not clear that Malaysia even wants short-term capital to return. As part of its new rules, it instituted a tax on investment profits that heavily favors foreigners who leave their money in the country for at least a year. And Dr. Mahathir is hardly putting out the welcome mat.
"I know some foreign fund managers are pessimistic, but to me, it doesn't matter very much," he said after his speech.
Foreign companies with operations in Malaysia, like Intel and Dell Computer, have not been harmed by the controls. They were exempt from the bans on moving money in and out of the country. In fact, some executives say the ringgit's fixed-exchange rate made it a bit easier to do planning.
When Dr. Mahathir imposed the controls, he said they would give the country desperately needed breathing space to repair its economy. There was, and is, plenty to do: many of Malaysia's banks are insolvent. And its corporations are a catalogue of dubious business practices, prospering on their connections to politicians and plowing billions of dollars into reckless projects.
The state oil company, Petronas, spent $800 million to build the Petronas Twin Towers. Although they were completed in 1996, they are only now attracting tenants. Petronas is also the lead investor in Putrajaya, Malaysia's new capital city. A pet project of Dr. Mahathir, the city is being built from scratch for $5.2 billion in a palm plantation south of Kuala Lumpur.
While Malaysia has made a few strides -- whittling down the number of bad loans in its banks to a creditable 12.8 percent of the total loan portfolio -- analysts here said Dr. Mahathir's record as a reformer is paltry.
"He has abused this window of opportunity to save his cronies, rather than undertaking the reforms that are necessary," said K. S. Jomo, a political economist at the University of Malaya.
Professor Jomo is particularly critical of a recently announced plan to consolidate Malaysia's 21 commercial banks, 25 finance companies and 12 merchant banks into 6 large banking groups. The mergers favor bankers allied with Daim Zainuddin, the powerful Finance Minister, while punishing those friendly with the ousted Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim.
Malaysia's economic policy has been accompanied by Draconian political moves from the beginning. Dr. Mahathir dismissed Mr. Anwar, his heir apparent, the day after he announced the controls. Mr. Anwar, who had opposed the measures, was subsequently sentenced to six years in jail on corruption charges that his defenders say were trumped up. He is now standing trial on a charge of sodomy, which he denies.
Dr. Mahathir's heavy-handed treatment of his former protege unleashed a storm of protest in this normally placid country. While the street protests were not deadly as in Indonesia, they gave birth to the most serious opposition movement the Prime Minister has faced in his 18 years in power.
The protests also echoed abroad. In a report issued this week, Amnesty International, the human rights group, said, "Step by step, the Malaysian Government has undermined constitutional protection, weakened key institutions and put in place an array of restrictive laws that stifle public debate and dissent."
Dr. Mahathir responded by asking why Amnesty International did not investigate the behavior of currency traders. Such sarcasm is typical of the 73-year-old Prime Minister, who seems to delight in thumbing his nose at the global political and financial establishment.
In his speech, Dr. Mahathir reserved his most acerbic lines for the International Monetary Fund. He said the fund had worsened the crisis in Thailand, Korea and Indonesia by insisting on high interest rates and deep cuts in government spending. By shunning the I.M.F., he said Malaysia had avoided impoverishing its people and handing over its corporate crown jewels to foreigners.
"We have been able to achieve what others have achieved," Dr. Mahathir said, "without having to sell our family silver and precious heirlooms; without having to auction off our precious corporations to foreigners at fire-sale prices; and without having to bend or bow to anyone."
For all of Dr. Mahathir's claims, he has not swayed his neighbors. Thailand, Korea and Indonesia have left their markets open. Few Asian leaders even seem in the mood to debate the issue. The Institute of Strategic and International Studies, a research group here, had hoped to draw officials from the region to a symposium this week on capital controls. Most declined the invitation.
If Dr. Mahathir was trying to be the pied piper of the emerging markets, however, it was scarcely evident in his remarks.
"We were and are fortunate that no one has followed or said they intend to follow Malaysia's example," he declared. "A heretic can be tolerated. But a heresy cannot."

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate in August Again Dipped to a 29-Year Low;
Labor Market Was Tight but Wages Barely Rose

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Despite the Federal Reserve's recent attempts to cool the American economy, the temperature is still pretty hot.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that the nation's jobless rate in August dipped once again, to 4.2 percent, the 29-year low first reached in March. 
 Employers added 124,000 workers to their payrolls on top of the 338,000 added in July. And a host of other measures -- from hours worked to the fraction of Americans who hold jobs -- showed that the labor market continued to boom.
"The labor market is tight and getting tighter," said Paul Kasriel, chief United States economist at Northern Trust in Chicago.
Economists at the Labor Department cautioned that both August and July payroll numbers were distorted because many factories and businesses that normally close in July to retool and allow workers to go on vacation did not do so this year. Since seasonal adjustment did not capture that departure from past patterns, hiring looked stronger in July and weaker in August than was actually the case.
"If you look at July and August together," said Tom Nardone, chief of labor statistics, "everything looks like it did earlier in the year."
Wall Street, which had been bracing for signs that the economy was even hotter, took comfort in the facts that the August payroll increase was not as large as expected and even more in the absence of any sign that wages were taking off.
Hourly pay rose a mere 2 cents in August, to $13.30. Pay had jumped 10 cents between May and July, frightening investors and helping prompt the Fed to raise rates twice this summer. But it is now just 3.5 percent higher than a year ago, an increase comfortably within the range of the last few years.
"This substantially alleviates concerns about another Fed tightening," said Ed McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "We thought we were seeing an acceleration in wages, but now it appears that maybe we're not."
Investors celebrated with stock and bond rallies. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 2.17 percent, and the Nasdaq composite index had its largest one-day point gain ever, 108.87 points, or 3.98 percent. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds fell from 6.13 to 6.03.
Employers have been expanding payrolls faster in the last two months than in the first half of the year, by 231,000 a month compared with 210,000 a month. That suggests that the economy has picked up steam since the spring when growth slowed to a mere 1.8 percent annual rate as a sharp widening of the trade deficit trimmed the nation's production of goods and services. A raft of recent reports, meanwhile, point to robust demand for everything from houses and cars to factory orders to exports.
"Nobody in his right mind would lower their G.D.P. estimate on the basis of today's jobs report," said Mr. McKelvey, who estimates that the economy is growing at more than a 3.5 percent rate this summer. "If anything, you could argue that you should raise it."
That leaves the Fed more or less in the same bind it has been in all year; namely, having to justify rate increases at a time when, despite rapid growth and a tight labor market, there is little evidence that inflation is breaking out -- especially at the consumer level.
Most of last month's hiring, as usual, took place in the services area, which already employs the bulk of America's work force. Service companies added 219,000 new jobs, only slightly fewer than the monthly average for the last year. Nearly 50,000 of those jobs sprouted in business services, many in computer and data processing. Hiring was strong at brokerage firms, doctors' offices, hospitals, law firms and all sorts of entertainment businesses, from movie theaters to amusement parks. But despite help-wanted signs in many stores, retailers hardly added to their head count. Retailers had added 99,000 workers to their payrolls in July. And while auto dealers and furniture stores kept on hiring, fast-food chains and other restaurants reduced the number of workers.
In the otherwise robust job market, there were some glaring weak spots. Despite numerous signs -- from rising materials prices to stronger orders and higher production -- that manufacturing was on the mend as economies in Asia and Europe recover and exports pick up, factory employment shrank by a sharp 63,000, more than reversing July's gain of 51,000. But Katherine Abraham, Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, cautioned against reading too much into the August drop. "The pace of manufacturing job losses has been much slower over the past two months than during the first half of the year," she said. Makers of cars, furniture, primary metals and electrical equipment all expanded payrolls.
Another soft spot was construction, which shed 29,000 jobs in August. Essentially, the number of construction jobs is no higher than at the start of the summer. Last summer, by contrast, 70,000 construction workers were added to payrolls. It is not clear, though, whether higher interest rates are crimping the demand for new houses, office buildings and roads. Hiring was exceptionally strong all winter and spring and shortages of both skilled workers and construction materials may be the problem.
The labor market continues to pull in workers who have historically suffered from high unemployment rates. Unemployment among blacks, Hispanics, women and workers with high school educations or less are all at or near historic lows. The Labor Department's broadest measure of unemployment, which includes not just those who are job hunting but also those who have stopped looking, has fallen sharply from a year ago. And employment growth is outpacing labor force growth by a wider margin than last year.
"The reserves are dwindling," Mr. Kasriel said. "We're calling them up. That's good for people who are working and want to work. But we're running out of workers."
There is every reason to expect the labor market to stay tight. Businesses say they anticipate adding to their head counts. "Hiring plans are strong for the fall," said Terry Hueneke, executive vice president at Manpower Inc., one of the nation's biggest employment services companies and the sponsor of a quarterly hiring survey. "It appears to be fairly well across the board."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS -- Jobless Rate in August Again Dipped to a 29-Year Low;
Markets Rally, Reflecting Hope on Interest Rates

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Financial markets made a volatile about-face yesterday, as stocks and bonds rallied on the news that the economy generated fewer new jobs than expected last month.
The news that only 124,000 new nonfarm jobs were created in August, well below the 215,000 Wall Street had forecast, allowed many investors to think that the Federal Reserve might not have to raise interest rates again this year in an effort to slow down the economy. 
 The central bank has already raised its target twice by a quarter of a percentage point. The second move, on Aug. 24, helped push long-term interest rates back over 6 percent, as investors suddenly began to worry that more Fed rate increases were in the offing because the economy was not slowing down enough.
But with such broad uncertainty about the outlook for the economy and inflation, it is impossible to say that this new mood will not change just as quickly again, especially if other economic data for August are stronger. Since Federal Reserve officials indicated in May that they were going to raise their short-term interest rate target, the Dow Jones industrial average has gone through five distinct selloffs and rallies and may now be entering its sixth.
"Is this another in the series of relief rallies after some ugly days over the summer, or is there some new fundamental news in the jobs report?" asked Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities. "I think it is a relief rally," he said.
The stock market followed the bond market higher yesterday. And the rally in both markets helped lift the dollar, which has been sliding recently, against the euro and the Japanese yen.
In below-average trading volume of 663 million shares, the Dow Jones industrial average surged 235.24 points, or 2.17 percent, to 11,078.45. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks climbed 38.13 points, or 2.89 percent, to 1,357.24. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 108.87 points, or 3.98 percent, to 2,843.11. It was the largest one-day point gain for the Nasdaq ever.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond leapt immediately after the release of the jobs report at 8:30 A.M and finished a pre-holiday half-day of trading up 1 17/32, to 101 17/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.01 percent, down from 6.13 percent Thursday.
The yield on the 30-year bond has crossed the 6 percent level more than a dozen times since June.
The price of the two-year note, which is more sensitive to Fed interest rate moves, rose 6/32, and the yield dropped to 5.62 percent, from 5.72 percent.
The dollar, which was helped by the rush of foreign investors back into the bond and stock markets, rose to 110.05 against the Japanese yen, from 109.11 Thursday. The euro, the 11-country European currency, fell against the dollar. It finished at $1.0612, down from $1.0686.
Financial stocks, helped by the sharp decline in interest rates, and the shares of computer companies led the stock market higher, with J. P.Morgan up 7 7/8, to 133 13/16; American Express rising 6 1/8, to 142; Microsoft increasing 4 1/16, to 95 7/8, and Intel jumping 4, to 89 5/16.
While the fear of higher interest rates is making investors wary about the outlook for the stock market, the improved prospects for corporate earnings are keeping the major indexes near the top of their recent trading ranges.
The resilience of the market is exhibited in the fact that the Dow Jones industrial average is now just 247 points below its recrd high, while the Nasdaq index, with yesterday's surge, is just 21 points from matching its record, which was set on July 16.
Although the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter would fall below expectations, it appears that growth in earnings for all companies in the last two quarters of the year will be quite strong. Coke's stock dropped 2 1/8 on the news, to 57 3/8.
A key reason for the strong corporate earnings is that the growth comparisons are to the last two quarters of 1998, when the global financial turmoil set off by the devaluation of the Russian ruble devastated the profits of many companies, including banks and brokerage houses. According to First Call/Thomson Financial, operating earnings of the 500 companies in the Standard & Poor's index are expected to rise 21.2 percent in the third quarter, which ends Sept. 30, and 21.3 percent in the fourth quarter.
One reason yesterday's investor relief might not last is that the August jobs figures, according to some analysts, are not as weak as they look. Job growth was lower than expected, but combined with the 338,000 new jobs created in July, the pace for growth is still strong. For the year the average is just under 230,000 a month, barely below the average of 249,000 a month for all of last year.
While there are economists who think the economy is showing signs of slowing, Richard Berner, the chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, says he thinks it is growing at a 4 percent pace in the third quarter, up from the 1.8 percent growth in the second.
If this is the case, the economy has probably not slowed enough from the 5 percent pace for the six months through March to satisfy the Federal Reserve.
"I continue to think the economy is very strong and inflation pressures are rising," Mr. Berner said.
But he acknowledged that some of his competitors think that the economy is slowing down. "There is a real vigorous debate going on about the growth and inflation outlook," he said. The August jobs data, he said, "will fuel the slowdown school" and "will give the Fed some breathing room and the market some breathing room." Fed policy makers are scheduled to hold their next meeting on Oct. 5.
One big question is whether this uncertainty about the outlook for the economy might keep the stock market contained in its current trading range in the near future even though the major indexes are so near their highs. Since the Dow breeched 11,000 on May 3, it has set five new highs. But reaching the latest record, 11,326.04 on Aug. 25, only added 2.8 percent to the Dow.

HEADLINE: Just How Uniform Must Uniforms Be?;
For Many Public School Students, It's a Struggle to Mesh The New Dress Codes With Their Own Sense of Style

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
Chanel Gilpin stood unsmiling as her mother cooed how cute she looked in her new school uniform: a blue, pleated jumper with a short-sleeved yellow shirt.
Chanel, who is in the fifth grade, was not upset about the jumper, which basically resembled a barrel with straps, but about the yellow shirt. She wanted to wear white. But only boys at Public School 9 in Brooklyn are allowed to wear white, her mother, Cynthia Malcolm, explained the other day while shopping at Cookie's, a children's clothing store in downtown Brooklyn that specializes in school uniforms. 
 "I agree with uniforms," said Mrs. Malcolm, a 42-year-old native of Jamaica who grew up wearing school uniforms. "Kids talk about name brands, but not everyone can afford them."
So while many New York City schoolchildren hunted for trendy cargo pants, wide-cuffed jeans and long skirts to wear when school reopens on Thursday, scores of students like Chanel looked through racks of button-down shirts, khakis and jumpers.
Under a Board of Education policy passed in March 1998, students at public elementary schools are required to wear uniforms beginning this fall unless their schools have chosen to opt out of the policy. Each school has broad discretion to create a uniform tailored to its own tastes. Parents at participating schools can submit a written request for an individual exemption for their child.
While students who fail to meet the uniform requirements cannot be suspended or sent home, they may be supplied with a reprimand or a loaner. To induce students to conform, some schools will provide banners and certificates for classes that have 100 percent compliance for a week, or offer pizza parties for those that comply for a month, said Philip Russo, a spokesman for the board.
So far, 163 of the city's 672 elementary schools have agreed to participate, said Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the board. But additional schools may join before Nov. 1, the deadline to notify board officials, she said. Schools that opt out of the program generally do so because of strong parental resistance.
William C. Thompson Jr., president of the board, who spearheaded the dress code effort, said he expected more than half of the city's elementary schools to have a uniform policy in place this school year. Last year, more than 300 schools participated in the program voluntarily, he said.
"I think it's safe to say that about 70 percent of the schools will participate," he said. "Our strong anecdotal experience is even where youngsters were at first resistant, they come to like them a great deal after they become required."
For parents like Chanel's mother, the new policy translates into savings. Mrs. Malcolm, an unemployed mother of three, hopes to get a job working in a school cafeteria this fall. She said she was pleased to get a break on the cost of clothes: uniform prices range from about $40 to about $100 for a complete outfit, according to a report by the city's Consumer Affairs Department that was released last week. Students are allowed to buy their clothes from any store as long as they fit their school's guidelines.
For other parents, the dress code saves them the headache of monitoring what their children are wearing to school. The mother of 8-year-old Sheena Fray prefers skirts, but Sheena's 16-year-old sister, Tracy, found a way to skirt that issue. While their mother sat at home, they picked out a pair of "skorts," a combination of a short skirt and shorts, and a cardigan. Tracy was prepared to take the heat.
"I don't think she will mind," Tracy said, admiring the outfit. "I know what it's like to wear a uniform, and I want Sheena to be comfortable."
Sheena, who lives in Canarsie and is a student at P.S. 244 in Flatbush, stood next to her sister looking pleased.
But in a city that defies uniformity, there are bound to be protesters. Robert Jackson, a longtime member of Community School Board 6 in Washington Heights, said that his 12-year-old daughter, Sumaya, would not participate in P.S. 187's uniform policy because students should be free of dress code restrictions.
"I'm not in favor of them, but if the wishes of the parents are that they want their kids to wear uniforms, then that's fine," he said. "If you look at the reasons for uniforms -- school pride, discipline, order and to avoid competition -- we don't have those same issues and concerns."
Sumaya, a self-described fashion plate who loves platforms, T-shirts and bell-bottoms, is grateful for the reprieve. As a student entering the eighth grade, she wants to be free to express herself.
"Everyone's different in their own way," she said. "Some people don't like looking the same as others. They like to look differently, so they wear other things."
Mr. Thompson, of course, disagrees with the Jacksons. He pushed the uniform proposal after visiting an increasing number of city schools that allowed uniforms but did not require them. Administrators cited the reports from schools across the country with dress codes: attendance was up, disciplinary problems were down and students seemed more attuned to their studies.
Educators in Long Beach, Calif., the first district in the country to adopt a mandatory policy, in 1994, say they are convinced that uniforms have had a positive influence on their 70,000 students, though no independent research confirms a link between uniforms and academic achievement.
"School uniforms bespeak authority," Carl A. Cohn, the Superintendent of the Long Beach Unified School System for eight years, said last week. "This is a system where the adults are still in charge. If you listen to anecdotal information from teachers, youngsters come to school more focused on the business of learning. That has to be a healthy sign."
Daniel J. Lipsman, 54, a retired high school and college teacher who lives in Washington Heights, filed a lawsuit last year to prevent his 11-year-old daughter, Angela, a student at P.S. 187, from even having to opt out of the policy. But the suit, filed in the Federal District Court in Manhattan claiming a violation of civil rights, was dismissed. Mr. Lipsman has filed an appeal.
Angela, in a telephone interview last week, argued that case: "Everyone is entitled to their rights, including kids. I don't think children should have to wear uniforms. If they want to wear them, fine. I don't think they should be forced to against their will. I will not wear one."
New York City, following the lead of cities like Long Beach, essentially hoped to avoid civil liberties challenges by giving parents the opportunity to opt out of the uniform policy. Just hours before the board voted, it took the "mandatory" out of the uniform policy.
"He lost the case right off the bat; he had no standing," Mr. Thompson said of Mr. Lipsman's suit. "The judge's comments were relatively strong as he talked about the benefits, even as he saw it, of a uniform policy."
The new dress code has prompted some stores around the city to devote a corner of their space to uniforms, as others stock up on dress code mainstays like white shirts and jumpers. But where the battle lines between parents and their children were once drawn over items like skin-tight jeans or extra-short skirts, they are now drawn over cotton-blend shirts with Peter Pan collars -- not exactly the first choice of a 9-year-old.
At the same time, uniform styles are not quite as staid as in the past. Cookies at the Fulton Mall, kente cloth jumpers were hung next to A-line skirts and skorts. Downstairs, in the boy's department, gray and black slacks hung neatly from racks.
Carolyn Bevans, the mother of three sons who attend P.S. 161 in Crown Heights, had her hands full the other day as they loped through the store while she looked for school emblems to sew on uniforms she bought the week before. Dorian, 9, Andre, 8, and Jordan, 6, said they were excited about the prospect of wearing uniforms of blue pants and yellow shirts.
"I like uniforms," said Dorian, who is entering the fifth grade. "They save my mother money."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Once Again, Coca-Cola Predicts Lower Earnings
Shares of Coca-Cola fell $2.125, to $57.375, after the soft-drink company confirmed Wall Street's fears that near-term profits will suffer, as improving unit volume remains a challenge for the rest of this year. Citing the lingering impact of halted sales in parts of Europe this summer, as well as sluggishness in other markets, Coke said unit case volume in the third quarter would increase only at a low single-digit rate. Analysts figure the increase to be about 2 percent, which is down slightly from the 3 percent to 4 percent they had originally estimated.
As a result, the company lowered earnings expectations by 3 cents to 5 cents a share. Including the product recall in Europe, which will account for 2 cents to 3 cents against earnings, third-quarter profits may be as low as 31 cents a share, in contrast to the 36 cents analysts had been expecting. Page C14. 

Court Victory for Tobacco Industry
The tobacco industry won a victory when a Florida appeals court ruled that damage claims in a class-action lawsuit must be considered one smoker at a time, removing the threat of a single huge verdict. A10.
 
Orwellian Visions of Microsoft
The discovery at a Canadian software company of a component in Microsoft's Windows operating system named NSAKey, set off a firestorm of messages on the Internet. Some took it as a key to let the National Security Agency spy on computer users. Microsoft insisted there were no "Big Brother" features in its software. A8.
 
Thailand to Sell Bank to British
Thai authorities plan to sell the troubled Nakornthon Bank to the Standard Chartered Bank of Britain. C2.
 
Chile Lifts Controls on the Peso
Chile's central bank lifted controls on the peso for the first time in 15 years. Although Chile is one of Latin America's healthiest economies, the peso fell to a record low of 522.30 to the dollar before a slight rebound. C2.
 
Union Narrows Choice for Auto Talks
Officials of the United Automobile Workers union have narrowed their lead company bargaining choices to General Motors and DaimlerChrysler. The current three-year contract expires at midnight on Sept. 14. The agreement covers 350,000 U.A.W. members at G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler. C14.
 
A.F.L.-C.I.O. Head Starts Trading
John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. It was the first time in history that an American labor leader rang the opening bell, and was intended to signal a new respect for the labor movement due to the movement's resurgence under Mr. Sweeney. It was also to honor Labor Day, and occurred on the day the Labor Department reported that the nation's jobless rate for August declined to 4.2 percent, the 29-year low first reached in March. C3.
 
Space Shuttle Fleet Grounded
The nation's space shuttle fleet has been grounded and will remain so through the end of October because of numerous cases of wiring damage, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said. One shuttle, Columbia, is being taken off flight status for a previously scheduled, 10-month, $80 million overhaul at a Boeing plant in Palmdale, Calif., and will have full wiring inspections done there. A7.
 
Phelps Dodge Starts Tender Offer
Phelps Dodge began its tender offers in its $2.5 billion takeover quest for rival copper producers Asarco and Cyprus Amax Minerals. C4.
 
U.S. Markets Closed Monday
Financial markets and banks are closed Monday in observance of Labor Day. Most financial markets in other countries are open.
