HEADLINE: State Election a Test for Germany's Governing Left

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: SAARBRUCKEN, Germany, Sept. 1

 BODY:
This gritty town is the home of Oskar Lafontaine, Germany's former Finance Minister, and of a slogan he coined that has proved less ephemeral than his brief tenure in the Government: "The heart beats on the left, and it's not yet listed on the stock exchange."
Mr. Lafontaine has gone, from Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's Government and from German politics. But in this coal and steel producing area with a strong labor union tradition, the conviction that Social Democracy must stand for solidarity, for workers' rights, for the downtrodden and for a comprehensive welfare state lives on. 
 So strongly, in fact, that the small Saarland region, which holds a critical state election on Sunday, has become an unlikely focus of the identity crisis of Mr. Schroder's 136-year-old Social Democratic Party and of the ideological battles of the European left as a whole.
Broadly, the left in Europe has been casting around for a new identity that draws a distinction between a "market economy," now generally endorsed, and a "market society," an expression widely used to denote an unacceptable European surrender to what is perceived as American capitalist excess.
But how business-friendly the left should be remains in dispute.
"America has a different culture, with less solidarity, and we do not want such social Darwinism in Germany," said Reinhard Klimmt, Mr. Lafontaine's Social Democratic successor as Governor of the region. "My heart, like my predecessor's, beats on the left, but I am afraid that Mr. Schroder's beats everywhere."
The Chancellor's policies have certainly veered this way and that since he took office almost a year ago. But lately he has appeared determined to steer the Social Democrats away from their proud roots in the German labor movement toward the entrepreneurial enthusiasms of Britain's New Labor.
In the last month, Mr. Schroder rejected calls for a wealth tax, clamped down on social security, said the state's 49 percent share of the economy must be slashed and proclaimed that the 40-year-old program defining Social Democracy's aims must be rewritten.
"For the new politics to succeed, it must promote a go-ahead mentality and a new entrepreneurial spirit at all levels of society," Mr. Schroder wrote recently in a paper on the so-called third way of a revamped left that he co-signed with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain.
It is to that sort of language, with its whiff of a business consultant's jargon and its remoteness from the factory floor, that Mr. Klimmt, 57, has objected. He has focused his campaign on the themes of social justice still dear to the French Socialist Party and praises old ideals of Social Democracy.
"People talk of high tech," Mr. Klimmt declared to a meeting of union leaders this week. "Well, there is high tech in coal and steel production, too. What is forgotten today is that behind all the computers there are people, and we are here to defend the rights of those people."
The applause was enthusiastic. But Mr. Klimmt is in a fierce struggle for his political life, running neck and neck with a Christian Democratic candidate, Peter Muller, 43, who has declared roundly that the Saarland coal industry, which employs about 11,000 people, must be closed.
"We have to confront the truth," said Udo Recktenwald, Mr. Muller's spokesman. "The German coal industry is uncompetitive and will die. What we should be worrying about is insuring that the children of these miners have jobs in telecommunications and service industries."
The Social Democrats won comfortably here in 1994, taking 49.4 percent of the vote to the Christian Democrats' 38.5. Mr. Klimtt's difficulties reflect several factors: the poor start of Mr. Schroder's Government, anger at Mr. Lafontaine for abandoning politics and the frustrations of a region that is uncertain of its economic future.
In many ways the Saarland is a microcosm of Germany's economic problems. It has deep-rooted coal and steel industries in which employment has already fallen to a combined total of about 20,000 from 120,000 a decade ago. There is an unemployment rate of 17 percent in the city of Saarbrucken, and there are nascent software and technology industries whose outlook could not be further removed from the hulking factories of old.
But of course, it was precisely the workers in the old heavy industries who long provided a bedrock of the Social Democratic Party. How the party can modernize while not alienating that core support remains its central dilemma -- to which Mr. Schroder and Mr. Klimmt offer sharply differing answers.
"I don't like Schroder's slogan of 'the new middle,' " Mr. Klimmt said. "I like innovation with social justice. Of course, we must encourage new businesses. But we must also raise wages in line with productivity, maintain pensions and not cut the budget too hard. It's fine to say, 'Let the best man win,' but we must also help the loser."
The specter of people stripped of their dignity by an uncontrolled global market seems to lie close to the heart of Saarland Social Democracy. But in fact, the Saarland has adapted considerably in the last decade, rapidly developing a car and auto-parts industry to replace some of the jobs lost in steel and coal. At the same time, a highly successful software company called IDS Scheer, which employs more than 800 people, has led a push into high-tech industries.
Drive westward out of Saarbrucken and the difficulty of this transformation -- still far from complete and uncertain of success -- becomes clear. The rusted pipes and brick chimneys of abandoned steelworks and mines seem to stand in massive rebuke to the brisk, silent activity of the offices at the Saarbrucken Innovation and Technology Center.
Here, IDS has its headquarters. "Germany's problem is that we are too deep in the old industries and not good enough in finance, computers, services," said August-Wilhelm Scheer, the company's chief executive and a member of the so-called future team of Mr. Muller, the Christian Democratic candidate. "Here, we have great technology thousands of meters beneath the earth mining an outdated product."
The coal industry is destined to consume more than $2 billion in subsidies by 2005. But Mr. Klimmt insists it has a future, saying contracts already signed with power plants will cover all production until 2010.
The real issue, of course, is far wider than coal. It is the pace of change, the place of traditional industries and the viability of the social-market model of consensus and mediation with unions that served Germany so well for most of the period since World War II. The Saarland election will hinge on those questions.
They are issues on which Mr. Schroder and Mr. Klimmt differ. Where the Saarland candidate sees the death of old socialist values, the Chancellor sees the possible birth of a more deregulated Germany that alone will create the jobs that must be found if Mr. Schroder is to stand a chance of re-election.
Despite their differences, the Chancellor has given guarded support to his party's candidate because the loss of the state would severely weaken the party in the upper house of Parliament. But if Mr. Klimmt wins, the tensions within the party may worsen.
"We are desperately stretched as a party, and our identity is unclear," said Hajo Hoffmann, the Social Democratic Mayor of Saarbrucken.
"A basic problem," he said, "is that Tony Blair has managed to combine new technology with emotion and so make it seem exciting, while we have not found a personality big enough to bind the modernizing center and the old guard beneath a single reformist banner."

HEADLINE: Financial Engineering in the Clinton House Deal

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
The package that the cash-strapped First Family will use to buy a $1.7 million house in Chappaqua, N.Y., is a clever and unusual piece of financial engineering designed to avoid tax and other pitfalls, real estate and financial specialists said today.
The deal calls for Terry McAuliffe, President Clinton's chief political fund-raiser, to personally supply $1.35 million in collateral that the lender, Bankers Trust Private Banking, could seize should the Clintons fail to make payments on a house costing more than three times what a Presidential salary could support. 
 Some private analysts said they were struck by what a good deal it appeared to be for the Clintons -- even though the bank itself, with whom three Clinton Administration aides or friends have had ties, seemed to have not been particularly generous.
For one thing, Bankers Trust, which was acquired in June by Deutsche Bank, would not want to have to explain to examiners an ostensibly uneconomic loan to a couple with negative net worth because of $5.5 million in legal debts, a sum that far exceeds their assets of about $1.5 million.
Nor would it be content to use only the house itself for collateral because of the public black eye it would certainly suffer in the unlikely, but imaginable, event it should ever have to foreclose. Banks and most other lenders generally find foreclosure a terrible hassle that they try to avoid whenever possible.
"They never make a loan they intend on collecting by selling the collateral after they've foreclosed," said James F. Smith, chief economist of the National Association of Realtors.
And although some people initially raised their eyebrows at the seemingly low interest rate, which was calculated at 6.52 percent, they agreed that while this would have been a concession for a conventional 30-year mortgage, it was about the going rate for the first phase of a five-year loan adjustable every six months. But the Clinton loan is a jumbo loan, an extra large one that normally carries a rate that is one-eighth to one-half point higher.
In providing additional details today, the White House said that Mr. McAuliffe's $1.35 million in collateral would consist of cash, rather than what some had presumed would be Treasury securities. Mr. McAuliffe's money would go into an account at Bankers Trust, and he rather than the Clintons would receive the interest.
The Clintons are to supply $350,000 for the down payment, drawn from their blind trust, an amount just above the 20 percent of purchase-price minimum that excuses the couple from paying many hundreds of dollars a month in mortgage insurance to protect the lender. The Clintons will be making their own monthly payments.
By putting up cash rather than making a guarantee or by co-signing, Mr. McAuliffe avoids either party's having to bare their financial souls. "There's the ability to remain discreet," said Melissa Cohn, president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company. "It saves them from any disclosure."
The White House also called the mortgage an existing bank product, not something invented for them. Many major banks have special units, like Bankers Trust Private Banking, that cater to the carriage trade and often accommodate situations like that of the Clintons.
Although political opponents may contend that something of economic value -- the use of Mr. McAuliffe's cash collateral -- is being conferred on the Clintons, tax specialists said they doubted that this would result in taxable income even if the McAuliffe collateral were taken to pay off the mortgage. But this might well be considered a gift, which would raise the issue of improper payment to a Federal official.
The contingent nature of the money's deployment also exempts it from Government disclosure rules, the White House said, declaring that the Office of Government Ethics agreed with its position.
It could not be immediately learned whether any of the President's onetime aides or Vernon E. Jordan Jr., a close friend, helped in setting up the transaction.
Mr. Jordan is a former director of Bankers Trust. The current vice chairman, Eugene Ludwig, served as Comptroller of the Currency. And Frank N. Newman, who was Deputy Treasury Secretary, became chief executive of Bankers Trust after leaving Washington. Mr. Newman, who oversaw the sale of the bank, retired with a $100 million severance package.
At least one group came forward today to denounce the deal.
"He's the President of the United States and someone is doing a million-dollar favor to him to help him with his personal financial needs," said Fred Wertheimer, president of Democracy 21, a policy body seeking to overhaul the campaign finance system. "That creates an appearance problem, a potential conflict problem, and it's a dangerous kind of act."

HEADLINE: ISRAEL AND P.L.O., WITH HELP OF U.S., REACH AN ACCORD

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Israel and the Palestinians, prodded by the presence of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, reached a crucial agreement tonight that envisions finalizing the borders between them and resolving the future of Jerusalem in one year.
Ms. Albright announced the agreement in Gaza City at the offices of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, who stood at her side. The accord also calls for the completion of a land-for-security agreement signed last fall in Wye, Md., which had been stalled until the coming to office of the new Israeli Prime Minister, Ehud Barak. 
 The central element of the new agreement is a plan to negotiate a conceptual "framework" for a permanent settlement between Israel and the Palestinians by Feb. 15, 2000, and the conclusion of detailed talks by next September.
The agreement called on both sides to refrain from taking unilateral action, which is understood to mean that the Palestinians will not declare statehood before a peace accord is reached and that Israel will not build new settlements in the West Bank or Gaza Strip. Mr. Arafat repeatedly declared in the last year that if no agreement was reached by May 2000 -- the date on which the original Oslo agreements were to conclude with a final settlement -- he would declare a Palestinian state then.
Today's agreement did not explicitly describe what sort of Palestinian entity would be established at the end of the process, leaving that to the negotiations.
On the land-for-security aspects of the Wye agreement, the Israelis agreed to cede control over 11 percent of the West Bank in three stages -- in September, November and January -- one American official said. Israel has already withdrawn from 27 percent of the West Bank.
The last major hurdle in the negotiations was the number of Palestinian prisoners to be released from Israeli jails. In the end, Mr. Arafat abandoned his demand for 400, and accepted Israel's offer to release 350, a senior Israeli official said. Israel resisted releasing Palestinians "with blood on their hands."
After an intensive display of Middle East brinkmanship in the last several days, the agreement tonight came after the American envoy for the Middle East, Dennis Ross, spent the day with the Israelis working on the language of the deal, and after the document was taken to Mr. Arafat by Ms. Albright.
In Washington, President Clinton hailed the agreement, saying, "It shows that when both sides are willing to work together, their fundamental requirements can be met, confidence can be built and the process can move forward."
A signing ceremony was scheduled for Saturday night, after the end of the Jewish Sabbath, for Ms. Albright, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and the Palestinian and Israeli leaders at the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheik on the Sinai coast.
Speaking in a stifling hot reception room at Mr. Arafat's headquarters in Gaza City, with her back to a huge painting of the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem, Ms. Albright praised both sides for working to reach a forward-looking agreement.
The arrival of the Secretary of State, who spent three and a half hours with Mr. Barak in the early morning, gave the two sides a deadline to work against, and her presence prodded them to overcome the last obstacles.
Ms. Albright stressed that she was not a mediator, perhaps not even a facilitator. "Maybe I was just the handmaiden," she said.
The announcement tonight gives Ms. Albright a boost as she travels to Syria on Saturday to meet with the Syrian leader, Hafez al-Assad, in an effort to persuade him to restart negotiations with the Israelis that broke off three years ago.
Mr. Barak has expressed eagerness to settle with Syria, but Mr. Assad's apparent initial enthusiasm when the Israeli Prime Minister first took office appears to have waned. With a successful Israeli-Palestinian negotiation in hand, Ms. Albright will be hoping that Mr. Assad does not want to be left in the cold.
The central conflict in negotiating the modifications to the Wye accords has been the competing longer-term aim of Mr. Barak and the shorter-term goal of Mr. Arafat.
For Mr. Arafat, getting the transfer of West Bank land from Israeli to Palestinian control has been an essential short-term goal. It was pledged in the Wye agreement but was stalled by the former Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. Mr. Arafat can show his people that with the new land and prisoner release, some progress has been made with the Israelis.
For Mr. Barak, the relinquishing of 11 percent more of the West Bank was not as enticing as getting the start of a process that will determine the permanent relationship between Israel and Palestinians and help shape an overall peace agreement that covers Syria and Lebanon.
The start of "final status" talks means dealing with the biggest problems of all: the status of Jerusalem, the return of refugees and the permanent boundaries of Israel in regard to the Palestinians.
A key element of the accord completed tonight is the Feb. 15 target date for a framework -- something like a declaration of principles -- for the final-status agreement. The details of the framework would be completed by September.
Mr. Arafat had been reluctant to set the February date, fearing that if such a framework was agreed upon early in the new year, Mr. Barak would feel free to turn his attention away from the Palestinian relationship and look instead toward negotiating with Syria.
Another sticking point, apparently one of the last, was Mr. Arafat's desire to be able to take such unilateral action as threatening to declare a state. He used this threat as leverage earlier this year: By pledging to delay the declaration of a Palestinian state last May, he won a promise from President Clinton that he would call a summit meeting of Middle East leaders within a year.
Without being specific, a member of Mr. Arafat's cabinet, Nabil Shaath, the minister of planning, said tonight that the Americans had been helpful to the Palestinians on this matter in "letters of assurance."
Israeli officials indicated tonight that the redeployment of Israeli troops would begin within 10 days. Two further redeployments would take place on Nov. 15 and Jan. 20, they said.
These moves would leave 40 percent of the West Bank under full or partial Palestinian control.
The release of 200 Palestinian prisoners would also take place within the next 10 days with another 150 released in early October, they said.
A member of the Israeli Prime Minister's office, Haim Ramon, said today that the dispute on how many Palestinian prisoners would be released was settled on Thursday when the Israelis told Ms. Albright that they would not agree to the Palestinian demands for 400 released prisoners instead of the 350 offered by Israel.
"We said we would release 200 in September and 150 in October and in the future will consider more," Mr. Ramon said. If the Palestinians did not accept the offer, the Israelis had threatened to release only 102 prisoners, the number the Israelis said was required under the original Wye accords.
The question of the number of prisoners had become highly charged because the Israelis said they would not release Palestinians charged with killing Israelis.
After the signing of the agreement on Saturday, work is set to start on opening safe-passage routes across Israel that will allow Palestinians to travel between the West Bank and Gaza, a move intended to enhance economic development in both places. As well, construction of a seaport in Gaza, which was called for in the Wye agreement but not begun, will also start.
The talks for the framework agreement on the final-status issues are to begin at once, American officials said.
The February date for reaching a framework is ambitious, officials said. But by focusing on an early date, an American official said it was hoped to focus both sides on the final outcome of how Israel and the Palestinian lands would be shaped. Israeli officials said the framework would also serve to defuse the threat of a unilateral Palestinian declaration of statehood.
The agreement to work toward final status within a definitive time frame changes the focus from incremental deals -- which is the essential nature of the Wye accords -- to what is expected to be the final round of negotiations that will end the conflict between the Palestinians and Israelis.
"We began the incremental road in 1993, but everyone has been positioning for the endgame," said David Makovsky, executive editor of The Jerusalem Post. "Six years later, it looks like we're finally there."

Preparations to begin in the next few weeks to open a seaport in Gaza and a safe- passage route between Gaza and the West Bank. (pg. A1)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Umpires Ponder a Future With and Without Work

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The umpiring crew that worked the game between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Cubs at Wrigley Field in Chicago yesterday was a shell of its former self. Jerry Meals was the lone remnant. Larry Poncino and Gary Darling were no longer working, a result of the umpires' mass resignation movement, and Steve Rippley was in Florida deciding whether he would end his career, too.
"I announced my retirement yesterday," Rippley said. "They haven't taken it yet. They're giving me time to think about it." 
 Rippley, a 17-year National League veteran, said he was contemplating retirement because he was disheartened over the loss of 22 of his colleagues, concerned about the ramifications of that action for him and fearful that the economic package available to him if he retires now will not exist four months from now.
His state of mind was not an unexpected aftermath of the National and American Leagues' termination of 22 umpires, who resigned as part of their union's bargaining strategy and then, to their surprise, had their resignations accepted. The umpires who support the union leader Richie Phillips, Rippley among them, are angry with Major League Baseball and the umpires who abandoned the resignation strategy, blaming them for their colleagues' unemployment -- even though the 22 lost their jobs because of the strategy designed by Phillips.
"Why am I retiring?" the 45-year-old Rippley said, repeating a question. "In support of the 22 guys who got fired. I can also see down the road that my workload will be overloaded because there's no one left to work. They're not going to let the new guys they hired work post-season play, or a lot of important games in the next month. Who's going to get overloaded? The senior guys."
Rippley, chief of his crew, said he also expected umpires to be "on the street" as of Jan. 1. Their contract expires the day before, and the umpires believe they will be locked out.
"I know what I have in my hand right now if I retire; I don't know what's in the bush," he said by telephone from South Florida. "Come Jan. 1, I don't know if I'll have a paycheck; I don't know what my benefits will be. Everything becomes a jump ball Jan. 1. I could be on the streets. I may be one of the guys who's not hired back."
Rippley, whose salary under the umpires' pay scale is $155,000, would receive at least $300,000 in severance if he walked away from the job now or after the season. If he stayed and worked the post-season, he would earn additional money.
Rippley denied that he receives money from Pilot Air Freight, a Philadelphia shipping company that Phillips operates. Other umpires included him on a list of seven umpires that they said were on Pilot's payroll. Terry Tata, an N.L. umpire who has lost his job, was also named, and he, too, denied being on the payroll.
Rippley and Tata accused umpires from the anti-Phillips faction of disseminating false information. "The people who are spreading it can't prove it and they shouldn't be saying it," Rippley said. "Their rumor is because we sit on the union board they're slipping us this money, paying us $20,000, so we keep Richie as our lawyer. There are some people who have done p.r. work, speaking engagements and such, for Pilot. There's some compensation for that."
The schism between the two factions, divided mostly along league lines, is only growing deeper. "I don't see how the two groups can fit back together again," Rippley said. "We have to get back together, but I can't even fathom what's going to happen if we're in the same room."
Although some baseball people had suggested that some of the 22 umpires could be rehired next season, if crews were expanded from four to five, an official said last night that the idea of five-man crews has been abandoned. Another official said it was possible that two or three of the 22 umpires could be rehired.
Meanwhile, Rippley planned to spend the weekend deciding whether to head for Milwaukee and his next scheduled assignment Tuesday or into early retirement.

HEADLINE: The World Before Starbucks

BYLINE: By Betty Fussell; Betty Fussell is the author of "The Story of Corn" and the forthcoming "My Kitchen Wars."

 BODY:

UNCOMMON GROUNDS
 The History of Coffee
 and How It Transformed Our World.
 By Mark Pendergrast.
 Illustrated. 520 pp. New York:
 Basic Books. $27.50. 
 Caffeine is the most widely taken psychoactive drug on earth, and coffee is its foremost delivery system. That got my attention, along with the fact that the United States is Caffeine Country -- 90 percent of us imbibe caffeine in one drink or another -- but not until I read all 520 pages of Mark Pendergrast's encyclopedic coffee epic did I realize how powerful the coffee image has been even beyond its caffeine component.
In the 1930's, while 98 percent of American families were coffee drinkers -- including 15 percent of children between 6 and 16 years of age and 4 percent of children under 6 -- my family swigged only Postum and Sanka. We believed C. W. Post's warnings that caffeine disintegrated brain tissue by attacking the pneumogastric nerve. At the same time we were completely addicted to "Amos 'n' Andy," Major Bowes, the "Maxwell House Show Boat," Edgar Bergen and Charlie McCarthy; all our favorite radio stars were sponsored by Big Coffee.
As I romanced to "Let's have another cup of coffee, and let's have another piece of pie," behind my every dream was an advertiser, pushing. "Every businessman wants a product that is habit-forming," wrote the Maxwell House adman Bill Benton, of Benton & Bowles. "That's why cigarettes, Coca-Cola and coffee do so well." And that's why the history of advertising can be equated with any of these habit-formers and why the history of coffee is a natural follow-up for the author who earlier wrote "For God, Country and Coca-Cola."
However, coffee is an even better model than Coke of the way in which social, economic and political forces interact globally whenever addiction is aroused, whether for tobacco, sugar, diamonds, gold, pepper, petroleum, cocaine or caffeine. No surprise there, but what is surprising is how early coffee was commodified in the Americas and how much the violent history of Latin America is still tied to the lure of the coffee bean.
Once the bean migrated from its native Abyssinia (Ethiopia) into Yemen, probably in the sixth century A.D., the coffee habit conquered Arab traders, Ottoman emperors, the courts of Europe and finally the colonists of the Americas. Europe's habit was sustained on the backs of New World slaves, both native and imported. Early in the 19th century, coffee supplanted sugar on the vast plantations of Brazil. Even after Brazil revoked slavery in 1888, it relied on indentured peonage. Coffee was grown wherever labor was cheap -- in Central America, Africa and the Dutch East Indies. Where the bean was planted, so too were the seeds of revolt.
The boom-and-bust cycles endemic to this commodity were established as early as 1823, when European speculators, gambling that war between France and Spain would close overseas trade, bought up Brazilian beans and went bankrupt when war was avoided. "The modern era had commenced," Pendergrast writes. Henceforth coffee's price would swing wildly as a result of speculation, politics, weather and the hazards of war.
Coffee, in other words, is an organic commodity subject to drought and disease, to over- and underproduction and to hoarding and dumping through coffee syndicates, speculators, commodity brokers and government-supported quota systems and price supports. Because the picked green bean, long before it is brewed, must be heavily processed (depulped, fermented, roasted and ground), growers, harvesters, roasters and marketers all have their hands in the till. Coffee, as one grower complained a century ago, "is the most speculative business in the world."
Pioneers of the United States coffee industry saw that the way to make money was to do their own roasting, invent packaging to keep roasted grounds fresh, use cheaper beans as needed, buy up competitors ruthlessly and advertise endlessly. Happily, Pendergrast puts a human face on the shenanigans of the coffee barons, detailing a remarkable cast of American eccentrics in the wars between the big roasters of the last century -- Folger's, Hills Brothers, MJB, Maxwell House, Chase & Sanborn, A.& P. -- and the giant corporations of this one. An ironist as well as a moralist, Pendergrast notes the interlocking of delivery systems after Philip Morris moved into the coffee business by buying General Foods and after Coca-Cola merged with Duncan Foods.
From such Byzantine intertwining no coffee purist or anti-caffeinist is safe. But quality begins with the bean. Robusta, the commodity bean of Brazil, is hardy but rough on the palate. Arabica, the finest bean, is far more delicate in flavor but harder to grow in the mountainous regions of Jamaica, Hawaii, Costa Rica and Kenya. Naturally, Arabica costs more.
The coffee industry produced its own backlash when a new generation ignored cost for other values, like social justice, ecology and -- of all things -- taste. Earlier heroes like William Black, who founded his own brand, Chock Full o' Nuts, in New York in the 1950's, and Alfred Peet, who dark-roasted his own quality beans at Peet's Coffee and Tea in Berkeley, Calif., in the 60's, were followed by the trio of college boys in Seattle in the 70's who started Starbucks. True to market patterns, after the founders sold the company in the 80's to their former marketer, the specialty brand went national and then international, Starbucking all of America and now moving into Japan.
Today we Americans drink less coffee than we did in the 30's, but we are drinking and brewing it better. We no longer boil grounds campfire style or percolate them genteel style in the pot. And we have a taster's dream choice of beans, roasts, grinds and brewing equipment. Even our lingo has changed -- from "Gimme a cuppa joe" to "Give me an iced short schizo skinny hazelnut cappuccino with wings." (Translation: a small iced hazelnut coffee with one shot of regular and one of decaf, plus skim milk with foam, to go.)
With wit and humor, Pendergrast has served up a rich blend of anecdote, character study, market analysis and social history. And while the reader sometimes needs a caffeine jolt when too much raw data and too little structuring clog the brew, still everything you ought to know about coffee is here: even how to make it. Measure two tablespoons of freshly roasted and ground coffee per six ounces of not-quite-boiled water and steep four to five minutes.

HEADLINE: Gang of One

BYLINE: By Lisa See; Lisa See is the author of "Flower Net" and the forthcoming novel "The Interior."

 BODY:

THE PEKING LETTER
 A Novel of the Chinese Civil War.
 By Seymour Topping.
 300 pp. New York:
 A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/Public Affairs. $25. 
 ON the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the establishment of the People's Republic of China, Seymour Topping has written "The Peking Letter," a novel that weaves together the intrigue of China's civil war with discussions of ancient Taoist philosophy and personal integrity. Topping, a former managing editor of The New York Times, comes to this material in the best way: He covered the war for The Associated Press. He has firsthand knowledge not just of the big battles and the ideological conflicts but of the small and telling details that other writers would never find in the course of traditional research.
The book opens as Eric Jensen, a Taoist scholar, is kicked out of his living quarters in Peking (Topping uses Wade-Giles romanization in keeping with the era of the story) for having sex with one of the residents. He soon falls in love with Lilian, a Chinese medical student and revolutionary, who engages him in conversation about his love of the city, his political views and his loyalty. Jensen has all the right answers and is soon enlisted to carry a letter, which outlines a Communist plan for the surrender of Peking, to the American ambassador in Nanking. (In an author's note, Topping explains that while the conversations between the Chinese and American historical characters are fictitious, their substance reflects the actual views of those personages.) Along the way, the C.I.A. blackmails Jensen into joining its own clandestine operation to get the inside scoop on the Communists.
Topping's Peking is peopled by foreigners who've fallen in love more with the idea than the reality of the place. For them it's much better to be a secretary living in a luxurious apartment and eating caviar out of kilo glass jars than to go "back to sharing a crummy apartment in Washington with another State Department broad," or to be a young diplomat enjoying a live-in prostitute and picking up antiques on the cheap than working as a salesman in a clothing shop in Des Moines. For these characters -- as it was for many foreigners who lived in China in those days -- the civil war is an inconvenience in lives that otherwise are as far from mainstream America as possible. At the same time, these people aren't above lecturing the Chinese on the virtues of democracy, mom and apple pie.
This paradox isn't lost on the Chinese. As one character who spent time in the United States points out: "When we deal with the British or the French or the Japanese they make no secret they act out of self-interest. But you Americans wrap yourselves in your morality and insist you are befriending us . . . that you know what's best for China." Even Jensen, for all his good will, eventually sees himself like the United States: "a well-intentioned giant, blundering about the Middle Kingdom and suffering from unrequited love."
In Jensen's defense, he does a little more than blunder. He finds himself at the decisive battle of Huai-Hai, saves Peking from destruction by carrying another letter back to that city and beds a good number of women. (Although Jensen proclaims undying love for the beautiful Lilian, he has a James Bondian notion of a relationship. But this -- along with a plethora of characters who appear only to become cannon fodder a couple of pages later -- may be an accurate portrayal of the times rather than an old-fashioned male fantasy.)
Although Topping is writing about events a half-century ago, many of the issues are very much in the headlines today. The arguments over democracy and Communism may, in fact, be even more germane now as China grapples with its free-market economy, the United States holds its annual debate over China's most-favored-nation status and the two countries continue to struggle with their mutual feelings of distrust. The activists of Topping's China, who carry placards that read "Protest Government Brutality" and "No More American Interference" could just as easily be students seen on a Beijing street today, only today's students wear Nike cross-trainers and Gap T-shirts, and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's witch hunt can be seen in much of today's China bashing. Meanwhile, every major American manufacturer, media conglomerate and service provider is trying to figure out how to break into the world's largest market. Topping has shown in the way only a veteran reporter can that the infatuation -- or, conversely, the xenophobic distrust -- Americans have always felt for China is just another instance where the more things change, the more they remain the same. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Exploring the Amazon, Without the Machete

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE 

 BODY:
PSSST! Pssst! Lady . . . excuse me. . . . "
A wiry, 40-ish man in jeans and baseball cap ambled over to where I was sitting, on a bench in a plaza in Manaus, Brazil. I stiffened, expecting a shady proposition -- perhaps a black-market currency exchange, or a deal on a "gold" wristwatch. Manaus, a hot, steamy city of nearly two million people surrounded by Amazon rain forest, is something of a Brazilian Wild West town. From its 19th-century days as a raffish river port swelled by money of rubber barons, to its modern incarnation as a tax-free trade zone, Manaus has lured fortune seekers and adventurers from all over the world. 
 I was in Manaus for adventure, too. The city, 1,770 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro, is near the juncture of the Amazon -- or Rio Solimoes, as it is also known in this region -- and one of its giant tributaries, the Rio Negro. With no other major city within 600 miles, it is the jumping-off point for excursions into the rain forest. It is also the best place to catch one of the public riverboats that make the five-day journey downriver to Belem, at the mouth of the Amazon. I flew to Manaus in June, when the Amazon is at its highest, and conditions for boat travel are excellent. My plan was to spend a few days on a jungle trip out of Manaus -- the first part of a 21-day trip that would take me 800 miles down the Amazon.
But first I had to figure out what to do about the guy in the baseball cap. He drew closer, and I could see he held something in his palm. Jewelry for sale?
It was a business card: Claudio Gonzaga, Registered Jungle Tour Guide. "Maybe you are interested in a trip up the Rio Negro?"
I suppressed a chuckle -- while traveling, I've been offered a lot things on city streets, but never a jungle trek -- and declined Mr. Gonzaga's offer. Just 30 minutes before, I'd arranged for a trip with another jungle tour company called Swallows and Amazons, run by Mark Aitchison, an American expatriate, and his wife, Tania, a Brazilian.
There are dozens of tour companies and even more independent guides operating out of Manaus. Some offer boat trips, others offer a package that includes a stay in a jungle hotel and guided fishing, trekking or camping. Many of the companies have Web sites, and before I left I checked them out. For a single person, the all-inclusive packages were pricey -- $140 to $160 a day.
I felt sure I'd be able to negotiate a better deal in Manaus. Brazil's currency, the real, had been devalued in January, and now traded at almost half its former rate relative to the dollar. I also figured that my solo status, a disadvantage as an advance customer, might work in my favor on the spot. On a group tour, there's almost always room for one more. If I found a tour operator who'd already set up a group, I could hop on as a last-minute extra -- gravy for the tour operator, savings for me.
It took exactly an hour after I unpacked in the Best Western in downtown Manaus to find such a situation. Mr. Aitchison had a tour leaving the next morning, which I could join for three days. It sounded good -- there were only six other travelers booked, two Americans and four Brazilians, and the Brazilians would be along for the first day only. I liked the fact that the trip combined river travel in a gaiola, a typical Amazon small wooden motorboat, with trekking, as well as canoe excursions on the narrow jungle waterways called igarapes. On the first day, we'd cruise the basic tourist sites nearby, like the Encontro das Aguas (where the black waters of the Rio Negro feed into the brownish Amazon, creating dramatic swirling patterns on the surface), and visit the celebrated Ariau Jungle Tower, a luxury hotel on stilts in the forest. The next two days' program included canoeing, bird-watching, fishing and a forest hike. Overnights were at the Over Look Lodge, Mr. Aitchison's lodge, upriver.
Mr. Aitchison offered me a price of $100 a day, including guides, transportation and all meals and activities, which was less than what I'd seen on any Web site. Still, I hesitated, wondering if perhaps I should spend the rest of my day comparison shopping at other operators in Manaus. The time factor decided it for me -- I hadn't seen many foreign tourists at my hotel, or in my brief stroll around town to visit Manaus's only real tourist attraction -- the magnificent 19th-century opera house, the Teatro Amazonas, inlaid with Italian marble and rife with elaborate plasterwork and wood carvings. I doubted I'd be lucky enough to hook up with a group taking off the very next day. Also, it was hot -- Manaus is only a few degrees off the equator -- and I was eager to get out on the river. So I signed on.
What would an Amazon jungle trip be like? Before I'd left home, I tried to anticipate the experience by dipping into travel literature. From my reading, I'd spun a scenario that had me thwacking through thick vines with a machete, stepping carefully over pythons, avoiding exotic diseases, and occasionally stopping to chat with an earnest bespectacled eco-advocate. My neighbor, Steven, had traveled down the Amazon 15 years ago, and when I asked him about it, he immediately regaled me with more about the habits of leeches than I wanted to know. Shuddering, I packed my mosquito net and three brands of insect repellent. The four Brazilian women, well-to-do grandmothers from Sao Paulo, had packed their hair spray and diamonds.
"La floresta, que maravilhosa!" said Lydia, gesturing dramatically with her polished nails toward the bank of the Amazon. I smiled, and so did the two Americans from Indiana, both schoolteachers, both named Cathy. I hadn't expected an Amazon trip to be so genteel, and from their expressions -- and their gear of cargo pants and T-shirts -- I guessed the Cathys hadn't, either.
ON the other hand, we weren't complaining as we sat down to a tasty lunch, prepared by the boat's cook, of stewed tambaqui (a rich, meaty Amazon fish), vegetables, salad and fresh papaya. Our boat chugged briskly upriver, and a cool breeze wafted across the deck. There wasn't a mosquito, leech or eco-advocate in sight.
There's a well-worn tourist track on trips from Manaus, and for the first day of the excursion, we hit all the stops. Our little boat jockeyed for position among the other tour boats at the "meeting of the waters," where pink river dolphins reliably leap. (They didn't disappoint us.) We docked on a tiny sandbar at a hut where locals sold key rings, blowguns and other gewgaws, and where tame monkeys and sloths stretched across the wooden-plank dock. We left our boat and took a motorized canoe to a quiet lagoon where the famous Amazon giant waterlilies grow -- several canoes were already there, with a video crew. We toured (for an exorbitant $9 a head) the grandiose -- and mostly empty -- Ariau Jungle Tower hotel and tramped through the $1,000-a-night Cosmica Suite where Bill Gates had stayed during his visit last year. It was a room that boasted a 360-degree view of the forest and amenities ranging from a dartboard to a Barcalounger. Finally, our little boat pulled up at a riverbank with thick forest behind it.
"Now we get ready for a short jungle walk," said our Brazilian guide, Conrado Jose Farias.
The Cathys and I dug into our bags for the insect repellent. So did the Brazilian women -- except for Lydia. Reaching into her purse, she pulled out a mirror and flame-red lipstick and proceeded to apply it carefully.
As it turned out, Lydia made the right move. We encountered no mosquitoes on the little trail. But the women snapped dozens of pictures of each other "in the jungle" to show their grandchildren.
As a student of tourism anthropology, and a fan of tourist kitsch, I was glad to have experienced Amazon Lite. I was eager to go beyond it, however, and therefore felt pleased when our group dwindled the next morning to just the Cathys and me.
As we packed up our gear in the Over Look Lodge -- a simple bunkhouse with single and double rooms and shared bath-showers, I saw Conrado smile and relax now that he had fewer charges. A muscular, crew-cut young man with military bearing, Conrado told me he'd been a cadet in jungle training before a back injury sidelined him. At breakfast on shipboard, Conrado laid out the day's itinerary like a platoon sergeant: canoe trip, bird-watching, more canoe in a different spot, piranha fishing and moonlight alligator catching.
Conrado promised a thrill-packed day, and he delivered. The gaiola took us up the Amazon, which because of its much higher oxygen level and high fish population has more wildlife than the Rio Negro. Transferring to a motorless canoe, we paddled silently on the igarapes that led into the forest. Because of the high water, our canoe floated at treetop level, close to where the animals live.
Conrado soon spotted a couple of sloths. We paddled closer, and I pulled out my binoculars and was thrilled when I saw that the two sloths were four -- there were two babies, each clinging to its mother's fur.
The intoxicating silence was broken by the call of unfamiliar birds and the sleek whoosh of our canoe moving through water. The silliness of yesterday's tourist track faded away, replaced by the gravity of the real equatorial forest, astonishing in its diversity and fecundity. I was glad to have lucked into a knowledgeable and fit guide like Conrado, since every turn of our canoe led to a thicket of vegetation that appeared exactly like what we'd left behind. To venture here without a competent guide, I realized, is absolutely nuts.
At last, we pulled up into what Conrado said was a good spot to catch piranhas, which we could give to the cook for dinner (they are unlikely to make dinner out of you unless you swim with a school that's particularly famished). Excited, the Cathys and I grabbed poles strung with a simple nylon line, divvied up some raw meat and secured it to the hooks. "Jiggle the line, like this," Conrado demonstrated, working up a froth in the water. We followed suit. Nothing. We jiggled again.
Suddenly, my line went taut -- a catch! I pulled in the pole, but the line went loose again. I checked the hook, and the meat was gone. Then Cathy felt a bite -- same deal, slack line, empty hook. This went on for an hour, at the end of which the score was piranhas 8, humans 0.
Conrado was not happy. That evening, after dinner on the big boat, he told us to get ready for a canoe excursion. Paddling furiously out into a lagoon, he began to shine his flashlight into the thickets. From one of them, two orange lights shone back. Quickly Conrado paddled over and, in one swift motion, pulled a caiman (a small alligator) from the murky water with his bare hands. Triumphantly, he held it up in the moonlight; it dangled helplessly for a moment, silhouetted against the sky, until he chortled and tossed it back.
I came to the Amazon with nature on my mind, intrigued by the thought of encountering wild animals at every turn. What I learned in my three days on the rivers is that animals like their privacy. We spent hours quietly searching, only to spy a handful of sloths and monkeys (although the bird-watching was excellent). But though animal life was uncooperative, the people living on the Amazon were friendly and numerous.
AS our guides explained, these Amazon dwellers, who are known as caboclos, are descendants of the original indigenous people and the Portuguese colonists. Over centuries, the caboclos have developed a culture combining elements of European and Indian heritage.
As we traveled the river, we met caboclos everywhere -- passing in canoes with hardwood logs stacked and ready to take to market, fishing in narrow streams, tending their crops of manioc (cassava, an Amazon staple) along the riverbanks. The opportunity to meet them and observe their life up close turned out to be the unexpected highlight.
Senhor Luis, a grave, sun-weathered farmer in his 80's, invited us to climb up his dock and into his fine wood house, which bore a For Sale sign. Proudly, he showed me around the place, which he'd built himself. The windows had sliding shutters that glided in hand-chiseled grooves. Mango and guava trees shaded the yard. On the other side of the property was a shed and equipment to grind manioc into the flour that is a staple of the Amazon diet. A small boat, also for sale, hugged the shore. I took this all in -- the land, the fruit, waterfront property -- and my New York real estate gene did the rest.
I asked Senhor Luis the price. Five thousand cash, he replied.
Only five thousand! I thought about this on the two-hour trip downriver back to Manaus. I calculated what it might cost to dig a well and install running water, and put on a new aluminum roof. Finally I could contain myself no longer. When we returned to the Over Look Lodge, where I was going to catch a boat back to Manaus, I asked Mark Aitchison, who was riding back with us, whether Senhor Luis was asking a fair price for the property.
He looked at me and laughed. "Well, if Senhor Luis owned it, it would be a great deal," he said, explaining that almost all the riverfront land here belonged to Brazil's army, and the caboclos squatted there (with the military's tacit permission).
So much for my fantasy of an Amazon summer home. Perhaps I'd find a less shaky real estate opportunity somewhere downriver. I had 800 more miles to explore.
 
The bottom line
 I spent $439 for hotel, meals and activities during my four nights and five days in Manaus and the surrounding rain forest.
 
Getting There
I booked my flights through BR Online Travel, (305) 379-0005, a Miami-based air ticket consolidator that specializes in Brazil. My itinerary on Varig -- New York to Manaus via Miami, return to New York from Belem via Miami, and a side excursion between Belem and the city of Sao Luis -- cost $1,058, about $800 less than the lowest fare quote directly from the airline.
 
Accommodations and Dining
At www.travelocity.com, I reserved a single room at the Best Western, 217 Rua Marcilio Dias, telephone (55-92) 622-2844, fax (55-92) 622-2576, for $57 for my first night in Manaus. After my jungle excursion, I stayed another night at the Best Western, and my rate mysteriously dropped to $52. The price includes the traditional Brazilian breakfast buffet -- an enormous selection of fruits, breads, cheeses and fresh juices. The Best Western is clean and well kept with somewhat drab but spacious air-conditioned rooms (insist on a high floor with a city view) in a safe and central neighborhood.
Dining choices in Manaus are limited. The Best Western serves a superb lunch buffet for $6.50. On my trip with Swallows and Amazons, I ate three meals a day of fresh fish, free-range chicken and local fruits and vegetables, expertly prepared and included in my daily rate.
 
Getting Around
Manaus is crawling with tour operators and independent guides. Before arriving in Brazil, I consulted the Lonely Planet Guide to Brazil and the Passport South American Handbook, two excellent sources.
I also found descriptions of hotel packages and guided tours on line -- www.zfnet.com/manaus, in Portuguese, has a directory of state-approved tour operators. The Web sites gave a sense of current rates.
Swallows and Amazons, 189 Rua Quintino Bocaiuva, (55-92) 622-1246, Web site www.overlookinn.com/ swallows.html, is recommended by my guidebooks. It is run by Mark Aitchison and his wife, Tania. Their tours combine boat and canoe travel with land trekking and stays at the Over Look Lodge, about 35 miles upriver on the Rio Negro from Manaus. My three-day, two-night trip included a boat excursion to popular nearby tourist sites like the Encontro das Aguas and the Ariau Jungle Tower Hotel, wildlife- and bird-watching, a canoe excursion through small streams off the Rio Negro, and two short hikes in the rain forest. The price, $100 a day, included overnight accommodations in the simple lodge, and all meals. I found their guides and staff to be professional and knowledgeable.
 
What to See
Entry to the opera house in Manaus, Praca Sao Sebastiao, Centro, telephone (55-92) 234-0508, is about $2.50, including a tour in English.
 DAISANN McLANE

HEADLINE: Style;
Serena on Tap

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill

 BODY:
The Chelsea Hotel sprawls along 23d Street like a seedy lament to the Age of Innocence, when this part of Manhattan was "uptown" and Lillian Russell was the girl of the hour. Built in 1883 as a co-op, with a pink Victorian facade and lacy balconies, the Chelsea did not open its doors as a hotel until 1905.
Since then, the likes of Mark Twain, Sarah Bernhardt and O. Henry have bedded down on Chelsea sheets. Here, Thomas Wolfe wrote "You Can't Go Home Again"; Arthur Clarke, "2001 -- A Space Odyssey," and William Burroughs, "Naked Lunch." In its slow shamble toward bohemia, the historic landmark played host not only to the wannabes and down-and-outs but also to Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller and Dylan Thomas, the Welsh poet who took his last drink in Room 205, then slipped into a coma and died. Andy Warhol's most glittering superstar (and "Chelsea Girl"), Viva, made the place her home for 30-odd years. And Sid Vicious enhanced the Chelsea Myth when, in 1978, the punk rocker stabbed his girlfriend Nancy Spungen to death in Room 100. 
 Yet the miracle of the Chelsea is that, homicidal maniacs notwithstanding, eccentrics and artists alike have always found sanctuary within its walls. The managing owner, Stanley Bard, has said he never wants the Chelsea to turn into just "a place to make money." So it is all the more curious that he leased the Chelsea's unfinished basement to the fashion world's premier caterer, Serena Bass. In partnership with her son Sam Shaffer, Bass will open Serena, a chic little bar and lounge, on Sept. 9.
Now, a hot saloon could certainly burn away some of the hotel's recent tarnish, but the idea of very thin people lining up in very expensive dresses to push through Serena's heavy wrought-iron door, drink cosmopolitans under her tin palm trees, recline on pillows made by a top London designer (Bass's sister, Gaynor Churchward) and munch on root-vegetable pancakes (her niece Minnie Driver's favorite) seems almost antithetical to the Chelsea spirit. But Bard is not worried. "Serena fits," he insists.
She is 53 years old but a convincing 30-something from a distance. All ash-blond pixie, can-do affability and high-voltage drive, she is preparing herself for a photo shoot in the office above her West 13th Street catering kitchen and is too busy putting on a face -- kohl eyes and blood-red lipstick -- to have much time for guile.
"With Mortimer's down, everybody is dying for a place to go," she gushes. "Peter Duchin and Brooke Hayward call me every day, every day! Renny Reynolds, the florist? He's helped me so much. Alexa Hampton, you know, Mark Hampton's daughter, we couldn't have done it without her! None of them can wait until we open! And all Sam's friends, the young artists and models, are so eager!" Stacking the evidence in favor of success, Bass has neither the time nor the inclination to consider the possibility of failure.
At the moment she is basking in maternal triumph. "People tell me it must be hard -- I say it's easier," she says of her partnership with Sam, who majored in economics at Tufts, worked in marketing at Details magazine and learned the bar business at Ian Schrager's hotel Morgans. "At the end of the day we call and say: 'Sorry I was such a. . . .' 'Sorry I was such a. . . ."'
Bass grew up in Brighton, England, so disgusted by the pigs' feet and headcheese that her stepmother served that she ate only cheese omelets. At 16, she headed for Swinging London, where she was swept away by David Shaffer, a young doctor with a taste for fine food and fancy friends, including Dudley Moore and Jonathan Miller from "Beyond the Fringe." In short order, the couple married and had two sons. (Joe, 30, is a dermatologist.) And Bass, a quick study, went from scrambling eggs to whipping up pheasant with cr<heart>me Calvados. (It didn't hurt that she lived around the corner and drew inspiration from a gourmet shop owned by the British food writer Elizabeth David.)
In 1977, the Shaffers arrived in New York. "And we entertained everybody -- my husband was very taken with it all," Bass says, adding that she herself was much more smitten with the artists and writers she met in the hallways of the Chelsea Hotel, where the family lived while renovating their brownstone in Greenwich Village.
When the marriage broke up five years later -- Shaffer subsequently married Anna Wintour, of Vogue -- Bass started catering to support herself. (She has been divorced twice.) "She's incredibly talented," says her friend Brooke Hayward. "Serena has a homespun quality, a natural design sense and a weird eccentricity, which makes her unique."
Bass, who is hoping that Serena will be to Chelsea what Elaine's is to the Upper East Side, says there is no other watering hole where people of all ages can socialize. "People my age are going to feel comfortable here, and the younger people will have someplace pretty to go." Her nine-month renovation, costing $500,000, has turned a once-dank and rodent-replete dungeon into a handsome colonialist cocoon whose cinnabar-colored walls exude sensuality. The first room, a cafe, features marble tables, 50's-style sconces and raw silk and faux-suede banquettes. Through an archway is the hexagonal bar, with a red-and-green-striped daybed under the window and banquettes against the far wall. The third room, a dark, opulent lounge, features green velvet banquettes, Indian cushions and Chinese lanterns. "My plan," Bass says, "is that you meet in the cafe, see who you like, move that person into the bar and get drunk, then move into the den and" -- either eat some of her marvelous tandoori chicken and shrimp ceviche or, as she puts it -- make out."
Which is O.K. by Laura Kirar, designer of the stylish restaurant Fressen, who joined a gaggle of natty creative types, among them the songwriters Danny Keough and Angela McCluskey, at a preview party recently. "You can walk in here and picture your favorite rock star fitting in," Kirar says. "It's great. A little trash, a little rock-and-roll."
As opening night approaches, the would-be doyenne is serene, befitting her name. After all, Kwan Lau, the Feng Shui master, came by the other day. "He positioned the cash register and blessed the whole place and said that everything is perfect."
 
Tandoori Chicken Fingers
 
 6 tablespoons tandoori masala (see note)
 3 tablespoons Patak's Tandoori
 Curry Paste (see note)
 1/4 cup peeled, finely grated ginger
 2 cloves garlic
 1 1/2 cups heavy cream
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
 2 pounds boneless, skinless chicken breasts, cut into 1/2-inch-wide strips
 Chopped cilantro for garnish.
1. In a large nonreactive bowl, combine all the ingredients except the chicken and cilantro and stir until well mixed. Add the chicken, toss to coat and cover the bowl. Refrigerate overnight.
2. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Cover the bottom of 2 large sheet pans with parchment paper and lay the strips of chicken on top of the paper. Discard excess marinade. Bake the chicken, turning once, for 10 minutes, or until just cooked through. Garnish with cilantro and serve.
Yield: 8 appetizer servings.
Note: Available at specialty stores or by mail from Adriana's Caravan, (800) 316-0820.
 
Root-Vegetable Pancakes
 
 2 parsnips, peeled
 1 medium celery root (celeriac), peeled
 1 sweet potato, peeled
 2 teaspoons unsalted butter
 1 small yellow onion, peeled and diced
 2 teaspoons curry powder
 1 heaping tablespoon all-purpose flour
 1/2 teaspoon salt
 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
 1/8 teaspoon cayenne pepper
 2 large eggs
 2 tablespoons vegetable oil.
1. Using the shredding disk on a food processor or a hand-held grater, shred the parsnips, celery root and sweet potato, keeping each vegetable separate. Place a large nonstick skillet over medium heat and cook the vegetables, one at a time, covering the skillet and allowing them to cook in their own juices until they are just soft, about 3 to 5 minutes each. As they are cooked, transfer the vegetables to one large bowl.
2. In the same skillet, melt the butter over medium heat. Add the onion and cook, stirring, until it is translucent, about 5 minutes. Add the curry powder and cook 1 minute. Stir in the flour. Add the onion mixture to the bowl with the root vegetables. Add the salt, pepper and cayenne and mix well. Add the eggs. Toss until thoroughly mixed.
3. Wash out the skillet and place it over medium heat. Add the oil. Form the vegetable mixture into small cakes about 3 inches in diameter and add them to the skillet. (Do not crowd; you will need at least 2 batches.) Cook the cakes, turning once, until they are nicely browned and cooked through, about 5 minutes per side. Transfer to a plate. Continue cooking until all the vegetable mixture has been used. Serve hot with tomato or mango chutney.
Yield: 12 to 15 pancakes.
 
Ecuadorean Ceviche
 
 1 1/2 teaspoons seafood seasoning
 6 tablespoons freshly squeezed lime juice
 1 teaspoon salt, plus more to taste
 2 1/2 pounds medium shrimp, peeled and deveined
 6 very ripe plum tomatoes, peeled and seeded
 1/4 cup ketchup
 1/2 cup chopped cilantro
 3 small red onions, peeled, halved and thinly sliced
 Freshly ground pepper to taste
 3 strips bacon, diced
 1 1/2 cups dried corn (see note).

 1. In a medium saucepan, bring 3 cups of water to a boil over high heat. Add the seafood seasoning, 2 tablespoons of the lime juice and 1 teaspoon salt and stir to combine. Add the shrimp and simmer for 2 minutes. Remove from the heat and transfer the shrimp and liquid to a large bowl. Set aside.
2. Place the tomatoes in the container of a blender and puree. Transfer puree to a bowl and add the remaining 4 tablespoons lime juice, the ketchup and cilantro and stir until combined. Stir in the onions. Pour this mixture over the shrimp and liquid and stir until combined. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Chill at least 2 hours.
3. Meanwhile, heat a medium skillet over medium heat and add the bacon. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the bacon is crispy and has rendered its fat, 6 to 7 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, remove the bacon and reserve for another use. Add the dried corn to the skillet and cook, stirring, until the corn is browned and crispy, about 5 minutes. Transfer to a small bowl and sprinkle with salt.
4. When the ceviche is chilled, spoon it into bowls. (Leftover liquid can be put to another use or discarded.) Garnish with toasted corn and serve.
Yield: 8 appetizer servings.
Note: Available in Spanish grocery stores or by mail from Adriana's Caravan.
 
Chocolate Tres Leches
 
 For the cake:
 5 large eggs, separated
 1 cup sugar
 1 cup cocoa powder
 2/3 cup all-purpose flour
 1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
 1/4 teaspoon salt
 1/3 cup milk
 1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract
 1/2 teaspoon cream of tartar
 1 cup evaporated milk
 3/4 cup sweetened condensed milk
 3/4 cup heavy cream
 1 tablespoon light rum
 
 For the meringue topping:
 1 cup sugar
 3 egg whites
 1/2 teaspoon cream of tartar.
1. To make the cake, preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Generously butter a 10-inch round cake pan. Place the yolks and 3/4cup of the sugar in the bowl of an electric mixer and beat until light and fluffy, about 5 minutes. Meanwhile, sift together the cocoa, flour, baking powder and salt. When yolks are fluffy, use a large spoon to fold the milk and 1/2teaspoon of the vanilla into them, then fold in the cocoa mixture.
2. In a clean bowl with a clean beater, beat the egg whites until frothy. Beat in the cream of tartar and continue beating until soft peaks form. Gradually beat in the remaining 1/4cup sugar, beating until the whites are glossy and firm. Fold the whites into the cocoa mixture. Scrape the batter into the prepared pan and bake until a toothpick inserted into the center of the cake comes out clean, about 40 to 50 minutes.
3. Remove the cake from the oven and cool in the pan on a wire rack. Then unmold it onto a deep platter. Pierce the top all over with the tines of a fork. In a bowl, combine the evaporated milk, condensed milk, cream, rum and remaining teaspoon of vanilla. Pour the mixture over the cake, spooning the milk that puddles on the platter on top of the cake, little by little, until all is absorbed.
4. Meanwhile, make the meringue topping. In a small heavy saucepan, combine 1/4 cup of water and all but 2 tablespoons of the sugar. Place over high heat, cover and cook for 2 minutes. Remove the cover and continue cooking until the mixture reaches the soft ball stage, 239 degrees F on a candy thermometer, about 5 minutes.
5. While the sugar syrup is cooking, place the egg whites and cream of tartar in the bowl of an electric mixer and begin beating. When soft peaks form, beat in the remaining 2 tablespoons sugar. Continue beating the whites until stiff peaks form.
6. As soon as the sugar syrup reaches the correct temperature, with the beater running, begin pouring the hot syrup very slowly into the whites. Continue beating until the mixer bowl no longer feels warm, about 10 minutes.
7. Wipe the edges of the platter. Using a small spatula, spread the meringue over the top and sides of the cake. Refrigerate at least 2 hours before serving.
Yield: 10 servings.
