HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
The Baseball Treasures He Just Can't Part With

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW; Ira Berkow is a sports columnist for The New York Times.

 BODY:
THE nearly 80,000 items of baseball memorabilia -- from the gorgeously historic to the madly esoteric -- that filled the comfortable home of Barry Halper in Livingston, N.J., have mostly been packed up and shipped out. About 20 percent of his collection was sent to the Baseball Hall of Fame, where a wing named for this collector non pareil has been built. Most of the rest of the collection will be sold at a weeklong auction at Sotheby's in Manhattan, begining on Sept. 23, which, according to Sotheby's, has a chance to break the house record of $34.4 million set by the sale of the Jackie Kennedy Onassis estate.
But in Mr. Halper's home, some things remain the same. He was unable to part with some items of value, for sentimental reasons. He was also unable to part with some items of perhaps little economic value, for the same heart-plucking reasons. He has held on to books and photographs signed "To my friend, Barry Halper" from the likes of Joe DiMaggio and George Brett, a lock of Babe Ruth's hair, a rubber glove once used by a doctor to examine Mickey Mantle, to name a few. 
 In Mr. Halper's spacious den, which is sectioned off into four rooms, are empty glass cases and barren areas on the walls. No longer can one peer into the window in one part of the wood paneling and see, with a flick of a switch, 1,053 baseball uniforms come rolling past on a dry cleaner's carousel. Many of the uniforms are signed; they include those worn by Cap Anson for the 1888 Chicago White Stockings, Jim Thorpe for the 1918 New York Giants and Jackie Robinson when he played for Kansas City of the Negro leagues in 1946; others belonged to Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Willie Mays and Pete Rose. (About the only things left on the carousel are a few of Mr. Halper's seldom worn suits and some dresses that belong to his wife, Sharon.)
Gone from his home, as well as from warehouses where the rest of his collection was kept, are the baseball treasures he compiled over a half century. Mr. Halper, now 60, began his quest when he was 8 years old and continued it through his years as a partner in the family's wholesale paper business, now defunct, in New Jersey. He went about collecting with a determination, a passion, sometimes with an obsession that some people might reserve for, say, a different kind of amour.
The list of what he has got rid of is staggering. Gone are the myriad baseball gloves and shoes and caps and bats. One bat, for example, bore the signature of Earl Averill, the Hall of Fame outfielder, who signed it for Mr. Halper a month before his death. Gone, too, are the mountains of signed baseballs and photographs and rarest of baseball cards and letters and contracts and trophies. And, alas, gone as well is the first issue of Playboy Magazine, published in 1953, with Marilyn Monroe on the cover and in the centerfold. Mr. Halper asked her husband, Joe DiMaggio, to autograph the cover. He agreed but only on the condition that Mr. Halper not show it in DiMaggio's lifetime.
"When I was going through my collection," Mr. Halper recalled, "I said to my wife and sons, Steven and Jason, 'I'll have to keep this contract of Babe Ruth's from the Red Sox in 1918, and I have to keep this ball and that bat . . . ' And they said, 'If you're going to keep all those things, you might as well start a new collection,' and so I let most of it go."
Mr. Halper had suffered a stroke a few years ago -- he has recovered almost fully -- and decided that it could create financial chaos for his family if he left the collection as it was. "And I didn't want a fire sale," he said. So he went about looking for a home for it, and wound up with the current arrangements.
Matt Robbins, a spokesman for Sotheby's, conservatively estimated that the sale would yield $10 million. "I would hardly be surprised, however, if it surpassed our record auction," he said, referring to the Onassis sale. Another indication of the worth of the Halper collection was a $42 million appraisal from an insurance company.
STILL hanging on the wall in Mr. Halper's basement, however, is a framed letter from 1932 that reads: "In all my years in baseball I have received many requests of autographs, balls, bats, equipment, but you are the first person to ask for some of my hair. Therefore I feel I am obligated to comply with such a request at least once. You will find enclosed an envelope containing some of my hair. I don't know what you're going to do with it, but I hope you enjoy it. Good luck with your collection. Sincerely, Babe Ruth."
Inside the frame is a lock of the Babe's hair, dark brown with a few strands of gray. A note beside it reads, "I guarantee that the enclosed hair is my own, Babe Ruth." The note was addressed not to Barry Halper but to Matthew Ward, a memorabilia collector from Ruth's time with whom Mr. Halper would have obviously identified.
Mr. Halper, whose hair remains as thick and dark as Ruth's and whose stocky build, in sport jacket and tie, is a scaled-down version of the old slugger's, walked around his den, stopping at various places to point out to a visitor what wasn't there and explaining why he had kept what he had. As he did so, one could sense the enthusiasm for what was essentially his life's work and the bitter-sweet feeling he had about parting with much of his collection. (While understanding of her husband's obsession, Sharon Halper was not reluctant to see the collection go. "She's not much of a baseball fan," Mr. Halper said. "Besides, I think all the mildew in the house was getting to her.")
"What I kept are some items that I felt personally about," Mr. Halper said. Many of the objects he kept are associated with the Yankees. He owns 2 percent of the team, enough to enable him to sit in the box of the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, when attending games. (One thing he held on to is a felt yarmulke with the red-white-and-blue Yankee logo sewn into it. A letter accompanying it describes it as a gift to Mr. Halper from Mr. Steinbrenner.)
From a shelf in the office of his den he pulled off a silver nail-file case bearing the initials "GHR," for "George Herman Ruth." "I rub this for good luck when I'm watching Yankee games," he said. "Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't." He also has the Babe's tweezers, hand mirror, shoe brush, hair brush and glass tooth-brush case, all monogrammed.
In a glass case nearby, he has a handful of baseball bats autographed to him, including one from some 30 years ago that reads: "To Barry -- the No. 1 collector from the No. 1 home run king. Best always, Roger Maris."
Mr. Halper pointed out an empty spot in the case where the Averill bat once stood. He recalled how he had acquired it: He had been attending the 1983 All-Star game in Chicago on the 50th anniversary of the first major-league all-star game, in which Averill had played. "I saw him in the hotel lobby after the game," Mr. Halper said, "and he was looking very sickly. He said he'd sign the bat tomorrow. I thought that if he made it to tomorrow it would be a miracle. I just about begged him to do it now, and we went to his room, where he signed it.
"The next morning I came down to the lobby, and there's a big commotion. Averill was leaving the hotel in an ambulance, and died shortly after. I don't want to be callous, but I did get lucky."
On another shelf Mr. Halper has also kept high school yearbooks of famous players (a 1963 yearbook from Scottsdale, Ariz., includes a senior named Jim Palmer, star baseball and basketball player, as well a junior varsity basketball player listed as "Danny Quail," who later became Vice President of the United States and who himself had at least one moment of shaky spelling).
A framed cover of a record album on a wall is titled "My Favorite Hits, Mickey Mantle." It is inscribed with Mantle's own peculiar brand of spelling, "To Barry -- You should here me sing! Mickey Mantle."
Mr. Halper, pausing to look at the album cover, smiled. He had become friends with Mantle, as well as with DiMaggio and other ball players. Many came to his home not only to look at his remarkable collection but also to eat at the table of Sharon Halper, who is known for her Italian dishes. (Her shrimp fra diavolo over linguini was a particular favorite of DiMaggio's.)
"Mickey had a great sense of humor, sometimes a bizarre one," said Mr. Halper. "I was in Dallas shortly before he died, and he was holding a news conference to discuss his liver cancer. He saw me and hollered, 'Hey, Barry, do you want to buy my liver?' "
"Mickey knew that I had Ty Cobb's dentures," Mr. Halper added, with a laugh. "Maybe he was trying to be helpful." Mr. Halper wasn't interested in Mantle's liver, but he did covet the scalpel used in the liver-transplant operation. The surgeon said he could not be sure which one he had used, but Mantle had another idea. A few weeks later Mr. Halper received a Federal Express package, and when he opened it he found a plastic glove, with a note: "This is the glove from my hemmorid exam. Mickey Mantle."
Mr. Halper framed the glove in a glass butterfly case but discreetly tucked it in a drawer. "What should I do?" asked Mr. Halper. "Throw it away?"
Hanging from a peg in Mr. Halper's den office, meanwhile, is another glove, but this one an actual baseball glove, which also bears Mantle's name. In the Sotheby catalogue for the Halper collection, a glove worn by Mickey Mantle, "circa 1960," is listed at $10,000 to $20,000. And what is this one worth?
"Nothing," Mr. Halper said. "It's my glove. It just happens to be a Mantle model. But it's from the days I played softball."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 30; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2107 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
A Queens Factory Is Born Again, as a Church

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
THE new New York Presbyterian Church, which officially opens on Sept. 18, is as striking a piece of architecture as those we once had to go to Los Angeles to see. Situated in Sunnyside, Queens, the church can claim a place on the small list of projects that are helping to lift New York architecture out of its long creative slump.
The building was designed by Doug Garofalo, Greg Lynn and Michael McInturf, three whiz kids of the computer generation who live and work in three different cities -- Los Angeles, Chicago and Columbus, Ohio -- and who practice together in an office somewhere in cyberspace. For this trio, design is a paperless enterprise, aided by software originally developed for automobile styling and movie animation, and conducted with the playfulness of a video game. These people are wired. 
 Computers have long been standard equipment in architectural offices, but few architects have tried to exploit the potential of software as an expressive medium. Wes Jones, the Los Angeles-based architect, has used the term blobmeisters to describe architects who are pursuing this potential today. Conventional (so-called orthogonal) buildings are typically rendered by plans and elevations, two kinds of two-dimensional drawing. Blobs, on the other hand, are rendered as three-dimensional computer models, like those we see for cars, bodies or molecular structures. By collapsing plan and elevation into a single three-dimensional form, the computer model encourages architects to break out of orthogonal, right-angled space. Instead, they can manipulate all dimensions at once. Space becomes as plastic as a hunk of Silly Putty. It can be pinched, rotated, kneaded, stretched, cut into sections, shattered or left to ooze. The computer model displays the impact of each manipulation on the whole.
Blobmeisters use software the way modernists used structure: as a springboard for form. By way of explanation, Lynn says that a movie like "Antz" came about not because a director wanted to make a movie about insects, but because a technician discovered that a particular computer program was effective at depicting animated bugs. At the Presbyterian Church, the architects used a program called Alias, developed for movie animation and industrial design. They have combined new blob elements with the box form of an older, existing structure to produce a hybrid design, or para-building -- an addition that radically transforms what came before.
Founded in 1970, the Presbyterian Church of New York has a rapidly growing congregation whose members are mostly of Korean descent. In addition to the religious services held in the sanctuary, the new building's largest space, the church functions as a social and educational center for the Korean community. The new building, which cost $10 million, contains 80 classrooms, a banquet hall-cafeteria with seating for 1,000, a wedding chapel, day care center, library and medical clinic. As an expression of faith, parishioners fasted one day each week while their church was in construction.
The church's physical context is almost lyrically gritty, flat and gray, an area dominated by used-car lots, warehouses, factories and chain super stores. Grand Opening, pennants fluttering, Nobody Beats Our Prices: a Northern Boulevard version of Ed Ruscha. Across the street from the church, Long Island Rail Road trains zip by on an overpass. Beyond, the leafy streets of Sunnyside emphasize the nearby urban grit. Into this sliced-up, wrong-side-of-the-tracks setting, Garofalo, Lynn and McInturf have introduced chop-shop architecture: an assemblage of old and new industrial parts.
The original structure was built in 1932 for the Knickerbocker Laundry Factory, a commercial firm that held the franchise for cleaning Yankee uniforms. A local landmark, the precast concrete Art Deco edifice later housed a perfume factory. The church retains the laundry's street facade, though its curving Deco surface, once white, has been painted black. The architects call it the Shroud.
In the original building, a two-story industrial shed lay behind the Deco facade. For the remodeling, the architects have added a new structural framework that doubles the height of the shed. They have sheared away three of the existing walls -- chop, chop -- and replaced them with new ones: two finished with a purple-gray stucco, the third made of translucent fiberglass panels inset with clear glass windows.
Blobmeister forms often resemble horror movie monsters. Earlier this year, Lynn presented an installation in Vienna called "The Tingler," after the old William Castle movie about a centipede-like parasite. For the church, he and his partners have invented a form they call Nestor, so named because it is composed of trapezoidal shapes that appear to nest inside one another, like a stack of baskets laid on its side. Nestor is not an object, but a form, a spatial void that is used to define different areas on the top two floors of the church. Imagine it as the hollow cavity of a Jurassic fossil.
Nestor's form is reptilian, with a serrated surface that recalls a lizard's hide. The form is only partly visible from outside, in a series of zinc-clad, folded canopies that cascade down the northern facade of the building, sheltering an exterior fire stair of poured concrete. Admirers of 50's sculpture may see a resemblance of these canopies to the work of Seymour Lipton. Inside the shed, Nestor contains the church's main space, the sanctuary, with seating for more than 2,500 parishioners. The capacity is roughly that of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Lynn and McInturf both worked in the New York office of Peter Eisenman and make no effort to cover their tracks. We have seen lots of work from the generation after Frank Gehry, but it's a novelty to see second-generation Eisenman, particularly in New York, where the mentor himself has built only a humble fire station, and that some years back. There are people who break out in hives whenever Eisenman's name comes up, but the Presbyterian Church may persuade them to reconsider. The younger architects give us Eisenmanesque forms without the Hate me! Hate me! provocation. That loss is a gain all around.
For the convention center in Columbus, Ohio, Eisenman designed "snakes," curving shapes that turned the roof into a so-called fifth facade. Lodged within the Presbyterian Church are what the architects call tubes: three vertical corridors that contain entrances, hallways, stairs and elevators and provide circulation throughout the building.
Shroud, shed, Nestor, tubes: these are the basic components of the church's organizing system, and it is helpful to keep them in mind, because it's not immediately apparent that a system is in operation. The tubes, for example, overlap as they weave through the structure. The overlapping areas are sometimes, but not always, articulated by ceiling soffits and by the color of the linoleum flooring. The building's undulating roof corresponds to Nestor's bulging contour just below. The canopies are not, as one might think, arbitrarily sculpted shapes, but Nestor's serrated western edge.
The sanctuary is the most impressive interior to be built in New York in many years. The room's ceiling (Nestor's inner hide) serves an acoustical function but is mainly an experiment in folded planes, a device long associated with Eisenman. The space is asymmetrical, with angled banks of seating that violate the traditional arrangement around a central axis. The effect is not weird or Caligariesque. Rather, the asymmetry makes the space more fluid, its vast size less overwhelming. Chop-chop: a glass wall slices through the sanctuary along its northern edge, allowing natural light into the space and dissolving any sense of confinement.
Other fine moments: a magnificent processional staircase that leads from the main entrance lobby to the sanctuary two floors above; the most dramatic feature within the tubes, the stair curves and narrows slightly as it rises, the deviations accented by strips of neon lighting overhead. The black asphalt parking lot, surrounded by white concrete walls, that sets the church off like an industrial velvet matte. The fixtures and furnishings brought in by the church itself -- lots of wood, vases with scrolls on them -- that help draw the place into the vernacular. The view of the church from Northern Boulevard: a free-falling image, pure formal play, the zinc-covered canopies reverberate across the northern facade like tolling bells.
Shortcomings in blob architecture might be called glitches, blips or crashes. The Presbyterian Church has a few. Stairs. In the balcony aisle, and an exterior stair near the parking lot, the treads are too long. You have to hop-skip, leading first left foot, then right. This rhythm is boring and distracts from the irregular geometries of the space. Such discomforts can be found in many conventional buildings, but it's screwy when formalist architecture does not work with the geometry of human form.
The funereal palette: purple gray; black; mauve. The architects say that their adaptive reuse replaces the laundering of dirty uniforms with the cleansing of tarnished souls. A lovely conceit. Why the mourning dress? One senses the strain of young architects trying to look sober beyond their years.
Wasted space. The upper landing of the outdoor fire stair, sheltered beneath the topmost canopy, is a wonderful space, perhaps the best in the building, with views of the Manhattan skyline and the sanctuary inside. A perfect place for a garden of contemplation. Fire codes permitting, the entire staircase, and the spaces beneath it, would benefit from landscaping. Software-driven design should maximize what chat rooms cannot provide: habitable public space for integrated bodies, minds and souls; physical proximity; tactility; the here as well as the now.
The glitches do not, however, diminish the stature of this work, as both a fulfillment of historical forces and as a preview of things to come. Half a century ago, the British historian John Summerson said that architects should "learn to study not merely minimum requirements, but maximum possibilities; to learn not only how to economize space but how to be extravagant with it; to study the overtones of architecture and the geometrical discipline of space as space; to learn not only to use space but to play with space."
The words come from an address Summerson delivered to the Architectural Association in London in 1947. He was responding to the impact on architecture of modern communications technology. Radio, television and telephone, Summerson thought, had relieved architects of the need to create imposing public symbols of social cohesion. This had liberated them to focus on space, an element media could not supplant.
Half a century later, however, communications technology has gone far toward capturing the spatial dimension. The culture now lives more imaginatively in simulated spaces -- blue screen backgrounds, VR, SimCity -- than in those created by architectural means. Obviously, Garofalo, Lynn and McInturf are not opposed to this development. In fact, their cyberspatial mode of working may be more revolutionary than their design. They have dealt with displacement by incorporating new media into their method. The church is a natural extension of the process the architects used to design it. That process caused three architects to reconfigure the spatial relationships between them. The church amplifies those relationships in architectural terms.
IT would be odd if the computer did not set off a spatial revision comparable to that sparked by Brunelleschi's development of linear perspective in 15th-century Florence. Indeed, blob architecture undermines the enduring authority of perspectival space. While blob architecture has its Baroque aspects, its twists on axis, symmetry and procession violate classical norms. In Queens, the classically symmetrical Deco facade accentuates the anti-classicism of the addition.
It was fitting that this project was commissioned by a church. Faith is supra-rational, like mountain climbing. Believers throw a line up into the unknown and we haul ourselves skyward, and it's only when we have done this quite a bit that we know that faith works: we can look back and see how high we have climbed. Architecture works the same way. Architects may have no idea what's up there, but they throw the line anyway, and when this happens often enough, a history of architecture is revealed. The New York Presbyterian Church signifies a new stage of ascent.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
In San Jose, Hopes for a More Livable Downtown

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
TWO high-density residential developments, one a rental building and the other a condominium project, are the latest expressions of a 20-year effort to create a vital downtown in the largest city in Silicon Valley.
The projects represent the city's attempt to introduce new housing into a thinly populated urban center. With 900,000 people, San Jose is the third-largest city in California, but less than 1 percent of its residents live downtown. 
 With the completion of the new apartment and condominium complexes, the city will have built only a quarter of the 8,000 units it hopes to complete by 2010, when it expects the population of downtown San Jose to have swollen to 19,000, from 6,585 today.
City leaders hope that the two new projects, with 424 housing units, and projects with 1,200 more housing units in the planning stage will bring hundreds of new residents into the downtown area, where extensive redevelopment has already brought new office buildings, parks, cultural venues and historic preservation activity.
Many of those new developments were either created by or heavily subsidized by the San Jose Redevelopment Agency, which is sprucing up the downtown area to compete with better-established office locations throughout suburban Santa Clara County -- the region popularly known as Silicon Valley.
Despite being the largest urban center in Santa Clara County, downtown San Jose is still coming from behind in the competition for high-tech tenants in Silicon Valley. Smaller, more suburban cities like Palo Alto, Menlo Park, Mountain View and Cupertino have been the main beneficiaries of the phenomenal expansion of computer and Internet-related companies.
Until World War II, San Jose was an unremarkable farming community whose greatest distinction was being the seat of Santa Clara County. Surrounded by fruit orchards, the city was a center for the canning of pears, prunes, cherries and apricots. After the war, it grew as a bedroom community for the region's computer- and defense-related businesses. In the 1950's, city officials saw homebuilding and annexation as sources of growth, and the city expanded by 47 square miles during that decade.
The small downtown area was suffering from the loss of major employers, however, many of them leaving for the suburbs. And it sustained a severe symbolic loss in 1954, when the city government left downtown for peripheral neighborhoods. The image of a depressed downtown became even more dismal in the 1960's, when entire blocks of aging buildings were bulldozed in the name of urban renewal.
Dennis Korabiak, downtown coordinator for the Redevelopment Agency, recalled the dismay he felt when walking through downtown in 1982, shortly after joining the organization. "I walked down First Street and said, 'What have I got myself into?' " he recalled. "It was that bad."
AT the time, San Jose was just starting a long-term redevelopment program, funded principally by a portion of the property taxes levied on newer, suburban-style business parks on the city's northern and southern edges. The success of those business parks provides downtown San Jose with the richest flow of tax increment financing available to any California city, about $90 million annually, Mr. Korabiak said. (In tax increment financing, a portion of property tax revenues is used for redevelopment.)
In recent years, the Redevelopment Agency has assisted or provided partial funding for so many downtown projects that it would be only a slight exaggeration to say that San Jose's new downtown is the agency's creation.
Among the projects that the agency assisted are the Children's Discovery Museum, the San Jose Arena, the San Jose Convention Center, the San Jose Repertory Theater, the Tech Museum of Innovation, the Biblioteca/Youth Center and the Mexican Cultural Heritage Gardens. It also helped restore the Civic Auditorium.
The city has also provided big subsidies to businesses willing to relocate downtown. Adobe Systems, the software maker, moved into a new downtown building in 1994 after receiving a $35 million subsidy from the city. (Much of the subsidy paid for a parking garage.)
The Redevelopment Agency has also paid for most of an extensive landscaping program that has turned the banks of the Guadalupe River into a 20-mile regional park. The riverfront was a selling point for the Adobe deal, according to Mr. Korabiak, who added that the riverfront is now so popular that the city no longer provides incentives to companies willing to relocate along it.
The single most ambitious project of the Redevelopment Agency is the San Jose Civic Plaza, a seven-block redevelopment project that would bring City Hall back to downtown San Jose, together with a new Symphony Hall, a new elementary school, a renovated supermarket, a multitiered public parking structure and 50 housing units. The City Council approved the project in June.
But downtown housing remains an unrealized ambition. Elsewhere in Santa Clara County and in San Jose, the expansion of computer-related businesses has stimulated home development and prices. At the end of July, existing single-family houses in San Jose were selling for an average of $400,657, while condominiums were selling for an average of $228,576, according to the Santa Clara County Association of Realtors. In 1994, the average single-family house sold for $238,258; the average condominium price was $150,575.
Downtown, the 104-unit Paseo Villas condominium complex, currently under construction, is being built by Goldrich & Kest Inc. of Los Angeles with the assistance of the Redevelopment Agency. The agency contributed the land and is a partner in the venture. Completion is expected next March.
Although the developer has not yet set prices for the units, comparable condominiums in the area are selling for $250 to $300 a square foot, "which is not that high for the area," according to Mr. Korabiak. The condos, all two-bedrooms, will range from 1,600 to 1,900 square feet.
The 320-unit apartment complex, known as 101 San Fernando, is being built by Forest City Enterprises Inc. of Cleveland. Completion is expected in fall 2000. Rents have not been announced, although city officials say they expect the apartments to rent for about $1.85 per square foot. The apartments will range from a 421-square-foot studio to a 1,390-square-foot three-bedroom. The city agency assisted the project by buying the land from the developer and leasing it back for 55 years, which gave the developer cash to build the project.
"You have a lot of people with well-paying jobs looking for places to live that are closer to where they work," said Greg Anderson, vice president for development at Forest City, "and we are responding to that with this project."
The city allowed the developer to build up to 107 units per acre, making 101 San Fernando the densest housing project ever built in downtown San Jose, and possibly in the entire city.
"These are densities that are comparable to those in Berlin and Vienna," said Daniel Solomon, a San Francisco-based architect who designed the complex. With the high densities, civic leaders can concentrate housing in certain areas of downtown to create a natural customer base for neighborhood merchants.
The architect and the city collaborated to produce a design for the apartment building that would not seem imposing or impersonal, Mr. Solomon said. He provided seven separate entrances to the building, each with its own small courtyard. In this way, the large building resembles a row of smaller courtyard apartment buildings.
The multiple entrances of 101 San Fernando also have an urban design role: the street is enlivened with doorways, rather than deadened by impenetrable walls.
Housing is the "final ingredient" needed to make downtown San Jose successful, Mr. Anderson said. The city has "done a lot, and the downtown has hotels and restaurants, it has night life, and the retail is coming along."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 3-Story Addition at Bleecker and Sixth;
'Little' School Grows Bigger

 BODY:
A school house it is. And red, too. But little?
While the addition to the Little Red School House at Bleecker Street and the Avenue of the Americas has only three stories and a basement, it was a colossal undertaking for the parents and alumni of the 78-year-old progressive school, which prides itself on its socio-economic diversity. 
 "It's not just a new building," said Eve Stuart, the chairwoman of the board. "It's a new school."
The red-brick structure adjoins and links the existing lower school at 196 Bleecker Street, built in 1920 as a mission of the First Presbyterian Church, and the middle school at Nos. 200 and 202, two 19th-century row houses. It stands in what was the school's courtyard, overlooking a triangular slice of park bearing an official sign: "Little Red Square."
The building is to be ready for the beginning of school next Thursday. Construction costs are about $3 million, financed by an Industrial Development Agency bond. Some $2.2 million has been raised in a $4 million campaign to provide tuition aid, new technology and furnishings and to reduce the strain on the operating budget in retiring the bond.
The architects are David Piscuskas, a Little Red parent; Juergen Riehm and Carmen Lenzi of 1100 Architect (so called because its first office was in Room 1100 at 225 Lafayette Street).
"This building creates a hub," Mr. Riehm said. "It connects buildings that were disconnected into a campus." Because the other buildings had different floor levels, an expensive elevator was required with front and rear doors capable of stopping at eight different points in its four-story trip.
Small as it is, the new building is full of surprises. The middle school art studio on the third floor, which replaces a basement classroom, has a peaked skylight reaching a height of 13 feet. Under a broad expanse of sky and through the veil of a sycamore tree outside, one can see the steeple of Our Lady of Pompeii Roman Catholic Church nearby.
The 100-seat cafeteria in the basement has a clerestory window that makes it seem more luminous than most underground halls -- at least on a sunny summer afternoon. It is also distinguished by an undulating ceiling of ash-wood louvers.
And though the courtyard was lost, there is a 575-square-foot outdoor play area on a roof deck. The speckled rubber safety tiles make a squishy-crunchy sound under foot -- a child's delight.

HEADLINE: Mercy College Head Extends Her Hand

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: DOBBS FERRY

 BODY:
LUCIE LAPOVSKY is an educator on a mission: to enrich the economy with untapped talent from an unlikely source -- the ranks of students that other colleges often turn away.
As Mercy College's newest president, Dr. Lapovsky, the former chief financial officer for Goucher College in Towson, Md., recently took up residence in a spacious office overlooking the Hudson River here -- along with a sprawling collection of paperweights brought with her from her previous job. "I want them close by," she said of the colorful glass objects. "They encourage me to keep dreaming." 
 One recent morning shortly before the fall semester began, Dr. Lapovsky took time to discuss those dreams and describe the nontraditional students she has staked her career on. Among others, the students include dropouts, troublemakers, the offspring of families with no tradition of higher education, students with little or no money for college courses and those who work during the day and have little time for the usual social activities associated with college life.
"Among this group," she said, "lie society's hidden jewels."
An economist by training (she earned a doctorate in economics from the University of Maryland in 1981), Dr. Lapovsky said she was motivated less by ivory tower philosophies and esoteric social theories than by dollars and cents and statistical realities. Describing herself as an educator with the dream of giving students a helping hand in the world, she said that that did not necessarily mean she was a bleeding-heart liberal or do-gooder.
"I'm just a very practical, reality-oriented person," she said. "The fact is that if we don't nurture students like these, we run the risk of a society of haves and have-nots, where only the elite run the country and there is no middle class."
Even though one of its primary goals is to attract nontraditional students, the college does not have an open-admissions policy, which accepts all applicants. Mercy tests incoming students to weed out those who do not have the basic skills necessary for college-level courses, accepting about 70 percent of students who apply.
A decade ago, by serving students with weaker academic credentials, Mercy cashed in on an overlooked college population in the late 1980's and early 90's and headed off bankruptcy, Dr. Jay Sexter, the former president said then. Dr. Sexter is stepping down to teach psychology, most likely, at Mercy College.
Enrollment at Mercy College was 4,800 in 1990; it was up by 46 percent, to 7,000, four years later, under Dr. Sexter's direction. He increased enrollment through new program offerings. It now has an enrollment of 9,500 students, among them 1,500 graduate students.
The college, which has a $68 million yearly budget, relies mostly on tuition for its income, said Edward (Ted) Dunn, chairman of the Mercy College board of trustees and a former Mayor of Rye. In addition to balancing its budget now, it also maintains a surplus.
In a unanimous vote in April, the trustees elected Dr. Lapovsky the eighth president, and Mr. Dunn said that he hoped that under her tutelage, the college would become "less tuition dependent" and significantly increase its present $20 million endowment.
Recently named one of Maryland's Top 100 Women by the Maryland Daily Record, a business journal published in Baltimore, Dr. Lapovsky, also taught economics at Goucher, from which she graduated in 1972. Before her appointment as chief financial officer of Goucher, she was a special assistant to the president at the University of Maryland at College Park. She has also held administrative posts at the Maryland Higher Education Commission.
She writes for college and university professional publications and lectures extensively around the country about college tuition pricing policies. Dr. Lapovsky serves as treasurer of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools and is chairwoman of the National Association of College and University Business Officer's Financial Aid Advisory Committee.
She is the mother of three children, 15, 18 and 20. Her husband, David, is an executive vice president for a media research firm.
Mercy -- an independent, coeducational institution with its main campus here and branches in White Plains, Yorktown and the Bronx -- offers more than 80 undergraduate and 25 graduate programs. Its graduate school offers master's degree study in acupuncture and Oriental medical, physical and occupational therapy, nursing and speech therapy, among other fields of study.
Tuition at the four-year college and graduate school is $8,000 a year, compared with yearly tuition at institutions like Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, where tuition is $24,810 a year.
Mercy College also suffers from an image problem -- an issue that most Mercy insiders choose to sidestep. To date the college has kept a low profile in the community, offering little in the way of cultural activities like poetry readings and concerts to outsiders -- a situation that Dr. Lapovsky said she wants to change.
"Let's just say we don't have an image yet," she said. "A lot of people aren't even aware that we exist."
The vice chairman of the trustees, Richard Rosenblatt, agreed, saying that although he lived barely a block from the college, "For years I didn't know about it."
Job recruiters, however, know it well, returning each year to draw teachers, industry workers and other skilled graduates into the labor force, Mr. Dunn said.
So far, though, it is a college with only a modest list of famous alumni -- "Obviously not a Cornell or a Columbia or an N.Y.U." is the way that Barbara W. Flynn, an Assistant State Education Commissioner described it.
Still it has attracted the attention of some well-known students -- like Mookie Wilson, a former first baseman with the New York Mets in the 1980's who graduated from Mercy in 1996. Mr. Wilson was 33 credits shy of graduating from the University of South Carolina when he was signed to play professional baseball; his famous single produced a series-winning run in the 1986 World Series. Then when he was 40 and retired from professional baseball, he received a bachelor's degree in behavioral science at Mercy College's 58th commencement.
Another well-known alumnus is Walter Anderson, editor in chief of Parade Magazine, author and Clinton appointee to the National Commission on Libraries and Information Science. Mr. Anderson graduated in 1972 and later became a member of the Horatio Alger Association -- the "poor boy who makes good club," he said.
Mr. Anderson, a trustee emeritus of Mercy and chairman of its board for eight years, dropped out of high school at 16, entered the Marines and returned to graduate as a valedictorian first from Westchester Community College and then Mercy College.
Joan Demarest Wolf, author of more than 15 historical novels, graduated in 1965. And Wesley Walker, a former All-Pro wide receiver with the New York Jets, graduated with the class of '88.
In Westchester, Donald W. Ferraro, the police chief of Scarsdale, received his bachelor's degree from Mercy College in 1974. And Michael Mosca, chief of police in Mount Vernon, got a bachelor's degree in 1997 and a master's degree in organizational leadership the next year.
This fall, students like Susanna Seifu of Ethiopia, Kara Alverson from Saratoga, Angel Santiago from the Hell's Kitchen section of Manhattan and Jordan Ray from Southampton are hoping they will add to Mercy's College list of distinguished graduates.
Ms. Seifu, 27, was living in Stockholm before she came to Mercy to study journalism. Ms. Alverson, 24, is studying for a master's degree in school counseling. Like many of the other students, they work on campus during the day to pay for tuition and attend classes at night.
Mr. Santiago, who is 23 and majoring in English, described himself as a "typical kid from New York City who did a lot of bad things" and is now the first in his family to attend college. He hopes to become a writer. Mr. Ray is also 23, majoring in English and planning to become a writer. "Like Angel," he said, "I did not leave myself a lot of opportunities when I was growing up." Mr. Ray earns his tuition working as a secretary in Dr. Lapovsky's office and covers his room and board by serving as a student in charge in one of the college's dormitories.
In January, the magazine Black Enterprise named Mercy College the fifth best regional college offering a liberal arts education to black students. Based on enrollment percentages, the State University of New York in Westbury was first, Ramapo College in Mahwah, N.J., second, the University of Houston third and Marymount Manhattan College fourth.
About 27 percent of Mercy College students are black, 34 percent Hispanic and 33 percent white.
In the Kaplan/Newsweek College Catalog 2000, a new guide to campuses deemed exceptional by high school guidance counselors, three Westchester County colleges are listed. Sarah Lawrence College is cited for its strong liberal arts education and for the individual academic attention students receive. Manhattanville College in Purchase was cited for liberal arts studies and an overseas study program. Pace University in White Plains was noted for offering credit for on-the-job experience.
In U.S. News & World Report's most recent guide to top colleges, Purchase was one of the North's top-ranked liberal arts schools, and Manhattanville was cited as one of the nation's most diverse campuses. The top college overall was California Institute of Technology, which surpassed Harvard University, Princeton University and Yale University, last year's winners.
The rankings were based on, among other things, Scholastic Achievement Test scores, the percentage of freshmen who go on to graduate, faculty pay, class size and student-faculty ratio.
Mercy College, which was founded in 1950 as a junior college under the auspices of the Sisters of Mercy, became a four-year college offering programs leading to a bachelor's degree 11 years later. In 1969, its board of trustees agreed that the college should become independent and nonsectarian. It employs 156 full-time and more than 500 part-time faculty members.

HEADLINE: Teacher Glut, Substitute Gap

BYLINE: By ALLAN RICHTER 

 BODY:
WHEN Tara Edwards set out to land a Long Island teaching job this spring, she circulated 78 resumes and won interviews with four school districts. This week, with the taste of postage glue gone, the 22-year-old West Babylon resident will begin her first paid teaching post -- as a full-time substitute in a Copiague elementary school.
Ms. Edwards, who graduated from SUNY Oneonta, will earn no health benefits in the provisional post. And her $85 daily take will be only $10 more than the Copiague Union Free School District pays its more transient substitutes. But she counts herself fortunate. Only a quarter of the 20,000 teachers churned out annually by New York universities find jobs in the state, and Long Island teaching posts are among the most coveted. 
 "Just to have your resume looked at is an accomplishment," Ms. Edwards said.
Yet against all conventional wisdom, the supply from that large reservoir doesn't seem to be meeting the Island's intense demand for substitute teachers. Some said the shortage could disrupt classes and drain school budgets if left unchecked.
"When you have a revolving door and you're not even certain that you can cover a class with a certified person or who that person might be, it inevitably takes a toll on the continuity and quality of education," said Candee Swenson, president of the Suffolk County Council of Superintendents.
In the past year, at least 40 of the Island's 126 school districts have adopted measures to attract more substitute teachers, Dr. Swenson said. Some districts are offering their first pay raises to substitutes in years. Others have hired more certified teachers to work as full-time substitutes.
Two factors have contributed to the shortage of substitute teachers: a healthy local economy and notoriously low daily salaries for substitutes.
"People have more employment options in this economy, and that applies particularly to substitutes and other temporary workers," said Gary Huth, a state Labor Department economist.
One of the more dramatic pay increases was enacted in the Longwood Central School District, where Dr. Swenson is superintendent. Math and science substitutes who earned $65 a day will earn $100 a day this year. Substitutes in less-strained subject areas will draw $75 a day.
On Long Island, substitute teachers on average earn $75 a day, according to a survey of 92 districts earlier this year by the Copiague district. Half the districts said they employed full-time substitutes, but only a quarter of the districts that employ permanent substitutes said they offer them health insurance or other benefits.
"It's more attractive for people to come work for us if we can say to them we can guarantee you an assignment every day," said Terry Bouton, executive personnel director at the Northport-East Northport district. The district employs permanent substitutes in its high school and is bringing full-time substitutes into its elementary and middle schools for the first time this year.
State law allows a school district to hire uncertified substitutes for a total of 40 days each year. But two-thirds of the districts responding to the Copiague survey said they hired only substitutes who had state teaching certification.
The Western Suffolk Board of Cooperative Educational Services has been under pressure to boost daily pay rates because its teachers must be certified in the special-education programs it provides to 18 districts, said Jennifer Sneed, the agency's executive personnel director. In July, the agency's board increased the daily rate by $5, to $70. It also cut in half the 40 days that substitutes had to be on board to qualify for another $5 raise.
Demand for substitutes has also grown because the state's new, tougher educational standards has induced more teachers to take time away from class to attend training sessions and to score the new standardized tests. Sandy Rosenberg, personnel director at the Kings Park district, said last year's fourth-grade tests jolted the district's teaching staff.
"We had to send 18 teachers out for two days in the fourth grade alone, and that's just one example," Ms. Rosenberg said. "All the other districts had the same constraints and that's why we couldn't get subs; we were all sharing them."
Over the summer, Kings Park interviewed candidates to fill 22 permanent substitute positions -- up from 10 two years ago -- that it will need this year to continue accommodating the state requirements, Ms. Rosenberg said.
Roseanne DeFabio, an assistant commissioner at the state Education Department, said she expected the teacher absences spurred by the fourth-grade tests to abate.
"I don't think there will be that great a demand for that many absences as the years go on and people become used to the test," Ms. DeFabio said. "The scoring will go more easily and there won't be as much need for training days."
The Copiague district has decided to double its permanent substitute roster to 10 in the new school year rather than raise its $75 daily substitute rate.
"We kicked around whether it be worth it to increase the pay another $5 or $10," said Charles Leunig, the district's personnel director. "The conclusion we reached was we would simply be spending the additional money on the people we already have, that it wouldn't necessarily bring us more people. We'd be throwing our money away and unfortunately we can't put out a giant increase and make it $100 a day, which would conceivably have an impact."
The Riverhead district reached a similar conclusion, but too late. In the last school year, the district raised its daily substitute rate from $65 to $75 -- its first substitute pay increase in at least five years -- but administrators said the effort attracted few new substitutes.
Now the Riverhead district is counting on permanent substitutes and is considering other solutions, such as dismissing students early on staff development days.
But David Carlson, the district's finance manager, said that he expects Riverhead to continue to face substitute shortages for at least several years as the district moves its permanent substitutes into staff teaching posts with benefits -- precisely the goal that motivates teachers to take the full-time substitute jobs.
Some teachers are skeptical. Alyssa Brodie, 24, had substituted in Long Island districts for six months when she turned down a permanent substitute post. "My thought was it would be a good foot in the door, but there were no benefits, no job security, and it's not your own classroom so it doesn't even look good on your resume," she said.
Instead she took a job teaching elementary school in New York City for two years. It is that experience, she believes, that helped her win the job she will start this week: teaching fourth grade in Hewlett.
"I didn't get this job because I was a substitute teacher," she said.

HEADLINE: From Here to There and Back

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
A QUARTER of a century after Westchester County took charge of the area's bus routes, the system is said to be one of the most cost effective in the state but has been able to do little to get people out of their cars.
The Bee-Line System, as it is known, operates as a public-private partnership and carries about 30 million passengers a year, or 100,000 rides a day, making it the 35th largest system in the United States. While the County Transportation Department says that every commuter who switches from driving a car to public transit saves 200 gallons of gas a year and eases the region's congestion and pollution, most of Westchester's residents have still not found public transportation the way to get from there to here. And, officials say, they probably never will. 
 "Most of us in suburbia drive our own private cars, but the bus system is essential," said George S. Latimer, a Democrat from Rye and chairman of the Westchester County Board of Legislators. "When I was a kid growing up in Mount Vernon in the early 1960's and we had just one car, the bus system was a life line. Today I don't personally need the bus system, but that doesn't mean there aren't people who do need it. And the constituency that does need it is one whose voice isn't always heard."
The county's Department of Transportation says 14 percent of Westchester residents ride the Bee-Line system, with 70 percent of them depending on the system for their transportation needs, usually as a way to get to work. A department analysis of ridership shows that 70 percent of the riders earn less than $35,000 a year, 51 percent are black, 26 percent white and 10 percent Hispanic and 48 percent are between 25 and 44.
"There are a lot of class issues, but these could be overcome,"said Maureen M. Morgan of Ossining, a past president of Federated Conservationists of Westchester County, an environmental group, and herself an avid supporter of public transportation. "Overall, the more critical aspect of the bus system is its perception and the perception of its riders. The majority of bus stops are just pieces of dirt and there is a negative message that this gives to riders and nonriders. There are many people who won't take the bus because it's just so uncomfortable to stand in the rain and wait for a bus."
Interviews with those actively involved with the bus system or longtime observers of it suggest that apart from the fare ($1.40) there is general satisfaction with the bus system in the southern part of the county. The Board of Legislators last year rejected a proposal from County Executive Andrew J. Spano to raise the fare a dime.
There also seems to be a general consensus that many routes in northern Westchester are not economically feasible, since residents there do not use the buses enough.
Back when Mr. Latimer rode the bus as a teen-ager, there was no centralized county system. Instead, recalled Dr. Sal Prezioso, who has held various paid and voluntary jobs in county government for decades: "We had 40 bus lines in the mid-1950's. Then if you went from one village to another, you needed another bus. People were screaming like the devil."
All this began to change in the closing days of the administration of the late County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian, and in the early days of the administration of his successor, Alfred B. DelBello, who took office in 1974. Mr. DelBello was influenced by several things: a new state law that gave counties the authority to control buses, generous reimbursement from the Federal and state governments to counties that bought buses (as much as 95 percent) and the continued acquisition by Liberty Lines of Yonkers of a number of other private bus companies. Instead of going in the direction of Nassau County and taking over the buses and running the system as a public entity, Mr. DelBello created a public-private bus system.
Under that relationship, still in effect today, the county government buys and owns the buses, which it leases to the private bus companies for a nominal fee. The private companies operate the buses on routes determined by the county (now 34 regular routes, plus special routes like express service to Manhattan), collecting fares determined by the county. In return, the county guarantees the private companies a certain profit. Today, the Department of Transportation has four contractors (Liberty being the largest), operates more than 350, and has the Paratransit system, a door-to-door reservation system for the disabled, which uses an additional 54 vans that serve 3,700 riders. Besides the four contractors, there are also two separate contractors that provide services under the Paratransit system.
"What we have today is good to a degree," said Dr. Prezioso, who headed the Westchester 2000 Task Force, a citizens group appointed in the late 1980's by Andrew P. O'Rourke, who was then the County Executive, to look into the county's needs for the millennium. "While people in the upper part of the county -- including me in Pound Ridge -- don't benefit much, the southern people do. At the time the system was created, the mission was that we would take care of the inner cities. They were dying and people were screaming about the need for public transportation and about traffic."
Mr. DelBello, who is now in private law practice, said: "It's an excellent system. It has always run at less cost per passenger mile than other systems."
Jerry D'Amore, president of Liberty Lines, said that the county system has the lowest cost in the region: 37 cents a passenger mile and $1.97 a trip compared with 51 cents and $2.62, respectively, for the Nassau County system. With the fare for a single trip $1.40 and quantity discounts available for regular riders, the county government must rely on state and county subsidies to meet expenses. As projected in the county's 1999 budget, bus operations (regular bus service and the paratransit system for the disabled) will have a net cost to county taxpayers of about $10 million this year -- an amount that represents about 1.5 percent of the county tax levy. Officials like Marvin V. Church, the county's Transportation Commissioner, remain concerned that the number could go higher in future years because the Federal Government has stopped all bus subsidy funds and the state has been decreasing its bus subsidies. "We have a very unstable state funding mechanism," he said.
The department is therefore studying the routes to determine which are the most used. For example, Route 84, from Putnam to Westchester, was eliminated in June, based on an analysis that showed it had 40 round-trip riders and cost $400,000 a year to operate. In addition, the department is focusing efforts on attracting new riders on special routes. As outlined by Mr. Church, here are some of the initiatives and plans:
*Beginning Tuesday, with $600,000 in funds from the state, the county is starting a one-year experimental route from the Franklin Delano Roosevelt State Park in Yorktown to the White Plains Trans Center. The nonstop route, with four round trips each day, hopes to attract people to White Plains and possibly to a connecting bus route on nearby Central Avenue that travels to Manhattan. Parking at the park is free and for the first month, so, too, will be the bus rides, said Susan Tolchin, director of communications for the county. The county received permission from the state to allow the buses on the Taconic State Parkway, something that had been forbidden.
*With welfare to work programs required of the county government, the bus system will work with the county's Department of Social Services to develop programs that should help former welfare recipients. Possibilities include day care at some central sites near railroad stations that serve as bus stops.
*The County Transportation Department is looking into running more reverse-commute buses, which would take people from Manhattan to Westchester at rush hour, as well as expanding bus service to serve commuters from the train stations.
*The department says it would like to have better communications with developers who are considering offices in the county so that before they commit to a certain area they have investigated the feasibility of bus routes for their employees.
For information about the county's Bee-Line bus routes, the number to call is 682-2020.

HEADLINE: Q&A/M. Jody Rell;
The Job of Lieutenant Governor Is Good Fit for This Republican

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT'S 105th Lieutenant Governor, M. Jody Rell, is the first Republican woman to hold the position. She laughs at all the speculations and "what ifs" concerning her future. What if Texas Gov. George W. Bush wins the Presidency and what if Connecticut Governor John G. Rowland joins his administration? The Lieutenant Governor would automatically inherit the seat in that scenario. She deflects the questions about running for seat by pointing out that Mr. Rowland enjoys being governor, there are no term limits in Connecticut, it is premature to discuss the elections and she would very much like to see him run again. 
 What if he decided not to? Finally, she said: "If he chooses not to, I am the kind of person who looks at an opportunity and never says 'no' to an opportunity if it is something I want to do. Right now I'm very happy doing the job of Lieutenant Governor."
She comes to the office with 10 years' experience as a Representative from the 107th District, Bethel and Brookfield where she still lives with her husband, Louis, a retired airline pilot.
Recently she met to discuss the Lieutenant Governor's job and her plans for the next year. Following are excerpts from that conversation:
Q. What does the Lieutenant Governor do?
A. By the powers of the State Constitution the Lieutenant Governor serves as Acting Governor in the event that the Governor is incapacitated or goes out of state. He sends me a letter each time he goes out of state to say he will be away from this date and time to this date and time. Our Governor has a great sense of humor and the first time he sent one of these letters he wrote a little postscript that said "Stay away from the notch."
 T. Clark Hall, the Republican Lieutenant Governor under Gov. Thomas Meskill, decided with his sense of humor he would invade Massachusetts and reclaim the notch. The notch is the little part on the top of the state that is cut out and belongs to Massachusetts. So while the Governor was away I made up a copy of a newspaper with a mock headline that said, "Rell vows to take back the notch."
Q. What does the Lieutenant Governor do with the legislature?
A. The other role is to preside over the State Senate. Connecticut is one of many states that have that role. As the president I have the power to break a tie vote. That is a constitutional power given to the Lieutenant Governor. I have done it on a couple of occasions, mostly on procedural matters.
It's more important now because in the first two years of the administration there was a Republican controlled Senate with a 19-17 margin. Now it is 17-19 the other way with the Democrats in the majority. Not everything they do up there is a partisan vote.
I think if there is one thing I am known for in the Senate it is the ability to be fair and to preside with an even hand. I have ruled equally against the Republicans and Democrats in breaking tie votes. Having had to break those ties I have never felt any remorse or regret.
Q. Does the Governor ask you to take on special tasks?
A. The Governor is asking me to head up a new study of technology for our public schools, universities and libraries. This group will basically get a handle on where we are, what's available and help to research what we can do to bring us into the new age. Frankly, I would like to think of Connecticut as being the shining star in this new technology. That's a challenge I'm looking forward to.
Q. Are you leading other projects?
A. The Governor asked me to chair a group to put together an economic revitalization plan for the City of Hartford. The Governor also said not to give him recommendations of anything that would simply be put on the shelf to gather dust. We've seen enough of those over the years and that was not the plan of action here. We reviewed the outstanding plans for development for the City of Hartford. We interviewed an awful lot of people about great plans and things they wanted to see done. We came to consensus. We met for about eight months. We came up with what we have since referred to as the six pillars of progress.
They are: The sports center complex, the much talked about stadium, the convention center, the parking garages or new parking facilities, the downtown higher education piece for the Community Technical College to oversee. That's the one that's probably going to come to the forefront first. Then there's a cleanup of some of the vacant buildings and vacant lots to ready them for development. Some of this is already taking place. I think Hartford is poised to see, as the Governor is fond of saying, "the cranes in the air and the shovel in the ground."
Q. Any other responsibilities?
A. One of the things that we are starting is called Connecticut Treasures. We are going to solicit from various organizations, like the Lions and Kiwanis, their Connecticut treasures, someone they would like to recognize. We would like to offer the Lieutenant Governor's recognition of a Connecticut treasure. We are not sure if we are going to do a citation or some other sort of presentation. It doesn't have to be a person, it could be a club or an organization. We are starting by sending out forms to Kiwanis Clubs and those types of organizations. We will put the forms in libraries and town halls. We would like to do this at least once a month.
Q. One of your biggest jobs is overseeing distribution decisions involving the Tobacco Settlement Agreements, about $3.6 billion over 25 years. How is that going?
A. The Governor has asked me to look at the tobacco settlement dollars that the state would anticipate seeing from the settlement and how best to use them. I met with the Commissioners of Public Health, Mental Health, Public Safety, a whole host of legislators and many others on what is the best use of this money. We need to do something to educate our youth on the dangers of smoking. We also hope to do as much as possible for those who have suffered the ravages of smoking. It's multifaceted. Connecticut has the unfortunate distinction of having the youngest age of children who start to smoke in the first place. That is age 11.
For the Department of Public Safety we would like to have more money for enforcement. You cannot sell cigarettes to those under age 18 but people don't pay attention to that. Enforcement needs to be increased.
Cessation programs need to be supported. Insurance companies may not pay for the nicotine patch, for example, and yet that may be the most effective way for someone to kick the habit.
People may be in nursing homes because of ill health due to years of smoking. Who is paying for that? Where do we get the money from? Who helps out?
When we looked at how best to spend all this money we broke it down into different categories. We also said one of the things you have to do is put money aside in a trust fund. Down the road we are going to be able to pay for the programs we are putting in place now. Nobody had the best idea of how to spend all that money immediately. I'm always a little bit cautious. So we took an immediate $20 million and set up a trust fund.
We earmarked $5 million for a media campaign, cessation programs, advertising and to set up a panel of 14 members who will actually help in future distribution of additional dollars.
Q. Do you miss your lack of privacy?
A. People think you have somebody do everything for you and forget you are a normal person. I go grocery shopping. I do laundry. Once, early on a Sunday morning I was grocery shopping and there was only one other lady and me. We both got to the checkout line. She asked me, "Has anyone ever told you look like the Lieutenant Governor?" And I said "No, she's better looking than I am." She started to laugh. Then she saw the car in the parking lot and saw my license plate. It says "L Rell," my husband's license plate. She said, "Oh you are Jody Rell! I didn't mean to bother you." I really don't mind.

HEADLINE: Q&A/Dr. William V. Costanzo;
Overseeing a World of Films and Talk

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
LEAVE your popcorn money home when you go to the Friday Night Film Series at Westchester Community College. It is definitely not part of the evening that Dr. William V. Costanzo, an English professor who runs the series, has in store for moviegoers.
Rather, the series at the college in Valhalla, entering its 35th season this month, will offer premovie refreshments, and then the agenda calls for serious film watching and animated discussions about what was seen. 
 A resident of Mount Kisco, Dr. Constanzo, 54, teaches literature, composition writing and film classes and has headed the film series since 1991. This year's offerings, which begin on Sept. 17 and end on Oct. 29, and their respective country of origin are "Central Station," Brazil; "The Apple," Iran; "Night of Cabiria," Italy; "Sherlock Jr.," the United States (a silent Buster Keaton film); "Underground," Serbia, and "Tango," Spain. Subscriptions for the series are $30 or $24 for older residents and can be reserved by calling 785-6700. Tickets for a single film are $6 ($5 for the elderly). Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Dr. Constanzo:
Q. What got you interested in film?
A. I discovered film when I began teaching, partly through my students and partly because I was given an opportunity to teach a film class the first year I was here. And I just became enthralled. I saw 364 movies that year. I was down in the city watching all the new wave movies and the South American movies and the Eastern European movies, and it just opened up a whole new world to me. I think what I liked about it was that expansive quality. You could just enter into completely different worlds.
Q. More so than with books?
A. In a way, yes. I always talk about this with my students -- what you miss when you are watching movies and not reading books and how much of the imaginative work of reading is given on the screen. You see the face, you cannot see anyone but that face. A movie is more of an immersive experience because there are sounds and visual elements that surround you in a film, and I like that.
There is a social dimension to being in a theater with other people being told the same story. In my literature classes, where we go back to Homer and to Anglo-Saxon times, we notice that storytelling has taken different form at different times. In Homer's time you passed the story down by word of mouth. And then there were epics passed down and recited at occasions where people got together and part of the experience was listening to the same story together and laughing and sharing tears, that sense of community.
Reading is essentially a solitary activity. Movies have restored some of that shared story listening, and I think that's important and why people come to our series. I love to stay at the end and hear what other people's perceptions are.
Q. How has the Film Series changed since you took it over?
A. I enjoy being in touch with the audience. So I began giving little introductory talks. People were coming up to me and felt a connection to me and the film. So I introduced discussions. Stanley Feingold, who headed this before me, had them occasionally, and I think that's what I enjoy the most. A 10-minute talk to introduce the film and there is an hour before when people are assembling for refreshments, and I like that sense of being part of the film community. I chat with the regular subscribers and meet some of the new people.
Q. How many people attend?
A. We have seats for just under 400, and I'd say about 300, 350 people come.
Q. People of all ages?
A. All ages but most of the people take advantage of the senior discount, so we have a very mature audience of people who are retired, who, I think, see this as an alternative to the multiplex phenomenon. They see it as a place to meet their friends week after week and discuss the latest movie they've seen and discuss the next one.
Q. What kind of movies do you personally like? Or do you like to call them films?
A. I do like movies and I like film and I sometimes appreciate cinema. I particularly enjoy international films and the classics. And that's mostly what I show. There is a phenomenon recently that I think has to do with the popularity of the movie "Life Is Beautiful," which was popular despite the fact that it's a subtitled film. I think we're seeing more and more theaters carrying subtitled films.
And I think that's part of a larger phenomenon. Every once in a while the Italians will make a really great, popular film, like "Cinema Paradiso," or "Il Postino." But I think it's part of the global village, as McLuhan called it, and the international economy and the sort of multicultural nation that we've become. There is more of an interest in other cultures. And more of a curiosity of how people live in other parts of the world.
Q. Curiosity by people of all ages, or more mature people?
A. I see more and more young people coming to our series, and it's often a new experience for them, and they're delighted. And also I see them coming to films like Buster Keaton's. Last season we showed "The General," and when we have silent films we always have live musical accompaniment. That's one of the highlights. Lee Erwin comes up on the train from New York once a year and sits down at his Steinway, and he plays original music to accompany the action. He goes way back. He studied the organ in Paris, and he created the original scores for all the Buster Keaton movies. So when he comes, he's a master and people adore him. And it's a real treat for people who have never seen a silent movie before. He'll be here again this season. We're doing "Sherlock Jr.", which is the movie where Buster Keaton jumps into the movie screen and becomes part of the movie.
There is another phenomenon. I think as we reach the 100th anniversary of the history of movies we're much more conscious of preserving our heritage as literature of the 20th and 21st centuries. So there has been a lot of attention to the classics and refurbishing them. We're showing "Nights of Cabiria," which was redone last year with a new print and subtitles you can read, a new sound track, and they've restored one of the sequences that was censored by the Roman Catholic Church when it came out in 1957.
Q. What do you think of the state of popular movies at this point. Are they too oriented toward making a quick buck?
A. For many years I adjudicated a New York young filmmakers program, and I got a chance to see a lot of what young filmmakers were making, and I think they begin by imitating. And what they imitate is the technique of movie making -- because young people don't have that much to say.
They haven't lived much of a life. But they have a wonderful visual sense. They have been honed on all those wonderful video games and television shows. So they have technique in search of something to say. As they get older, they learn to make connections between more and more things in their lives but there certainly is a great interest now in independent filmmaking -- there is an explosion. It's partly because it's easier to make films and to get them distributed. You can distribute your movie now on the Internet. It's a little scary, too.
Q. Who do you admire of American filmmakers. Spielberg for his imagination?
A. Spielberg is an interesting example of someone who has matured. He began with wonderfully crafted films, and his movies were very successful because he really understood American audiences. And as he got older he began going into deeper subjects -- the Holocaust, black America. So we'll probably see that with a lot of other independent filmmakers as well.
Quentin Tarantino is a big hero among my students. His movies are scary, filled with quirky acts of violence, and I think older audiences don't respond to that. This is always one of the debates that come up when you have both younger and older audiences together.
Younger people see a lot of screen violence as part of the choreography of cinema. They don't see it as aspects of violence connected to real people and real suffering, and it doesn't bother them. The same is true of what is called adult language. A lot of older people are disturbed by the profanity of some movies. But for kids, it's just filler words.
 
http://www.nytimes.com
