HEADLINE: As Economy Continues Surge, Sailors' Dreams Turn to Yachts

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
LAST winter, when Ray Kish went looking for a new sailboat to replace the 25-foot Catalina he had sailed for 12 years in a Pennsylvania lake, he knew he wanted a bigger boat, but all he had intended to buy was a 30-footer.
But Mr. Kish didn't like the way the cabin of the 30-foot model was laid out, so instead, last April he and his wife, Bonnie, bought a Catalina 42, which he described as "our summer home." 
 The single-mast sloop, Marketeer, is 14 feet wide at the beam, and has a full galley, two bathrooms and three staterooms. It is packed with electronic gear, including radar, a depth finder, and an auto-pilot. Mr. and Mrs. Kish have spent every free hour this summer on board, sometimes just relaxing at the dock at Captain's Cove marina in Bridgeport or sailing off for a weekend or a week to to visit Block Island and Martha's Vineyard.
"At the age of 55, you only go around once," Mr. Kish explained. "I know many people my age who never had the opportunity to live out their dream."
This summer, more people are living out their dreams along the Connecticut shoreline than ever before. The repeal of a 10 percent luxury tax, low interest rates and a strong economy have combined to push boat sales to the boom levels of the mid-1980's.
Boats of every size and for every corner of the market have sold well, but for vessels large enough and sufficiently well appointed to be called yachts, the difference has been the most dramatic. Salesmen have reported shortages of both new and used boats at the top end of the market, those costing more than $100,000, and marinas are hard-pressed to find dock space for them.
These large vessels are as costly as a vacation house, and often more luxurious, so Mr. Kish's metaphor is no exaggeration. He purchased his boat second-hand and declined to say what it cost, but noted that a new Catalina 42 like his would cost around $200,000.
His neighbor at the end of the next dock, Michael Lenihan, wanted to live aboard his boat, and he wanted to live well. If Mr. Kish's sailboat is a vacation home, Mr. Lenihan's Carver 42 aft-cabin motor yacht, Wild Thing, is, he said, "like a floating, very elaborate apartment in Manhattan."
Mr. Lenihan's boat has two salons, two staterooms, a bridge, a full-sized refrigerator in the galley, and three-zone air conditioning and heating. He also declined to say what he paid for his boat, which was purchased second-hand, but noted that a new Carver 42 costs around a half-million dollars.
He is a pilot for United Airlines who flies Boeing 747's from New York to Tokyo and back, a job that keeps him busy only six to nine days a month.
The rest of the time he travels around the Sound, visiting the many harbors and often tying up in Newport, R.I., where a friend of his owns a restaurant.
"You can get more out of life living on a boat," he said, sounding very relaxed.
Dan Brewster, a retired engineer from Westport whose Monterey 33 express cruiser, Judy's Joy, is docked near Mr. Lenihan's boat.
"He just travel around and see what we can see," Mr. Brewster explained.
What they see along the shorelines and islands of Southern New England, New York and Long Island is considered by some boaters to be one of the most congenial places for shoreline cruising in the United States.
"We've got some of the best cruising areas in the country," said Grant Westerson, executive director of the Connecticut Marine Trades Association. "You can touch three states in an afternoon if you plan your trip carefully."
Although he said he had no statistics and the Department of Environmental Protection couldn't furnish any, either, Mr. Westerson said boat sales have been climbing steadily for three years. "We've probably seen, over the last three years, a 60 percent increase," he said.
One of the chief reasons is Congress's repeal in 1993 of a 10 percent luxury tax on boats costing more than $100,000 that had stalled the luxury boat business severely after it was passed in the late-1980's.
Combined with the recession that occurred then, the tax drove many boat manufacturers out of business.
With few boats being built and even fewer being sold earlier in the decade, there is now a shortage of fairly new, large second-hand sailboats and powerboats for sale.
"Five- or six-year-old boats are like hen's teeth," said Mr. Westerson. "You can't find any. Boat brokers are having as much trouble getting boats to sell as new boat dealers are."
Jeff Marshall, owner of Sailing Specialties in Groton, which sells new and used sailboats, said every size boat, from nine-foot boats to 60-foot luxury yachts, sell almost immediately if they are in good condition. He said the boom was related mostly to the good economy.
"People are confident in the economy, interest rates are low and people are more willing to spend on a luxury," he said.
For someone to buy a boat, Mr. Kish said banks will loan the purchase price at 7.5 percent interest with no money down. He said the Federal Government also allows the owner to write off the interest payments just like mortgage interest, and Connecticut charges no property tax on them.
Jim Gardella, who operates Cove Marina and Norwalk Boat Sales in Norwalk, said his marina was full and dock space was very tight. "This is the first year our marina has no docks available since 1990, '91," he said.
A mainstay of the top end of the market for Mr. Gardella is the Ocean Alexander 42, which is comparable to Mr. Lenihan's Wild Thing.
"Every time we get one in we sell it," he said.
His son, Rob Gardella, showed off a new Ocean Alexander 42 while workers installed hardware and fittings. The boat has a salon with a parquet wood floor, a galley with a microwave/convection oven, and two staterooms, one with a queen-size bed. It also has radar, a global positioning satellite system and an auto-pilot device, which allows the owner to program its course and let the boat pilot itself.
"You can steer with your mouse and your laptop computer," he said. "That's the new thing."
The younger Mr. Gardella said the old term "cabin cruiser" is obsolete. The 42-foot Ocean Alexander is classified as a trawler, characterized by a conservative design, extended cruising range, and live-aboard furnishings. Norwalk Boat Sales was offering it for $446,125.
Smaller vessels with sleeker, more modern designs, that are faster but have shorter cruising ranges and less luxurious cabins, are known as express cruisers. Large vessels, 50 feet or longer, that are bigger, wider, and faster than trawlers are classified as flush-deck motor yachts. A 68-foot Ocean Alexander model costs nearly $2 million. Many of these yachts will be on display at the Norwalk Boat Show, Sept. 23-26, at Cove Marina.
Albin Marine Inc. makes diesel-powered cruising boats ranging from 28 feet to 39 feet long, and from $100,000 to $250,000 in price. The boats are made in Rhode Island, and the company is headquartered in Greenwich.
The company's owner, Fred Peters, said his sales are backlogged.
In the last three years, Mr. Peters said his sales have grown by 50 percent. He said he thought the growth had more to do with the improved economy than with the repeal of the tax. When people have money, they spend it.
"A boat is like a summer house," he said.
Still, like many other people in the boating industry, Mr. Peters spoke bitterly about the luxury tax. "Our industry was singled out," he said. "Trips to Hawaii were not singled out."
At Captain's Cove, Mr. Brewster said it took a while to get used to his 33-foot boat. Just last year he had bought a 23-foot boat, but "when I had the opportunity to retire early, my wife said, 'That boat is not going to do it.' " There were some tricks to learn to maneuver the new boat, 10 feet longer, into a dock slip.
Mr. Lenihan said he has already decided he wants a bigger motor yacht, a 55-footer with three staterooms, so he can entertain more guests and use one of the staterooms as a home office.
He had owned sailboats before, but he is very happy to own a powerboat instead. At age 40, he has grown tired of raising and lowering sails all the time.
"I'm done with that," he said. "All I want to raise and lower is my beer."

HEADLINE: KPFA;
Crossing Borders

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 I agree with Mr. Shere that it is time to return Pacifica stations to the communities that paid for them, and that the Pacifica board should step down. But much of the rest of Mr. Shere's thinking is inconsistent, politically naive and contemptuous of the very communities he refers to. 
 He writes that "the powerful transmitter at the commercial frequency of 94.1 megahertz is wasted on Pacifica as it now operates, and they would be right to sell it and use the money to encourage the development of a number of smaller stations, locally programmed, locally responsible, locally administered."
I am all for the development of small, locally administered stations, but I reject the assumption embedded in Mr. Shere's statement that local communities do not deserve, and should not administrate, a powerful transmitter.
Currently, 99.9 percent of the nation's powerful transmitters are given over to corporate propaganda, commercial pandering, religious indoctrination, unquestioned government pronouncements, context-less ahistorical soundbite news and ill-informed loudmouth talk show hosts. And all of it floats in a sea of musical offerings from media conglomerates that serve the mission of increasing their owners' wealth and influence. That's the real waste!
To think that small local stations alone can adequately grapple with the issues of our time is to ignore what has happened to the world since the 1960's. There are few purely local issues anymore. Globalization of the economy and transnational corporate domination of media and politics force local communities to make common cause across borders just to maintain their autonomy. Residents of a town in rural America are likely to find themselves in a struggle to prevent their home from being turned into a repository for another state's, or another country's, nuclear waste. Farmers in the United States must engage in dialogue with farmers in Britain and India to prevent the contamination of their crops by the products of transnational biotech firms. And residents of a tiny Pacific island will see their homeland submerged unless they can stop countries thousands of miles away from disgorging greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.
Far from being a waste, Pacifica radio is an antidote to the alienation and passivity fostered by the way mainstream media present news. Recent events have shown that only open, accountable administration of this national treasure can guard against its seizure for corrupt or self-serving purposes.
 
LYN GERRY
Waterloo, N.Y.
 
The writer is the editor of the Free Pacifica and Radio 4 All Web sites (www.radio4all.org), and is a former sponsor and staff member of Pacifica station KPFK in Los Angeles.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Counselors Move In and Then Tune In

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
ON a recent summer evening the haze had almost given way to darkness and 11-year-old twin brothers Brian and Byron Faulks were hanging out in one of the courtyards at the Farnam Courts Housing development in New Haven.
Not far away the nightly drug deals were just getting started, and groups of teen-agers clung together. One brazen young teen-ager with tattoos on both arms walked by with what appeared to be a handgun sticking out of his pocket. 
 But 20-year-old Pierre Gouborn stood near the twins and reminded them to stay away from trouble. It was a theme Mr. Gouborn, a former drug dealer himself, had touched on repeatedly throughout the summer while working as a counselor in a special year-round program serving 1,200 children in Connecticut's low-income communities.
Mr. Gouborn was among a group of college counselors who were spending the summer living in vacant apartments at the housing project so they could work both day and night with many of the young children. The nonprofit program, which was established in New Haven in 1992, is called Leadership, Education and Athletics in Partnership, or LEAP, and it is now in five of Connecticut's largest cities, including New Haven, Hartford, Bridgeport, New London and Waterbury.
"It's tough because these kids are growing up in such hopeless and impoverished conditions and they see dealers making big money and driving shiny new cars. I know what that's like because it happened to me," said Mr. Gouborn, who grew up in the Fairhaven section of the city.
Now an advertising major at Johnson & Wales University in Providence, R.I., Mr. Gouborn talks about how he left the drug trade several years ago after watching so many of his friends and relatives be killed.
That's something Margaret Sawyer, a Yale University senior who grew up in a Cleveland suburb, never faced. Ms. Sawyer spent this summer as a counselor working with young girls.
"It's been an amazing, eye-opening experience for me that I don't think would have been as powerful if I hadn't been actually living here," said Ms. Sawyer, gathered recently for a strategy session with several other LEAP counselors in one of the apartments the program provides for them throughout the summer.
The counselors -- sitting on old, gray couches, dirty and torn, placed on patches of musky, light brown carpet -- were living in conditions similar to many of the project's 218 families.
"The girls we work with are facing the temptations of teen-age sexuality that leads many of them into single motherhood by the time they are 14 or 15, as well all the drugs and violence they see on an almost daily basis," she said. "We try to help them by showing there is another way, that through education and social participation, they don't have to be resigned to this kind of life."
Helping inner-city children is what motivated Brad Williams after he arrived at Yale University from Little Rock, Ark., in 1992. He began working as one of the first counselors in the LEAP program, which had just begun. The program is financed by individual donors and foundations like the Kellogg Foundation as well as Federal grants and state grants.
Moses Nelson, then 9 years old, was one of the first pupils Mr. Williams worked with. Moses was born with the congenital white hair and skin pigment condition known as albinism.
Mr. Williams was a freshman majoring in psychology, economics and political science, and Moses was a special-education fourth-grader already pegged as a problem child with serious emotional and behavioral difficulties, and a bad attitude that stemmed in part from being constantly teased by his peers.
"I knew there was a lot more to him than what people could see at that point, and the more I worked with him the more I discovered what an incredible mind he had," Mr. Williams said. "As I gained his trust and worked to improve his reading and social skills, he began to thrive."
Now, Mr. Williams is executive director of LEAP, which has grown into a multifaceted year-round educational and social enrichment program with an emphasis on reading and literacy that is helping children in Connecticut's most impoverished inner-cities.
Moses now works with younger children between 7-14 and is one of the most popular high school counselors in the program.
"Before I met Brad and got involved in LEAP, I felt that I didn't fit in anywhere and I hated school," said Moses, a 16-year-old junior at Hill House High School and president of the Dixwell Community Center Youth Council. "When I was 9, I desperately needed a role model, and Brad inspired me to keep trying and never give up."
There are more than 125 college counselors in the program matched with the same number of high school counselors, and their job is to help poor children improve their reading and writing skills, and to develop a bond as mentors to help influence the youngsters about life choices as much as about academics.
"When the children see you are so committed that you're even willing to live in their neighborhood and work with them after hours, they take what you're trying to do a lot more seriously and open up in ways that would be impossible without that component," said Damian Arrington of Pittsburgh, a junior majoring in elementary education at South Carolina State University who has also spent the summer living at the Farnam housing project.
Mr. Arrington said he was getting the opportunity to "learn so much more about" his chosen occupation as an educator through real-life experiences "than by just sitting in a classroom or reading a textbook."
That was one of the goals of the nonprofit program's founder when it was established in one New Haven neighborhood seven years ago. Anne Tyler Calabresi, wife of the Federal judge and former Yale Law School dean, Guido Calabresi, said she wanted the program to help two entirely groups of young people.
"My vision was that this program could be a springboard to help children in cities throughout the state, and at the same time provide college and high school students with invaluable real-life experience for future careers in education, social work and whatever else they might want to pursue," Mrs. Calabresi said.
The children are encouraged to read aloud to their peers, engage in Internet-based computer technology projects, learn to resolve conflict, reflect on their lives in journals, take overnight camping trips and travel in groups to cities such as Washington, Boston, Chicago, Philadelphia, Atlanta and Toronto.
During the summer, public schools are used during the morning where 100 students are divided into groups of eight, where counselors work on both academics and engage the students in frank discussions about what's going on in their lives.
Educators say the program is making their job easier.
"The program not only reinforces the goals and missions of the New Haven Board of Education, it enhances and enriches the lives of children every day of the year through real-life experiences like trips to cities around the country," said Leroy C. Williams, principal of Roberto Clemente School in the Hill section of the city and one of five LEAP sites in New Haven.
"It's one thing to teach our pupils about the way the government works in Washington, but LEAP actually takes them there and shows them," Mr. Williams said.

LENGTH: 1190 words

HEADLINE: From Bungalows to Nouveau Chateaus, It's a Bang-Up Year for Knock-Downs

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: LOVELADIES

 BODY:
FOR the last decade or so, when Long Beach Islanders wanted to show off a distinctive house, they would take visitors to the 100 block of Long Beach Boulevard here and point them toward the unusual residence known, for obvious reasons, as the "Pyramid House."
But time moves quickly by the shifting sands at the Jersey Shore. A flurry of dollars has showered community and many other Shore towns, and it is snowing under even some landmarks. 
 "The Pyramid House, that is going bye-bye," said Gail Cook, the owner of HCH Real Estate in neighboring Harvey Cedars. "People bought it and it's coming down. President Nixon rented that house. All the ships at sea used that as a landmark. I'm sure the new house there will be gorgeous. Things are just changing at the Shore and little will be able to stop it."
There is little doubt that 1999 has been a bang-up -- or rather, a knock-down, build-up -- year in seashore real estate. Longtime observers say that from Long Beach Island to Cape May, they have never seen anything like the amount of homes being bought and demolished, only to be replaced by mansions.
"It's to the point now where people buy a four-bedroom, three-bath 15-year-old home and just mow it down with the furniture in it," said John Tracy, the building official in Avalon's construction department. "In the past, there might have been open land, or at least people would be happy with the house they bought. But there is clearly a lot of stock market money out there and people willing to spend it."
In 1995, a good year by most economic standards, Avalon issued only 20 demolition permits for house construction. This year, the borough matched that by March 1. In neighboring Stone Harbor, records show the first million-dollar property sold in 1995, and only one other house in that borough sold for more than $700,000. This year, by contrast, after four years of negligible inflation, 13 houses sold for more than $700,000 by May, and one of them for more than $3 million.
But even that seems a pittance only a few months later. One home in the dunes in Avalon is being offered for sale at $8 million; it has two pools and its expansive tropical architecture makes it look like a Miami Beach hotel. On Long Beach Island, one realtor, Benee Scola has a bayfront, six-bedroom property for sale here for $5,950,000.
"The bayfront is as good as the ocean these days," Ms. Scola said. "On the ocean, you have a limited outdoor space on which you can build. On the bay, you can have a tennis court, gardens, decks, a dock, whatever. People spend this kind of money, they want a great quality of life."
Yet this rising quality of life and its accompanying surge in expensive home building at the seashore is altering the quality of life.
"It is changing the complexion of these towns,' said David Swift, president of Citizens for Historic Preservation, a two-year-old Ocean City group that says it is opposed to rampant development in Shore communities. "People came here originally because it exuded a certain charm. Families came back summer after summer, people from all walks of life. Now it is becoming increasingly dense and expensive. How long will people be able to pay $3,500, $4,500 a week to rent?"
Mr. Swift, who has lived in Ocean City since moving there from Philadelphia in 1972, organized his group early last year when he noticed many of his favorite houses in town being torn down for what he said were monstrosities. He called for a demonstration in front of one of them on a cold day in January. In one sense, the demonstration was unsuccessful because the house was demolished anyway. But he also got 2,000 signatures on a petition in hopes of saving it, and since then his group has filed suit against the Ocean City government to stop the destruction of a circa 1885 lifesaving station at Fourth and Atlantic Avenues where developers want to erect three duplexes.
"The town just wants the additional ratables, but they forget about the stresses on things like the sewer system," Mr. Swift said."And the issue of the character of the town is very important. There will come a time when the economy is not so good, and then these places may well be abandoned. That will be doubly sad."
In the meantime, the tearing down and building up goes on apace. Ocean City alone issued 209 demolition and building permits in 1998 -- the largest number of any town in the state -- and another 102 by June of this year.
"Suppliers are getting short on materials and it is increasingly difficult to find qualified help in all areas right now," said David Fabbri, of Fabbri Builders in Vineland, which does home and commercial construction at the Shore. His prize right now is a huge frame house with a three-story turret that will provide an unobstructed ocean view a block from the beach on 100th Street in Stone Harbor. He is building it for a family member, "so it will be a little cheaper," but a smaller home nearby sold for $800,000 last year.
"Houses are now tending to be quite grand," Mr. Fabbri said. "Before, they were plain boxes. Now there is attention to every detail. I don't see it changing right now. People have money, as long as the stock market is booming."
Ms. Scola, the Long Beach Island realtor, said this particular building boom is different than the previous one in the mid-1980's in ways that make it seem like it will have more staying power.
"This is being fueled by the leading edge of the baby boomers, those in their 50's who are doing well financially," she said. "They are not looking for just a beach house, but something that maybe 10 years down the road they will retire to. They want central air-conditioning. They want gas heat for the winter. They want every amenity they can get and the old houses they are buying just don't have them.
"Back in the 1980's, too, lots of people were merely into just flipping houses here to make a profit," said Ms. Scola. "You know, they would want to say, I flipped this Shore house over in two months and made $50,000. This isn't a speculation market. It is much healthier this way."
Still, there is the admission among many that this latest spree is likely to change the character of many beach towns.
"There are more and more people here buying something that they feel will be distinctive," said Ms. Cook, the Harvey Cedars realtor. "It's about views, mostly. When the towns were first laid out, homes were built geometrically along a road. You were down at the beach to be at the beach. A water view didn't matter. Now people vie for the view and once they knock down a smaller house, they naturally need a bigger one to get that view."
And as prices go up and up, the average family may well lose even the dream of a beach house of its own.
"A second home transaction for $200,000 minimum, I don't think you can say that is for the common man any more," said Ms. Scola. "To have a beach house in a good town, you have to have done well enough to have discretionary income, it's true. But the lure of the ocean has always been great. We just have to make sure there is a place on the beach for everyone."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2637 words

HEADLINE: In Cape May County, a Time of Growing Pains

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE

 BODY:
GAIL DWYER, talking about the houses rising across the street from hers in Avalon, displacing the killdeer that used to roost there, wonders whether there will be an inch of green space left. "I took my first steps in Avalon," she said. "They're taking away too much of what people come here for."
On the beach along the other shore of Cape May County, Tim McGarvey of Turnersville, near Philadelphia, remembered aloud when there were just tiny bungalows behind the dunes. His wife, Darlene, said she used to drive down on Route 47 through glorious emptiness. When asked about the prospect of more development, she said, "Where are they going to put it?" 
 People on this sandy southern spit of New Jersey talk wistfully about the past, before the beauty of the place courted subdivisions and cinder-block chain stores. Since the future will only bring more of them, it is already cause for regret.
And this summer, the issue of growth has become combustible as never before, thanks to the convergence of two voluminous land-use plans for Cape May County. One would put in 100 miles of sewer lines, and the other would reconfigure the development allowed under the state's coastal protection law.
Environmental groups statewide have protested both, saying they will permit 50,000 more housing units in the county, which now has about 92,000 homes and 110,000 year-round residents. "It's hard to take a growth chart and see it," said Jody Carrara, project director for the New Jersey Association of Environmental Commissions, "but let your imagination picture 150,000 more people."
The estimate is disputed by developers and many local officials, who contend that the buildable land remaining in the county cannot accommodate anything close to that number.
"There's not that much left," said Grover R. Webber, environmental director of the county health department. "These guys are rattling their sabers, and I don't know what that's all about. It's not going to happen."
Passions are unusually high for debate over a sewer plan and a statute -- the Coastal Area Facility Review Act, called Cafra -- that most voters never heard of. "I've seen more fights coming out of Cape May County in the last two months than in the last decade," said Bill Neil, director of conservation for the New Jersey Audubon Society.
Environmental groups depict a battle to preserve what is left of the New Jersey shore and its water supply, to save a nationally critical bird habitat and to test the state's resolve on containing sprawl. "The implications on the state and national level are just so important because if we lose Cape May we lose New Jersey," said Jeff Tittel, president of the state chapter of the Sierra Club. "It's that much of a symbol. It's one of the last rural counties left, and the last one at the shore."
Judy Jengo, the deputy commissioner of environmental protection who is shepherding the revisions to the coastal review act, scheduled to take effect in December, said they were an especially touchy subject here. "Cape May does seem to be the case study," Ms. Jengo said.
Much of the state is directly affected by the coastal review act, enacted in 1973 to protect a band of waterfront from the Delaware Memorial Bridge to the Raritan Bay. But while other counties have fringes in the review's jurisdiction, almost all of Cape May County is within its sweep.
As such, the county has become a kind of testing ground for Governor Whitman's "smart growth" initiative to rein in sprawl.
THE current rules in the coastal review act require a site-by-site examination of plans for major developments. But the Legislature amended the law six years ago to require new rules consistent with the goals of the State Development and Redevelopment Plan, which would restrict building on rural and environmentally sensitive land and direct it to population centers. To that end, the Department of Environmental Protection designated existing development "centers" and four other types of land-use areas, assigning allowable densities for each.
Politically speaking, the department has been forced onto the narrowest of paths between those who say its rules would give away the store to developers and those who say it would chase them away from the Shore.
All along, the rules were attacked by development interests and by State Senator William L. Gormley, Republican of Atlantic County, who maintains that while the Whitman Administration is giving other communities money for open space, it is simply regulating the Shore into submission.
But then many environmental groups, ordinarily reliable advocates of smart growth, also turned against the plan, arguing that it would allow even the most restricted areas to become dotted with new houses.
Their larger complaint, however, is with the limits of the law itself: the coastal review act does not apply to housing developments of fewer than 25 units or commercial projects with fewer than 50 parking spaces. Because of the "Cafra loophole," Ms. Carrara said, "Cape May County is being lost to 24-unit developments."
The critics are gathering allies in the Legislature; Assemblyman Reed Gusciora, a Princeton Democrat, expects to announce legislation this week to close the loophole. "Developers are nickel-and-diming the Shore to death in 24-unit spurts," Mr. Gusciora said. "It's a statewide issue. Shore area legislators are always going to be fearful of retaliation from developers. It's going to be up to the inland legislators to push Cafra along. It's our Shore, too."
State Senator Gormley, of course, disagrees. He has repeatedly urged the Governor to change the whole planning process to allow local officials to devise their own shore-protection plans. "Whether people are coming from a sound environmental perspective or a political survival mode, they're not going to submit a map that would subvert the quality of life in the area," the Senator said in a telephone interview. "That would be stupid."
But Ms. Jengo described painstaking groundwork with hundreds of local officials. Even in mapping some of the centers, she said, "we met with them and asked, 'Do you want the lines here, or here?' "
Ms. Jengo also said that while the loophole was "a wild card," the new rules would allow development on only 2 percent of all of Cape May County's land area. "We're protecting vast amounts there," she said.
The department maintains that the change in rules does not affect the total amount of new construction allowed, but others' assessments vary wildly.
The Sierra Club, for example, which has counted up vacant acres in the hundreds of designated centers, predicts that they will undergo unprecedented building booms. But the New Jersey Builders Association has contended that local zoning rules and political opposition in already-developed areas makes them the hardest places to build.
Nancy Wittenberg, the association's director of environmental affairs, also said the department had provided no basis for calculating how much land in the centers was actually buildable. "We don't know whether those centers were drawn to reflect what's on the ground already, or whether they were drawn to accommodate some percentage of growth in the future," Ms. Wittenberg said. "If the boundaries are drawn around what's already there, it leads us to believe the department didn't do any analysis of growth."
In Cape May County, the fight proceeds acre by acre.
Douglas Jewell, a real estate agent and writer who has helped organize local opposition to both the sewer plan and the proposals for the coastal review, has much of the county's building and zoning mapped out in his head. On a driving tour with Ms. Carrara, he traced the path of the proposed sewer lines and pointed out parcels already claimed by developers.
"These wooded areas?" he said at one point in Middle Township. "Sewers are going in. The whole area could be rezoned for retirement communities."
Middle Township, the county's large midsection, is the township expected to develop most quickly, and that is what township officials want. The sewer extensions will bring it up Route 9, through stretches of woods and meadows now dotted with businesses like John's Transmissions and the Chatterbox nursery school.
"This will all be a shopping mall," Mr. Jewell said upon entering his hometown of Swainton. "There are 36 acres, and he can only use 16 acres of it because of wetlands, but he can put in 10 stores."
Up the road are the Stone Harbor Golf Club and the Avalon Golf Club, each of which will build more than 300 housing units when the sewers arrive. They will easily double the number of houses in Swainton.
Mr. Webber at the health department said that under current zoning, the new sewers would enable 2,050 new housing units in Middle Township and only about 600 more in other parts of the county -- altogether, he said, a tiny percentage of the 50,000 new units that environmentalists predict.
Ms. Carrara's objections to new development focus on the water supply -- already, the peninsula's southern tip has a desalinization plant because the aquifers have been drawn down enough to permit saltwater intrusion into wells -- and the prospect of sprawl. "By running sewers up Route 9, you're going directly against the state plan goals," she said.
For many reasons, the sewer plan, which must be approved by the Board of Freeholders and then by the Department of Environmental Protection, has brought emotional responses. A hearing six weeks ago lasted more than four hours and drew more than 200 people. Some represented groups like the Audubon Society and the League of Women Voters (both opposed), some were residents complaining of being left out of the plan, and many were citizens dismayed by the prospect of new building.
"There were people in tears testifying," Mr. Jewell said. "There were people who had never spoken in public before. They were shaking. It's not just a few. It's everybody pleading with the freeholders, don't do this to our county."
On their drive, Mr. Jewell and Ms. Carrara noted that the county has areas in need of redevelopment, notably the Wildwoods. In Villas, a densely built neighborhood of bungalows along the bay, Mr. Jewell pointed to tattered properties, some of which he said he had sold for as little as $40,000, that were excellent candidates for teardowns.
"This area could keep the real estate industry busy for 50 years," he said. "There's plenty of money to be made here."
Environmentalists predict that the industry will be kept busy one way or another. "People are going to say, 'I've had enough of East Orange or Bergen County.' " Mr. Jewell said. "They're going to want to come here for the Shore life."
When faced with complaints about an imminent population boom, he said, many local officials are dismissive. "They say, 'Oh, come on, do you really think they're going to put in 50,000 new housing units?' Well, some of us think it's going to be 70,000."
The Sierra Club maintains that under the proposed development regulations, Cape May County could grow by at least 65,000 housing units in 20 years.
"If you build it, they will come," Mr. Tittel said. "The only limiting factor is infrastructure, and if you put it in you'll get growth. Cape May is a desirable place. It's got beach, open space, bay, places to sail and play golf. They're going to market Cape May the way they marketed Myrtle Beach. You say, oh, Victorian homes, the beaches, and then it becomes a land rush. Then all those forecasts based on current trends are out the window."
The county's estimates of growth are far lower: It projects an increase in the year-round population from about 110,000 now to 140,000 in 2020. "The economy is booming now, and Cape May County isn't," said James J. Smith, the planning director. "We're growing, but we're not booming."
He said nearly two-thirds of the county consists of wetlands, which will always be protected, and that publicly owned property like the large Federal wildlife refuges makes up much of the rest. Finally, a big swath in the county's northwest corner is in the Pinelands.
Still, Mr. Smith said that while it would take many more decades than they predicted, the environmentalists' figures on residential growth could eventually be realized. "Is 50,000 new housing units realistic?" he said. "Yeah, maybe."
To builders, it does not look so possible. Jonathan Sachar, who is working on his third subdivision project, puzzled over the planning department's estimate that Lower Township could accommodate more than 8,000 new homes. "There are only about 1,000 acres available now," Mr. Sachar said, "and that means 1,000 houses."
Mr. Sachar has done a lot of scouting for acres. He knows many farmers in the township, having grown up in the area, and they are the principal owners of buildable land.
Mr. Sachar, who became a builder after practicing land-use law in Cape May, said much of the land was off-limits not only because of the coastal building regulations but because of other waterfront-development requirements and sewer restrictions.
He said he did not absolutely oppose the proposed new rules but argued that they penalized the farmers whose land would be devalued. "If you want to preserve property," he said, "do it the old-fashioned way: buy it. It's amazing how many people are calling me now who really don't want to see their land developed but are panicking because they see the value sucking away."
The upshot is that "they're putting in development applications right and left," he said. "In a way, the state is forcing development."
Mr. Sachar is about to start putting roads in for his Egret's Walk development, 24 houses in Lower Township. He bought 180 acres for $750,000 two years ago, sold 120 acres to the Nature Conservancy and carved the rest into lots that will sell for $70,000 to $140,000.
AS he leaned against his pickup truck and surveyed the property, which borders a wide, peaceful marsh, he said he would preserve tree lines and keep wide buffer areas. "This is the lesser of what could have happened here," he said.
If people are filling up developments like Mr. Sachar's, it is largely because prices for the scarce remaining land on the barrier islands have reached dizzying levels. Barbara Boeshe, a real estate broker who is also chairwoman of the county planning board, said a friend recently decided to move his house to a small lot in Town Bank, on the bay side of the peninsula, that he bought for $12,000. By contrast, she said, a lot on dune ground in Avalon cost more than $300,000, or $2 million an acre.
Gail Dwyer, who lost the nesting birds across the street to new construction, described Avalon's new houses as "monsters."
"What do people need to live in those for?" said Ms. Dwyer, who works as a legal secretary. "I'm sorry to say it, but it's showing off. It's not like these people have 10 kids. I don't know where all the money's coming from."
On the county's bay side, a few big houses are appearing, too. Most are on the dunes, in the densely built bungalow villages from North Cape May to Villas.
Valma Zak, an 80-year-old widow who spends summers in her white dunefront cottage in Villas, frowned as she pointed out the houses on either side, both of which had been expanded beyond recognition.
"I don't like any of the big things, really," Mrs. Zak said. "I used to get breezes from both sides, and they cut off the air."
Mrs. Zak and her husband bought the cottage 47 years ago for $6,000 -- she said the bungalows a few blocks inland could be had for $1,800 -- and said she had no intention of changing it now.
But around her, more homeowners are building up and out. And for them, there is a gleaming new Home Depot not far away, just off Route 9.

HEADLINE: On Politics;
Next Governor's Challenge: Keeping Things Neighborly

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
Things for the next governor of New Jersey to think about: The economy. Federal clean air regulations. School financing. Prison crowding. Urban development. And the neighbors, with their vexing, competing casinos.
In the early part of the decade, New Jersey's relations with its neighbors were marked by a fretful vigilance over every dime's worth of economic development. Luring another back-office operation from Wall Street was a triumph, losing another manufacturing concern to South Carolina -- or South America -- a tragedy. New York and New Jersey would periodically vow to stop trying to pirate each other's businesses, but cooperation was hard on an empty economic stomach. 
 But it is easier for a big family to get along when all the cousins drive Cadillacs.
Last week, Governor Whitman's Council of Economic Advisors reported the strongest economy in 25 years, and Joseph Seneca, the chairman of the council, said he had never been so optimistic. And while the rising economic tide reduced the cross-border squabbling, Governor Whitman, who was elected governor a year before both Republican counterparts -- George Pataki of New York and John Rowland of Connecticut -- has managed to play out her role as the pathfinder for her peers in the region. As a result, this has been a period of good feeling between New Jersey and its neighboring states.
"I'm a Whitman Republican," Governor Rowland said when he was running on a platform of lower taxes and smaller government in Connecticut So did Mr. Pataki in New York.
Sure, there will always be the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to squabble over, because both states own it and families always fight about the family business. But aside from that, prosperity and matching political philosophies have gone a long way toward making things neighborly for years now.
So how will these friends handle the looming problem of casinos? Governor Whitman has always jealously guarded the primacy of Atlantic City as the East Coast's premier gambling town. Any other town in the state that tried to think out loud about developing its own casinos, whether Asbury Park or Wildwood along the shore, or the Great Gorge resort area on the New York border, have been sharply rebuffed by the Whitman Administration with the warning that one big casino center is enough, thank you.
Now the Mohawk Indians are trying to organize a casino at an old Catskills harness track in Monticello, just 75 miles from New York City and the thousands of Atlantic City visitors who live there. So far, the governor has been politely silent on the matter of a competing casino closer to New York City (Atlantic City sits about 150 miles south of Manhattan), but New Jersey has not been silent. Senator Robert Torricelli, New Jersey's outspoken Democrat, has taken up the task of lobbying the Clinton Administration to put roadblocks in the way of any such a development, most recently by asking the Department of the Interior to require approval from the New York Legislature before any land can be transferred to the Indians for gambling purposes. Seen in the recent history of good feeling among fellow Republican governors, Mr. Torricelli is just the person to try to interfere in New York's business. He is a Democrat, after all, and so he can defend New Jersey's casino interests without the state's Republican governor having to utter a contrary word to her Republican friend in Albany.
Just how sensitive the casino issue is became clear last week, when Mr. Pataki fired back to Mr. Torricelli at a news conference: "I just think it's wrong that he's trying to intervene in affairs that are strictly between New York state and the Federal government on behalf of interests in the state of New Jersey. He should let New Yorkers and the Federal government deal with issues affecting New York."
Backers of the proposed Indian casino in Monticello have also taken out newspaper advertisements attacking Mr. Torricelli as a crony of Donald Trump, who is one of Atlantic City's biggest casino landlords.
The ads do not lie, but they do not tell the whole story. As for defending Atlantic City from competition, Mr. Torricelli is also Governor Whitman's crony. It is just that with Mrs. Whitman being such good friends with Mr. Pataki and all, nobody has to come right out and say it. Not yet, at least. But it's something for the next governor to worry about.

HEADLINE: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

 BODY:

MUSEUM MILE
Shofar Decorating Followed by a Mass Toot
The Jewish Museum's fall season of family programs is opening on Thursday with the fourth annual Shofar Festival, an afternoon of learning and laughing for people of all ages. 
 The shofar is an ancient musical instrument that is sounded in synagogues as part of Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur services. Developed by early Hebrews, it is made from the horn of an animal, usually a ram.
To begin the festival, children can decorate plastic shofars that really work, and later in the day the shofars can be trumpeted in a parade around the museum. The parade concludes with a museumwide sounding of all the shofars, and a contest for sustaining the longest blast.
For children too young to toot (ages 2 to 4) there will be a sing-along and story hour featuring stories about Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, which will begin at sundown on Friday.
Shofar Festival, Thursday 3:30 P.M. to 5:30 P.M.; Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue at 92d Street; free with museum admission: adults, $8; students and people over 65, $5.50; children under 12, free; (212) 423-3200.
 
MIDTOWN
Daylong Brazilian Festival With Food and Samba
All things Brazilian will be celebrated today in a daylong party in the city's Little Brazil, on 46th Street between Madison Avenue and Broadway. Music is the main event, and the festival streets will be lined with booths offering Brazilian food, drinks, fashion, jewelry and crafts. The Brazilian American Cultural Center is sponsoring.
The main stage is located at 46th Street and Madison, and will feature performances throughout the day. Grupo Saviero, a samba band, will perform at 3 P.M., and at 4 P.M. the main act, Terra Samba, pictured at left, will take the stage. Terra Samba is an 11-member ensemble from the Bahia region, whose melodies are top record sellers in Brazil. A second stage is at 46th Street and Broadway.
Brazilian Street Festival, today from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; 46th Street from Madison to Broadway; free; (212) 382-1631.
 
ST. GEORGE
One Last Beach View (Hands Off the Cone Shell)
It may be a sign that summer is ending that the exhibition "Life's a Beach" is closing after having been open since May. But you can still catch the show today and tomorrow. Put on by the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, the exhibition features old photographs and postcards that depict the bustling resort areas of South and Midland Beaches on Staten Island during their heyday in the late 19th and early 20th century.
Also in its last days is the exhibition "Shelling Out," which displays shells from around the world (including the shell pictured below, a chambered nautilus from the Indo-Pacific Region).
Rare and beautiful species and some dangerous shells will be on view, including a deadly cone shell and an assortment of conchs, volutes, murexes, whelks and scallops. Historical information about the impact of shells on the local economy will be provided as well.
"Life's a Beach" and "Shelling Out," today 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. and tomorrow, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, 75 Stuyvesant Place (near Wall Street), Staten Island; suggested donation $2.50; students and people over age 62, $1.50; members, free; (718) 727-1135.

SELLING THE SOUNDS -- "Music Business Basics" are the topic of a series at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, meeting the first Wednesday of every month beginning this Wednesday at 6:30 P.M.; the first presentation is on how to write a press release and manage public relations; 58 Seventh Avenue at Lincoln Place, Park Slope, Brooklyn; $10; students and people over 65, $5; (718) 622-3300.
 
MASQUERADE -- "Other Caribbean Visions: the Mas," the masquerade tradition of the Carnival of Trinidad and Tobago, will be performed by Peter Minshall and the Callaloo Company; at the Brooklyn Museum of Art; Thursday, 7 P.M.; 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn; free; (718) 638-5000.
 
GARDENS AND SHINTO -- The Japan Society is presenting a lecture on the origins of the Japanese garden and the role that Shinto, Japan's indigenous religion, has played in shaping the basic elements in both traditional and modern Japanese gardens; Wednesday 6:30 P.M.; 333 East 47th Street, between First and Second Avenues; $10, students $5; (212) 752-3015. HEADLINE: HOUSING;
$35 Million for Atlantic City Housing

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
What Mayor James Whelan describes as arguably the worst neighborhood in Atlantic City sits right next to the pride of the city's redevelopment efforts, the Northeast Inlet area where hundreds of new housing units have been constructed along grassy lanes and modern streets in the last decade to create an economically and racially integrated neighborhood.
Now, the deteriorating neighborhood, where the Shore Park and Shore Terrace housing developments are situated, is set to be demolished and rebuilt with a federal Housing and Urban Development grant announced last week. 
 "Hundreds of millions of dollars has gone into the Northeast Inlet for nice homes and Gardner's Basin, which is a thriving tourist attraction with a restaurant, shops, tour boats, and the new Ocean Life Center," said Louis Toscano, senior policy advisor to the Mayor. "The impediment to some people moving there or going there to visit the waterfront has been some of them don't want to go through the neighborhood of the projects next door."
The grant to Atlantic City, as well as another $35 million grant to Newark, were announced last week by Andrew M. Cuomo, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. In all, grants of $571 million were made to 21 cities nationwide, out of 80 that asked for a total of $1.8 billion to demolish deteriorating public housing, said Jodi Bennett, a spokesman for Senator Robert Torricelli.
In Atlantic City, the money, along with at least an equal amount from the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, will be used to build 600 townhouses that will be rented or sold, some below market value. The new housing will be made available to the 214 families now living in the low-rise public housing apartments on the site. Temporary relocation costs for the public housing residents will be paid for by HUD.
"This will complete the transformation of an entire area of the city," Mr. Toscano said.
The board of education will build a kindergarten-through-eighth-grade school on the site and a Boys and Girls Club is nearly complete. It is not known when construction of the houses will start. Overall, some $192 million in public and private money is expected to be invested in redevelopment of the area where the public housing apartments now stand.
In Newark, the HUD money will be used to demolish the Stella Wright housing project. Built in 1959, it is the last remaining high-rise public housing project in the city. The site will be redeveloped with 750 homes and townhouses for low- and moderate-income residents.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RICHMOND HILL;
An Indo-Caribbean Bazaar, But Some Yearn for the Gap

BYLINE: By RAMIN P. JALESHGARI 

 BODY:
For Jai Ramoutar, a tourist from Trinidad, a trip to Liberty Avenue is not what New York City is all about. The 20-block strip is packed with West Indian markets, sari palaces and shops selling roti, the tortillalike bread stuffed with curried meat and vegetables. Rather, Mr. Ramoutar said over his dinner at the Hot and Spicy Roti Shop, Liberty Avenue is too much like home.
That could change if Agenda 21, a neighborhood economic and community development group, succeeds in its plans to create a merchant cooperative, spruce up the strip and attract mainstream chain stores. 
 The plan has its critics and supporters among owners of the existing stores, which are supported mainly by Indo-Caribbeans, the neighborhood's largest ethnic group. Indo-Caribbeans are descendants of immigrants from India who settled in Suriname, Trinidad and Guyana during the 19th century. Like West Indians of African descent, they tended to settle in Flatbush, Brooklyn, until about 10 years ago, when they splintered off to Richmond Hill.
Raymond Ally, an Agenda 21 co-chairman, voices worry that their numbers will not be enough to keep all the specialty shops in business, "especially since second-generation Indo-Caribbeans are more likely to go to more mainstream stores that have better selections."
Mr. Ally said the first step was to sign up enough merchants by next spring to raise money for the improvements. He envisions repainted columns under the A train, repaired lampposts, improved sanitation and flags that say "Liberty Avenue, the New American Market."
He said the group would also try to persuade roti shops to prepare their fare in a more healthful way, using less oil, leaner meats and whole wheat flour.
But Sandra Ramlakhan, the owner of Hot and Spicy, said her customers, even the non-Caribbean ones, come to eat Trinidadian home cooking. "It is what it is," she said, "and that's what they come for, not an Americanized version of our food."
The plan does have some appeal for the second generation. While her daughter, Charry, likes shopping in the traditional clothing stores, she said, "I wouldn't mind it if there was a Gap here."
Across the street at Ascot Wine and Liquor, most of the customers are Indo-Caribbeans who buy rum from Trinidad and Guyana. "Trying to change the flavor of this neighborhood by mainstreaming isn't a good idea," said Harriet Hendler, an owner. "Why would someone come to this neighborhood if it's just like everywhere else?"
Mr. Ramoutar, the tourist, was skeptical, too. "This area says 'unity' to me," he said, as Indo-Caribbean music filtered into Hot and Spicy from the busy street. "It's the only place in New York where I've seen so many people just like me."
 RAMIN P. JALESHGARI

HEADLINE: August 29-Sept. 4;
Cars for the Credit-Challenged

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH

 BODY:
Mel Farr, a Detroit car dealer, doesn't mind leasing used cars to people with bad credit, as long as they don't mind driving around with a gizmo on the dashboard that keeps their cars from starting if they miss a payment.
Those who lease from Mr. Farr must pay up weekly in order to get a code to punch into the device on the dashboard. Anyone who is late paying can still drive around, but once they turn the car off, they'll find it won't start again. 
 With lobbying help from the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and financial help from Wall Street, Mr. Farr, a former Detroit Lions football player, said he was helping those who otherwise couldn't afford a car. Critics, including Ralph Nader, worry that the devices could prove unsafe, and said the interest rates of up to 25 percent take advantage of the desperate. Mr. Farr counters that the high prices reflect his risk. ROBYN MEREDITH

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Tougher Talk for Indonesia

BYLINE: By VIVIENNE WALT 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia

 BODY:
MARK BAIRD was picking his way through a tiny lunch. It was barely past noon, but, as the World Bank's new country director in Indonesia, he had already had breakfast at this same Hilton hotel with an Indonesian economist and, later, meetings with a variety of business people and officials. Now he was explaining to a reporter how, in a country jaded by years of bureaucratic bungles, he intended to reshape the image of the World Bank.
"First, the name's got to go," Mr. Baird said with a dry laugh. " 'World' is too grandiose, and for most people, the word 'bank' sounds like we are just here to make money, like every other bank." 
 What Mr. Baird is here to do is supervise the multibillion-dollar bailout of Indonesia's shattered economy, a rescue planned by the bank, the International Monetary Fund and foreign nations. In early August, just as the currency, the rupiah, seemed to be recovering from its 1998 collapse,investigators found that Bank Bali had paid more than $70 million in fees to a company controlled by a top official of the ruling party. Baligate, as the local newspapers labeled the scandal, could scare away investors again.
Mr. Baird, a New Zealander with a master's degree in economics from the University of Canterbury in England and many years of experience at the World Bank, never expected his current job to be easy. He arrived here last March, shortly after the bank, in a startlingly powerful self-criticism, acknowledged that it had ignored widespread Government corruption during the 33-year rule of former President Suharto.
Whether or not the comparison was justified, people here for years associated the World Bank with the Government, says Eric Bjornlund, Indonesia mission director for the Washington-based National Democracy Institute, an American organization that promotes democratic politics. "There was all this money sloshing around," he said, "and here was the World Bank in partnership with Government."
Mr. Baird, 48, says that as an economist for the bank in Jakarta in the late 1980's, he followed the old style. "We prided ourselves on working behind the scenes, with the Government," he said. "We got things done that way. Now, I think we should have spoken out on corruption."
Mr. Baird left Jakarta in 1989, returning to New Zealand to help his own Government introduce economic reforms. Later, he held senior posts at World Bank headquarters in Washington.
When Mr. Baird returned to Jakarta, it was a very different place. Street protests in 1998 had ousted Mr. Suharto. A frenzied democratic election campaign was under way. The economy was in shambles, and the World Bank was determined to hold officials accountable for the use of billions of dollars in foreign aid.
Upon his arrival, Mr. Baird did not head directly downtown, to his offices in the Jakarta Stock Exchange building, or to the Jakarta home where he and his wife and younger daughter would live. Instead, in line with the World Bank's new policy of having its officials experience life below the lofty level of national leaders, he spent a week with a family in a small rural village in Central Java. There, hundreds of miles east of the capital, women in conical hats stoop over the rice paddies, harvesting crops by hand.
"The Government was irrelevant, and the World Bank was totally unknown," he said. "It was darned hard to explain to people what we do. People can't begin to comprehend millions of dollars. They count in terms of hundreds of rupiah" -- pennies, at the current exchange rate.
But the people's curiosity challenged his natural reserve. Crowds followed him even to off-duty appointments. "I had several massages, and people would gather just to see this weird white guy getting a massage," he said. "They would stand around talking and serve coffee."
Even a $700 loan to the village -- minuscule to Mr. Baird, but a fortune to the villagers -- became a lesson in the hurdles faced by the World Bank. "The men haggled over who would deal with the money, and the women came up with five ideas of what to do with it, like opening a restaurant," Mr. Baird said. "It was obvious that development is about more than money; it's about people."
Mr. Baird says some of his recent actions would have been unthinkable for a World Bank functionary 10 years ago. Recently, for example, he told reporters that the bank would consider withdrawing financing if Baligate was not resolved to its satisfaction..
Indeed, Mr. Baird says, Indonesia is a crucial test case of the organization's new willingness to challenge its partners around the world. Ending corruption, he said, has become essential.
He still faces a tough battle convincing some Indonesians of the World Bank's intentions.
"Mark doesn't do much to make the image better," said Wardah Hafidz, the coordinator of the Urban Poor Consortium, a collection of activist groups in Jakarta. Ms. Hafidz and others, accusing the government of corruption and waste, pleaded with Mr. Baird to delay millions of dollars in loans for Government social programs until elected representatives could appoint a new president this fall. Mr. Baird refused, arguing that the loans would provide essential financing so that poor Indonesians could sell their crops and send children to school.
"They say they aren't involved in politics, but that's like saying you're in timber, chopping down trees, but you're not involved with the environment," Ms. Hafidz said. "A bank is a bank."
Which is exactly what fuels Mr. Baird's fantasy of a change in the World Bank's name.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Butcher, Baker, Skyscraper Maker: What America Earns

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE and KARL RUSSELL 

 BODY:
HOW do your earnings measure up?
This set of charts allows you, over the Labor Day weekend, to compare the fruits of your labor with the fruits of others in the same line of work, not only in your home city, but in other cities as well. Are you a podiatrist in Chicago? Well, consider moving to Detroit, where the average annual pay for your profession is $94,080, considerably above the $80,020 in Chicago. 
 Such detailed data are being gathered for the first time by the Government's Bureau of Labor Statistics, which has expanded its wage surveys. Instead of just telling the nation what secretaries, for example, earn in an individual industry -- the hotel industry, for example -- annual wage levels are now available for secretaries across all industries and in 300 cities.
The goal of accumulating all this data is to help the Labor Department's Alien Labor Certification Program determine prevailing pay for a particular occupation in a particular city. By law, employers are required to pay at least the prevailing wage to immigrant workers; now the Government has a new tool for applying the rule.
But beyond keeping pay apace for immigrant workers, the detailed data have other uses. For one, millions of Americans can now compare their pay with the average wages for their occupation -- in their hometowns, in other cities and regions, or across the nation.
And the expanded data are becoming available just as states and cities are taking over programs once operated at the national level. Welfare is one. For the first time, the wages for low-skilled jobs -- those generally available to people shifting from welfare to work -- will be easy to determine. The average pay of a janitor in Kokomo, Ind. -- $29,170 -- is more than double the amount in Wichita Falls, Tex.
"We will be able to judge how people are faring as national programs disappear," said Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute.
But beware the shortcomings of the bureau's new survey. How can it be that the highest-paid occupation in New York City is "structural metal worker" -- the people who erect a skyscraper's steel framework? There is no question that great skill is required to walk narrow girders dozens of stories up. Even so, don't investment bankers and white-shoe lawyers earn more?
Well, of course they do. The problem is that the bureau's survey covers only employees who get regular paychecks, with taxes withheld, and qualify for unemployment insurance. That eliminates a whole army of workers, including business owners and partners (the latter is the status of most well-paid lawyers and investment bankers), the self-employed and day laborers.
Another problem is the survey's response rate. Since 1996, the survey has been mailed annually to 400,000 companies, and roughly 30 percent have failed to reply each year.
For lack of enough replies from New York companies, the bureau could not produce reliable wage estimates for salaried physicians, lawyers, judges, top executives and securities brokers.
The annual earnings in these charts are for 1997. The 1998 numbers will be published in December and those for 1999 in December 2000. Meanwhile, says Douglas Himes, a bureau economist who helps to produce the survey, one should add roughly 5 or 6 percent in raises over the last two years to bring the wages up to date.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 847 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Finding the Steam Valve On an Overheated Market

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
EVERYONE knows by now that the spectacular rise in stock prices has helped to make the economy boom, and that a steep market fall could do a lot of economic damage. So it is natural to want to head off disaster by taking some of the steam out of stock trading. There are tools to do this, but surprisingly, they are rarely mentioned in the public debate. The Federal Reserve even rejects their viability.
For the Fed, inflation is the danger. A rising stock market, in its eyes, is only a contributor to inflation; it makes people feel wealthier, so they spend more, and the stepped-up spending helps to make prices rise. But rising stock prices are not a big danger in themselves. 
 That was the overall message last weekend at the annual gathering of central bankers in Jackson Hole, Wyo. The big economic issues of the day were debated, the main one being inflation and the stock market. The consensus prescription was to fight inflation with higher interest rates, but to leave measures directed at the market idle in the toolbox. Only at the very end did one speaker suggest using one: Try, he said, to dilute the enthusiasm for buying stocks by restricting their purchase on credit.
That was it, a one-minute reference in 10 hours of speeches and discussion -- short shrift for what was once a common practice whenever the stock market got out of line in the first three decades after World War II.
Raising rates to fight inflation does indeed discourage spending on credit. But it is a blunderbuss tactic that also damages the wider economy. And when stocks decline in response to a slowing economy, debt accelerates their fall, as investors hurry to sell and retrieve enough money to cover what they owe.
"Before World War II, big recessions in the United States were triggered by stock market collapses," said Albert Wojnilower, a Wall Street economist.
Since the war, recessions have often resulted when the Fed miscalculated in raising rates. Now the old danger of a stock market collapse has reappeared, and proposals for dealing with the market directly are surfacing. "The basic idea is to have more than one weapon to deal with what is essentially separate dilemmas," said George Perry, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "One dilemma is inflation and the other is the stock market."
Regulators could tame a possibly overvalued stock market by raising obstacles to speculation. For example, investors could be required to put up more of their own money. Right now, investors can borrow up to half the purchase price of a stock, a "margin" requirement that the Federal Reserve has not changed since 1974. Or, as James Tobin, the Nobel laureate in economics, argues, a transaction tax on each trade could discourage rapid-fire buying and selling. Introducing a 100 percent capital gains tax on stocks held for less than, say, 90 days would devastate day trading, a big source of speculation. Warren Buffett once proposed such a tax.
Regulatory changes could be useful as well. Companies could be forced to abandon accounting practices that falsely inflate profits (the Securities and Exchange Commission is trying to do this now), and bank examiners could demand stricter standards for lending, particularly to buy stocks.
"The examiners have not been what I would call tough," said Charles Peabody, senior bank analyst at Mitchell Securities. "The regulators have made a lot of speeches about lax lending standards, but I don't get the sense their examiners have followed through."
BUT the Fed's interest-rate approach has wide support on Wall Street, and among economists who are skeptical of the effectiveness of narrower measures. They argue that raising the margin requirement to, say, 70 percent would not stop investors from buying stocks with money raised through home equity loans, for example, or by borrowing abroad.
More philosophically, Federal Reserve officials and their supporters argue against trying to second-guess the judgments of millions of investors. In this era of deregulation, they say, there must be faith in a free market's ability to correct its own shortcomings -- with some well-timed help from the Fed. If stock prices collapse, the Greenspan Fed will lower interest rates quickly and feed money to banks to keep credit -- and the economy -- from "seizing up."
Still, a lot of stock is owned on credit. Federal Reserve statistics show that more than 55 percent of all borrowing in the United States now finds its way to the financial sector, up from roughly 35 percent in 1992, according to the calculations of Jane D'Arista, an economist with the Financial Markets Center, a research group. Much of this money has apparently been borrowed by brokerage firms, insurance companies and the like to invest for their own accounts. "There is a lot more leverage in this market than anyone realizes," Ms. D'Arista said.
And for this reason alone, the moment may have come to use some of the now-shunned alternative tools -- a higher margin requirement, for instance -- to reduce the potential for calamity.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%); 

STATE: WYOMING, USA (79%); 

COMPANY: FEDERAL RESERVE BANK OF NEW YORK (75%); GREENSPAN FED (78%);

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Munis GainingLuster As Yield Gap Narrows

BYLINE: By JOANNE LEGOMSKY 

 BODY:
LESS than two weeks after the Federal Reserve raised its Federal funds target rate by a quarter percentage point, high-quality municipal bonds are still looking extraordinarily attractive relative to plain-vanilla Treasury bonds, experts say.
Last Tuesday, for example, New York's Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority priced $225 million of highly rated, general purpose revenue bonds due in 2030 to yield 5.74 percent, or 94 percent of the 6.08 percent yield on a 30-year Treasury bond. So an investor would give up only a smidgen of yield in return for munis' freedom from taxation. And while that 94 percent figure is less than the 100 percent ratio that munis hit briefly last fall, it is still far above the 85 percent that they have averaged since the Tax Reform Act of 1986. 
 "It's absurd," said David Kotok, president of Cumberland Advisors, a muni bond manager in Vineland, N.J. "Tax-free yields are nearly equal to those on taxable instruments." He noted that for a taxpayer with a combined state and Federal tax rate of 45 percent, a muni with a 5.8 percent coupon has a tax-equivalent yield of 10.5 percent.
A couple of factors are at play here. The amount of Treasury bonds outstanding has been tapering off and is expected to shrink by $100 billion this year, making them relatively more expensive, compared with most other kinds of debt, according to R. B. Davidson 3d, director of municipal investments at Sanford C. Bernstein. A result, he said, is that "individuals in high tax brackets should move out of Treasuries and into high-grade munis."
Moreover, the robust United States economy has vastly improved the credit quality of most municipal bond jurisdictions, so default risk for high-quality munis is virtually zero, analysts say.
But because of rising supply, the increased credit quality has not come at the expense of higher muni prices. Taking advantage of interest-rate cuts last year, muni bond issuance rose sharply as governments sought to cut borrowing costs.
Demand for munis by institutions, meanwhile, has all but evaporated. "No money has gone into muni bond funds since April," said George Friedlander, fixed-income strategist with Salomon Smith Barney.
The biggest factor weighing down muni prices, however, is the protracted, take-no-prisoners bull market in stocks, said Christopher Dillon, a strategist with J. P. Morgan Securities. Against annual double-digit gains in the stock market, 6 percent yields on munis look puny.
Still, because muni bonds are not subject to the ebb and flow of foreign demand, they have been far more stable investments than Treasuries, said Steven Harrop, a manager with Strong Capital Management. Mr. Kotok added that investors in an index of muni bonds -- say, the Bond Buyer 40 -- at about this time last year would have ridden out the turmoil in global financial markets without experiencing much volatility. He calculated that over the last 115 weeks, 10-year Treasuries were three times as volatile as munis, as measured by their standard deviation.
Those interested only in income might do best to buy individual bonds and hold them to maturity, instead of buying muni bond funds. The strategy allows investors to tailor bond cash flows and maturations to their particular needs.
But if you think muni prices will rise and you want to take advantage of the gain, a fund or managed account might make sense. Mr. Kotok said current prices offered the chance for capital gains of 15 percent or more if, as he expects, muni prices rise enough to push their yields down to 85 percent of that of Treasuries.
Michael Shamosh, fixed-income strategist at Tucker Anthony Inc., said that with rates at their current levels, buying munis yourself makes more sense. "In a 5 percent rate environment, management fees may outweigh the advantages of management expertise, purchasing efficiency and diversification," he said.
