HEADLINE: Internet Wars

 BODY:
With each new technological advance, the Internet beckons as a rich and competitive playing field for business, communication and entertainment. One of the most promising recent innovations is high-speed Internet access through upgraded cable television lines. Before long, these lines are expected to offer a nearly limitless variety of television programs, movies, music, face-to-face telephones, commercial transactions and other interactive services.
But that lucrative prospect has produced a battle royal in cyberspace. It revolves around AT&T's acquisition of major cable systems as well as its big stake in Excite@Home, an Internet service provider that would give AT&T customers access to the World Wide Web. The fear is that by controlling both the cable and the avenue to the Internet, AT&T can dictate where users can go and what to buy. 
 The alarms are understandable. America Online, with more than 18 million customers, has joined with other Internet companies and consumer groups to warn that they all could get shut out if AT&T gains an Internet stranglehold, or be forced to pay high fees to AT&T to reach potential customers. Similar concerns have been raised over Time Warner's plans for its cable lines.
The critics want the Federal Communications Commission to require AT&T and Time Warner to grant equal access to America Online and other companies that provide Internet services. For now, the commission has demurred, and rightly so. As William Kennard, the F.C.C. chairman, has said, it seems premature to impose rules on cable Internet access to head off a problem that does not yet exist in a market that has not yet developed. The F.C.C. is also right to try to block localities from imposing restrictions.
Whether consumers will have a choice other than cable monopolies like AT&T and Time Warner will depend on the emergence of other high-speed technologies. Local telephone companies have begun to upgrade their service with a technology known as digital subscriber lines, or D.S.L., which could compete with cable. They may not have acted so quickly if it were not for the threat of AT&T and Time Warner. Satellite and wireless communications might also provide consumers with another way to tap into the Internet. America Online points out that these alternatives to cable are only in formative stages. But the interest of consumers is served by letting all these technologies develop and taking regulatory action only if they fail to provide adequate competition.
The Internet's future and its prosperity clearly depend on the principle of maintaining open access for all competitors. This principle has led the Justice Department to block Microsoft from using its operating system monopoly to force consumers to use its browser as the sole means to surf the Web. With 130 million users around the world, the Internet is driving a major part of the American economy. The question now becomes whether cable systems, which are inherently monopolistic enterprises that traditionally belong to the companies that built and paid for them, become so dominant that they will restrict consumer choices in getting news, watching programs or buying products.
In monitoring AT&T and Time Warner as they venture more and more into cable Internet services, the F.C.C. should not let down its guard. Even though cable systems are not now regulated, as telephone lines are, the F.C.C. should insure competition and open access in the future. For now, it is best for the F.C.C. to wait and see how the new world unfolds before trying to set rigid rules for it. But if AT&T and Time Warner do not exercise some self-restraint and act like good citizens, allowing fair access for America Online and other Internet service providers with a legitimate service to offer, they will find themselves subjected to demands for regulation by the F.C.C. and local communities. It is in their interest to preserve the open spirit of the Internet.

HEADLINE: Libya's Maverick Leader, 30 Years in Power, Makes a Bid for Respectability

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Muammar el-Qaddafi's Libya turned 30 this week, and a spree of congratulations here has been intensified by a conviction, at least in some quarters, that the leader may finally have outgrown his bad-boy past.
From all across Africa, where Colonel Qaddafi's Government once meddled so famously, other heads of state are on their way to Tripoli for an extraordinary meeting of the Organization of African Unity that is to begin on Monday, timed in his honor to coincide with the anniversary celebrations. 
 Among those who have already paid tribute was King Abdullah of Jordan, whose father, King Hussein, could never abide the Libyan leader. King Abdullah's visit last Wednesday came on the anniversary of the date that King Idris I of Libya was toppled -- Sept. 1, 1969 -- in a coup led by a 27-year-old Colonel Qaddafi, who replaced him as Libya's leader.
The annual ceremonies to commemorate that revolution have always been triumphal, with the capital covered in the trademark Libyan green, on pennants and posters and innumerable tiny lights. But even compared to a year ago, the backdrop this time is not at all usual.
Thanks to a deal struck in July, Libya enjoys full diplomatic relations with Britain -- a country that suffered from Libyan terrorism -- for the first time in 15 years. Thanks to another struck in April, it has been freed from the bind of United Nations sanctions that, among other things, had since 1992 rendered its "international airport" international only in name.
And the fresh flow of potential investors now arriving on direct flights from European capitals is seen by the hopeful here and outside Libya as a tangible symbol that an end to Libya's isolation is at hand.
Colonel Qaddafi is best known in the West as a serial troublemaker, with the defiance and unreality of a perpetual youth. But lately he has tried to encourage a fresh look, with acts and comments that some believe reflects additional maturity.
"The guy has grown up," said a Tripoli-based Arab diplomat. "He tried everything when he was young, but he's 57 now, and he's made up his mind. In the next millennium, he wants to present a new Libya."
Last month, for example, Colonel Qaddafi told African journalists that he in fact shared an aspiration, voiced by President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria, who said that people were eager to see something new from the Libyan leader.
"The world knows Muammar Qaddafi as the leader of the world revolution, which is contributing to the liberation of peoples," the Libyan leader said that President Obasanjo had told him. "And now that the liberation stage has ended, the world wants to know Muammar Qaddafi as the leader of peace and development in Africa and other countries."
"In fact, I hope that Muammar Qaddafi meets this description," the Libyan leader added.
Colonel Qaddafi remains eccentric; at most international gatherings, he usually stays apart, in a tent. But many African leaders -- like President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and President Idriss Deby of Chad, who were helped greatly by Colonel Qaddafi in their own revolutionary days -- now seem to see him as a force for stability.
These days, Colonel Qaddafi is hardly a picture of youth. He hobbles on an aluminum cane that he acquired last summer after he broke a thigh under circumstances that have not been fully explained. His skin looks puffy and wrinkled. Still, most observers say his firm grip on power remains undiminished.
And, with his flowing dark hair and striking features, he retains his rugged glamour. For public appearances this week, his outfits included a double-breasted white blazer, traditional Arab robes, and a dashing white linen suit that he wore for a speech to foreign investors.
Yet even as he tries to promote a new image, he sometimes reverts to old patterns. In front of the gathering of investors, he accused the United States of promoting "a satanic policy" by using economic sanctions for political purposes. He then went on to claim that the International Monetary Fund was "controlled by the Zionists," and complained that if Libya wanted to obtain a World Bank loan, it would be necessary to "go first to Tel Aviv."
Despite such lapses, most foreign observers here say they are nevertheless convinced that Colonel Qaddafi is fully committed to better behavior. And while it is not easy to gauge public opinion, the changes of the last few months have clearly made many Libyans more hopeful.
For many, the most important change, which came with the suspension of United Nations sanctions, is the fact that Libyans can once again travel abroad without enduring an arduous journey by car or ship. And, as they recognize, foreigners have begun to do the same.
"The best thing is that it will allow tourists and businessmen to come, and that means more jobs," said Latif Abdelsaid, a 24-year-old computer technician who works in a Government ministry.
Of course, Colonel Qaddafi's long record of political and economic mismanagement means that many skeptics remain. In Libya, which is Africa's richest country on a per capita basis, many people remain poor, and some grumble over what they say has been Colonel Qaddafi's longstanding disinclination to pay attention to problems at home. The most bold among them say they are waiting now to see results.
"Now the excuse for the bad economic situation is over," said a 40-year-old accountant who would give only his first name, Abdelsalem. "We can't blame the sanctions anymore."
Among foreign countries, the main skeptic, of course, is still the United States, and its grounds are Libya's long record of support for terrorism, particularly as practiced by radical Palestinian groups. Together with Britain, the United States supported the plan to suspend United Nations sanctions on Libya after a deal was struck to try the suspects in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am airliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, that killed 270 people.
But now the Clinton Administration stands as the main obstacle to a Security Council decision to lift those sanctions altogether. Beyond that, the Administration has left in place tough unilateral sanctions against Libya, some of which date back to 1978.
They include a comprehensive trade embargo imposed in April 1986, at a time when American outrage over Libya's sponsorship of terrorism led to bombing raids on, among other targets, Colonel Qadaffi's house and was said by Libyans to have killed one of his daughters.
The United States has said those sanctions will not be lifted until Libya can demonstrate that it has renounced terror "in word and deed." For now, Libya still appears on the State Department's list of international sponsors of terrorism.
European countries, struck by the new softening in Libya's old intransigence, have proven far more willing than the United States to give Colonel Qaddafi the benefit of the doubt.
A general consensus among observers here holds that after seven years of United Nations sanctions, Colonel Qaddafi decided that defiance was no longer sustainable. Not only did the sanctions cut off air links to Libya, they also banned the import of aircraft parts, weapons, and equipment needed for oil production.
Although Libya has succeeded in maintaining oil production at undiminished levels, the cost to the Libyan economy has been estimated at $24 billion, and the incalculable cost to popular morale may have been greater.
"I think probably Qaddafi himself recognizes that he might have made some mistakes," said a Western ambassador here. "But the past is the past, and now they want to move quickly into a different future."
In the Lockerbie case, the Libyan leader agreed to surrender the two suspects only after the United States and Britain first bent to his demand that the trial of the two men, said by Western officials to be Libyan intelligence officers, take place in a third country. The trial is now expected to begin next year in the Netherlands, and Colonel Qaddafi's Government is obligated under the Security Council resolution that suspended the sanctions to cooperate with prosecutors.
In two other notorious cases, Colonel Qaddafi has quietly moved closer to accepting some responsibility. In one, involving the 1989 bombing of a French UTA airliner over Africa, the Libyan Government in July transferred $31 million to France to compensate relatives of 170 people killed in the attack. But Colonel Qaddafi specified in a recent interview that the move should not be construed as an admission of guilt.
It came after Libya cooperated in a French investigation that led to the conviction of six Libyans for their role in the attack, including Abduallah Senoussi, Colonel Qaddafi's brother-in-law and top security aide.
Libya always refused to surrender the defendants to the French court, so the trial was held in their absence. All of the men were sentenced to life in prison, but French officials have little expectation that any will spend even a day behind bars. Even so President Jacques Chirac of France proclaimed at a conference of French diplomats last month that France and Libya had turned past "a dark page."
In the second case, Libya has now explicitly accepted responsibility for the 1984 killing of a British policewoman, Yvonne Fletcher, by shots fired from the Libyan Embassy in St. James Square in London. That step, also taken in July, was the one that prompted Britain to restore diplomatic relations, which were severed at the time of the incident.
Now, for first time in 15 years, there is officially a British Embassy in Tripoli, although the old quarters have not yet been restored, and diplomats are working from lower-profile quarters established previously on the grounds of the Italian Embassy.
One effect of all those moves, taken together, is that rarely a week goes by in which Colonel Qaddafi is not visited by a foreign head of state trying to make up for lost time after the long ban on international air flights. Another can be measured in the crush of foreign delegations that have descended on Tripoli. Some 30 have been from Italy alone, others have come from Saudi Arabia, South Africa, the United Arab Emirates and countless private firms.
Still, few here expect any investment boom soon. Colonel Qaddafi's Government has issued scores of new contracts, but it has not signed any of them yet; it is not known for swift decision-making. Investors remain wary too, particularly of the fact that the United Nations sanctions could technically be renewed at any time.
Libya has held talks with British Aerospace on a multi-billion dollar deal to acquire new aircraft for its debilitated commercial fleet and rebuild the country's crumbling airports. But some observers say that what Libya would prefer to persuade the United States to join in the new embrace.
In the minds of some Libyans, it would also mark a true end to the bad old days. "Things have been going downward for a long time," said a storekeeper who would give his name only as Mohammed. "The politics are too complicated for me to understand, but things were better when the Americans were around."

HEADLINE: In America;
The Baker's Slice

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
If you listen too long to the rhetoric you could begin to think we've stepped into some kind of economic nirvana. Things are going well, and maybe it is nirvana for the lucky ones at the top. But the economic reality for middle-class American families is somewhat more modest.
A new study by the Economic Policy Institute in Washington shows that middle-class workers are only slightly better off now than they were 10 years ago. 
 Make no mistake, these are good times. Tight labor markets, increases in the minimum wage and the earned income tax credit have helped low-wage workers. Unemployment over all is very low. And the C.E.O.'s and others at the very top have more money than they know what to do with.
But at $44,468, the annual income for the median American family (using the latest available data, adjusted for inflation) is less than $300 above where it was in 1989.
The men in that group are actually doing a bit worse than 10 years ago. The institute noted that "despite gains over the past 2 1/2 years, the inflation-adjusted hourly wages of middle-wage men were 1.8 percent lower in 1999 than in 1989, the previous business cycle peak."
Nirvana, that ain't. What we are seeing is that the families right in the middle are struggling, as always, to make ends meet. "Though middle-wage women workers have fared better than their male counterparts, by the middle of 1999 the median female worker's wage was only 3.4 percent above its 1989 level," the report said.
That is not much of a raise over 10 years. The families faced with constant worries about mortgages and the costs of education and health care may well be wondering what all the celebrating is about.
The authors of the report said: "The booming economy has thus far failed to lift the economic prospects of middle-class workers beyond where they were before the last recession. Despite their substantial contribution to the growing economy, wages for these workers have been stagnant or declining, manufacturing jobs are disappearing at an accelerating rate, and the share of non-college educated workers with employer-provided health coverage has declined."
To make ends meet, middle-income wage earners, men and women, have been working more and more. The report found that "the typical married-couple family with children put in 256 more hours of work -- six additional full-time weeks --than it did in 1989."
And yet even as the number of hours on the job has increased, the benefits -- particularly health benefits -- have declined. Sixty-two percent of the work force in the U.S. are individuals with a high school diploma and perhaps some college, but not a college degree. The report found that "the share of high school educated workers with employer-sponsored health insurance coverage fell from 72.1 percent in 1989 to 69.5 percent in 1997. For those working full time, year-round, the share with health insurance through their own employer fell by 5.3 percentage points between 1989 and 1997, from 66 to 60.7 percent."
Jared Bernstein is a labor economist with the Economic Policy Institute and one of the authors of the report. In an interview, he said: "We, as much as anyone, have made positive noises about the last few years. But if you look at the business cycle over the last 10 years, you will see that despite some positive results in the most recent years, folks are just about back where they started. And that's not the most impressive economic result I can think of."
What has happened is that the wages of middle-class workers have trailed the growth in labor productivity in the U.S.
Said Mr. Bernstein: "When productivity is increasing on average, and workers at the middle of the wage scale -- who certainly make a non-trivial contribution to that growth -- when their wages are not keeping up with it, that's evidence of an unfair distribution of economic growth. And if it's not going to the middle, we know it's been going disproportionately to the top.
"I like to look at it this way: If the pie is growing faster, then the bakers of the pie ought to get a bigger slice."
For the folks in the middle to really get beyond where they were in the late 80's, the economic recovery will have to continue at approximately the same pace for another few years. You might mention that to Alan Greenspan if you see him.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Amid Political Cynicism, Standing Steadfast in Her Faith

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SERVING in Washington in the 1990's has sorely taxed the faith of Alexis M. Herman, the Labor Secretary and one of the few remaining survivors of every blessed day of the Clinton Administration.
She has endured a nasty confirmation battle, the embarrassment of President Clinton's dalliance with an intern and a little-noticed but continuing investigation by an independent counsel. The Republican-led Congress has nickel-and-dimed her agency's requests for increases in spending for job-training programs and other labor initiatives. And she is tempted at times to give up on politics in an age of cynicism and the poisoning of public discourse. 
 Yet her faith abides, rooted in the teachings of her father, an early advocate of voting rights for blacks in her native Alabama who once was dragged from his car and beaten by members of the Ku Klux Klan as his 5-year-old daughter looked on.
Ms. Herman said she still remembered the heft of the pearl-handled pistol that her father handed her before the attack, instructing her to use it if any of the Klansmen threatened her.
But Ms. Herman, in a conversation late last week over lunch, did not want to dwell on that day 47 years ago. It was part of the upbringing that ignited her lifelong devotion to Democratic politics and minority rights and that landed her in the 24-by-36-foot corner office at the Labor Department with a commanding view of the Capitol.
Her devotion has been shaken in recent years, but never to the point of apostasy.
"It does cause me to go back and remember the early days and the path I took to get here," she said over a plate of cold sliced turkey and overcooked green beans in the private study off her huge ceremonial office. "I try not to be distracted by the cynicism and the negative climate in politics today."
An observant Roman Catholic since childhood, Ms. Herman begins each meal with grace ("Bless us, O Lord, for all of our gifts and for these we are about to receive.") and fluently recites her favorite Biblical passage, from the Book of Proverbs ("Lean not unto thine own understanding but in all ways acknowledge Him and He shall direct thy paths."). Prominently displayed on a side table in her office is a photograph of the Labor Secretary with her pastoral and political shepherds, Pope John Paul II and Bill Clinton.
Steeped in Southern gentility -- she takes four bites to finish a single cherry -- Ms. Herman is enduringly gracious and reluctant to talk about her personal life. She has never been married, except to her work, and finds relaxation in hiking, biking and reading. She entertains her friends and her large extended family with "old-style Southern cuisine," including about a half-dozen versions of her signature dish, red beans and rice.
Ms. Herman is at once earnest and glib. A friend once called her "the queen of schmooze."
She did not want to talk about the inquiry by an independent counsel ordered in May 1998 by Attorney General Janet Reno, to resolve accusations of influence-peddling and conflict of interest. Investigators are looking into her role in a series of White House fund-raising coffees in 1995 and 1996 as well as her private business dealings in the 1980's when she was a consultant on affirmative action and minority business contracts.
She would discuss the investigation only off the record, and only then to express bewilderment at the charges and to profess ignorance of the inquiry's progress.
Her lawyer, W. Neil Eggleston, would say only, "It's not taking up too much of my time and almost none of the Secretary's."
Neither Ms. Herman nor Mr. Eggleston would estimate how much the investigation has cost her in legal fees, but the final bill will almost certainly be in the six figures.
Calls to the office of the independent counsel, Ralph I. Lancaster Jr., a lawyer from Maine, were not returned.
MS. HERMAN has spent almost her entire career engaged in the struggles of working women and minorities.
Her first job after graduating from Xavier University of Louisiana in New Orleans was with Catholic Charities in Pascagoula, Miss., lobbying the shipyard to give apprenticeships to unskilled black workers. In the 1970's, she lent her dresses to black women applying for office jobs. She served as director of the Women's Bureau at the Labor Department during the Carter Administration. And she worked on the Presidential campaigns of Jesse Jackson in 1984 and 1988 before joining the Democratic National Committee in 1989 as deputy director under Ron Brown.
She was on the Presidential transition team in 1992 and in the White House as director of the office of public liaison through Mr. Clinton's first term. She was nominated for the Labor post in January 1997 and was confirmed four months later after a bitter struggle with Congress over the same issues that ultimately led to the appointment of an independent counsel.
The position of Labor Secretary -- she is the first black woman to hold the job -- has given her an enviable platform to address issues that have animated her all her life: the rights of workers in the United States and overseas, the difficulty balancing work and family, job programs for disadvantaged youth, the transition to a technology-driven economy.
She listed as her priorities for her remaining months in office an expansion of the Administration's welfare-to-work programs, additional help for unskilled workers and passage of the President's health care bill of rights.
On l'affaire Lewinsky, Ms. Herman toed the company line: She was "disappointed" in the President's behavior but never doubted his ability to lead the nation or the sincerity of his contrition.
"The President made a mistake and he told us he made a mistake," Ms. Herman said, the smooth smile never fading. "I was raised in a faith and a tradition of a forgiving gospel."

HEADLINE: A Homeless Organ Donor Gets Help

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
An unemployed woman who donated a kidney to a young boy but was left homeless when she was evicted from a public housing project in Alexandria, Va., has been offered her own place to live.
The woman, Marian Neal, has been staying in a shelter for the homeless since she was kicked out of the housing project, where she had been staying in a friend's apartment. Managers of the project said that Ms. Neal's presence violated the friend's lease and that a complaint had been filed. 
 But on Friday, after Ms. Neal's ordeal had been widely publicized in Washington, Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said his department would lease Ms. Neal a recently renovated one-bedroom town house in Washington. The rent will be based on her income, which Ms. Neal said made the town house affordable.
"She was a heroine who should be treated decently," Mr. Cuomo was quoted as saying by The Associated Press.
William Dearman, executive director of the Alexandria Redevelopment and Housing Authority, which runs the housing project on the edge of Alexandria's Old Town neighborhood, said he had been unfairly cast as the heavy because he had evicted Ms. Neal. But he defended his actions.
"I think it's a great thing that she did," Mr. Dearman said, "donating a kidney to this kid. But, you know, we have rules in this world."
Ms. Neal said she had no hard feelings for whoever turned her in.
"We pray for them," she said. "We feel no anger."
People who have met Ms. Neal, 40, say they come away impressed by her spirituality and her stoicism, which actually masks a sharp sense of public relations. That has helped her collect donations, but she is still living in Carpenter's Shelter, a place for the homeless in Alexandria, a Washington suburb.
"Marian has done most of her own publicity on this," said Frances Becker, executive director of Carpenter's Shelter.
There have been news features on three of Washington's four major television stations. When a Washington radio station, WRQX, told of the eviction of a woman who had donated a kidney, listeners called in pledges of $5,000.
On Wednesday, Ms. Neal sat in the living room of her friend's apartment and talked about her decision to donate her kidney last year to Terrance Varner, now 8, who lives in the Old Town neighborhood.
She said she began helping Terrance's grandmother take care of him last year by taking the boy, who suffered from renal failure, to dialysis treatments three times a week. Terrance was on a long waiting list for a new kidney.
When Ms. Neal learned that none of Terrance's family members were suitable kidney donors, she offered one of hers. Even though they were not related, she was found to be a close match. The transplant was a success, and Terrance is doing well, Ms. Neal said.
Bob Spieldenner, a spokesman for the United Network for Organ Sharing in Richmond, Va., said that of the 4,038 kidneys donated by living donors last year just 163, or 4 percent, were from people unrelated to the recipients by either blood or marriage.
Ms. Neal is from Philadelphia, where she worked in hospitals as a housekeeper and then sorted packages for Federal Express. She said she had to stop working in 1994 because of a degenerative back disease that has forced her to use a cane to get around.
Asked why she was not receiving Social Security disability payments, Ms. Neal said she was appealing a decision in which her application for benefits had been rejected.
"It's all right," she said when asked whether she harbored any ill feelings toward the person who had made that decision. "Everything that happens in life, it's all for the good of the Lord."
The decision meant that she was forced to live on the $210 a month that she received from the city welfare agency in Alexandria and $120 a month in food stamps, which led her to move into the tiny, well-kept apartment of Patrice Hall, whom she describes as "my sister in Christ."
This summer, Ms. Neal and Ms. Hall provided Bible study, tutoring and arts and crafts for the children in the housing project, Ms. Neal said.
Mr. Dearman of the housing authority said that he had offered to allow Ms. Hall to sign a new lease with Ms. Neal as the official co-tenant but that she had declined. As a result, Ms. Neal had to go to the bottom of a list of applicants for public housing in the city and turn to the homeless shelter.
"There are 60 people on the waiting list ahead of her," Mr. Dearman said. "Some of them are homeless. Would it be right to put her ahead because she is a kidney donor? Sometimes there are hard decisions that have to be made."

HEADLINE: Prime Minister Says Russia Is Cooperating in Corruption Probe, but Discounts Significance

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Prime Minister Vladimir Putin said tonight that Russian law enforcement authorities are cooperating in an investigation into a suspected money laundering scheme involving Russian money at the Bank of New York, and asserted that the sums involved were far less than the billions of dollars reported.
"The scope described in the press -- huge billions -- obviously doesn't correspond to reality but I repeat, the problem exists and we will work on it, without dramatizing it but without ignoring it," he said in a television interview. 
 The Russian Government has been accused of playing down the significance of an investigation into at least $4.2 billion transferred over the last 18 months to accounts at the Bank of New York in what American investigators have called a scheme involving money illegally taken out of Russia.
Appearing on a news show on ORT, the largest television station, Mr. Putin, a former chief of Russia's domestic intelligence service, acknowledged that illegal capital flight out of the depleted economy is a serious problem. But he echoed the view of several top officials that the ongoing investigation involving Bank of New York has become a "campaign," fueled by election year politics in both the United States and in Russia.
While Mr. Putin appeared on one television program tonight, former Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov appeared on a rival show on NTV, an independent television station, where for the first time he accused members of President Boris N. Yeltsin's inner circle of conspiring to remove him from office last May.
"I think the cause was that some people in the circle close to the president supplied him with wrong information about me and the Government," said Mr. Primakov, who has returned to politics as head of a coalition that could mount a presidential campaign next year.
As attacks against Mr. Yeltsin's small group of advisers gathered steam, Mr. Putin dodged an interviewer's question about a scandal that has reached into the Kremlin itself, touching one of Mr. Yeltsin's longest-serving aides and members of his own family.
According to several investigators, an ongoing probe into alleged kickbacks paid to Kremlin officials by Mabatex, a Swiss-based company that landed a lucrative Kremlin reconstruction contract, is focusing on suspects including members of the Yeltsin family, in particular his two daughters, Yelena Okulova and Tatyana Dyachenko.
An article published in an Italian newspaper on Saturday reported that Pavel P. Borodin, head of the Kremlin's property management office since 1993, was one of three signatories on a Swiss bank account opened by Mabatex in March 1995. The newspaper also said that Russian investigators believe that two other bank accounts, opened in the names of two of Mr. Borodin's deputies, codenamed "Cinderella" and "Tsarina," were put at the disposal of the two Yeltsin daughters.
The Kremlin last week denied that any members of the Yeltsin family held bank accounts abroad.
But the charges have already entered Russia's highly charged political arena, where Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov of Moscow, a Yeltsin foe and a leader of the newly formed political coalition, openly challenged Mr. Yeltsin and his family to come forward with a full accounting of credit card and bank accounts held abroad.
Charges of corruption are expected to fly fast and furious as the struggle for power intensifies with parliamentary elections in December and presidential elections next summer.
The report in Corriere della Sera, Italy's leading newspaper, largely corroborated a report published in July in Vestiya, a Russian investigative newspaper, that Mr. Borodin was one of three names listed on an account at the Gotthard Bank, which showed about $3 million in separate transactions. The other signatories were Mr. Borodin's daughter, Yekaterina Siletskaya, and Behgjet Pacolli, president of Mabatex.
Members of the Borodin family were among the 24 names of Russian officials -- many of them connected to Mr. Borodin's Kremlin department -- which Swiss prosecutors, at the behest of Russian prosecutors, circulated among Swiss banks this summer seeking information on secret bank accounts.
Mr. Borodin has repeatedly denied having his own Swiss bank account, although he has said that Mabatex paid his expenses on trips to Europe for the Kremlin renovation. Mr. Pacolli has said that his firm had opened a bank account to pay those expenses, but that other money -- including $1 million transferred to a Budapest bank in 1995 -- had been sent through the account by mistake.
Mr. Putin said tonight that the case was still under investigation but suggested that evidence in the press could have been manipulated.
"An account can be opened in your name very easily, and then it is possible to say that you have it," he said. "Then this account may be made bigger and you will be asked: where did you get the money? These are technologies that are well known."
Some newspapers have reported that credit card bills showing charges made by Mr. Yeltsin and his family were found during a search of Mabatex offices by Swiss authorities in January.
Asked if he thought Mr. Yeltsin might have ever used a credit card, Mr. Putin said with a half-smile, "Not likely."

HEADLINE: Jackson Recalls When Jews And Blacks Marched as One

BYLINE: By DAVID BARSTOW 

 BODY:
His voice was all weary and worn out. But the church was hushed, and it was time to talk, time to resurrect the details of history -- those crucial moments during the great struggles of a fading century when blacks and Jews fought together for the same causes.
In a robe of green so luminous that he seemed to shimmer in yesterday's milky morning light, the Rev. Jesse Jackson recalled Jewish lawyers who joined with Thurgood Marshall to defeat segregation. He recalled black soldiers who liberated Jews from German death camps. He recalled blacks and Jews who joined forces to pass anti-lynching laws, to fight for labor rights. 
 "As the century ends, what should we tell our children?" he had asked at the outset of his sermon at Riverside Church in Morningside Heights. Near the end of his remarks, he answered the question. "Tell them," he said in a tremulous voice, "haters will lose."
When he was finished, hundreds of worshipers -- black and white -- stood and gave him an ovation. Some wiped away tears. Mr. Jackson simply beamed and raised his hand in appreciation.
Though he never mentioned Khallid Abdul Muhammad by name, Mr. Jackson clearly meant to remind New Yorkers of the bonds between blacks and Jews, bonds tested in the last few weeks by Mr. Muhammad's daily displays of anti-Semitism.
Again on Saturday, during his second annual Million Youth March in Harlem, Mr. Muhammad punctuated his demands for black separatism by portraying whites in general, and Jews in particular, as the mortal enemies of black people.
Mr. Jackson, speaking with reporters after his sermon, suggested that the sparse crowd at Saturday's rally showed that the great majority of blacks had rejected Mr. Muhammad's views and his leadership. But while Mr. Jackson condemned Mr. Muhammad for inciting hatred with his inflammatory words, he also called Mr. Muhammad a "voice of alienation and despair," and he argued that people should be more offended by "the realities" of economic distress that have helped to produce such voices.
Citing crumbling schools, abuses by the police and the failure of Wall Street to invest in places like Harlem, Mr. Jackson said, "So long as there is alienation and pain, there will be voices of alienation and pain."
Mr. Jackson is no stranger to the relationship between blacks and Jews in this country. In 1984, during his Presidential campaign, Mr. Jackson referred to Jews as "Hymies" and to New York as "Hymietown," for which he subsequently apologized. In the years since, Mr. Jackson has made several efforts to solidify relations between blacks and Jews.
In 1988, speaking at a Jersey City memorial for Holocaust victims, he called for "the sons and daughters of the Holocaust" to find common ground "with the grandsons and granddaughters of slavery." In 1992, he assisted in arranging for a documentary film about black G.I.'s who liberated a German concentration camp to be shown at the Apollo Theater in Harlem. Two years later, after the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith bought newspaper advertisements to publicize Mr. Muhammad's anti-Semitic speeches, Mr. Jackson quickly denounced the remarks.
Mr. Jackson said yesterday that he may try to visit Iran on behalf of 13 Iranian Jews facing death sentences as alleged spies for Israel. "So long as those Jews are threatened with death, it creates great pain," Mr. Jackson said.
But beyond their differing views toward Jews, Mr. Jackson and Mr. Muhammad offer distinctly different visions for the future of blacks in the United States. Mr. Muhammad insistently calls for blacks to disengage from whites at all levels. On Saturday, for example, he urged blacks to form separate schools and separate "people's militias." He recommended that blacks not marry whites, and he criticized "white imperialistic corporations" for trying to invest in Harlem.
Mr. Jackson, by contrast, argued yesterday for blacks to finish the job of integration, saying that the effort to end segregation had led to huge economic and political gains for blacks as they made inroads into once forbidden spheres of life.
Referring again to the "details of history," Mr. Jackson recalled yesterday how Lena Horne could not sit in the seats of the whites-only theaters where she once entertained, and how Congressman Adam Clayton Powell Jr. could not get a haircut from the Capitol Hill barber. And yet now, decades later, Mr. Jackson said, Tiger Woods is the world's best golfer, Colin Powell is a widely respected former military leader, and black executives run major companies across the country.
"We have hills to climb," Mr. Jackson said, "but mountains behind us."
He said the most important fault lines in America today divide the country not by race, but along economic and educational lines. To overcome what he described as an "opportunity gap," it seems only natural for blacks and Jews, given their history of shared scars, to again join forces.
"We have a century of struggle together," he said.

HEADLINE: A Treat for Women: Cheering Women

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
"Did you ever think you'd live to see the day," asked Sharon, an insurance adjustor, of her friend, Peg, "when a women's bar would be showing sports?"
Usually, women go to Rubyfruit, a bar in Greenwich Village, for a drink or two with friends. But yesterday afternoon, Rubyfruit turned into a sports bar, complete with screaming, groans and waving arms, as women settled in for the uncommon pleasure of watching women versus women in a nationally televised event: the New York Liberty facing the Houston Comets for the Women's National Basketball Association championship. 
 By rights, the Liberty should not have played yesterday. The Comets, the favorite by far, were 0.4 seconds away from victory on Saturday night in Houston when Liberty guard Teresa Weatherspoon sank a near-miraculous half-court shot, winning the game by a point and creating a sliver of basketball history.
So spirits were high yesterday for the last game of the best-of-three series.
"I practiced screaming for today," said one woman, who said she watched a tape of Weatherspoon's play late Saturday night and early Sunday morning.
The fans proved to be serious yellers. Every time Liberty scored a point, they screamed and jumped. Every time a player fell, they cried out. Every time the ball balanced suspensefully on the rim, they shrieked. And they laughed. The sounds were those of women having a good time.
The fans cramming the cozy bar, many in T-shirts with Liberty logos, included rank novices: "Basically, I'm like, if our team has the ball and it goes in, it's good," one said.
There were many who had been high school players, watching intently. A few had brought newcomers to the game, and were explaining the fine points. Michelle Roun, 28, a technical recruiter, went to her first basketball game at Madison Square Garden earlier this season and, she said, was immediately hooked.
"It was brand new," she said. "It was real. I was, 'Oh my God, this is exciting!' I started jumping! Now I know their names. That shot by Teresa last night was just a miracle."
Jody Rajcula, 42, a college coach, said she used to play professional basketball herself, as a forward with the defunct Women's Basketball League. She said she played with the Chicago Hustle and the New England Gulls in the early 1980's, making all of $11,000.
"We were pioneers, the first professionals," said Ms. Rajcula, now a coach at Western Connecticut State University in Danbury. "This is a dream of mine, basketball as a women's game. Little girls running around with Liberty T-shirts."
Sharon, the insurance adjustor, who spoke on condition that her last name was not used, was one of many women who played on high school teams. "I loved it," she said. She follows the Knicks sporadically, she said. But she is loyal to Liberty.
"It's a personal thing," she said. "It belongs to you -- more than the Knicks.
Many women over 40 said they would have liked to have played sports in high school. But the schools did not have girls' teams. Some said they were even discouraged from playing after-school pick-up games.
"I was supposed to be doing home economics," said Sunny Toscano, a painter in her 50's who was wearing a Liberty T-shirt. "I used to sneak over to the gym instead."
Ann, 52, a saleswoman who used to play pick-up ball after school said: "I follow the Knicks. But I like to see women have a league. We deserve a league. We're good players."
A lone male, sitting with a group of women who play after work on an amateur team, seemed to be the only spectator startled by the roughness of the female professionals. Ernesto Cano, a Fort Lauderdale hairdresser, expressed dismay at the pushiness and competitiveness of players. "I've never seen this side of women before," he said.
In the end, the miracle was not repeated. The Liberty lost, 59 to 47. The crowd grew quieter, but not depressed. "They played great, they deserved it," said Sharon, graciously giving the Comets their due.
Christa Kirby, 32, an actress who works in a law firm, said Liberty should have tried harder. "But it's great to be here," she said. "Instead of being in a men's sport bar, it's great in here with women, watching a women's team."

HEADLINE: New Race But Old Walk On the Beach For Bradley

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: SPRING LAKE, N.J., Sept. 5

 BODY:
The storm-whipped winds had been lashing the beach all day today, driving dark clouds before them, roiling the surf and forcing summer's last vacationers out of the water when former Senator Bill Bradley stepped onto the boardwalk for an afternoon of handshaking.
Call it dumb luck, or call it a good omen, as Mr. Bradley did. But at that very moment, the sun broke through the clouds in this town south of Asbury Park, briefly warming the small crowd that had gathered in their tank tops, swimsuits and sandals to welcome Mr. Bradley on his annual Labor Day political pilgrimage to the beach. 
 But this was no ordinary beach walk for Mr. Bradley -- who has done this nostalgia-laced event for 19 of the last 21 years -- and so the weather was more welcome than ever. For Mr. Bradley is running for the Democratic nomination for President, and today's stroll was a kickoff of sorts for his national campaign. (He will make another kickoff in his hometown of Crystal City, Mo., later this week.)
Although the day did not quite have the feel of a major Presidential event, it was quite a bit more intense than Mr. Bradley's past laid-back Labor Day visits to the shore.
The clutch of more than 20 reporters tailing him was the largest ever, his aides said, and included television crews from Britain. Instead of his usual small coterie of aides, he brought several car loads this year. And the beachgoers' enthusiasm for their favorite-son Presidential candidate seemed louder than in past years.
"Take a french fry, Bill," shouted Gloria Hennessy, 64, from Point Pleasant, N.J. "You're the best. You're going to the White House."
Asked later why she liked Mr. Bradley, who represented New Jersey in the United States Senate for three terms and still lives in Montclair, Ms. Hennessy said, "He's honest and he played basketball."
But if things around him seemed somehow different than in past years, Mr. Bradley looked and acted every bit the same. As he has on all his beach walks, he wore the sort of informal clothes he did 30 years ago, when he was playing professional basketball for the New York Knicks: forest green shorts, size-13 Adidas sneakers and orange-and-blue socks that were falling around his ankles from the moment he stepped out of his car.
And if Mr. Bradley was charged up about kicking off his campaign, he did his best to hide it. He just wandered up to people, offered his hand without introducing himself, asked a question or two, and then ambled on. He did not kiss any babies, except his own grandchildren, and did not ask anyone to vote for him.
His aides referred to his Labor Day shore visits as "walking focus groups" that allowed him to hear the common complaints of common folk. But today, surrounded by cameras and boom microphones, the conversations tended to skirt national policy and sounded a bit more like this:
Mr. Bradley, to a boy carrying a huge Winnie the Pooh bear: "You win that?"
"Yeah."
"What'd you do to win that?"
"Shot water into the hole."
"Shot the water in the hole, eh?"
For most people, even Republicans, that was enough. They lined up for his signature and the chance to be photographed standing next to the candidate, a Hall of Famer as a professional basketball player. More than a few asked him to sign dollar bills -- his nickname with the Knicks was "Dollar Bill" -- but Mr. Bradley dutifully declined, citing Federal laws against defacing currency.
They included Tom McHugh, 53, of Pearl River, N.Y., a registered Republican who is quite sure he will not be voting for Mr. Bradley. But he asked for a signature anyway. "I'm a fan of his," Mr. McHugh said. As a politician or a basketball player? "As a celebrity," he replied.
But Doris Meyer, 62, a registered Republican from Caldwell, N.J., said she was certain she would vote for Mr. Bradley, provided, of course, that he gets through the Democratic primary, which she cannot vote in.
"He's very natural," said Ms. Meyer. "He doesn't come across as a snob."
Of course, there were those who had no idea what all the commotion was about. Parents could be heard telling young children that the tall man was once a famous basketball player. One man said, "There's Gov. Bill Bradley."
And then there was Maria Jimenez, 27, from Westchester County, N.Y., who had the excited look of someone who just received a free handout at the mall after meeting Mr. Bradley, telling a friend, "Whoever he was, I shook his hand."
There were a few questions to be answered, mainly from reporters. At a brief news conference along the arcade in Point Pleasant a few miles to the south, Mr. Bradley was asked by an English reporter about those "dogging questions" concerning his being too vague about his agenda.
Mr. Bradley replied that he had already offered detailed proposals to require registration of handguns and to revamp campaign finance laws, and would soon be releasing more on health care, the economy and preserving people's pensions. "I don't feel dogged," he said, adding, "I feel like we're going out and telling the people what I believe and what I want to do and who I am and where I came from."
Mr. Bradley also said he felt that President Clinton should not have offered conditional clemency to 16 members of a violent Puerto Rican independence group, a move that has puzzled and angered Republicans as well as some Democrats.
Asked to identify the major differences between himself and Vice President Al Gore, his rival for the Democratic nomination, Mr. Bradley said Mr. Gore did not seem willing to support far-reaching gun restrictions and changes to campaign finance laws. He also questioned the depth of Mr. Gore's support for teaching evolution in schools.
And then there was the issue of style. "I'm having more fun," Mr. Bradley asserted. "I like being out with the people."

HEADLINE: Just Published: Minutiae Without Meaning

BYLINE: By Stanley Fish; Stanley Fish is the dean of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences at the University of Illinois, Chicago. His most recent book is "The Trouble With Principle."

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Although biographies are a staple in bookstores and a favorite of reviewers, I confess that I rarely pick one up and almost never finish it when I do. Beginning a biography always makes me queasy, and queasiness turns into something close to a feeling of illness by the time I reach the third sentence.
The first sentence is usually O.K. It goes something like this: "On the fifth of May, 1879, in a small town in Ohio, John Smith was born to Aaron and Sarah Smith in the main house of their family farm." 
 Nothing much to quarrel with there, but nothing much to hold a reader's interest either. Interest is supposed to be supplied by the second sentence, which might be, "It was a year of drought, and the collapse of farm prices seemed imminent." Or, "Memories of the Civil War were still strong, and quarrels between partisans often erupted in the inns and ale-houses of southern Ohio."
It is with this second sentence, no matter what it is, that a gap opens up and a question is implied. What connects the first and second sentences? What is the relationship between the birth of John Smith and the imminent collapse of farm prices or post-Civil War tensions or anything else?
Presumably the gap will be filled or at least begin to be filled by the third sentence, but in fact the third sentence only widens the gap. When it arrives you realize that it could have been almost anything. "Little did little John know . . . " Or, "Only years later would it become clear . . . " Or, "Meanwhile, in another part of the country . . . "
And if the third sentence could be almost anything, so could the fourth and the fifth, and on and on, with nothing stopping the spiral sprawl of unconvincing speculation except the occasional sentence that, in its solidity and flatness, reminds you of the first: "John Smith married Betsy Jones in the fall of 1901." Or, "On Dec. 10, 1944, he was hit by lightning and died immediately."
It's the stuff in between that's the problem. You know what it's supposed to do -- it's supposed to supply the explanatory structure that links and gives depth to the bare recital of dated events -- but all it really does is call attention to the stretch and strain of conceptual bridges that are not connecting, bridges made up of psychology, economics, military analysis, astrology, whatever.
The falseness of it all is overwhelming, and you begin to be embarrassed at the spectacle of a biographer who knows so much and is trying so hard, but who can deliver only transitions that creak and analyses that you don't believe for a minute.
It wasn't always that way. Once upon a time, biographers didn't have to invent connections because they came ready made in the form of master narrative models. The two most durable were the providential model (everyone lives out the pattern of mistakes bequeathed to us by the original sin of Adam and Eve) and the wheel of fortune model (every life worth chronicling is an example of the general rule that what goes up must come down).
The great advantage of these models was that they supplied in advance the meanings modern-day biographers desperately seek in letters, medical records, the names of boyhood sleds, anything. In an age like ours, when master narratives have little or no credibility, meaning is supposed to just well up spontaneously from the details biographers obsessively collect. But details unattached to a master story don't mean anything in particular, or can mean anything at all. Which is why the biographer is compelled to invent or fabricate a meaning by riding his or her favorite hobbyhorse until every inch of the subject's life is covered by some reassuring pattern of cause and effect.
Cause and effect took care of themselves when you knew before you began that the life you were narrating would end up illustrating a general truth familiar to everyone. But when general truths have been foresworn, the biographer is left with little more than a collection of random incidents, and the only truth being told is the truth of contingency, of events succeeding one another in a universe of accident and chance.
The honest thing for a biographer to do in this situation would be to give up cause and effect and just go with contingency. But cause and effect are the biographer's very stock in trade, and contingency is what no self-respecting biographer can allow to stand; it must be pushed away and replaced with an explanatory structure, any explanatory structure.
The only exceptions to this general rule (and the only kind of biography I can endure) are the biographies of film stars and other celebrities, a subgenre that does quite nicely even when explanations are either absent or weak.
The reason is that contingency and accident are pretty much the content of celebrity lives. First, there is the accident of "the discovery" (in a drugstore or a chorus line, on the beach or on the street), followed, after false starts and failures, by the accident of the "big break," followed by the even bigger accident of the "role of a lifetime" (turned down by Lana Turner or Clark Gable), followed -- not inevitably, but often -- by the accident of the "decline and fall" (Fatty Arbuckle, Elvis Presley, Ernest Hemingway), followed by the most glorious accident of all, the "comeback" (Frank Sinatra, John Travolta, Judy Garland, Marv Albert).
There are a few variations on the basic formula -- the accident of a life cut off in its prime (James Dean, John Lennon, Princess Di and almost any country-and-western singer who ever boarded a plane), the accident, often in dispute and mysterious, of suicide (Marilyn Monroe, Kurt Cobain), the accident of heroically overcoming an accident (Christopher Reeve, Ann-Margret, Montgomery Clift, George Jones).
But these are just variations on contingency, and since by definition the contingent is what defies explanation, readers and viewers will not be disappointed if the explanatory structure is missing. Indeed, whenever A&E's "Biography" interrupts its rehearsal of improbable successes and failures to indulge in a fit of explanation, the effort is so obviously halfhearted and pathetic -- "Meanwhile, their marriage was unraveling" or "Meanwhile, the public turned away from that form of entertainment" -- that you are not even tempted to take it seriously.
My criticism of biography does not hold for autobiography. It makes none of the claims made for biography and is therefore not subject to any of the criticisms. You cannot fault the author of an autobiography for failing to be objective, or for substituting his story for the story of his subject.
He is his subject, and his performance, complete with the quirks and blindnesses of his personality, is not a distraction or deviation from the story of his life but an extension of it. Autobiographers cannot lie because anything they say, however mendacious, is the truth about themselves, whether they know it or not. Autobiographers are authentic necessarily and without effort.
Biographers, on the other hand, can only be inauthentic, can only get it wrong, can only lie, can only substitute their own story for the story of their announced subject. (Biographers are all autobiographers, although the pretensions of their enterprise won't allow them to admit it or even see it.)
Biography, in short, is a bad game, and the wonder is that so many are playing it and that so many others are watching it and spending time that might be better spent on more edifying spectacles like politics and professional wrestling.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: The Policy Behind the Exodus of Russian Money

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You are right to suspect that a large exodus of capital from Russia has occurred, but you forget the central role of economic policy in accounting for that outflow ("The Russian Money Trail," editorial, Aug. 31). 
 Until August 1998, Russian companies were not legally barred from holding money abroad. If a Russian businessman profited from buying products like precious metals locally at controlled prices and then exporting them at market prices, the profits could have been held abroad.
Since August 1998, exporters have been required to return foreign earnings within 90 days, and importers must deposit the full value of imports in rubles with the Central Bank of Russia until the imports cross the border.
So the continuing outflow of capital has taken the classic route: Russian exporters get an invoice from a foreign company understating their exports and importers get an invoice from a foreign partner overstating their imports. They stash away the differences in foreign banks, violating Russian rather than foreign laws.
 
PADMA DESAI
New York, Sept. 2, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: When the Market Pops

 BODY:

To the Editor:
One's confidence doesn't increase on hearing that the Federal Reserve has commissioned a study on how to handle the dangers of soaring stock prices from two academics whose thinking it already knew and agreed with (Business Day, Aug. 31). 
 As Charles P. Kindleberger, an economist, has pointed out, if the market knows a lender of last resort can be counted on to come to the rescue, risky or imprudent behavior may follow. The old savings and loan industry and twentysomethings that still live at home are two good examples.
Many seem confident that the rapidly inflating United States real estate market (and the spending that flows from it) couldn't possibly be a bubble that might burst, because it would never approach the insanity of the ruined Japanese market. To admit to bubbles only when they reach the levels of Japanese real estate or Dutch tulip bulbs is to ignore a large amount of important economic history.
 
ROBERT HOWARD
Berkeley, Calif., Aug. 31, 1999

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Relivin' The Fun Life In Some Pop Showdowns

BYLINE: By ANN POWERS 

 BODY:
As autumn creeps into the air, a critic's thoughts turn reflective. Recent history offers insight into our current obsessions. What was the song of the summer? The singles that blare forth from car radios or boom boxes in parks and at the beach are the catcalls of a nation baring its collective skin. With the pop scene in a giddy, fast-moving mood, such quickly fading shout-outs seem more resonant than usual.
Offered here, in the hopes of causing some entertaining arguments among pop aficionados, is a ringside view of this summer's tournament of hits. 

'LIVIN' LA VIDA LOCA' VS. 'BAILAMOS' -- The ballyhooed Latin music explosion was really just an overdue acknowledgment of America's bilingual reality, a point reinforced by the return of Carlos Santana, whose music has been explosively Latin for decades. But the media's largely clueless coverage did not diminish the enormous fun of Ricky Martin's crazy song, propelled by a rocking salsa beat and scrumptiously silly lyrics, delivered by the former teen-age pinup with appropriate sarcasm.
"Bailamos," by Enrique Iglesias (son of Julio Iglesias, himself a formidable adult pinup), is subtler and more insinuating while fulfilling its share of spicy south-of-the-border cliches. Still, the knockout punch takes the match. Winner: "Livin' la Vida Loca."
 
'IF YOU HAD MY LOVE' VS. 'GENIE IN A BOTTLE' -- The actress and singer Jennifer Lopez is also a contender in the Latin category, but her seductive whisper has more in common with the coy teasing of the former Mickey Mouse Club member Christina Aguilera than with Mr. Martin's confident bluster. Both the romantic come-on offered by Ms. Lopez and the titillating maybe whispered by Ms. Aguilera creep under the sheets fully clothed, generating sexy but ultimately modest fantasies. The difference between them is a matter of better beats and a real voice, both the property of Ms. Aguilera. Winner: "Genie in a Bottle."
 
 'BILLS, BILLS, BILLS' VS. 'UNPRETTY' -- Today's most interesting popular conversations about feminism are taking place on the rhythm-and-blues charts. TLC's slap in the face of freeloading guys, "No Scrubs," set the tone last spring. Another girl group, Destiny's Child, addresses women's economic anxieties in an earthier and more heartfelt manner in "Bills, Bills, Bills." These songs earned the ultimate hip-hop tribute: answer songs, both by the gold-digging male group Sporty Thieves. But the surprise champion in the round robin of empathetic girl talk is "Unpretty," an effervescent meditation on the beauty myth, in which the gamines of TLC confront the damage done to women by the very materialism the singers blithely embraced in "No Scrubs." Winner: "Unpretty."
 
 'BEAUTIFUL STRANGER' VS. 'AMERICAN WOMAN' -- Getting sick of Austin Powers was a popular pastime this season, as the bucktoothed sleuth played by Mike Myers grinned through endless promotions for "The Spy Who Shagged Me." These two singles from the movie's soundtrack kept everyone doing the tie-in twist.
The video for "Beautiful Stranger" featured Madonna crawling all over a befuddled Austin, while the Lenny Kravitz remake of the Guess Who classic showed Mr. Myers's co-star Heather Graham frugging atop a bus. As for the songs, Mr. Kravitz capably tore the original to pieces, while Madonna offered a swooning love ballad with a subtext about the hype that such hits help generate. "You're everywhere I go," sang the head of Maverick Records, who released the soundtrack, to her cash cow. No kidding. Winner: "Beautiful Stranger."
 
'WILD WILD WEST' VS. 'JAMBOREE' AND 'JIGGA' -- Hip-hop shout-alongs are a summer staple. The rapper and movie star Will Smith followed up his irresistible "Miami" with a site-specific song that did better than the cyber-Western it promoted. (What's next? A hip-hop "Blue Hawaii"?) Naughty by Nature returned to form with an anthem best heard at a picnic. And hip-hop's smoothest foul mouth, Jay-Z, collaborated with the Ruff Ryders crew to augment his list of chart-toppers based around lyrical hooks that get censored on most radio stations. Titillated teen-agers nationwide filled in the blanks. Winner: "Jigga."
 
 'ALL STAR' VS. 'SOMEDAY,' 'SCAR TISSUE' AND 'LAST KISS' -- Every summer hit by an even slightly seasoned alternative-rock group jovially took on the genre's faded status, and the devil-may-care made for fine pop. Smashmouth and Sugar Ray defied the odds of a sophomore slump with perky, ska-tinged reflections on the one-hit wonder status they ended up avoiding. The Red Hot Chili Peppers reminisced on a life of troublemaking in a tune as peacefully desolate as a desert sunset. And Pearl Jam, covering a 1964 teen-age car-crash saga, transformed it into a sly nod to the dramatic burnout of grunge, the subculture this classic rock band steered to the top. Winner: "Last Kiss."
 
'WHAT'S MY AGE AGAIN?' VS. 'MY OWN WORST ENEMY' -- As their immediate elders pondered extinction, punk-inspired brats examined their own growth spurts. Mark Hoppus of the gleefully obscene Blink 182 poked fun at his gender's propensity for juvenile behavior in a song that had him whining like Dennis the Menace getting his ear pulled.
A. Jay Popoff of Lit moaned about being so irritating that his girlfriend makes him sleep in the car. Both songs are more honest than they probably were meant to be, but Blink 182 wisely sticks with jokes, while Lit gets stuck in faux sincerity. Winner: "What's My Age Again?"
 
 'BAWITDABA' AND 'COWBOY' VS. 'NOOKIE' -- Call it the new hard rock, or just call it bothersome. The willfully offensive mix of hip-hop, metal and head-banging hard core beloved by an ascendant generation of white rap fans is not going back into its corner. Those who like at least a little panache from their obnoxious rock stars can take comfort in Kid Rock.
This Detroit-based journeyman understands that he can sneak into a black-owned musical genre not simply because he's skilled, but because he lucked upon the right historical moment. So he rocks with dedication, raps with humor and plays up the unlikelihood of such a skinny goofball making it big. Either of his two singles, the one with the nonsense word for a title and the one in which he makes out like a horse-riding bandit, easily bests Limp Bizkit's nasty ditty about hating girl germs. Winner: "Cowboy" and "Bawitdaba."
 
 'THE HARDEST THING' AND 'I DO' VS. 'SUMMER GIRLS' -- While America's young men holler along with Kid Rock, their younger sisters are busy squealing for much hunkier pop stars. A few teen-age--oriented "boy bands" bridge this gender divide by looking enough like football heros to inspire today's body-conscious male youth; 98 Degrees generates macho well-being while crooning devotion to female fans. The group's one-two punch this summer started with a poignant song about two-timing, then resolved that moral dilemma with an old-fashioned walk down the aisle.
Yet the graceful 98 Degrees can't top the lion cubs of LFO. These three dudes know what they like (girls who shop at Abercrombie & Fitch) and what they don't (Chinese food). And as they drawl out these preferences in a loping rap, they sound just like the high school seniors who prevail in every fight. Winner: "Summer Girls."
 
 'STEAL MY SUNSHINE' VS. 'I WANT IT THAT WAY' -- The greatest summer singles are like modern-day nursery rhymes, going beyond the moments they reflect into the realm of pure pleasure. Only two this summer reached the level of inspired frivolity defined by "Tutti Frutti" and "Itsy Bitsy Teenie Weenie Yellow Polka Dot Bikini."
The first, by the Canadian group Len, relies on a girlishly sung hook that warms the skin like the very rays of light it describes. But it's the only line in this very wordy song that makes sense. The lyrics seem to be about the hangover Len's leader, Marc Costanza, had when he wrote it, and it expertly captures the pleasantly fuzzy feeling of the morning after a very enjoyable night.
Len might have been the summer's victor, if not for pop's unstoppable force, the Backstreet Boys. The latest smash by these dream dates is an overwhelmingly earnest love ballad, of course, but one without a shred of lucidity. "I never want to hear you say, I want it that way," the boys beg, but they never specify what "it" might be, or exactly which way someone might or might not want it.
The music sweeps forward, delicate and soulful; the words might have been computer-generated. Yet everywhere Americans went this summer, in sports arenas and concert halls, in malls and parking lots, they sang along with the Backstreet Boys, deeply feeling those nebulous emotions that only coalesce within the strange language of pop. Winner and overall champion: "I Want It That Way."
