HEADLINE: A Lull in Art Sales? Well, Not Anymore;
New Collectors Are Changing the Market

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Like Broadway, baseball and big-game hunting, the art trade has always had a season. It began in mid-September, rose to heights each fall and again each spring, then tailed off at the end of June, when rich collectors headed for a summer of leisure at their country homes.
"August," said Arnold Glimcher, the chairman of the Pace Wildenstein Gallery, "was a time when you could pull in the sidewalk, and some galleries would even close for the whole month." Certainly, big-name dealers left town, leaving skeleton crews in charge of their galleries. 
 But not last year, and especially not this year. "It's been insanity this summer; our business has not let up at all," Mr. Glimcher said, still working one day in mid-August and willing to reel off sales of major works by Rothko, de Kooning and Lichtenstein.
Dealers all over Manhattan related similar experiences. And Nancy Rosen, an art adviser who makes regular visits to Chelsea, SoHo, midtown and uptown to look at all kinds of art, witnessed the same thing. "I go to galleries all the time, and this summer they're not empty," she said. "Almost all the dealers I know have said they've had more activity this summer than they've ever had before."
For the last few years, art dealers and auction houses have gloried in the exuberant economy and the ever-ascending stock market, which have created many multimillionaires and billionaires eager to plow their excess cash into paintings, sculpture and decorative art. People like Michael Dell from the high-tech sector, Robert D. Soros from the investment world and Gwyneth Paltrow and Leonardo DiCaprio from the entertainment industry have all been bitten by the collecting bug.
Now these new collectors, along with many executives and entrepreneurs who began collecting in the 1980's and have since grown richer, are so strong in number and buying power that they are changing the art world. For a start, the business, which once followed the rhythms of the carriage trade, is instead moving to the beat of Wall Street. That means that art buying has become a year-round activity, and lazy Augusts are a thing of the past, even when dealers do go on vacation.
"I was on the phone every single day for work," said Jennifer Vorbach, a partner at C&M Arts, about her two recent weeks in the Hamptons. "These were significant pieces of business wanting to happen, and the business had to go on no matter where I was." C&M's August sales included a major Warhol painting, a Rothko painting and a Cornell box.
"With mobile phones and the Internet, I don't think business stops anymore," agreed Rachel Kaminsky, the director of Otto Naumann Ltd., an Old Masters dealer that also had visits in August from collectors she called significant.
Diana D. Brooks, who as the chief executive of Sotheby's sees a lot of collectors, new and old, is not the least bit surprised by the gallery activity. "The new collectors are people who work 12 months a year, and if they work 12 months a year, they want to buy art 12 months a year," she said.
So far neither Sotheby's nor its archrival, Christie's, is holding sales in New York during the summer. But both auction houses, concerned that the big sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art in New York and London are bunched too closely in November-December and May-June, are considering spreading the sales more evenly throughout the year. They are also counting on Internet sales to cater to people who simply must buy between auctions.
Besides buoyant sales, dealers and auction houses alike are seeing a second effect of the influx of new money: their business is more volatile. Ms. Brooks said that when she joined Sotheby's 20 years ago, she was told the art market did not follow the stock market. Then, in the 80's, the art market was said to lag the stock market by a couple of years. "Now we track the stock market much more closely," she said, "and we have more ups and downs."
"When the stock market was off its record highs for six or eight weeks earlier this year, it had an impact," she added. "Even in that short period of time it had an impact psychologically. Those ups and downs affect people who are willing to spend $500,000 or $1 million or $5 million on a picture."
Christopher Burge, the chairman of Christie's in the Americas, who used to make a strong case that the art market rose and fell in fairly predictable cycles lasting about seven years, said he had long since given up that theory. "We're a full nine years into this cycle," he said, thanks to the prosperity of the 90's.
This newfound dependence on the whims of the stock exchanges is widely acknowledged. "Why are you calling me?" asked one dealer when queried about the market outlook. "You ought to be interviewing Alan Greenspan."
With Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve so far keeping their cool, the art world is counting on a strong fall. Although it is early for announcements, Sotheby's, for example, said it would offer a Cezanne still life, "A Stoneware Pitcher," estimated at $18 million to $25 million, and Monet's landscape with his wife, "In the Meadow," estimated at $15 million to $20 million, both from private collections. Christie's has a van Gogh, "The Bridge at Trinquetaille," from the estate of Akram Ojjeh, which has an unpublished estimate said to be $20 million.
In the galleries, Pace Wildenstein will have new work from the estate of Saul Steinberg, while Alexander and Bonin, Luhring Augustine and others will have shows by Young British Artists featured in the "Sensation" exhibition that opens at the Brooklyn Museum of Art in October.
But that is a small sampling, since the new collectors' tastes are broad. While many of those with megadollars to spend do want trophies by Impressionists and 20th-century masters, many more, with smaller budgets, seem to be interested in contemporary art, especially the youngest collectors. "They focus more on the highly publicized sectors, to young artists they have heard about," said Francesca Guglielmino, the business head of Citibank's Art Advisory Service.
Just how beholden the art market is to the new class of collectors is difficult to say, although some dealers say they are posting record sales. Many more say they are having their best year since the market peak of 1989-90, when vigorous buying from Japan sent prices for even mediocre art to unprecedented highs. But dealers, as private businesses, do not report their sales as public companies do.
Yet signs that the art business is strong are everywhere. At the auction houses, for example, combined North American sales of Christie's and Sotheby's climbed from $1.68 billion during the 1996-97 season (from July 1, 1996, through June 30, 1997) to almost $2.15 billion in the year ended June 30, 1999. That is an increase of nearly 30 percent in two years.
Art insurers are also smiling. "Business really picked up in 1996," said Dietrich von Frank, president and chief executive of AXA Nordstern Art Insurance. He said the average increase of private collection holdings among his clients was up about 10 percent in the last year, after a jump of about 7.5 percent the previous season. Jeffrey Haber, an expert at Acordia, which also specializes in art insurance, said his clients had on average increased the insured value of their holdings by 15 to 20 percent in the last two years.
And those figures do not capture the effect of many beginning collectors, who tend to insure their early art purchases by adding to their homeowner policies, rather than buying special policies to cover their art.
Throughout the economy, while consumer spending continues to be robust, conspicuous spending is even more so. Spending on luxury goods like art, according to Robert Frank's recent book, "Luxury Fever," is increasing four times faster than spending over all.
Art buying is always tied to real estate, and the size of new homes -- first, second and sometimes third -- is exploding. Twenty thousand square feet, which used to sound baronial, is unexceptional nowadays. Homes of 40,000 square feet to 60,000 square feet, with yards of walls to cover, are being built not just by Bill Gates but also by people whose names do not sell magazines. The Whitney Museum of American Art, meanwhile, has only 42,000 square feet of exhibition space.
Experts agree that collectors are filling these homes with art, but they insist that new houses are not driving the market. "I don't have the sense that it's people decorating," Ms. Brooks said. "Collecting is a lot more focused today. New collectors are driven people who are very intense about everything they do."
Dealers report that during the last two summers it is the browsers who have disappeared, not the collectors. "The people coming in aren't surprises," said Andrew Fabricant, a director of the Richard Gray Gallery. "It's not walk-in trade." Some seem to come to New York, often from the Hamptons, but sometimes from the West Coast, specifically to look and buy, several dealers said.
Still other buyers, apparently, are intense enough to go collecting on their real vacations. "Rich people get bored," said Thea Westreich, an art adviser. "They're on vacation and spending money is a kick." She said she was busy all summer with "high-end business, significant money, willing to buy $5 million to $10 million pictures."
Another new factor, during August especially, was European collectors, who by all signs were in the United States primarily for vacation and decided to go shopping for art, too.
Delighted by all this activity, dealers and auctioneers nevertheless take pains to make distinctions between the 90's and the 80's, when speculators inflated the market, and anything and everything sold. The whole thing fell apart when the Japanese economic bubble burst.
This market, by contrast, remains more orderly and rational, they said. "Now," Mr. Burge said, "collectors are so well advised. They have advisers, curators, restorers, conservators following them around in packs. Anyone with serious money is buying with advice." For the most part the frenzy is gone, except perhaps in contemporary art, some experts said, although not for attribution.
The market is so strong that some collectors are starting to sell. For example, in July -- also an unusual occurrence -- Richard York, an American art dealer, received an 1871 Hudson River painting by Jasper Cropsey from "one person who thinks it's a good time to sell." Both the Monet and the Cezanne at Sotheby's are voluntary sales. And Mr. Burge promised, "It will be a rich fall because of discretionary selling. You'll see."
The appearance of discretionary selling has both positive and negative implications. It is desirable because dealers and auctioneers have had a hard time finding good, fresh material to sell. On the other hand, it does mean that some people think prices are peaking. Or perhaps, everyone hopes, the sellers simply want to trade up to better, more expensive works.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Fruits of 'Realism'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

 BODY:
The savagery taking place in East Timor -- armed Indonesian thugs taking over the territory by mayhem and murder -- is something besides a human disaster. It carries a profound lesson for international affairs: the price that can be paid for Kissingerian "realism."
Henry Kissinger, then Secretary of State, and President Ford visited the tyrant ruler of Indonesia, President Suharto, in December 1975. Mr. Kissinger knew that Mr. Suharto planned to invade East Timor. He made no objection, on the ground that it would be unrealistic to offend Indonesia. 
 The day after he and President Ford left, the Indonesians invaded. They used arms obtained from U.S. aid: a violation of American law. That was pointed out to Mr. Kissinger in a cable from his State Department aides, but he angrily rejected the point.
"I know what the law is," he told a staff meeting when he got back to Washington, "but how can it be in the U.S. national interest for us to . . . kick the Indonesians in the teeth?"
That was Kissingerian realism: the view that the United States should overlook brutalities by friendly authoritarian regimes because they provided "stability." Thus Mr. Kissinger supported Augusto Pinochet in Chile and the Shah in Iran.
The people of East Timor have paid a heavy price for that realism. In the invasion and subsequent occupation, a third of the population of 600,000 died. The Indonesian military carried out, over many years, what The Financial Times of London called "unspeakable atrocities." Now, after voting overwhelmingly for independence, many thousands have been driven out of their country by militiamen armed by Indonesia.
Indonesia has also paid heavily for its seizure of East Timor, and it is going to pay a lot more. The stubborn East Timorese insistence on independence has inspired other remote areas of the archipelago state to rebellion. And what foreign company will want to invest in a country that, apart from human concerns, cannot control its own military?
The United Nations and the entire international community have been badly hurt by the debacle in East Timor. Having led the way to the referendum on independence, they relied on Indonesian promises to maintain security because -- once again -- they did not want to offend the Government.
Now U.N. employees have been killed and U.N. offices sacked by the militia forces. The international community has been made to look hapless against a ragtag challenge. And the only response by the U.N. Security Council so far has been to send a mission: not to East Timor but to Jakarta.
The international community has been so silent about all that has happened in East Timor over the last 24 years, and so feeble, that it has a responsibility to act firmly now. Many responses are available.
The United States should immediately end all programs involving the Indonesian military: training, sharing of intelligence, military aid. Indonesia's military is either covertly supporting the militiamen or has failed to oppose their rampage, violating many assurances.
The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are heavily involved in keeping the Indonesian economy afloat. The country has asked for $71 billion in funding this year from the two institutions. Further tranches should be withheld until legitimate order is restored in East Timor.
If those measures do not bring the Indonesian Government and military leaders to their senses, it will be necessary -- quickly -- to send in an international peacekeeping force.
American political leaders, especially, should reflect on the larger lesson. Ignoring human realities may not, after all, be "realistic." The Shah did not bring stability to Iran; his policies opened the way to a virulently anti-American regime. General Pinochet awaits justice in the British courts.
Using American troops abroad is always, rightly, a delicate decision. But it is not so hard to speak out, and the voice of American leaders carries weight. In Bosnia we learned the price of failing to speak out promptly against aggression. The price of silence on East Timor remains to be calculated.

HEADLINE: Prisons as Mental Hospitals

 BODY:
Rikers Island handles some 25,000 mentally ill prisoners in New York City each year. While in jail, even if only for a few days, they can get treatment and are housed in special units if their problems are severe. But afterward is a different story. Many have neither homes nor families, and carry histories of repeated arrests. It does not take a trained social scientist to predict what will happen to these people if they are left to their own resources after release. Nevertheless, for many of them the city's post-incarceration plan is brutally simple: They are put on a bus and dropped off at Queens Plaza before dawn, with $1.50 and a two-fare Metrocard.
Advocates for the mentally ill recently filed a lawsuit asking that the city be required to plan for the continuing treatment of these prisoners after release. Some of the cases they cited seem to underscore the growing concern that the prisons are becoming the housing of last resort for the state's mentally ill. Brad H. was a homeless man who actually grew up in a mental hospital. He had been jailed 26 times as an adult, always treated for mental illness at Rikers, and then released without any plan for his future treatment. Another, Robert K., was a suicidal schizophrenic whose 30 separate confinements followed the same pattern. 
 The Urban Justice Center, which is leading the advocates who filed the suit, says that prisoners who have been prescribed medication at Rikers to control their symptoms are released without enough drugs to tide them over until they can get a prescription on the outside. While most of the mentally ill prisoners would be eligible for Medicaid, the advocates say, the prison makes no effort to help them qualify for it.
Members of the Giuliani administration point out that there are already programs that help some mentally ill inmates prepare for the future. But the city denies that inmates at Rikers have a legal right to the sort of pre-release planning that mental patients at hospitals are supposed to get. Most of the prisoners are awaiting trial, and typically stay only a few days. The city fears the lawsuit could lead to an expensive mandate that will be impossible to fulfill.
Court mandates are often a costly and cumbersome result of government's failure to do something obvious. Whether mentally ill prisoners have a legal right to help in applying for Medicaid, maintaining their medication program or finding a treatment program on the outside seems beside the point. From a humane point of view, and in the interests of public safety, dumping inmates who may have little or no control over their behavior onto the city streets is outrageous. On a policy level, it makes no economic sense. Any service that keeps the mentally ill from returning to the prison system saves money. There is no more costly way to treat them than to confine them in jail.
The city's first response to the Urban Justice Center's lawsuit should be to review the way it handles the release of mentally ill people, and determine what services it could offer that might help keep more of them on medication and under treatment. Once Rikers Island accepts its obligation to offer whatever help it reasonably can to this particularly vulnerable population, it will be much easier to argue that it should not be mandated to do more.

HEADLINE: European Stocks Gain as Rate Fears Ease

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Most European stock markets rose yesterday, led by fast-growing companies as concern faded that interest rates would soon rise.
In Britain, the FTSE 100 rose 43.6 points, or 0.7 percent, to 6,375.7. The DAX Xetra index of 30 major companies in Germany rose 64.33 points, or 1.21 percent, to 5,400.55. But in France, the benchmark index fell 4.33 points, or 0.09 percent, to 4,668.04. 
 "We're going to see a shift into European markets," said Heiko Veit, who is adding Deutsche Bank and Siemens shares to the 500 million mark ($270 million) fund he manages at BW Asset Consulting. "There is earnings momentum."
In Tokyo, Japanese stocks rose for the first time in three days, led by exporters, as a report showing lower-than-expected United States wage inflation eased concern that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates a third time this year. The benchmark Nikkei 225-stock average rose 126.52, or 0.7 percent, to 17,756.51. Canon, Fujitsu and Bridgestone accounted for more than a third of the benchmark average's gains on hopes that stable rates would sustain growth in the United States economy and demand for their products.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng index gained 206.85, to 13,385.16. South Korea's stock market rose 32.60, to 943.22, its second day of gains.
Financial markets in the United States will reopen today. They were closed yesterday in observance of Labor Day.
DaimlerChrysler, Lafarge and British American Tobacco led gains among automakers, building-materials suppliers and cigarette makers, respectively. All but one of the 19 industry groups in the Dow Jones Europe index rose.
Concern that interest rates are about to rise has lessened, as one policy maker after another at the European Central Bank said inflation did not look like a threat. The latest was the Bank of France Governor Jean-Claude Trichet, one of the 17 members of the rate-setting E.C.B. council, who told a weekend conference in Cernobbio, Italy, "I'm confident that Europe will see noninflationary growth."
Steady or falling rates make it less expensive to buy high-growth stocks, like computer and telecommunications companies.
"We're not so concerned about the rate situation for the moment -- profit forecasts keep getting revised higher," said Lionel Antoinat, who helps manage about $2.7 billion at BBL Asset Management in Paris.
Phone stocks' gains helped push the Dow Jones telecommunications services index 2 percent higher -- the biggest gain by an industry group -- for a two-day rise of 5.4 percent.
Car makers gained after a report showed that sales of imported automobiles in Japan rose 0.3 percent in August from a year earlier. DaimlerChrysler advanced 0.81 euro, to 72.91. Sales of Chrysler vehicles rose 28.5 percent in the month, while Mercedes-Benz sales increased 39.5 percent.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Investigating Russian Bank's Use of Loans

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 6

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund began its own investigation today into whether the Russian central bank misused the fund's loans, officials said.
The investigation comes amid allegations that money from the fund may have been illegally diverted through the Bank of New York. American investigators reportedly believe that up to $10 billion may have been funneled by Russians through the bank, and some suggested that I.M.F. aid might have been part of that money. 
 But fund officials have insisted that the new investigation is unrelated to the allegations involving the Bank of New York.
The investigation of the Russian central bank is being conducted by the fund and the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, and is examining whether the bank misused fund loans by means of foreign affiliates, a source close to the investigation told Dow Jones Newswires.
The central bank has misled the I.M.F. about its finances before, and the Russian Government had to agree to independent reviews of its books as a condition for a $4.5 billion loan the fund approved in July.
Russia has received the first $640 million installment of the loan. The second installment, expected next month, will depend on the fund's assessment of Russia's compliance with the terms of the loan.
"We are ready to provide the necessary information," Deputy Finance Minister Oleg Vyugin was quoted as saying today on television.
After the allegations of money laundering through the Bank of New York were made public, the United States -- the dominant member of the fund -- said it would delay a decision on whether it should support new fund loans to Russia until a full accounting was made of money already loaned.
An earlier investigation by PriceWaterhouseCoopers found that in 1996 the central bank secretly moved $1.2 billion of its reserves to an offshore company, Fimaco, based on the Channel Island of Jersey. The deputy managing director of the fund, Stanley Fischer, said the fund would have suspended Russia's loan program at the time if the truth had been known.
Money laundering and capital flight have been major problems for Russia throughout this decade, with tens of billions of dollars pouring out of the country.

HEADLINE: Americans Lead the World in Hours Worked

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Americans put in the longest hours among workers in industrialized countries, according to a report released today.
But increasingly efficient Europeans and Japanese workers are chipping away at the United States lead in productivity -- the amount of goods and services produced for each hour worked -- according to the 600-page study by the International Labor Organization. 
 Americans put in an average 1,966 hours at work in 1997, the most recent year studied. That is 83 more hours, an increase of nearly 4 percent, than the average 1,883 recorded by United States workers in 1980, according to a United Nations agency report on global labor trends.
"Currently, the U.S. worker works more hours than his or her counterpart in other industrialized countries and he or she also leads the way in terms of productivity," said Lawrence Jeff Johnson, the labor organization economist and co-author of the study, "Key Indicators of the Labor Market."
The annual report examines 18 facets of the labor market, including productivity, costs, unemployment and underemployment and hours worked in more than 240 countries between 1980 and 1997.
American workers continue to outstrip their European and Asian counterparts, producing an average $49,905 of goods in 1996 -- more than other countries for which statistics were available. But the gap in some cases was narrow. The French lead the Europeans, producing an average $47,958 for each worker, followed by Germany at $46,100 and Britain at $38,890. In Japan, the average worker produced $39,434 in 1996.
In comparing productivity gains, however, the United States was behind its rivals in the period studied. The country gained 22 percent between 1980 and 1996. That fell short of the gains of 141 percent in Thailand, 43 percent in Japan and 30 percent in France, Germany and England in the same period, the study found.
The findings followed last week's United States Labor Department report that American productivity growth had slowed from 6.8 percent in manufacturing in the first three months of 1999, to a rate of 4.8 percent.
"While the benefits of hard work are clear, working more is not the same as working better," the labor organization's head, Juan Somavia, said of the report's findings.
While Americans were putting in more time at the office, Western Europeans logged fewer hours, with the French, who are considering legislation to shorten the work week to 35 hours, clocking in 1,656 hours annually in 1997 and the Germans working an average of 1,560 in 1996, the last year for which comparable data was available. Norway was at the bottom, with an average 1,399 hours worked in 1997.
Japanese workers logged 1,889 hours in 1995, the last year for which statistics were available, compared with 2,121 in 1980.
 The report was produced by the International Labor Organization together with the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and drew on statistics from the United Nations, the World Bank, and the statistical offices of the European Union and the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

HEADLINE: Clinton as Laborer in Campaign for Schools

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 6

 BODY:
President Clinton performed a bit of light labor today at a 75-year-old elementary school here to dramatize his call to Congress to finance a plan to build or modernize 6,000 schools across the nation.
Donning a hard hat and rolling up the sleeves of a blue work shirt, the President used a cordless electric screwdriver to help assemble a computer desk at the school, Coleman Place Elementary. 
 Mr. Clinton seemed unfamiliar with a tool used by millions of American homeowners and weekend hobbyists. He joked that with the purchase of a home last week in Chappaqua, N.Y., the first private residence he has owned in two decades, he would have to get with the home-improvement program.
"Now that I'm a homeowner, I better get one of these," the President said, as he uncertainly wielded the electric tool. "I've never seen one of these."
Mr. Clinton's Labor Day project in classroom 29 of the school took about five minutes. The work was completed by volunteers from a local construction trades union.
Later, speaking to several hundred students and parents in the schoolyard, the President said that rebuilding the nation's schools should be one of Government's top priorities.
Pointing at 10 trailers being used as temporary classrooms at Coleman Place, Mr. Clinton said, "Now, folks, we have to fix this."
He said that 3,000 trailers were being used as classrooms in Virginia alone and that tens of thousands more were serving that purpose across the country.
"This is a national problem," the President said. "If we can meet this big long-term challenge to America, don't we have the obligation to do it?"
The Administration has proposed a $3.7 billion Federal tax relief program to help local school districts float construction bonds backed by the Government. The Republican Congress rejected the plan last year, but it appears to stand a better chance of passage this fall with a smaller Republican majority in the House.
Before returning to Washington this evening, Mr. Clinton appeared at the annual Labor Day picnic and political rally sponsored by Representative Robert C. Scott, Democrat of Virginia, at Mr. Scott's mother's house in Newport News, Va.
While not technically a fund-raising event, the picnic did have as one of its goals energizing support for Senator Charles S. Robb, Democrat of Virginia, who faces a tough re-election challenge next year from former Gov. George F. Allen, a Republican.
Mr. Scott, a member of the House Judiciary Committee, was one of the President's most ardent defenders during the panel's impeachment debate last fall. He is seeking a fifth term in the House.
The President plugged the two lawmakers' re-election bids and once again criticized the Republicans' $792 billion tax-cut proposal. He said passage of the bill would raise interest rates for all Americans and jeopardize the eight-year economic expansion.
And he delivered a Labor Day endorsement of unions. He was accompanied on the trip today by John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.; Sandra Feldman, president of the American Federation of Teachers, and Robert Chase, president of the National Education Association.
"I'm pro-business," the President said, "but I'm pro-labor, too. I don't think you can help the economy if you hurt the working people."

HEADLINE: Jordan's King Visits Kuwait as Tensions Ease

BYLINE: Agence France-Presse 

DATELINE: KUWAIT CITY, Sept. 6

 BODY:
King Abdullah II of Jordan began a two-day visit to Kuwait today, the first visit by a Jordanian ruler since relations soured during Iraq's occupation of Kuwait in 1990 and 1991. 
 Kuwait accused Jordan of supporting Iraq and froze all ties, although relations have recently improved. In March, Jordan reopened its Embassy in Kuwait.
The King was met at the airport by the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, and said the visit was a "historic new chapter in the brotherly relations which bind us to Kuwait."
His comments echoed a front-page editorial in Al-Qabas newspaper here that called for greater cooperation between the two countries. A political analyst, Shamlan al-Issa, said such cooperation should be encouraged by a Kuwaiti offer of economic aid to Jordan so that Jordan would be less dependent on Iraq.
"Oil, direct economic assistance and opening the Kuwaiti job market to Jordanians are weapons that can be used to apply this strategy," Mr. Issa said in an interview.
Nearly 300,000 Jordanians of Palestinian origin who were working in the emirate in 1990 were expelled after the United States-led coalition won the gulf war in 1991.
Information Minister Saad Mohammed bin Teflah al-Ajmi of Kuwait said on Saturday that the improved climate with Jordan would hasten the overthrow of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
On Sunday, an Iraqi spokesman said the Kuwaiti leaders were corrupt, people who "resort to every possible type of deceit to destroy any form of Arab solidarity."
Jordan has relied on Iraq for all its supplies of crude oil since the gulf war. Ninety thousand barrels of oil a day, or 3.8 million gallons, is transported by road, with United Nations approval. Jordan is also a crossing point for Iraqis who travel abroad, because of the air embargo against Iraq.
The Jordanian Information Minister, Ayman Majali, had said earlier that there was no fixed agenda for the King's talks in Kuwait.

HEADLINE: The Frantic Final Days Before School;
Long Before Doors Open, a Principal Is Busy Juggling Crises

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
Working in his cluttered principal's office at a table piled high with memos, stacks of school schedules and blueprints for the library renovation, Ron Attivissimo should have looked like a man under siege the other day.
A desperate mother wanted to speak to him about transferring her daughter to his already overcrowded school, James Peter Sinnott Middle School 218 in East New York, Brooklyn. A man was waiting to talk to him about a teaching job. An architect and his team were expected to arrive any minute to talk about the library plans. And the phones did not and would not stop ringing. 
 But Mr. Attivissimo, a principal in one of the toughest and poorest areas in the city, Community School District 19, prepared for the reopening of school this Thursday with the relative cool of a seasoned Broadway producer.
He and staff members worked long hours last week and over the weekend, juggling phone calls; drawing up student and teacher schedules; interviewing prospective teachers, 5 of whom were hired in a day; assigning classrooms to 15 new teachers; making room for 500 new sixth graders, and trying to determine who failed summer school and who passed. All within the constraints of a tight budget.
"It doesn't happen overnight," said Mr. Attivissimo, who has been in the business for 32 years, 9 of them as principal. "No one walks into a school one day and opens it the next day, especially not in this day and age."
Mr. Attivissimo, 52, like all city school principals, is under more pressure than ever to improve performance in this era of high-stakes testing and increased accountability.
In June, for example, in a shake-up of the city's worst performing schools, the District 19 superintendent was fired after fewer than a third of his students performed at grade level in reading and math on standardized tests. The superintendent, Robert E. Riccobono, is appealing his dismissal.
M.S. 218, a magnet school for health and health careers, was one of the few schools in District 19 to show strong gains in reading. Mr. Attivissimo is eager to achieve even greater gains, but he is acutely aware of the pressures and spotlight he and many other principals are under.
"It's tough," Mr. Attivissimo said, running both hands over his narrow, heavily lined face. "But I wouldn't be here if it wasn't worth it. I can go to a school on Long Island where 90 percent of the kids read at or above grade level. I can sit back behind my desk, relax and no one's going to come down on me because my reading scores aren't there. But here, there is a job to do in helping these kids succeed in their future lives. It's a commitment."
He started preparing for opening day on Aug. 6, though the Board of Education did not require principals, assistant principals and supervisors to report back until last week. (It also does not pay them for returning to work early; Mr. Attivissimo makes $73,000 a year, with or without overtime.)
In a way, Mr. Attivissimo's job is much like that of a Broadway producer: a delicate and demanding juggling act involving a cast of hundreds, innumerable logistical obstacles and a show that indeed must go on. The stakes, of course, are much higher. And forget the big budget, glitz and applause.
What follows is a snapshot of such a task, three days last week as reopening approached for Mr. Attivissimo and his staff.
 
Monday
So Many Details, So Little Time
 Mr. Attivissimo was greeted by several staff members, some of whom were returning to the four-story building with blue window frames for the first time after a long, hot summer.
Most of the activity took place in his office, about the size of two classrooms, and a small office to the side, where two workers with pencils huddled over several broad sheets lined with tiny squares. They were making out schedules for the school's 70 teachers, 23 of them new.
Short, thin and confident, Mr. Attivissimo sat behind two Formica-topped conference tables, sipping coffee, answering questions and signing papers shuttled in by his secretary, Barbara Abramowitz. The peach-colored walls of his office are lined with posters from Paris, Madrid, Ivory Coast and Mexico, reflecting his background as a French and Spanish teacher.
"This child is being held back," said Phyllis Schneider, a longtime math teacher who was there to help out, rushing into his office with a letter from the state. "He should have gone to summer school."
The lines in Mr. Attivissimo's narrow face grew deeper. He buried his face in his hands before looking at the letter.
"No, he isn't," Mr. Attivissimo said confidently. "I know this student. They're wrong."
He retrieved the student's records from a stack of nearby papers. They showed that the student had passed his standardized tests and did not require summer school. Bingo. The child was moving on to the eighth grade.
"One kid saved," Mr. Attivissimo said proudly.
But another problem surfaced. An architect from the School Construction Authority arrived with a design team. The library, on the second floor, was being renovated to give students a larger reading area, but the principal discovered that the blueprints showed that too much space was given to the new computer lab. The plans had to be redone to allow more room for reading. Renovations are to begin sometime this fall.
Then there was Alice Williams, 41, and her daughter Jessica, 13, who came to plead with Mr. Attivissimo to allow Jessica to enroll at the school. The school zoned for their Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood is too dangerous, Mrs. Williams said. She planned to move Jessica to her sister's house across the street from M.S. 218.
Crowding, Mr. Attivissimo explained, was a problem. But he asked if he could see Jessica's report card. She was a good student. But he was concerned about her 41 absences and 24 late days.
The marks, Mrs. Williams said, were recording mistakes made at a poorly run school. A stickler for attendance for students and teachers, Mr. Attivissimo grimaced as he handed the report card back and told them to come back on Thursday.
"He's nice," Ms. Williams, an unemployed mother of six, said as she packed up to go. "He sees a good student and is willing to give her a chance."
Next was a meeting with a man who was applying for a teaching position. The 60-year-old applicant did not have the credentials for the job, but he was enthusiastic and eager to teach. So Mr. Attivissimo met with him for 30 minutes anyway.
But Mr. Attivissimo was in a bind. He still needed about 12 new teachers. He made plans to send staff members to a hiring fair on Wednesday.
This school year, he will need more teachers than ever as the district completes the final phase of a three-year plan to move the sixth grade from elementary to middle schools. Enrollment at the school, which is largely black and Hispanic, is increasing from about 900 to 1,400.
"The sixth grade is going from 6 classes to 14," Mr. Attivissimo said. "We had a number of teachers who went to work on Long Island because of more pay and a closer proximity to their homes. How can anyone say no to $10,000 to $15,000 more and be 15 minutes away from home?"
 
Tuesday
A Meeting Here, A Rally There
Mr. Attivissimo attended an all-day meeting at district headquarters about Breakthrough for Learning, a program in which teachers and administrators can receive bonuses if student achievement improves. The program also includes teacher training and regular student assessment.
Run by the Board of Education and the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce -- one of the largest business groups in the city -- the program will put District 19 under the spotlight for the second year. Among other things, the meeting focused on teaching strategies and the extended school day.
Mr. Attivissimo says that he is a proponent of the Breakthrough program, but that he believes the bonuses should be aimed more toward the teachers and assistant principals. Perhaps it exposes his working class roots, which were planted in Bensonhurst. His father worked for years at a warehouse for the A.&P., while his mother stayed home to raise him and a younger sister.
Today, he lives in Forest Hills, Queens, with his wife and two cats.
"Of course bonuses are issued regularly to the best performers," Mr. Attivissimo said. "But I don't think you work harder because you're getting a bonus. I don't think because I could get $14,000 more a year, I'm going to do more. I don't think many of our teachers could do more than they're doing."
He excused himself from the Breakthrough meeting in the afternoon to join hundreds of colleagues at a principal's union rally at the Board of Education headquarters at 110 Livingston Street. The city's principals have been working without a contract for about three and a half years.
Negotiations have been deadlocked over tenure. The city wants to do away with it, but union leaders say no.
Mr. Attivissimo, like a growing number of principals, supports doing away with tenure if the city can guarantee that they will not be fired capriciously. Mr. Attivissimo is a tenured principal.
"The union fears we will lose due process," he said. "I disagree with the union a little bit. We should be held accountable. It's been three and a half years that we've been working without a contract. I'd like to know I'm worth something."
 
Wednesday
Five New Teachers, One New Crisis
Mr. Attivissimo began by deciding to extend the school day for about 120 seventh graders in the magnet program. The move would cost about $30,000, but his $5.9 million budget was already committed. He needed to appeal for assistance to the new superintendent, Joan Mahon-Powell, a proponent of longer school days. The school's sixth graders are already on an extended day, which lengthens the school day by an hour.
He also began holding back-to-back teacher interviews -- about five in all. He answered phone calls and questions from Mrs. Abramowitz throughout the interviews.
In the midst of it all, he managed to keep focused on the candidates and put them at ease, though two showed signs of stress. A woman perspired through her kelly green suit jacket, and a young man nervously chewed gum. He hired all five.
The new teachers, including a former student from 218, were carefully screened by Eileen Lew, an assistant principal, and Mrs. Schneider, the math teacher, who is also a lead teacher in the Breakthrough program, at a hiring fair at the district headquarters that morning.
Mr. Attivissimo's schedule was overflowing with other tasks: more resumes to plow through, classroom assignments to make, teacher schedules to finish and staff development issues.
But first, he had to rush to another meeting with Ms. Mahon-Powell at the district office. She wanted him to mentor a new principal. He left his staff with a mess of papers and shouted orders to Mrs. Lew as he ran backward down the long, empty hall.
There was a crisis: a longtime teacher had just called to say he had accepted a job on Long Island.
"Get him on the phone!" he yelled. "See if you can change his mind."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
New York Incomes Decline, Report Says

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The incomes of most New Yorkers declined in the 1990's relative to the cost of living, according to a report released to coincide with Labor Day weekend.
The disparity between the rich and the poor is greater in New York than in any other state, and the gap is growing at a faster rate, said James Parrott, chief economist at the Fiscal Policy Institute, a nonprofit Albany organization that issued the report. The group is supported in part by labor unions. 
 Middle-income families saw their earnings decline by 8 percent since the late 1980's, while incomes for the poorest 40 percent of families fell between 13 percent and 15 percent, the report said. At the same time, the incomes of the richest 20 percent of households grew by nearly 30 percent, the report added.
The report said New York City saw sharper income and wage declines than the rest of the state. On average, income fell by nearly 20 percent for all except the richest 40 percent of families.
Average hourly wages rose because of growth in the securities industry, but the median hourly wage fell 6.3 percent, the report said.
All the figures are relative to increases in the cost of living over the last decade, Fiscal Policy Institute officials said.
Mr. Parrott said the downstate region was heavily reliant on the performance of Wall Street. In recent years, Wall Street has experienced robust growth, but only 7 percent of New York households have reaped the benefits, receiving 85 percent of the capital gains, mostly from the sale of stocks.
The economy of upstate New York fared worse, as the region lost high-paying manufacturing jobs and gained low-paying service jobs.
Matthew Maguire, a spokesman for the Business Council of New York State, a statewide chamber of commerce, said the report's findings were "largely old news and old thinking." He acknowledged that the state's economy deteriorated in the early 1990's because of the national recession, but said it was "on the right track now."
Steve Kagann, Gov. George E. Pataki's chief economist, agreed, saying the report gives "a distorted view of the economic conditions in New York."
Mr. Kagann said the state ranks 20th in the nation in private-sector job growth, up from 50th in 1994.

HEADLINE: EATING WELL;
Different Genes, Same Old Label

BYLINE: By Marian Burros 

 BODY:
WHEN a field of genetically altered corn at the University of Maine was destroyed by protesters in mid-August, it was a rare hint that uneasiness over bioengineering in agriculture is growing among Americans. Such actions have become common overseas, with experimental fields burned in England, and the European Union and Japan decreeing that genetically engineered food must be labeled. But Americans have so far been slow to anger.
One reason may be that most of them don't have a clue that many foods are already being made with genetically engineered ingredients: no labeling is required in this country, nor is Government approval. 
 But the September issue of Consumer Reports includes a surprising shopping list of products tested by Consumers Union that were found to contain genetically engineered soy, corn or other ingredients. Among them were three powdered baby formulas -- Enfamil Prosobee soy formula, Similac Isomil soy formula and Nestle Carnation Alsoy -- as well as several soy burgers, including Boca Burger, Chef Max's Favorite, Morningstar Farms Better 'n Burgers and Green Giant Harvest Burgers. Ovaltine Malt powdered beverage mix, Bac-Os Bacon Flavor bits, Bravos Tortilla Chips Nacho Nacho, Old El Paso 12 taco shells and Jiffy Corn muffin mix also tested positive for genetically altered ingredients.
Consumers Union said it tested breakfast cereals and cooking oils too, but that the results were inconclusive. It also reported that 60 percent of all hard-cheese products are made with a biotech version of rennet, the enzyme from calves' stomachs. And it analyzed McDonald's McVeggie Burgers, sold in some of the chain's New York City restaurants, and they tested positive.
Consumers Union said it chose to test foods that were likely to include genetically altered ingredients; the testing analyzed the DNA makeup of those foods.
Genetic engineering involves the splicing of plant or animal genes into the DNA of other species, either to improve crop yields or to ward off insects or disease. Corn, potatoes, squash, papayas, soybeans and canola are among the bioengineered crops already on the market. All a company has to do to grow bioengineered products is certify to the Agriculture Department that it will take safety precautions.
Because so few safety studies have been done, there is no evidence that genetically engineered food now on the market is unsafe to eat. But some scientists and consumer advocates worry about the potential for unknown allergens, an increase in natural toxic substances, a decrease in nutritional value and especially environmental damage. In addition, some religious groups are concerned about the possibility that genes from foods they are forbidden to eat will be put into other foods, like shellfish genes into a tomato. The environmental concern has led to protests like the one in Maine, in which a group calling itself Seeds of Resistance claimed responsibility for cutting down 1,000 stalks of genetically engineered corn in an experimental field near Bangor.
But the big issue, as Consumer Reports emphasized, is whether consumers should be informed when bioengineered ingredients are used, so they can decide whether to avoid them.
A recent survey by the International Food Information Council found that 71 percent of consumers in this country rated themselves as poorly informed about food biotechnology. (Only 2 to 3 percent thought soybeans were genetically engineered, for instance.) But when they do know, they often act. After bovine growth hormone was approved in 1993 to increase milk production, sales of organic milk skyrocketed, and last year they doubled. That still represents only 0.3 percent of the $75 billion dairy market, but analysts say the figure could reach 2 percent by 2005. Between 10 and 30 percent of the nation's dairy cows have been injected with the gene-altered hormone rBGH.
Fears about genetically modified corn were raised last spring when it was reported that pollen from such corn killed monarch butterfly larvae in a laboratory experiment. Entomologists at Iowa State University are following up on the experiment in the field. Consumer Reports said that John Obrycki, one of the entomologists, reported that mortality data indicate that there is indeed a threat to the monarch.
Since the European Union has refused to accept some genetically modified American crops, farmers have begun to pay attention to the issue, too. A judge in Brazil has also banned the sale there of Monsanto's Roundup Ready soybean seeds, which are resistant to the company's Roundup herbicide.
Today, genetically engineered crops cover one-fourth of the cropland in the United States, representing 35 percent of all corn, almost 55 percent of all soybeans and nearly half of all cotton.
Consumer Reports, which has a circulation of 4.5 million, offered recommendations for dealing with the issue of genetically altered foods, like requiring a Federal review of the safety of such foods for humans before they are put on the market.
These were some of its other recommendations:
* That safety reviews be required before farmers are allowed to plant bioengineered species, in an effort to prevent insects from developing resistance to pesticides, the creation of superweeds and harm to beneficial insects.
* That a single national standard be established certifying that "organic" food meets certain standards, and that genetically engineered food not be considered organic. No Federal standard exists now.
* That the agriculture industry be made liable for economic or biological damage resulting from genetically engineered crops.
* That genetically engineered foods, both domestic and imported, be labeled. As the magazine put it, "Consumers have a fundamental right to know what they eat."
In a Time magazine poll published in January, 81 percent of the respondents said genetically engineered food should be labeled. In fact, labeling can work more than one way: some dairies and tofu makers have found that they can increase sales by noting on labels that their products are free of genetically engineered ingredients.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
30-Year Treasury's Yield Rises To 6.07% in Light Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury yields rose yesterday as investors awaited an inflation report scheduled for release on Friday and braced for speeches by Federal Reserve officials.
Government securities were also under pressure from coming issues of corporate debt, which are expected to compete with Treasuries for investors' cash. 
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 26/32, to 100 23/32; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, rose to 6.07 percent from 6.01 percent on Friday. The Treasury market was closed on Monday in observance of Labor Day.
Light trading continued to plague the market throughout the day, exaggerating shifts in buying. Analysts noted that the bond market had shown a penchant for volatility lately with plenty of obstacles to choke off any attempt at a sustained rally, including a busy calendar of Fed speeches and a steady stream of economic data.
This week's appearances at the podium by the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, and two Fed governors, Laurence H. Meyer and Roger W. Ferguson Jr., "have the power to send the bond market scurrying for cover," said Adam Blankman, Treasury market analyst for Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco.
Treasury prices slumped yesterday in what traders described as an uneventful session. Mr. Blankman noted that supply was weighing on the market, though estimates of the corporate debt this month are being reduced from about $60 billion to the range of $30 billion to $40 billion.
The firms that manage corporate bond sales often hedge against possible losses by selling Government securities before the corporate issues are sold, then buying back the Treasuries after the corporate issues are in the hands of investors.
Market participants looking for signs of the Fed's position on the economy and the direction of interest rates will be paying particular attention to the Fed officials' remarks this week and to a Government report on producer prices, or inflation at the manufacturing level, on Friday.
Analysts expect the report to show a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in August after gaining two-tenths of 1 percent in July.
The three-month bill was the session's top performer. "Thanks to the laws of supply and demand, this is the only instrument on the yield curve that is above water today," Mr. Blankman said.
The Treasury's bill auction was well received. The three-month issue was awarded at 4.72 percent, a little better than expected.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Ford Loses Bid to Keep Documents Off Internet

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Asserting that an Internet site has the same free-speech rights as newspapers and other traditional media, a Federal judge ruled here today that the Ford Motor Company could not stop the owner of the site from using information that he had gleaned from confidential Ford documents.
Ford had requested a preliminary injunction barring Robert Lane, the owner of the Web site about the company, from using, copying or disclosing the documents, which Ford said contain trade secrets. But Judge Nancy G. Edmunds of Federal District Court ruled that free speech under the First Amendment took precedence over Ford's secrets. 
 Newspapers and magazines have won cases over the years preventing corporations from exercising prior restraint on the publishing of information. Today's ruling adds to a small but growing collection of court rulings granting the same Constitutional protection to Web sites, said Mike Godwin, a lawyer specializing in free-speech issues on the Internet.
"It's an important case because it further establishes the scope of First Amendment protections in cyberspace," Mr. Godwin said.
The first cases involving prior restraint on the Internet were filed by the Church of Scientology in an effort to stop the electronic posting of church documents, Mr. Godwin said, adding that the church had prevailed in some cases and lost in others.
Judge Edmunds couched her decision today in broad language, saying: "In the realm of law, we are only beginning to grapple with the impact of the communications revolution, and this case represents just one part of one skirmish -- a clash between our commitment to the freedom of speech and the press, and our dedication to the protection of commercial innovation and intellectual property. In this case, the battle is won by the First Amendment."
Judge Edmunds did grant Ford a preliminary injunction barring Mr. Lane, a 32-year-old nursing student, from infringing on the company's copyrights. This might prevent Mr. Lane from posting Ford documents in their entirety on his Web site, as he had done until Ford sued him two weeks ago. But the copyright decision had little legal significance, several First Amendment lawyers said, because Mr. Lane's lawyer had already promised the court last week that his client would not post any more Ford documents on the site. Mr. Lane can write about the documents and quote them extensively without worrying about copyright issues, the lawyers added.
Ford's lawsuit, accusing Mr. Lane of violating its trademarks, copyrights and trade secrets, is still pending and could result in financial damages against Mr. Lane. His lawyer, Mark Pickrell, also agreed in court last week that his client would tell Ford whatever he knew about who provided the documents. But Mr. Lane said in court he did not know who had mailed them to him or dropped them off at his home, so this agreement may not help Ford.
Mr. Lane's site, which is called www.blueovalnews.com, is named for Ford's corporate logo, a blue oval with "Ford" inside. The site was started last year to provide news for Ford Mustang fans, but broadened this summer after Ford became critical of some of the news posted on it.
Mr. Pickrell welcomed today's ruling as a victory for free speech. Ford said it was pleased that Mr. Lane's constitutional rights had been respected but also glad that its copyrights would be protected. Ford lawyers want to discuss the ruling with Mr. Pickrell, and have not yet decided whether to appeal, said Terry Bresnihan, a company spokesman.
The case is particularly awkward for Ford because many of the secret documents say the company may someday be able to build automobiles, particularly sport utility vehicles, that emit less pollution and have better fuel efficiency than current models. Yet the company is lobbying against tighter emissions and fuel-economy regulations as unrealistic. The company builds the least polluting sports utility vehicles currently on the market, although not the most fuel-efficient.
The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed new rules that would crack down on tailpipe emissions from sport utility vehicles in particular. Separately, the Senate is considering whether the Administration should be allowed to raise fuel-economy standards for sport utility vehicles, pickups and minivans.
Mr. Bresnihan said today that the company had been frank in discussions with the Environmental Protection Agency about the feasibility of lower-emissions vehicles. Documents regarding fuel economy describe technologies that may not be feasible for technological and marketing reasons, he said.
David Cohen, a spokesman for the environmental agency, declined to comment on the documents, but said, "We're convinced that the rules we've proposed and the final standard will be the toughest ever."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
East TimorChaos Is Seen as Imperiling Indonesia Recovery

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 7

 BODY:
A failure to quell the chaos in East Timor could strangle Indonesia's fragile economic recovery, government officials and independent analysts warned today.
As the violence takes on every appearance of a military-backed terror campaign, officials fear that foreign lenders will shun Indonesia while local business will lose confidence in the Government's authority. 
 "If we are not able to overcome this, the recovery could slip away and we could fall into another deep crisis," said Umar Juoro, an economic adviser to Indonesia's President, B. J. Habibie. "We've got to be very careful."
The Jakarta stock market, after plummeting on Monday, leveled off today. But Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, continued weakening, reaching a rate of 8,250 to the dollar in Asian trading and settling in New York later at 8,245. Analysts regard an exchange rate of 8,000 rupiah to the dollar as a psychological benchmark.
Mr. Juoro said his greatest fear was that foreign lenders like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank would cut off billions of dollars in aid. Although these two agencies have not directly threatened such action, both have expressed shock at the flood of violence.
"We're terribly concerned and worried about the East Timorese, and we're following the situation closely," said Ben Fisher, the World Bank's deputy director and country program coordinator in Indonesia. "For the entire international donor community, this is a very difficult issue."
The International Monetary Fund said today that it would consider canceling a planned trip to Indonesia by its senior officials to review its program. "The I.M.F. continues to view with grave concern the deteriorating situation in East Timor," it said in a statement.
Some analysts said foreign donors had little choice but to continue pouring money into Indonesia. Without the aid, they said, the Government would default on its debt and the country would be ripe for further social unrest.
Indeed, Japanese officials said today that they were not considering halting their aid to Indonesia. All told, international organizations have pledged $47 billion to Indonesia since the onset of the Asian crisis in 1997.
The money is going toward rebuilding Indonesia's shattered banking system and aiding tens of millions of people thrown into poverty by the crisis.
Even more important than the money is the message. If the I.M.F. and other groups suspend their programs, Mr. Juoro and other analysts said, it will drive away prospective foreign investors, who regard the aid as a stamp of approval.
"It would really be a signal for foreign investors to get away from Indonesia," Mr. Juoro said. "It would also cause Indonesian capital to flee the country again. If they stop the support, it would be a disaster."
Even with the aid, the country's economy has followed a haphazard course. After contracting 14 percent last year, the economy showed a few glimmerings of life. Exports began growing in April for the first time in a year. In June, the stock market and the rupiah soared after Indonesia held peaceful elections, the first voting contested by candidates from more than one party in four decades.
But the euphoria dissipated the next month. Investigators discovered that one of Indonesia's leading private banks, Bank Bali, had diverted about $70 million in public funds to a top official of President Habibie's ruling party, Golkar. The money was apparently intended to help gain support for a plan to keep Bank Bali afloat. And it fed suspicions that Mr. Habibie's Government was guilty of the same corruption that marked his fallen predecessor, Suharto.
"The Bank Bali scandal was a big blow to confidence," said Mari Pangestu, an economist at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Jakarta. "Now, East Timor is dealing another blow."
Ms. Pangestu said the events in East Timor were particularly damaging in the intangible, but important area of business confidence. If executives doubt the Government's ability to control even a small province, she said it would discourage them from making new investments in the country.
In that sense, dispatching a United Nations peacekeeping force to East Timor might steady nerves. But other analysts warned that such a move could harm foreign companies with operations in Indonesia.
"There might be an anti-foreign backlash," said James W. Castle, an American consultant with the Castle Group in Jakarta. "In general, that hasn't been a problem here. But this could bring it to the surface."

HEADLINE: Insurance Service Company, and 770 Jobs, Leaving New York for Jersey City

 BODY:
The Insurance Service Office Inc., an information clearinghouse, will move 1,400 employees from five offices, including its Manhattan headquarters, to a building under construction in Jersey City, the company said yesterday.
The company signed a 20-year lease with the Lefrak Organization on Friday to occupy 394,000 square feet of an 800,000-square-foot building in Lefrak's Newport complex on the Hudson River waterfront. The move is expected in the second quarter of 2001, two years after Lefrak broke ground on the 22-story structure in May. 
 The company will move 770 employees, including its chief operating officer, Fred R. Marcon, from its headquarters at 7 World Trade Center, said David Ostwald, a company spokesman. Another 500 employees will come from a site in Pearl River, N.Y., with the rest from two sites in Manhattan and one in Rahway, N.J. The company, which is privately held, employs another 1,000 workers nationwide, who will not be affected.
The move is intended to improve the company's efficiency, although no layoffs are planned, Mr. Ostwald said. "We want to retain all of our current employees, so we wanted a site that was accessible to all our locations," Mr. Ostwald said. "We talked to New York City, but this was a more attractive arrangement."
Mr. Ostwald said other attractions include the city's accessibility by PATH train, ferries and the Holland Tunnel.
The announcement comes amid steady construction and job growth along Jersey City's Hudson River waterfront, often at New York City's expense. Alex Cohen, a senior manager at Cushman & Wakefield, the Manhattan-based real estate firm, said cheaper rent was only one factor. "There's not enough high-quality space being built," Mr. Cohen said.
Sam LeFrak, chairman of the Lefrak Organization, based in Rego Park, Queens, said Insurance Service Office would start out paying about $26 per square foot -- $5 cheaper than industry averages for downtown Manhattan, and $10 cheaper than midtown -- and increase its payments over the life of the lease. Mr. LeFrak said the $150 million building received a 20-year tax abatement from Jersey City. Tom Gallagher, Mayor Bret Schundler's chief of staff, said the company's arrival would "give further credibility and prestige to a Jersey City address."
Mr. Ostwald would not discuss New York's offer. Nor would Michael Carey, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation.
"What this demonstrates," Mr. Carey said, "is that when companies threaten to leave New York, their threats have to be taken seriously, because sometimes they will carry them out."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Mean Season

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia

 BODY:
For the past decade, Australian strategists have referred to the Southeast Asian nations to their north -- Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand & Co. -- as Australia's "strategic shield." Today, Australian strategists refer to Southeast Asia as "the arc of instability formerly known as Australia's strategic shield."
They have a point. When you look up at Asia from down under, what you see today is a region more explosive than at any time since the Vietnam War. For years it has been widely assumed that all these countries, even China, were in "transition" from underdeveloped to developed, from confrontation to multilateral cooperation and from closed political systems to more open ones. It was going to be the Pacific Century. 
 But today it is the fear of implosion, not the inevitability of transition, that dominates political discussions here. It starts with Indonesia. For the past 25 years Indonesia has been the keystone holding together Southeast Asia as a pro-Western, free-market bloc counterbalancing China. Today that keystone is crumbling. Indonesia is the Yugoslavia of Southeast Asia. Its economic downturn has weakened the center, and civil wars have erupted at both ends of the Indonesian archipelago, from Aceh in the north, where Muslim separatists want to secede, to East Timor in the south, where 80 percent of the population voted for independence and the Indonesian military simply won't let go.
The U.S. and U.N. are right to lay down an ultimatum to the Indonesian Government: Either stop the gangs marauding East Timor, and permit a U.N. peacekeeping force to go in -- which the Australians would gladly provide the forces for -- or Indonesia will be treated as a pariah state and its tentative economic recovery aborted. (The Aussies are ready to put troops into Timor because they know if Indonesia implodes, the boat people are heading for Australia.)
Unfortunately, this is not the only problem in the neighborhood. "Whether it is Indonesia, or the Korean Peninsula, or Taiwan, or the South China Sea or India-Pakistan -- all the most sensitive hot spots today are in Asia," remarked Gerard Henderson, director of the Sydney Institute. America's role in the region has gone from containing Communism to containing chaos. The Pacific Century is now officially on hold.
It need not be forever, though. There are still positive trends here that have a lot of human energy and aspirations fueling them. Look at Thailand. Its central bank, responding to the Asian economic crisis, just announced a whole new strategic approach "emphasizing new values of honesty and integrity, teamwork, competence, accountability and efficiency." Next door, Singapore's Government, which has always kept a very tight lid on what its citizens can read and say, indicated it may ease up a bit because it realizes this is the only way to attract more brains to Singapore. The Asian Wall Street Journal quoted Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong as saying, "We have to create a Silicon Valley state of mind in Singapore -- creative and willing to take risks." Meanwhile, Korea's Government is dismantling Daewoo, one of the four bloated family-controlled conglomerates that helped sink the country in a pool of foreign debt. China has even restarted talks on joining the World Trade Organization, which would open and regulate its economy as never before.
But then, when you look closer, you see that even these silver trends have cloudy linings. Korea may be dismantling Daewoo, but it isn't actually closing down any of its companies, for fear of unemployment, so they will limp along. There have been several unexplained bombings in Chinese cities, and billions of dollars of hot money keep being smuggled out of China.
It is no accident that the two countries that emerged unscathed from the Asian economic crisis also happen to be the two most democratic in Asia, with the freest media -- Australia and Taiwan. The others are like kids who spurted up economically, but never adjusted their political clothing. Well, now they are, and that adjustment is going to produce stresses and even implosions throughout this region. And that's why this yin and yang, between positive and negative trends, is going to be with us in Asia for a long time. So welcome to the "New Asia" -- the arc of instability formerly known as Australia's strategic shield.

HEADLINE: East Timor Under Siege

 BODY:
Last week, in a referendum with nearly 100 percent turnout, East Timor's voters overwhelmingly supported independence from Indonesia. Now rampaging militias, with the backing and apparent complicity of Indonesia's army, are taking revenge against the inhabitants of this unlucky territory. They have set East Timor on fire -- murdering residents and driving tens of thousands of people to neighboring West Timor. Unfortunately, the proposals coming from Jakarta to stop the terror are less than reassuring. The United Nations Security Council should immediately endorse Australia's attempts to assemble a quick-reaction international peacekeeping force, and countries with economic influence should use it to press Indonesia to end the violence now or let the peacekeepers in.
In 1975, after Portugal withdrew from its colony of East Timor, Indonesia brutally invaded. Its annexation, carried out with the acquiescence of the United States and Australia, led to the deaths of 200,000 Timorese, nearly one in three residents. 
But East Timor provided huge international headaches for the dictatorship of President Suharto. His successor, B. J. Habibie, decided to offer East Timor a plan for autonomy inside Indonesia. If Timorese voters rejected it, then Indonesia would pull out and East Timor would become independent. Despite growing violence by anti-independence militias, the U.N. agreed in May that if East Timor chose independence, Indonesia would withdraw its troops and the U.N. would take over security in the region -- but only well after a referendum.
Indonesia's military and millions of nationalists deeply resent the offer of independence, and worry that it could encourage separatist movements in other regions. What East Timor is suffering is not chaos but an organized rampage by the militias, as some of the more than 15,000 Indonesian troops there stand by and even participate. The violence is very likely being coordinated by military men in Jakarta. Indonesia's Government insists that it can solve the problem without international help, and has declared martial law. But Indonesia's military is the problem, not the solution.
Although Australia is now rightly assembling a peacekeeping force, the U.N. Security Council has announced that it will not endorse it without Indonesia's agreement. Getting Jakarta's consent will require strong and immediate pressure, especially from the United States, Australia -- which has strong ties to Indonesia's military -- and Japan, a large donor of economic aid.
All three nations should announce that they are cutting off all military aid and sales. They, and the international banks, should also stop all but humanitarian loans and economic aid. America should give the peacekeeping mission a strong endorsement. An international force is clearly the last resort, to be tried only if President Habibie and Indonesia's military leader, Gen. Wiranto, will not stop the violence. But a united, powerful threat from abroad is likely needed to persuade them to end the killings.
