HEADLINE: Backstage Drama Unfolds Over Taste-of-Broadway Show for Tourists

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Three longtime theater producers are creating a 60-minute, $25-a-ticket Broadway production aimed at the tourists swarming through Times Square. But their project at the Lyceum Theater has run into intense opposition from the most powerful theater owner on Broadway.
The dispute has embroiled other theater producers, Broadway labor unions, preservationists and city officials. And, as is often the case in a city of skyscrapers and wrecking balls, a real estate deal is also deeply entwined in the story. 
 The backstage drama pits Gerald Schoenfeld, the chairman of the Shubert Organization, which owns nearly half the Broadway theaters, against the producers David S. Singer, Thomas Viertel and Richard Frankel, whose collective credits include "Angels in America," "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," "Smokey Joe's Cafe" and "Stomp."
The producers of the new show, "Spirit of Broadway," say it will introduce the wonder of Broadway to newcomers who might be wary of shelling out $70 for a traditional show. But Mr. Schoenfeld contends that the show is not a legitimate theatrical attraction and should not appear at the 928-seat Lyceum, which has a covenant with the city to continue functioning as a legitimate theater.
Also at stake in the dispute is control of the Lyceum itself. It is owned by Mr. Schoenfeld and the Shubert Organization, but Bertelsmann A.G., the giant German media company whose American headquarters is adjacent to the theater, has an option to buy it.
The three producers have lined up Jerry Zaks, the Tony Award-winning director of "The House of Blue Leaves" and "Six Degrees of Separation," for the play, an inside look at the theater world complete with songs and the ghosts of Broadway's greatest actors. The show would run about six times a day, with tickets ($25 for adults, $15 for children) priced to lure some of the 30 million tourists who stream through Times Square every year, most without ever buying a Broadway ticket. The production would employ as many as 50 people in a theater that because of its small size is, more often than not, dark.
The entire program, known as the Broadway Hall of Fame, would also include a backstage tour, memorabilia and videotaped segments of current Broadway shows.
"The show will introduce people who are reluctant to go to a very expensive Broadway theater to the experience of live performance and the special bond it creates between the audience and the performers," Mr. Viertel said.
The three producers have raised about half the $22 million necessary for the project and signed a tentative deal with Bertelsmann for the use of the Lyceum, a landmark Beaux-Arts theater on the east side of the Bertelsmann headquarters at Broadway and 45th Street. Bertelsmann, which is now paying $600,000 a year in rent, would buy the theater for more than $13 million.
But Mr. Schoenfeld has objected, citing the covenant he signed with the city to get approval for the real estate deal that ultimately gave Bertelsmann the air rights from the Lyceum for its office tower. The covenant states that the Lyceum will be preserved as a legitimate theater.
"It's not a play or a musical," Mr. Schoenfeld said of the proposed production. "The Broadway Hall of Fame presentation will have a live component, a museum component and a concession component. To us, that is not a legitimate theatrical use consistent with the covenant."
While Mr. Schoenfeld said his sole concern was upholding the covenant, others suggested that he might be reluctant to see Bertelsmann exercise its option to take over the Lyceum. Another developer holds a similar option at another Shubert theater, the Belasco.
"I don't know why Jerry's opposed," said William Moriarity, president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians. "He's got 16 1/2 theaters. He'd have 15 1/2 theaters after this deal. It's a theater that he himself says gets very little use. This looks suspiciously like a real estate problem, not a theater problem."
Whatever the motives behind the dispute, the Lyceum covenant does not define legitimate theater.
"What they say about pornography may apply here," Mr. Schoenfeld suggested helpfully: "You know it when you see it."
There are some other Broadway denizens who privately dismiss the "Spirit of Broadway" project as Broadway lite, a cheap imitation that would allow visitors from the hinterlands to say they had seen a real Broadway show, thereby narrowing the audience rather than expanding it. But many others do not understand the fuss.
"The only difference between this and other Broadway productions is the number of times it'll be shown in a day," Mr. Moriarity said. "We always saw this as a fairly good thing."
As the number of Broadway theaters fell from 60 in the 1930's to fewer than 40 in the 1970's, preservationists and theater activists have sought to preserve the number of legitimate theaters, which last year attracted a record 11.7 million people and gross ticket sales of $588.5 million.
But Mr. Schoenfeld was never in the forefront of such efforts. He opposed the landmarking of the Lyceum and once tried to install a community court in the Longacre, both small theaters that are difficult to book. At the time of the air rights deal, Mr. Schoenfeld described the Lyceum as a "liability," saying: "It doesn't make money; it loses money. It is the oldest theater extant, a two-balcony house on the wrong side of Broadway."
Nevertheless, Mr. Schoenfeld sounded the alarm about the potential "loss" of the Lyceum at a May 28 meeting of the Broadway unions. According to those who attended, the impresario described the "Spirit of Broadway" as a museum, which would employ ticket-takers rather than union actors, stagehands and musicians. He urged them to write letters to Joseph B. Rose, director of the City Planning Commission, opposing the project. Many did.
But then Mr. Frankel and his cohorts swung into action, visiting each union and Mr. Rose to correct what they said was the mistaken impression left by Mr. Schoenfeld. They won the support of Marvin Hamlisch, Harold Prince, Todd Haimes, the artistic director of the Roundabout Theater, and Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn Theaters Corporation.
As a result, the Theatrical Wardrobe Union Local 764 quickly retracted its protest letter to Mr. Rose. Alan Eisenberg, executive director of Actors' Equity, said last week that his letter was "premature," and that the union's executive board would vote on the issue Sept. 14.
"I didn't realize how much work will be involved for Equity members," Mr. Eisenberg said.
In the end, it may be up to Mr. Rose at City Planning, which will have to rule on the issue.
"From the city's perspective, the Broadway theaters are an extremely important cultural, aesthetic and economic resource," Mr. Rose said. "We will adopt an extremely protective approach to the Lyceum. This proposal has been described to us in several ways. Some versions would be unacceptable; others require further study."

HEADLINE: U.N. Says a Quarter of East Timorese Have Fled

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 7

 BODY:
As many as 200,000 people, nearly a quarter of East Timor's population, have been driven from their homes within the last four days by militias opposed to independence for the territory, the Secretary General's spokesman said here today.
Many displaced people who had sought refuge in churches and aid agencies are being rounded up and forcibly moved across the border to Indonesian West Timor, according to a report from the United Nations mission in East Timor provided by the spokesman, Fred Eckhard. Thousands of others have fled into hills and forests, the report says. 
 Its figures are based on reports from refugees, the few remaining journalists -- who say the capital, Dili, seems all but deserted -- departing aid agencies, church officials and the International Committee of the Red Cross, which until today had officials on the border with West Timor.
With most foreigners evacuated from East Timor and the remaining 335 United Nations staff members trapped in a compound in Dili, virtually all relief aid has ended, almost no food is available for emergency distribution and the fate of many refugees is unknown. United Nations officials in East Timor say they face an emergency "with potential catastrophic consequences."
But in the absence of a call for international military help from the Indonesian Government, the Security Council continued to stand by, giving President B. J. Habibie and his military commander, Gen. Wiranto, at least 24 more hours to end a reign of terror that seems to have been orchestrated by units of the military. The general, however, may not be able to call a halt to it. The United Nations believes that the Indonesian Army as well as local militias have been involved in the violence.
"I can assure you that the Security Council will not give the green light if there is no permission on the part of the Indonesian Government," Peter van Walsum of the Netherlands, the Security Council president for September, said after a Council meeting.
A five-member Council delegation is due to arrive in Jakarta overnight to warn Indonesian authorities that they will have to stop the violence in East Timor or allow others to do it. In Washington, a Pentagon spokesman said that the United States still had hopes that the Indonesian military could restore order and that there were no plans at this point for the United States to help an evacuation from East Timor or to send troops to a peacekeeping force.
Today, the situation drove the territory's Nobel prize-winning religious leader, Bishop Carlos Ximenes Belo, out of the country to refuge in Darwin, Australia.
Jose Ramos-Horta, an exiled East Timorese independence leader, said in an interview today that through all the years of conflict in the territory, church buildings and convents had never before been attacked as they have been in recent days. Mr. Ramos-Horta, who shared the 1996 Nobel Peace Prize with Bishop Belo, is in the United States campaigning for immediate military intervention.
Mr. Ramos-Horta and some diplomats here have raise the question of why military intervention has not been requested by Portugal, the former colonial power in East Timor and the country still recognized internationally -- if only technically -- as the administering authority. Indonesia's seizure of the territory in 1995, after Portugal withdrew, was never accepted.
Antonio Monteiro, Portugal's representative at the United Nations, said in an interview that Portugal had been making such a request, saying that Indonesia had broken the agreement signed in May that allowed the East Timorese to vote on their future. Last week they decisively chose not to remain part of Indonesia, and that vote set off the anti-independence violence.
"The U.N. has to go there because there is an emergency, because there is chaos," he said, adding that his view met resistance in the Council.
David L. Phillips, executive director of Columbia University's Conflict Resolution Program, who visited East Timor earlier this year, said there was a real question whether the Habibie Government could speak any longer for Indonesia on the issue because the military seemed to have control over the situation in East Timor. But he agrees with diplomats that the United Nations cannot go in, for political reasons, unless the Government, however weak, makes the request.
"General Wiranto is being given the chance to demonstrate his ability to re-establish law and order in East Timor," Mr. Phillips said. "If that fails, there will be need for an international force." With a request from the Government, he said, no questions would be raised in the Security Council that would delay or impede its deployment.
He said Indonesia would also be pressured to seek help because it would not want to lose international aid with its economy just emerging from crisis.
Apparently in a gesture of good will toward the East Timorese, Indonesia today freed a rebel leader, Jose Alexandre (Xanana) Gusmao after seven years of detention.
Robert Fowler, Canada's representative on the Security Council, said it was obviously painful for Council members to see themselves portrayed as paralyzed in the face of this crisis. All around, he said, there are cries of why can't the United Nations do something?
"Do they mean, why can't the U.N. go to war with the fourth-largest country in the world?" he asked. "Is that what that means?"
"Indonesia has very specific commitments under the May 5 agreement that it will look after security," he added. "We have all, in a variety of different ways, been trying to cajole, convince, warn the Indonesians that they must do this, that their international reputation depends on it, and the whole world is watching. But up until now they have made it extremely clear that they will not allow a foreign presence into this part of their country.
"There is no taste in the Council or in the world for going to war with Indonesia."
Mr. Phillips said that Indonesia's international reputation might not be foremost in the minds of those responsible for the violence in East Timor but that international opprobrium remained a useful weapon toward a country that is in political turmoil and that is trying to crawl out of a severe financial crisis.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Big Vitamin Makers Agree To Settle Price-Fixing Suit
Six of the world's largest vitamin makers have agreed to pay about $1.1 billion to resolve a class-action lawsuit that accused them of taking part in a global conspiracy to fix vitamin prices over the last decade, people close to the talks said.
The settlement, which could come this week, would be one of the largest antitrust payments made in a private class-action suit in United States history, lawyers said. Page C2. 

3 Companies in Fiber Optic Venture
Expanding the reach of advanced fiber optic communications in Asia, Microsoft, Global Crossing of Bermuda and Softbank of Japan have agreed to form a $1.3 billion joint venture to build a fiber optic communications web stretching from Japan to Malaysia, executives close to the agreement said. The companies intend to announce the venture, to be called Asia Global Crossing, as soon as today. Shares of Microsoft fell $1.625, to $94.25, while Global Crossing fell $2.0625, to $20.3125. C2.
 
East Timor Chaos Affects Indonesia
A failure to quell the chaos in East Timor could strangle Indonesia's fragile economic recovery, analysts and Government officials said. Officials fear that foreign lenders will shun Indonesia while local business will lose confidence in the Government. C4.
 
Stocks Retreat on Rate Worries
Stock prices, especially for financial concerns, slid as investors feared rising commodity prices might lead the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 44.32 points, to 11,034.13. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.79 points, to 1,350.45, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 5.85 points, to 2,837.26. C16.
 
Treasury yields rose as skittish investors awaited Friday's report on producer prices and speeches by Federal Reserve officials. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.07 percent from 6.01 percent on Friday. C16.
 
Sun Introduces Network Computer
Sun Microsystems will introduce a second generation of its network computing business today with an ultra-stripped-down computing "appliance" for corporate customers. C6.
 
Ex-Bank Workers Sue Over 401(k)
Former employees of First Union, which owns the nation's sixth-largest bank, have sued the company, contending it put its profits ahead of its employees' best interests in managing in-house 401(k) retirement plans. C6.
 
Liberty Media in European Deal
Liberty Media Group, AT&T's cable-television programming company, agreed to buy a stake in Europe's No. 2 cable company, United Pan-Europe Communications, for $493 million in cash. Liberty, which is led by John C. Malone, is forming a venture with Microsoft and United Pan-Europe to cooperate on buying other cable companies and developing programs and technology. C8.
 
Knowledge of Inquiry Disclosed
Some Clinton Administration officials knew of the inquiry into Russian money laundering at the Bank of New York as long ago as March, not just last month, officials said. A5.
 
Toyota to List Shares Abroad
Toyota Motor plans to list its shares on the New York and London stock exchanges to attract more investors. C4.
 
Creditors Accept Sidanko Offer
BP Amoco and other foreign creditors said that they had accepted an offer by Russia to resolve the bankruptcy of the oil company Sidanko, a move that could bolster BP Amoco's yearlong effort to preserve its $571 million investment in the company. C4.

HEADLINE: 2 Are Indicted In Sex Abuse Of a Boy Met On Internet

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 7

 BODY:
A Yonkers official and a former public-relations executive for Pepsico were indicted today on charges of sexually molesting a Westchester County teen-ager whom they had met separately through the Internet.
The Westchester County District Attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, said in a news conference that the charges stemmed from a continuing investigation into the killing of a 12-year-old Yonkers boy whose body was found alongside the Saw Mill River Parkway in January. There was no suggestion that either man was a suspect in the murder case. 
 James Surdoval, 42, who was chief of staff to Terence M. Zaleski, the former Yonkers Mayor, and who is currently an economic development official for the city, was arrested on charges of third-degree sodomy and endangering the welfare of a child. At an arraignment this afternoon, Judge Kenneth Lange of Westchester County Court set bail at $20,000.
Patrick Murphy, 45, who had worked in public relations for Pepsico in Purchase, N.Y., was charged with 18 counts of third-degree sodomy, 1 count of endangering the welfare of a child and 1 count of third-degree reckless endangerment. The final count accuses Mr. Murphy, who is infected with H.I.V., of not using a condom during sex acts and not disclosing his health status.
Mr. Murphy's bail was set at $20,000 by Judge Barbara G. Zambelli of Westchester County Court.
The two arrests were the latest in an investigation by the Westchester County District Attorney's office into the abuse of the Internet by suspected pedophiles. More arrests are expected, Ms. Pirro said.
Last week, another Westchester County man was indicted on charges that he sexually abused four boys whom he had met through the Internet. The man, Robert D. DeRosario, 36, who was already awaiting trial on 17 counts of sexually molesting and sodomizing five other boys, is a suspect in the killing of Orlandito Rosario Maldonado of Yonkers, law enforcement officials said. The boy was last seen in Mr. DeRosario's apartment building in Yonkers.
It was not known if Mr. Murphy and Mr. Surdoval knew each other or knew of each other's contacts with the Westchester boy, who is 15 years old, Ms. Pirro said. Mr. Surdoval, who lives in Yonkers, had one sexual encounter with the boy, in July 1998, officials said, whereas Mr. Murphy, of Port Chester, had "numerous encounters" with him between November 1998 and January 1999.
People in Yonkers politics reacted with shock and dismay today upon learning of the charges against Mr. Surdoval, a respected policy maker who had also worked closely with Mayor Nicholas C. Wascisko during the city's housing desegregation battle in the 1980's. Mr. Surdoval's lawyer, Neal Comer, did not return a phone call left at his office.
Bob Donnelly, a friend of Mr. Surdoval who is a lawyer in New York City, said Mr. Surdoval phoned him today to tell him of his arrest. "He told me he was absolutely innocent of the charges, and he intends to fight this vigorously," Mr. Donnelly said. "He sounded upset but determined."
Mayor John Spencer of Yonkers issued a statement today that read in part: "To those who would rush to judgment in this matter, I urge restraint. The filing of charges is simply a prosecutor's formal accusation, and it is the first step in a legal process with a time-honored tradition of presuming the accused innocent unless proved otherwise. We support Jim and will await the outcome of these legal proceedings."
The statement went on to say that Mr. Surdoval would "continue as director of the Office of Downtown and Waterfront Development during the course of this matter."
Another political associate, Ed Meyer, who is a member of the State Board of Regents and a former State Assemblyman, called Mr. Surdoval a "person of high integrity" and a "prodigious public servant."
Few details about Mr. Murphy's former job at Pepsico were available today. A spokeswoman for Pepsico, Elaine Franklin, said only that he left in early 1996 after going on "long-term disability."
Mrs. Pirro said that on Thursday, her office planned to mail pamphlets to public libraries and schools across Westchester, warning of the possible dangers faced by children who use the Internet unsupervised.
"The Internet continues to give pedophiles and others who seek to have contact with children the opportunity to have access in a way we have never seen before," she said.
She urged parents and adults to tell children not to give their names or addresses to anyone they meet through Internet chat rooms and to warn them not to make arrangement to meet them in person.
"Even though kids are told, 'Don't talk to strangers,' they're not being told not to meet strangers via the Internet," she said.

HEADLINE: Gore Pledges A Health Plan For Every Child

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore proposed today to guarantee access to affordable health insurance for all children by 2005, expanding on a program enacted two years ago that he conceded had had limited success so far.
Mr. Gore acknowledged that the number of Americans without health coverage had increased steadily since he and President Clinton took office. But in a speech at Children's Hospital of Los Angeles, in Hollywood, he said, "If you elect me President, I will insure that by the year 2005, every single child in our country has full access to fully affordable health coverage." 
 The number of uninsured children rose by roughly 2.5 million in the last decade, to 11 million in 1997, the last year for which official data are available.
When Congress created the Children's Health Insurance Program in 1997, it gave the states billions of dollars and considerable flexibility in how the money could be used. Mr. Gore said he would expand eligibility for the program by increasing the limits on family income and by allowing some parents to enroll with their children. He would also impose financial penalties on states that did not meet Federal targets for the enrollment of children, while offering bonuses for states that did.
The Administration said in July that 1.3 million children had been enrolled in the children's insurance program. Mr. Clinton said that he would have expected at least three million by now and that he was therefore "a little disappointed."
Aides to Mr. Gore said his proposals, taken together, could provide coverage for 11 million to 15 million Americans, most of them children. The number of people without health insurance has been rising in the last decade and now exceeds 43 million.
The goal of offering affordable health insurance to all children, though ambitious, is modest by comparison with Mr. Clinton's original plan to guarantee health insurance for all Americans.
"We have all learned that we cannot overhaul the system in one fell swoop," Mr. Gore said in underlining the differences between his approach and the grand schemes devised in 1993 by the President and his wife, Hillary.
He also took a dig at the leading candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, noting that one-fourth of the children in that state lack insurance, a higher proportion than in almost any other state.
While focusing on children, Mr. Gore offered several proposals today to increase coverage of adults, too. He proposed a new tax credit to offset 25 percent of the cost of health insurance bought by individuals who lack access to employer-sponsored coverage.
"Today, companies that provide coverage get a tax break," he said. "But not individuals who have to get coverage on their own. That's just not fair, and we have to change it."
Many Republicans in Congress agree.
In addition, Mr. Gore's proposal to expand the Children's Health Insurance Program, created in 1997, would extend coverage to the seven million uninsured adults whose children are eligible for either Medicaid or the new children's program.
The logic of the proposal is simple. Most uninsured children come from families in which the parents are themselves uninsured. But Mr. Gore's proposal raises a question of equity and fairness: Why should the Government provide subsidized health insurance to adults with children while denying it to adults of working age without children?
Mr. Gore did not say how much his proposals would cost or how he would pay for them. Chris Lehane, a spokesman for the Vice President, said, "This will be done in the context of a balanced budget, and we'll put out a detailed budget proposal later, but we have no price tag right now."
Health-care experts said the cost of Mr. Gore's proposals would almost surely exceed $24 billion over five years, the amount appropriated by Congress to cover a maximum of five million youngsters in the new health program for children.
Administration officials have chided Congress and governors for not doing more to increase health insurance coverage. But this is a tricky issue for Mr. Gore, because the Clinton-Gore Administration shares responsibility for the failure to fulfill the promise of programs already enacted at the President's request.
Despite a vibrant economy, Mr. Gore said today, the number of Americans without health insurance has been growing by about a million a year. This is "one of the few social indicators that have not improved under the strong Clinton-Gore economy," says a new paper on health policy prepared by the Gore campaign. Even though Congress has created and expanded several health programs, enrollment has been "woefully inadequate," it says.
White House officials have known for several years that at least four million children eligible for Medicaid were not enrolled, and there is no evidence that this number has fallen, despite many efforts and exhortations by Federal officials in Washington.
Mr. Gore repeated Administration proposals to define the rights of patients in health maintenance organizations, to establish new prescription drug benefits under Medicare and to provide a modest tax credit for the cost of nursing home care. But the focus of his speech was on uninsured children, and Mr. Gore offered these ideas to deal with the problem:
*The Federal Government should impose financial penalties on states that do not meet Federal targets for enrolling youngsters in Medicaid and in the new health program for children. At the same time, the Government would pay bonuses to states that meet their goals. (Mr. Gore said this would make states accountable for their performance. But critics said it would reward states that are succeeding, at the expense of states that are struggling.)
*States could expand eligibility for the new Children's Health Insurance Program, so families with incomes up to 2.5 times the official poverty level could qualify. In most states, the ceiling on family income is set at twice the poverty level. For a family of four, the poverty level this year is $16,700.
*More affluent families should be allowed to buy insurance coverage for youngsters through Medicaid or the new children's health program if the parents work for companies that do not provide health benefits. Such families would have to pay the full premium, but this would often be a bargain compared with prices in the private market, because large government programs have much greater purchasing power than individuals. The Gore campaign said there were more than two million uninsured children in families with incomes exceeding 2.5 times the official poverty level.
Health-care experts said Mr. Gore's proposals would clearly help some working families, but might divert states from the task of finding and enrolling children who are already eligible for health benefits.
Mr. Gore would give states a bonus for enrolling children in a program that already offers states a generous financial incentive to do just that. In the new Children's Health Insurance Program, as in Medicaid, the Federal Government and the states share the costs, but the Federal Government pays a larger share of the costs in the new program.
Some of Mr. Gore's proposals are intended to restore health insurance for tens of thousands of children who lost coverage when their families were removed from the welfare rolls. In theory, most such children were still eligible for Medicaid, but their parents did not always realize it, and officials in some states improperly cut off health benefits along with cash assistance.
 
A CLOSER LOOK -- Gore's Proposal
Following are the principal goals of a health-care proposal that Vice President Al Gore outlined yesterday in an address at Children's Hospital of Los Angeles:
*Guarantee access to affordable insurance for all children by 2005.
*Expand eligibility for the Children's Health Insurance Program to include children in a family of four with an income of up to $41,750.
*Let uninsured parents enroll in this program if their children are eligible.
*Penalize states that fail to meet Federal goals for insuring children.
*Provide tax credits to help individuals and small businesses buy health insurance.

HEADLINE: Indonesia Is Warned It Could Lose Western Aid

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration and the International Monetary Fund separately warned Indonesia today that the financial aid that has kept the country economically afloat for the last two years could be suspended if violence in East Timor is not brought under control.
A State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said today that "productive relations between Indonesia and the international community, including the I.M.F., depend on Indonesia adopting a constructive approach towards ending the humanitarian disaster in East Timor." 
 Several hours later, the fund, which has administered the multibillion-dollar emergency package to Indonesia since the Asian economic crisis struck two years ago this month, said it was considering holding up a review later this month of Indonesia's economic troubles. Without it, the fund's board cannot approve the next loan installment.
Administration officials said the statements today were clearly intended as a warning to President B.J. Habibie that his biggest claim to success so far -- that he has worked with the I.M.F. and kept national bankruptcy at bay -- would be imperiled if he could not get Indonesia's military to stop the violence aimed at pro-independence East Timorese and United Nations personnel.
President Clinton is likely to have a chance to make that case to Mr. Habibie directly this weekend, when both leaders attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Auckland, New Zealand.
"There is a lot of running around right now, but no clear sense of what direction we should go and how hard to push," one senior Administration official said today. "No one is sure how much the U.S. could contribute to a U.N. peacekeeping force, even if one was invited in."
 In Canberra, Australia, Prime Minister John Howard said on Wednesday that the United States was likely to provide logistical support for any multinational peacekeeping force, Agence France-Presse reported. He said his Defense Minister, John Moore, had spoken to Defense Secretary William S. Cohen and Defense Minister George Robertson of Britain overnight. "We are confident now that the Americans would provide at least logistical support," Mr. Howard said.
If the Administration carried through on its warnings, it would be suspending an aid package that the Treasury and national security advisers assembled in 1997.
Mr. Rubin was quick to say today that his warning to Indonesia "doesn't mean that any specific loan or any specific fund" might be frozen. But the only real economic leverage the United States holds is its power within the I.M.F. to block disbursement of the next payment of loans.
Those loans are partly intended to stabilize the banks, but they also allow Mr. Habibie to continue using government money to subsidize food and fuel. If those subsidies ended and prices soared, it could easily set off the kind of violence that helped oust President Suharto last year.

SECTION: Section C; Page 14; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 766 words

HEADLINE: MAKING A MEDIA GIANT: THE REGULATORS;
Wide Belief U.S. Will Let A Vast Deal Go Through

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
If there were a nursery character to symbolize this year's corporate deal-making, it would almost certainly be a variation of Humpty-Dumpty, in which he was finally put back together again.
Nearly 30 years ago, Viacom Inc. became an independent company after regulators forced CBS to sell its cable television and syndication units. And about 60 years before that, the Government ordered the breakup of John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil, which led to the creation of Exxon and Mobil, two of the world's largest oil companies. 
 Now regulators in Washington are nearing completion of their review of the proposal by the Exxon Corporation to buy the Mobil Corporation just as other officials begin their examination of Viacom's plan to buy CBS in the richest merger of media companies in history. Earlier this year, the regulators once again approved a merger of two of the regional Bell telephone companies, companies that had been created as part of the antitrust breakup of the AT&T Corporation.
While experts agreed today that CBS and Viacom may have to shed a handful of television stations and other assets to complete the deal, there is a widespread consensus that at the end of the day Washington will bless the acquisition.
What has made all these corporate deals, which would have been unthinkable a generation ago, possible?
The short answer is that the companies and the economics of the industries they serve have changed sharply and as a consequence, so has the regulatory climate.
"The feeling is that the winds of competition are blowing and therefore anything can happen," said Professor Eleanor Fox, an antitrust scholar at the New York University School of Law. "The perception is that markets are more open than earlier times and that barriers are lower. In any of these markets, firms are more under the gun to survive growing competition. And of course, the philosophy of regulation has changed. It used to be there was a lot of socio-economic concern for the concentration of power in a few hands. The concentration of power used to be seen in a dark light."
"Now," Ms. Fox added, "the concern is that businesses be free from regulation in order to compete in the global marketplace."
Despite these changes, executives at CBS and Viacom today acknowledged that there important obstacles to the deal remain.
The Federal Communications Commission generally has the authority to approve or disapprove any telecommunications merger to make sure it is in the public interest. The agency which has not yet been formally notified by the companies, said in a statement that its policy "is to evaluate mergers to see if they meet the public interest standard."
"We will certainly evaluate this one when it is filed with us," the agency statement said.
But three regulations in particular limit the ownership concentration of networks and television stations. As a result, CBS and Viacom will have to either persuade the regulators to change the rules, seek waivers or, more likely, sell some of their interests in television stations and one of the two networks they now own.
So it was hardly surprising today when Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom, and Mel Karmazin, chief executive of CBS, announced that they would spend Wednesday huddled with top officials at the F.C.C. to both explain the deal and criticize some broadcast ownership rules, a few of which the agency announced only five weeks ago.
One older regulation that is of particular concern to the executives prohibits a company from controlling more than 35 percent of the television broadcasting market. The cap used to be 25 percent but was raised to 35 percent as part of legislation that largely deregulated the telecommunications industry three years ago. CBS already owns stations reaching 32 percent of American households, and its acquisition by Viacom would increase that to 41 percent. But the F.C.C. has indicated it is now reconsidering the cap.
A second F.C.C. rule prohibits a company from owning two networks, which is a problem because because Viacom has a 50 percent interest in the UPN network.
A third rule, adopted last month, substantially relaxes the television station limits that had restricted ownership for most of the century. The new standards permit a company to own two stations in cities where there are a sufficient number of "media voices," which include all radio and television stations, large daily newspapers and cable systems. Specifically a city must have at least eight independently owned television stations for a single company to own two.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Regulatory Hurdles"
Like most big media mergers, the Viacom-CBS deal will be subject to review by antitrust regulators and the Federal Communications Commission. Besides the F.C.C.'s mandate to review any merger involving broadcast licenses, to determine whether it is in the public interest, the agency has three rules that could affect the proposed Viacom-CBS merger. Here are the rules and their relevance to the deal.
 
NETWORK OWNERSHIP LIMIT
A company that owns a broadcast television network can own no more than one-third of a second network. Because Viacom already owns 50 percent of the UPN network, it would have to reduce that stake - or get the rule changed - in order to acquire CBS.
 
NATIONAL STATION LIMIT
A company cannot own television stations whose total reach exceeds 35 percent of the nation's television households. CBS's stations already reach 32 percent of households, and adding Viacom's stations would raise the total to 41 percent. Selling some stations - or getting the rule changed - would be necessary.
 
LOCAL STATION LIMIT
According to a rule announced only last month, which relaxed previous restrictions, a company can now own two television stations in a single metropolitan area - as long as the market ends up with at least eight independently owned stations and as long as a single company does not own more than one of the four top-rated stations in that market. Viacom and CBS both own stations in six metropolitan markets: Boston, Philadelphia, Miami, Pittsburgh, Detroit and Dallas. All of those markets currently have enough stations to make Viacom and CBS eligible for joint ownership.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 5; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 1369 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
The Great Home Run Race, Part II

BYLINE: By BILL DEDMAN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 7

 BODY:
They start three hours before game time, behind the ivy-covered wall of Wrigley Field, under the right-field bleachers, in the batting cage. This is where home run swings are built.
It's just two men, Sammy Sosa and his hitting coach, alone except for the shotgun sound of white ash on horsehide. Between underhand tosses from eight paces, the coach, Jeff Pentland, passes on the mantras he learned from studying Ted Williams. "Stay back." "Give yourself time to recognize the pitch." "Stay within yourself." 
 In his white pinstriped uniform pants and a blue sleeveless T-shirt, Sosa swings intently but easily, driving the ball into the net. It's five more swings, then two more, then end on a good one.
"How was that?" Sosa asks. Pentland answers through his chewing tobacco, "Ninety-nine percent."
A once-a-generation event is happening for the second straight year. The sluggers who entertained baseball fans and the nation last summer, Mark McGwire of the St. Louis Cardinals and Sosa of the Chicago Cubs, are again within reach of the record for most home runs in a season.
Only this time the leader is Sammy Sosa. With less than one month to go, Sosa leads McGwire, 58 to 54. No one-hit wonder, Sosa is excelling on a team so dreadful that Cubs fans have changed that old baseball lament to "Wait till next century."
And he's just warming up. Sosa, who did not homer in a doubleheader against Cincinnati today, needs to hit a home run every other day to reach McGwire's record of 70; that's just what he has done over the past month. If he were to hit as many in the Cubs' remaining 24 games as he has hit in the past 24 games, Sosa would finish with a record 73.
The McGwire-Sosa reprise provides a second chance for those who rooted for Sosa -- because he was the underdog, or because he wasn't pumping up his muscles with questionable substances, or just because he was having so much fun.
One year ago on Sept. 7, McGwire bested Babe Ruth's 1927 mark of 60 home runs. The next day, he made obsolete Roger Maris's 1961 record of 61. Then began the friendly competition with Sosa, who finished at 66 homers while McGwire pushed on to 70.
McGwire is a perennial, but few expected Sosa to do it again.
Before this season, 43 baseball fans in Chicago, mostly office workers in the downtown Loop, got together in a home run pool. In picking their roster of players, they were limited to only one of last year's leaders. Out of 43 fans, in Chicago, only 6 chose Sosa.
"I can't believe he's done it again this year," said one of the entrants, Mike Olah, 28, who works for an investment firm. "The winds seemed to be blowing the Cubs' way last year, and I figured that was the case for Sammy, too."
Fans saw how Sosa spent his vacation: throwing out the first pitch at the World Series, parading through New York City, helping the victims of a hurricane in his native Dominican Republic, lighting the national Christmas tree, touring Japan, sitting with the First Lady at the State of the Union Message and joking with Jay Leno.
And fans see Slammin' Sammy's exuberance during the game. How he starts the game sprinting to his position in right field, swapping salutes with the Bleacher Bums. How, in the first inning, he taps the umpire and the catcher on the back of the leg with his bat, just to say hello. How he follows a home run pop with a hop high in the air, and then, back in the dugout, blows kisses to the camera for his family.
Fans do not see Sosa's preparation for the game. Before noon, hours before an afternoon game at Wrigley, this is usually the time for rookies and old men. At third base, 23-year-old Cole Liniak is taking groundballs, hoping his first week in the majors won't be his last. At the gate on Waveland Avenue, Marty Mahinsk, age 77, is stacking up programs to sell, as he has since 1939.
In the cage, the 30-year-old Sosa is working on his swing, as Pentland's mantras continue. "The hands," he says, "are the communicators to the ball." The batting practice on the field just before the game is for timing. But the time in the cage is for the swing.
It's also the time to shed bad feelings after a strikeout or another Cubs loss. For Sosa is in danger of breaking another record: Never has a player hit more home runs than his team has won games. So far, Sosa leads the Cubs by two.
"He's a very emotional person, and he tends to be moody," Pentland said. "When he's in a bad mood, he wants to be by himself. But it doesn't affect his production on the field. He has incredible inner drive. The greater the pressure, the greater his performance."
It has been a most dismal year in a dismal century for his last-place Cubs. Everyone is being nice to the manager, because he's not expected to be back next year. The problem areas seem to be pitching, hitting and fielding.
During a game this summer, as fans tell the story, a Bleacher Bum in right field called over an usher. "These guys are bothering me," he said. "Which guys?" the usher asked. The fan pointed to the Cubs.
Not all great home run hitters have played on great teams. For every Ruth and Maris and Mickey Mantle, there is a Ralph Kiner of the Pittsburgh Pirates of the 1940's, a Jimmie Foxx of the Philadelphia Athletics of 1932 and a Willie Mays of the New York Giants of 1955.
Even playing for losers, Sosa and McGwire are drawing the largest crowds on the road. But there is no mania, no bidding for the home run balls, no tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service on what they might be worth. It's as if the nation has been inoculated against outright home run fever.
It is possible the home run is being devalued by its frequency, the product of weak pitching in an expanding league. In a single game on Friday night in Philadelphia, the Cincinnati players hit nine home runs. In more than a century of baseball, only 29 times has a player hit 50 or more home runs in a season; 12 of those seasons have happened in the 1990's.
But home run inflation doesn't explain why Sosa and McGwire are one-third ahead of the other players in baseball. In their National League, Jeff Bagwell of Houston was third in home runs with 39 before today's games. In the American League, Rafael Palmeiro of Texas and Ken Griffey Jr. of Seattle had 42. No one is close to "those guys."
"They're good" is Billy Williams's short explanation. The Hall of Fame player, and Sosa's first hitting coach with the Cubs, has a longer answer, too: "They're strong. They're quick. And every pitcher is told to keep the ball down, to guard against the home run. Those guys are low-ball hitters."
A fan can compare their swings six more times this season. McGwire's Cardinals and Sosa's Cubs play three games in Chicago, Sept. 20-22, and the last three games of the season, Oct. 1-3, in St. Louis. (That first game will be played on McGwire's 36th birthday.) Both managers say they will pitch to the other team's slugger, if the other team pitches to their guy.
The baseball statisticians believe a new home run record is attainable. The detail: Sosa has 24 games to go. Extrapolation: In his previous 24 games, he has hit 15 home runs (result: 73). Extrapolation: In his final 24 games last year, he hit 11 (result: 69). McGwire has 22 games to go; in his previous 22 games, he has hit 7 (result: 61); in his final 22 games last year, he hit 11 (result: 65.)
The failure of both teams has brought criticism of Sosa and McGwire from some fans and commentators, who suggest that their spectacular performances have somehow hurt their teams. While Sosa and McGwire are among the league leaders in runs batted in, Sosa leads in strikeouts, with McGwire not far down the list.
Strikeouts are common for home run hitters -- Ruth had 1,330, enough to fill three full seasons -- but some suggest the two players are a little selfish, swinging for the home run when a more cautious swing for a single might help the team more. Or perhaps their excellence is distracting their teammates.
Sosa doesn't follow that logic.
"They pay me to do my job," he said. "Just because the team is struggling, it doesn't mean I have to be struggling. If everybody had 57 home runs right now, we would be in first place."

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Yawning as the Earth Warms

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Bill McKibben (Op-Ed, Sept. 4) is right to wonder what will shock us into waking up to the realities of global warming. However, our actions are determined as much by the incentive systems shaped by our economic and social institutions as by individual perceptions. 
 Many Americans are aware of the coming environmental crisis but are personally unwilling to do anything about it until they see everyone else doing something as well. Once we appreciate this societal nature of the problem, it is easier to recognize that our inaction results more from a lack of collective political leadership than from individual disinterest or neglect.
 
FRANK FISCHER
Newark, Sept. 7, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of political science at Rutgers University.

HEADLINE: Wages, Then and Now

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re Bob Herbert's Sept. 6 column on the Economic Policy Institute's study showing that middle-class workers are only slightly better off now than they were 10 years ago: When comparisons are made over a 10-year period, we must ask if the same groups are being compared. 
 It must be remembered that the median family is much different from what it was. The booming economy has pulled in both legal and illegal immigrants. Many of these workers have less training and are more difficult to employ.
And many disabled people who never worked before are in the labor force today.
Regarding health care coverage, the study compared the situation of those workers who had a college degree and those who did not. Yet the percentage of the population going to college has increased.
The brightest and best-motivated workers are those who are in the better-off group with college degrees.
 
ABRAHAM IRWIN
Passaic, N.J., Sept. 6, 1999

HEADLINE: Wages, Then and Now

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Gap Between Rich and Poor Found Substantially Wider" (news article, Sept. 5): Frank Levy, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, suggests that market rules set by Congress and lobbied for by the rich allow them to become richer. When there is only so much money, if the rich earn more, others -- the poor -- earn less. 
 Yet having a low income not only means buying less. Poor people are generally in worse health than the rich. Poor children are more likely to have elevated lead levels, which affects their capacity for learning. Women living in or near poverty have a higher proportion of low-birth-weight babies than do rich women, and babies in poor families have a higher infant mortality rate than the babies of rich women. As the richest country in the world, why do we let only a few share the wealth?
 
SONIA KLEMPERER-JOHNSON
Oakland, Calif., Sept. 6, 1999

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Gore's Speech on Care

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an address on health care yesterday by Vice President Al Gore at the Children's Hospital of Los Angeles, as recorded by The New York Times:
For more than 50 years we have been engaged in a battle to provide the kind of health care a great nation owes its people. Now after that long century of effort, conflict and concern, it is time to move past theoretical and philosophical divisions beyond a sterile debate about labels and abstractions to ask what we can do now to take concrete, specific, realistic steps to improve health coverage for all of the American people.
Today I'm proposing and with your help as President, I will fight for a series of steps to do just that. We must and we can insure a set of rights so that all Americans can have health coverage and actually get the care they are -- all Americans who have health coverage, will get the care they are entitled to. We must and we can secure access to affordable quality health care for every child in the entire country by the year 2005. Join with me and we will do that. We must and we can move toward access to affordable, quality health care for every American family. 
 This is a fundamentally different approach. We have all learned that we cannot overhaul the system in one fell swoop. Experience has taught us that there is a way to keep what is right while fixing what is wrong with American health care.
The focus of my proposal is health care for working families. It will put doctors and patients in charge, not H.M.O.'s and insurance companies. The steps that I'm proposing here today will guarantee access to affordable health coverage for every child in America and will provide health-care options for millions more adults. But let me be clear. We cannot rest until every single American has affordable health coverage. . . .
Some will argue that greater access to health care is a luxury we can't afford even as they covet our record surplus for the special interests and propose to blow it on a risky tax scheme that would drive us right back into spiraling Federal deficits. For more than two decades I have seen the struggle between working families and special interests. The tobacco lobby, the gun lobby, those who stood against the Family Leave Bill I co-sponsored in the Senate. We've had to fight them all and we're not about to stop now. Others will argue against reforming our health-care system carefully, realistically and step by step. Some of them will tell you that the only acceptable answer is a one-size-fits-all solution. But I believe Americans know better. They know, you and I know, we need visionary but practical change, change that can be enacted into law, change that works for working families, change that meets their cares and concerns, that respects the diversity of health-care needs. Our cause is working families. And in this campaign and in the years ahead, let's put their interests first, ahead of the special interests, ahead of anything.
This is a unique moment for our nation, for our people. Our economy is strong, indeed we are in the midst of the longest period of prosperity in our peacetime history. But we know that prosperity alone will not meet the challenges that we face in American health care. And as Harry Truman reminded us when he began this fight 50 years ago, in a time of prosperity, we can afford many things. But ill-health which can be prevented or cured is one thing we cannot afford.
We must use our prosperity now to bring new change to our health-care system, to make our families healthier and more hopeful for the new century ahead. That's the kind of change that works for working families. And that's why I'm running for President of the United States.

HEADLINE: Planners Approve Harlem Shopping Center

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
The City Planning Commission yesterday approved a large shopping center for East Harlem that would bring Manhattan its first Home Depot and Costco stores.
The project, East River Plaza, was approved 9 to 3 after the developer, Blumenfeld Development Group, of Syosset, agreed to modify the facade and change the design to ease traffic. The two-level, 475,000-square-foot shopping center would be built on the former Washburn Wire Company factory site along the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive between 116th and 119th Streets. 
 "It's an important project for the economy of East Harlem and the city as a whole," said Joseph B. Rose, the Chairman of the Planning Commission. "The stores we think will do very well, and provide an important retail opportunity and a significant number of jobs. At the same time, it's a sensitive location, adjacent to residential areas."
The revised plans call for cars to enter the shopping center on 116th Street and leave on 117th Street, instead of doing both on 116th Street. "A great deal of traffic was going to make some very complicated turning maneuvers," Mr. Rose said.
Another change calls for the facade facing the highway to be clad in masonry instead of metal panels.
David Blumenfeld, the project manager, said he was not unhappy with the modifications, even though they would add millions of dollars to the cost, previously estimated at $150 million. "They made a big effort to make it work," Mr. Blumenfeld said of the City Planning Department. "I think it improves the project."
In addition to the 24-hour Home Depot store and the Costco warehouse store, the shopping center would include several other large retailers and parking for 1,250 cars. Mr. Blumenfeld said he was negotiating with Gap, its Old Navy subsidiary, Best Buy and Staples.
The next hurdle for Mr. Blumenfeld and his partner, Canyon Capital Management, is approval from the City Council, which has 50 days to act. Councilman Philip Reed, who represents East Harlem, said he favors the project but wants to make sure that all the traffic and design concerns have been addressed and that most of the new jobs will go to local residents.
The final plans must also be approved by the Empire State Development Corporation. A vote is expected within a couple of months, said a spokeswoman, Maura Z. Gallucci.

HEADLINE: Charter School Days Dawn in New York

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
This summer, Annie Harris, a P.T.A. vice president at Public School 65 in the South Bronx, put her daughter's name in the lottery for New York City's first charter school, a new kind of experimental school that supporters portray as the salvation of public education. The only person she told was her husband, a limousine driver, and she swore him to secrecy.
Although P.S. 65 is a failing school, Ms. Harris felt guilty about deserting it. She is a leader in the effort to fix it, and proudly confides that she is on a first-name basis with Chancellor Rudy Crew. But Loretta's future came first. 
No matter that the new school was in a church building in Harlem that is on a street as forlorn as any in the South Bronx. Its promise transcended geography.
"One of our kids is making it out of the Bronx," Ms. Harris said, overjoyed when Loretta won the lottery.
This week, about 1,000 schoolchildren, Loretta among them, will enter the first three schools to be created under New York State's new charter law. Two are in New York City, and one is in Albany.
A year ago, Ms. Harris and the other families, many of them among the state's poorest and most disadvantaged, would have had no choice but to go to traditional public schools. They switched because they are searching for new hope for their children, and because educators and politicians have given them faith that charter schools can cure everything that the stereotype says public schools lack: good teachers, higher test scores, discipline and safety.
It is far too soon to say whether charter schools, which are publicly financed but free of the Board of Education control and union rules, will work or be one more broken promise for families who feel they have been betrayed before.
But the dreams of parents and educators are just one face of the fledgling charter school movement. As Loretta's new school, the Sisulu Children's Academy, opens today, a day ahead of other New York City public schools, it is also the story of millions of taxpayer dollars going to a private start-up company with no track record.
The company, Victory Schools Inc., is run by a Wall Street financier better known for his billion-dollar leveraged buyouts than for his educational credentials. It promises to outperform surrounding public schools not by spending more, but by using novice, relatively low-paid teachers trained in a packaged curriculum, based on the popular "core knowledge" books by E. D. Hirsch Jr. and on another method, direct instruction, which dictates what teachers will do and say almost every minute of the day.
Victory intends to propagate schools as efficiently -- and if its owner realizes his ambition, nearly as profitably -- as McDonald's makes hamburgers.
Along the way, it has struck an informal partnership with a major institution in Harlem, the Canaan Baptist Church. By renting the church's nearly unused community center, the school is helping to rejuvenate the church. For its part, the church, led by the Rev. Wyatt Tee Walker, who lobbied for charter schools in Albany, is lending the school its credibility.
A decade ago, there were no charter schools anywhere in the country. (The first was in Minnesota in 1992.) Now there are more than 1,200, from schools in Arizona that have been investigated for financial improprieties to schools in Boston and Los Angeles that have been widely praised for their innovations.
What they have in common is that they are run by private organizations that have petitioned a governmental body for a charter to operate a school for a set period of years free from many union and civil service rules. These organizations must spell out what they propose to accomplish and, in New York's case, face monitoring by the State Board of Regents, not local boards of education.
When New York passed its charter school law last December, it entered the scene fairly late, becoming the 34th state to allow them.
The law imposes a limit of 100 on the number of charter schools that can be created, but there is no limit on the number of existing public schools that can convert to charter status.
Sisulu is among three new schools approved for this fall by the State University of New York board of trustees, which shared approval power with the Board of Regents. The second, the John A. Reisenbach School, is also in Harlem, but as a nonprofit institution, modeled on an existing small public school, it is less of a challenge to the status quo.
The third, New Covenant, is in Albany. It is a partnership between the Urban League and Advantage Schools Inc., a private company that runs schools in other states. Like Sisulu, it is intended to make a profit.
Sisulu, for one, has promised to do better than other public schools in the neighborhood, which are among the lowest-performing in the city. Even if the school fails to meet its test-score targets after three years, there is an escape clause: if 70 percent of the families approve of the school, the contractor may remain. But if it does not meet its targets within five years, Mr. Klinsky said, the state can revoke its charter.
Since the school goes up only to the second grade, children will not be required to take state tests, which begin in the third grade, this year. It is to expand by one grade each year.
Sisulu is the creation of Steven B. Klinsky, a partner in the investment firm of Forstmann Little & Company, which has no stake in the charter school. Mr. Klinsky said he started the school for a combination of altruistic and unabashedly capitalist reasons.
Quoting Martin Buber, he tells how he believes that everyone was placed on this earth to accomplish one good thing. "I can't invent a new medicine," Mr. Klinsky said. "But I can do something in education."
In 1993, he started an after-school program in memory of his brother, Gary, in East New York, an impoverished part of Brooklyn. That program, now serving 460 children, is nonprofit. Sisulu plans to use a similar after-school program.
But Mr. Klinsky contends that despite the populist veneer of charter schools, only a contractor with significant assets can overcome the financial and logistical hurdles needed to open one. Even before the first student has arrived, Mr. Klinsky said, he has invested hundreds of thousands of dollars in the school. To make a profit, he needs to achieve economy of scale by opening other charter schools.
The school's business plan permits up to 22 percent of its revenue to go to the contractor, at least 7 percent as profit. Mr. Klinsky expects to collect at least $6,000 per student and about double that for special education students.
"It's just about impossible for a normal group of citizens to open a charter school," he said. "For one thing, the economic requirements are very high."
Mr. Klinsky has capitalized, as well, on his political connections. The board of advisers to the school includes Erskine B. Bowles, former chief of staff to President Clinton, and the Rev. Floyd W. Flake, a former Congressman.
When Mr. Walker proposed to start a school but faced questions about the separation of church and state, Mr. Klinsky came to the rescue by agreeing to rent the community center, on 115th Street between Lenox and St. Nicholas Avenues, for $160,000 a year. After the first year, the business plan contemplates expanding to an adjoining church-owned building, with rent rising $48,000 a year. Two church members are unpaid Sisulu trustees.
The church has been the lure for some parents.
"It should be pretty good," said Valerie Banks, whose son, James, will go to first grade at Sisulu. "It can't be too wrong, because Canaan Baptist won't let anything go too wrong."
In the rush to recruit students, volunteers handed out thousands of fliers in hospitals and at subway stops, promising a refuge from existing public schools "with the quality of a good private school, but with no tuition." Some students were recruited by church members and people on the school staff.
Anyone living in the city was eligible to enter a bingo-style lottery for admission. Some parents waited more than two hours for the names of the lucky children to be fished from a drum. Despite the showmanship, almost every child who applied found a place.
The school hired teachers through newspaper ads and word of mouth, receiving 150 applications and hiring 11. Three of the teachers are uncertified. School leaders would not disclose the salaries offered, but many of the teachers are beginners who have never led an elementary school classroom and will need considerable support to succeed.
"I left corporate America," said Cathy Inniss, one of the teachers, a former commercial insurance underwriter. Her previous teaching experience, she said, was as a mentor to students in her Catholic high school and as a Girl Scout leader.
School officials have worked hard to instill a sense of ownership in the parents. The principal, Berthe Faustin, a petite, authoritative woman, promised that parents could visit their children's classrooms whenever they wanted. Some teachers, she said, would even give out their home phone numbers.
But in other ways, Sisulu is like any other public school. Class sizes are larger than those in elite private schools, and about on par with those in surrounding city schools.
The contract lists spending per pupil, including teacher salaries, textbooks, supplies and aides, of $3,110, compared with an average in Harlem public schools of $3,500.
The curriculum -- Direct Instruction for reading and math; Core Knowledge for history and science -- is focused on helping children pass the standardized tests, leaving as little as possible to chance.
In Direct Instruction, teachers are expected to follow a script, word by word, gesture by gesture. A consultant, Jane DeNapoli, spent seven days before school opened training the new teaching staff in the verbal prompts and hand gestures that Direct Instruction uses to cue children.
"Get ready," the teachers intoned again and again, copying Ms. DeNapoli's inflection exactly.
Core Knowledge, developed by Dr. Hirsch, a professor at the University of Virginia, tries to define cultural literacy, from nursery rhymes to historic events. Dr. Hirsch is the author of the commercially successful series of books "What Your First Grader Needs to Know," and so on for each grade.
To many parents, the cookie-cutter approach was reassuring, and parents seemed beguiled by the opportunity to try something new and different. Many of the parents have been shopping for effective, high-scoring schools, and Sisulu has done some recruiting, giving it an advantage over neighborhood schools forced to accept all nearby residents.
Loretta Harris was a top student at P.S. 65. She was recruited by Laurie Brown, a curriculum developer who worked at P.S. 65 and was hired by Mr. Klinsky.
Valerie Banks, who is on public assistance, would send her only son, James, to private school if she could afford it. She knows that her neighborhood school, P.S. 144 in Harlem, ranks among the lowest in the city, with 21.7 percent of students reading at grade level and 12.5 percent doing math at grade level in 1999.
When she spotted a flier promoting Sisulu, she jumped at the opportunity. "It's a risk, but what caught my eye was that it said discipline," she said. "When you're a poor person, public school is usually your only option."
Sisulu has given James a scholarship for his uniform, supplying two pairs of pants, two shirts, a sweater and a tie. Ms. Banks's mother, a retired transit cleaner, contributed 8 long-sleeved white shirts, one short-sleeved shirt and 24 pairs of socks. Now all he needs are the black shoes. (His good Easter shoes are blue.)
Last week, James received a welcoming card from his teachers. "Can't wait to see you," it said, signed, "Mr. Henderson and Miss Ortiz." His cousin, who will also go the school, got a postcard, too, but with a different message on it. Ms. Banks was pleased by the difference, concluding that the teachers had written the cards themselves.
"It sounds pretty good," she said. "You just got to wait and see."

HEADLINE: A U.S. Office Opens, Stirring Saigon Memories

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, Sept. 7

 BODY:
In the heart of the old Saigon, on the site where the American Ambassador fled in a helicopter from his embassy roof 24 years ago, a new United States consulate was dedicated today, a symbol of a new but unsure relationship of old enemies trying to be friends.
The new beige-and-green building is modest compared with the multistoried concrete block that was a nerve center for the Vietnam War. The old compound was demolished last year. 
 Instead of dealing with body counts and B-52 bombing sorties, the consulate is generally expected to grant 25,000 immigrant and 150,000 visitors' visas a year, making it one of the busiest posts in the world.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, here for the formal commissioning of the consulate, spoke of the changing dynamic between the United States and Vietnam, still cocooned by an orthodox Communist Party and struggling to emerge on the economic stage.
"In this place, surrounded by reminders of the past, our two countries will be moving resolutely toward a better future," she said.
As much as the two sides may try to put the war behind them, the dialogue and the visions of the past still reverberate. A former Deputy Foreign Minister of Vietnam, Le Mai, was fond of reminding Americans that "Vietnam is a country, not only a war."
The two top American diplomats in Vietnam fought here. Ambassador Pete Peterson, a former Navy pilot, spent six and a half years as a prisoner of war in Hanoi, where the American Embassy now stands. The Consul General here, Charles Ray, served two tours as an Army officer in the war.
They are both big admirers of Vietnam and contend that the emotions of the war should be replaced by closer political and economic ties. But a ceremony on the tarmac of Hanoi International Airport this morning was a reminder that the war's legacy is still very much alive.
Ms. Albright witnessed Vietnamese officials' handing over to a Pentagon group the remains of four bodies believed to be those of American soldiers who died in combat in the 1960's and who have been listed as missing in action. The remains were placed in four aluminum coffins, each covered with an American flag, and put aboard a C-17 Air Force plane for the trip home.
The search for American soldiers missing in action has been progressing since 1992, when the Vietnamese Government gave permission to the Pentagon to work here. Ms. Albright stressed that access to the Vietnamese countryside to find those still listed as missing in action was the basis on which the two countries resumed diplomatic relations five years ago and that it remained paramount to good relations.
Since 1973, the remains of 529 members of the armed forces have been identified and returned to their families, according to the Pentagon. An additional 1,530 are yet to be found. About 200,000 Vietnamese soldiers who died have not been accounted for, according to the Government here.
Recently, in a reciprocal gesture, the Pentagon agreed to open its archives to Vietnamese officials to examine records and maps to assist them in their search for their missing in action.
Ms. Albright devoted much of her time in Hanoi to trying to persuade the top Communist officials that it is in their interest to complete a trade agreement with Washington. The proposed pact, under discussion for four years, would open Vietnamese markets to American companies and would give Vietnam normal trading relations with the United States. Vietnam remains one of a handful of countries that has not been extended such status by the United States.
But since signing a preliminary agreement in July, the Vietnamese have not completed the final accord, even with the approach of an economic meeting of Asian nations in New Zealand this weekend, where the Vietnamese are widely expected to sign. Ms. Albright said after her talks in Hanoi that she was hopeful that the Vietnamese would resolve "technical issues" in time.
Some of the Vietnamese nervousness about the trade accord appears to rise from uncertainty in the Government about whether Communist Party control can be maintained with the intrusion of Western investment and accompanying trends that free trade would bring, diplomats said.
Hanoi remains one of the few cities in Asia relatively untouched by Western culture and consumption. McDonald's does not operate in Vietnam.
The governing Communist Party elite, including Prime Minister Phan Van Khai, were trained in the Soviet Union, and still, diplomats said, hark to those days. Ho Chi Minh remains a revered figure, and a visit to his tomb is a popular excursion.
The lack of a trade agreement, which is intended to slice import tariffs like the 200 percent duty on imported cars and to require a new openness in commercial transactions has severely hampered growth.
Despite an initial buzz of interest by Western companies when the United States and Vietnam opened diplomatic relations, foreign investment has declined in the last several years, according to the World Bank.
The economy was buffeted by the Asian financial crisis, and the state retains control of all important industries. The World Bank recently reported plummeting export growth. About 250 American companies are doing business in Vietnam. But many have reduced their presence. Some have left, and not many are making money, American officials said.

A picture caption last Wednesday about the dedication of the new United States Consulate in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, referred imprecisely to a picture of the American helicopter evacuation of the city in 1975. The building shown housed employees of the United States Embassy, but was not the embassy itself.
