HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Why Seinfeld ('Irony Incarnate') Is So Menacing

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

FOR COMMON THINGS
Irony, Trust and Commitment in America Today
By Jedediah Purdy
226 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $20.
"An ironic man, with his sly stillness, and ambuscading ways," wrote Thomas Carlyle in "Sartor Resartus," "may be viewed as a pest to society."
No, worse, argues Jedediah Purdy in his impressive if somewhat pious first book, "For Common Things: Irony, Trust and Commitment in America Today." The ironic man, whom Mr. Purdy personifies as the sitcom character Jerry Seinfeld, "irony incarnate," is an outright menace. 
 With his "style of speech and behavior that avoids all appearance of naivete -- of naive devotion, belief, or hope," the individual armored in the irony so prevalent among young people today has withdrawn from the political arena just when it needs him most. With good reason perhaps, Mr. Purdy concedes, politics these days being, in his words, "undignified, disreputable, vaguely ridiculous and thoroughly outmoded," especially compared with an earlier time in the century, when, as the German novelist Thomas Mann wrote, "The question of man's destiny presents itself in political terms."
But politics today is both less and more than a Promethean exercise intended to "bring about basic changes in the human predicament," Mr. Purdy argues. Politics can also serve the maintenance of what he punningly calls "common things," referring all at once to what is public, what we all share and what is ordinary.
Mr. Purdy says that the decline of the commons isn't as inevitable as the ecologist Garrett Hardin described it as being in "The Tragedy of the Commons," which argued that self-interest must lead everyone with access to the commons to take as much as possible -- that is, to overgraze or to clear forests -- until it is exhausted.
If only, Mr. Purdy implores, the commons can be seen less narrowly as three interrelated ecologies: first, "an interpersonal, moral ecology"; second, "a broad social ecology," including "the institutions and practices that affect the shape of our lives," and third, the "natural world." In this perspective then the ironist's shunning of politics will become untenable.
To reveal this vision of politics and the commons, he has written "so that I will not forget what I hope for now, and because others might conclude that they hope for the same things." He continues: "That would be the beginning of turning some of our private, half-secret repositories of hope and trust into common things. I think that some of them must be common, if they are to be at all."
As abstract as his ideas may sound, he has rooted them in the realities of West Virginia, where his parents moved in 1974, the year he was born. Growing up there until he went off to Phillips Exeter Academy at age 14, he was inspired both by the way his parents integrated their work and home lives with the community and by the indifference of the coal-mining companies that he sees as having ravaged the environment. He came away with a vision of work that embedded thinking in the dirt of reality, precluding irony.
By defining this work in moral terms, he hopes to unearth another kind of irony, one that "uncovers, in what is ordinarily imagined to be unimportant or banal, something that elicits surprise, delight and reverence." He concludes: "This irony is ecstatic, in the etymologically strict sense of drawing us out of our stasis. It is the irony of discovery. It moves us."
The difficulty is that little of what Mr. Purdy writes is new. As he is the first to recognize, it takes us back to familiar thinkers like Emerson, Thoreau, de Tocqueville, Marx, Camus, Orwell and Weber, among others. On top of this, he labors at length such crashingly obvious ideas as the ethical ambiguities of technology (in particular genetic technology) and the decline of neighborly communities.
Worse, he often sounds self-righteous. He treats the global market economy, which he anathematizes, as if it were something that came into existence in the absence of human effort, whereas it is arguably the consequence of decades of engaged political striving. (Yet on the issue of mountaintop-removal strip-mining, he takes the libertarian position that to pay the cost of coal-mining's environmental damage you must factor it into the price of coal.)
Finally, he trivializes his opposition, not only by reducing all ironists to Seinfeld but also by disdaining all those who seek easier connections to reality than the thankless task of politics.
One comes away from "For Common Things" feeling that the superficial people he seeks to convert won't be bothered to fight their way through his abstruse prose, with its sometimes complex way of saying the most simple things.
Still, you almost always sense what he's getting at, and you have to admire him for taking on the disease of irony, which some see as afflicting an entire generation. If many will not heed him, at least he has articulated a cure.
As his epigraph by Czeslaw Milosz puts it, "What is unpronounced tends to nonexistence." Now that "For Common Things" pronounces the case against a static irony, it gives one pause about reacting ironically.

HEADLINE: Concerts to Introduce Humanitarian Web Site

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
Three all-star pop stadium concerts on Oct. 9 -- in New Jersey, England and Switzerland -- are to introduce Netaid.org, a Web site that seeks to end poverty by bringing together relief organizations with donors and volunteers. In a news conference yesterday, Bono of U2 described Netaid as "the Yellow Pages of aid in cyberspace."
The concerts, produced by the people who assembled the Ethiopian famine-relief benefit Live Aid in the 1980's, are to take place at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.; Wembley Stadium outside London, and the Palais des Nations in Geneva. 
 At Giants Stadium, the performers are to include Puff Daddy, Celine Dion, Sting, the Algerian singer Cheb Mami, Mary J. Blige, Busta Rhymes, Jimmy Page of Led Zeppelin, Counting Crows, Jon Bon Jovi and the Italian rock singer Zucchero. Wyclef Jean of the Fugees and Bono are to perform a song they wrote in honor of Netaid, "New Day." Giants Stadium tickets go on sale tomorrow through Ticketmaster.
At Wembley the lineup includes David Bowie, Bryan Adams, Bush, the Coors, George Michaels, Robbie Williams and the reunited Eurythymics. A private concert in Geneva, where many of the relief organizations have headquarters, is to feature Bryan Ferry, Des'ree and the Scottish group Texas.
Jewel and Sheryl Crow have both agreed to perform, but their location has not been decided. The concerts are to be televised on VH1, MTV and, in Britain, on the BBC. Radio stations will carry the events to 60 countries, and there will be an Internet Webcast.
The concerts are not primarily for fund-raising, although the immediate proceeds will be dedicated to aid refugees in Kosovo and for relief work in Africa. Donations from listeners will be directed to the Netaid Foundation, which will distribute contributions under the direction of the United Nations Development Program, its antipoverty agency.
But the main purpose of the events is to draw worldwide attention to Netaid, a novel alliance of the United Nations, Internet entrepreneurs and musicians.
"It's about a billion hits against poverty, and we want to punch that sucker out," Quincy Jones, the musician and producer, said at the news conference.
Netaid will provide information and eventually direct connections for people working on projects as diverse as environmental problems, disaster relief or lobbying to cancel the international debts of the 52 poorest countries.
"The idea is for it to become the largest portal and directory for antipoverty organizations in the world," said Bob Chlopak, a spokesman for Netaid. After the concerts, the site will be overseen by the United Nations Development Program.
Cisco Systems, the networking company that has built the Web site and donated $10 million to the Netaid Foundation, announced that Netaid was 10 times larger than any other Web site.
Kofi Annan, the Secretary General of the United Nations, appeared at the news conference. By satellite, President Clinton and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain activated the Web site in North America and Europe. Nelson Mandela, the former President of South Africa, also appeared by satellite.
"As the Internet reaches more and more communities," Mr. Mandela said, "they will gain access to new information and resources they can use to uplift themselves."

HEADLINE: Forecast of PC Shipments Is Revised Upward

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Worldwide personal computer shipments should grow by nearly 25 percent in the third quarter compared with the similar period last year, according to International Data Corporation -- far more than it had previously forecast.
Three months ago, International Data, a research company in Framingham, Mass., had expected the global PC industry would grow 19.3 percent in the third quarter. 
 The firm said growth was being driven by strong consumer demand for less expensive PC's, healthy demand in Asian markets and the strong United States economy.
Shipment volume is expected to rise 7.2 percent in the third quarter compared with the second quarter, it said.
Researchers warned that the figures would not translate into similarly robust revenues; Dataquest, another research firm, expects the average price of PC's to grow by only about 5 percent this year.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
NETHERLANDS: KEY JUDGE QUITS WAR PANEL -- One of the most senior judges of the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal, Antonio Cassese, will resign next February, the third key figure to quit the United Nations court in recent months. Judge Cassese, an Italian, who has served on the court since its creation in 1993, said he would go back to being a law professor at Florence University, nearly two years before the end of his term. Gabrielle Kirk McDonald, the tribunal president, will leave in November and Louise Arbour, the chief prosecutor, steps down on Sept. 15. Marlise Simons (NYT) 

TURKEY: QUAKE DEATH TOLL -- The death toll in last month's earthquake has reached 15,303, and 23,954 were injured, the Government announced. Newspapers have reported that 30,000 or more people are still missing. About 250,000 survivors are homeless. Stephen Kinzer (NYT)
 
GERMANY: SPOOFING SCHRODER -- Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has appeared on German television as a kinky hermaphrodite complete with pierced breasts, a dog collar and a loony grin -- and he is not pleased. The Munich-based RTL-2 network faces possible legal action from Mr. Schroder after airing an "interview" with a leather-clad Schroder lookalike puppet on an erotic show called "Peep." Mr. Schroder said the show, about the sexual preferences of the Chancellor, was "worse than overstepping the boundaries of taste." Roger Cohen (NYT)
 
GERMANY: HISTORIC PROTEST -- Parliament held its first session in the renovated Reichstag in Berlin, and weathered its first protest. Doctors built a wall of ice 20 feet long by 10 feet high outside the building to protest Government health care changes, which they say could usher in a new ice age for the health service, threatening 19,000 jobs this year. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
SWITZERLAND: IMAGE MAKEOVER -- The Government wants to make a major effort to improve Switzerland's image abroad, especially in the United States. The Foreign Ministry is asking lawmakers to approve a $31 million program to promote the country's humanitarian work, its cultural diversity and democratic traditions. "Switzerland's image abroad has suffered quite a bit recently," said Foreign Minister Joseph Deiss. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
 
 SWITZERLAND: MILOSEVIC MONEY -- Two months after Switzerland agreed to freeze any assets belonging to President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, the Government said no firm evidence of any Swiss bank accounts had turned up. Acting on a request from the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague, Swiss authorities had promised to block bank accounts or other assets belonging to Mr. Milosevic, four Serbian leaders indicted for war crimes and 300 other senior Yugoslav officials. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
 
 SPAIN: PINOCHET INVITED TO COURT -- Judge Baltasar Garzon, who is seeking the extradition from Britain of Gen. Augusto Pinochet to answer charges of human rights abuses, has given the former Chilean dictator until Sept. 27 to voluntarily appear in Madrid court. The move comes in response to a motion by General Pinochet, who is under house arrest outside London, to defend himself in Spain -- and gain access to court papers -- while fighting extradition in Britain, where the next hearing is set for Sept. 27. Al Goodman (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
MYANMAR: 2d BRITON HELD -- A 28-year-old British woman was arrested for protesting in Yangon against Myanmar's military rulers but diplomats were not allowed to see her, the British Embassy said. Rachel Goldwyn, a human rights worker, is the second British activist arrested in Myanmar in a week. The embassy said it had still not been given access to James Mawdsley, 26, a Briton sentenced last week for 17 years for pro-democracy activism. (Reuters)
 
NORTH KOREA: TALKS WITH U.S. CONTINUE -- American and North Korean envoys held a second day of talks in Berlin in their latest effort to ease tensions on the Korean peninsula, but delegates refused to say whether they were making progress. The Clinton Administration hopes to persuade North Korea to freeze its missile programs during the five-day talks. (AP)
 
SRI LANKA: POLIO CEASE-FIRE -- The Tamil Tiger guerrillas and Government forces have agreed to a four-day cease-fire to allow a United Nations agency to carry out a nationwide polio immunization program. Unicef said the separatist Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam and security forces agreed to the "days of tranquillity" on Friday and Saturday and again on two days next month. (Agence France-Presse)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: PUBLISHING AGAIN -- Iran's most outspoken newspaper, which has published under three different names and been shut down each time by hard-liners, plans to come out under yet another title. Authorities closed the daily Neshat on Saturday for insulting Islam. The paper's Internet site said the daily would be published soon under the name Akhbar-e-Eqtesad, or Economic News. Neshat first appeared as Jameah shortly after the May 1997 election of the reformist President Mohammad Khatami, who called Saturday's closing illegal. (AP)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: SUIT OVER BANK PAPERS -- Overriding President Ernesto Zedillo's political party, the opposition in Congress voted to sue in the Supreme Court to force the Government to turn over bank documents from his 1994 presidential campaign. Investigators are looking into whether Mr. Zedillo received illegal donations from Carlos Cabal Peniche, a banker embroiled in fraud charges. Julia Preston (NYT)
 
ARGENTINA: EXILE MAY BE MOVED -- The Government said it was considering moving Lino Oviedo, the former Parguayan army chief who fled his country and lives outside Buenos Aires as a political exile, to a ranch on an isolated pampas in central Argentina. The move is in response to growing tensions with Paraguay, which has twice called for General Oviedo's extradition to face charges he was involved in the assassination of Vice President Luis Maria Argana last March. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
CANADA: QUEEN'S NEW REPRESENTATIVE -- Prime Minister Jean Chretien named Adrienne Clarkson, a former television journalist, as the country's new Governor General, the representative in Canada of Queen Elizabeth. Ms. Clarkson, who was evacuated from Hong Kong as a child during World War II, is the first immigrant to hold Canada's top ceremonial post. James Brooke (NYT)
 
CANADA: SEARCH FOR TRUDEAU SON -- Canadian Mounted Police divers started searching a high-altitude British Columbia lake where Michel Trudeau, a son of Pierre Trudeau, Canada's former Prime Minister, drowned last Nov. 23. The 23-year-old was traversing a steep snow slope on skis when an avalanche swept him and a friend into the waters of Lake Kokanee. The friend managed to get out, but Michel was last seen struggling in the water. Two days after he disappeared, ice sealed the lake. The ice melted only two weeks ago. James Brooke (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
LIBYA: AFRICAN LEADERS MEET -- More than 40 African leaders met in Libya to discuss ways of restructuring the charter of the Organization of African Unity in order to strengthen closeness among member states. The Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qadaffi walked into the meeting 280 miles southeast of Tripoli with a trade-mark clenched fist raised high, prompting other African leaders to follow suit. An O.A.U. spokesman said 43 African heads of state were present, far more than officials had expected. (AP)
 
ALGERIA: REBELS SURRENDER -- Fifty radical Muslim guerrillas surrendered to the Government under a peace plan to be put to a referendum this month, the state-run radio said. It said the surrender took place 140 miles east of Algiers, but did not say when it took place. More than 100 guerrillas surrendered last week. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Americans' Use Of Credit Cards Rises Steeply

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Shoppers amassed credit card debt at the fastest pace in nearly three years in July, Federal Reserve figures showed today, indicating that spending is continuing to keep the economic expansion on track toward a record.
The use of consumer credit increased by a larger-than-expected $8.8 billion, to $1.35 trillion in July. Revolving loans, which include credit card obligations, rose $5.9 billion, the biggest increase since November 1996. 
 The July increase would mean an annualized growth rate of 7.9 percent in consumer debt, compared with a 2.9 percent annual pace in June and a 5.4 percent increase for all of last year. People are so optimistic about the economy that they have little hesitation in charging purchases, analysts said.
Consumer spending has been pushing the nation's economic expansion, now in its ninth year and five months away from becoming the longest ever.
Investors and economists watch the Fed's report on credit to help them gauge consumer demand, even though the report does not account for home equity loans and other lending secured by real estate.
Cynthia Latta, an economist at Standard & Poor's DRI in Lexington, Mass., said that "as long as the labor market remains strong and inflation stays low, we see no obvious reason for the consumer to cut back on spending."
Auto and other loans increased $3.1 billion after falling $2.3 billion in June, the Fed said. Revolving credit had increased $5.5 billion in June.
For June, consumer credit rose a revised $3.3 billion, previously reported as an increase of $2.8 billion.
Other data today, from the Commerce Department, showed that wholesalers' inventories rose nine-tenths of a percent in July, the fastest pace in 10 months. Sales fell two-tenths of a percent, for the first time since January.
Department and chain stores reported sales gains in August compared with figures a year earlier. Auto sales rose markedly.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Welcome to Kremlingate

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Surprise, surprise: corruption has been rampant in the Kremlin.
Swiss investigators are finding funny money in secret bank accounts of President Yeltsin's personal and official family members. In the U.S., the Bank of New York is being forced to explain the laundering of billions ripped off by favored oligarchs. 
 "Five years ago," says Grigory Yavlinsky, the reformist leader who has long been blowing an unheededwhistle on the grandest larceny of the century, "you could have asked any little child in the smallest village in Siberia about this, and he would have told you all about the criminal conspiracies. Why is it news today? Because of your elections and ours."
The Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission, with its hundreds of junketeering bureaucrats, treated the corruption as a mere bump on the road to a market economy. Vice President Al Gore even famously scrawled a barnyard epithet across a C.I.A. memo warning of the diversion of foreign aid into the pockets of Yeltsin's clique. (Why doesn't Al enliven his speeches with such colorful expressions?)
As 2000 approaches, the time ripens for exposure of the blind eye Gore turned to "Kremlingate." We Republicans smack our lips here in the run-ups to our primaries, and the would-be successors to Yeltsin rub their hands before elections to their Parliament this December and their White House next June.
Russia's second contested national election is similar in some ways to our own tumultuous contest in 1800, when the established Federalists John Adams and Alexander Hamilton fell out and deals were made in Congress to help the anti-Federalist Thomas Jefferson squeak in.
In Russian politics, three main forces are also taking shape: On the left is the Communist Party, its members aging and dying, its Stalinists and Agrarians splintering off. Though it holds nearly half the Duma seats now, that could drop to below a third in December's elections.
In the sinister center is the front-running team of the old spymaster Yevgeny Primakov and Moscow's Mayor, Yuri Luzhkov. They have the main money men and the media moguls behind them. Cozy corruption would most likely continue in this "Yevgeny and Yuri Show."
On the right is Yabloko, the democratic party headed by Yavlinsky, the only reformer not to have been suckered and dumped by Yeltsin. He's just been joined by Sergei Stepashin, also 47, one of the revolving-door prime ministers; this cop expands the party base by bringing along not-nutty nationalists. Yavlinsky insists he's clean, and should help Yabloko in its goal of doubling its strength to a fifth of the Duma seats.
There's also an Inconsequential Right, ranging from the grumpy economist Yegor Gaidar to the attractive young reformer Boris Nemtsov to Yeltsin's cunning Anatoly Chubais. But this segment even trails the sidelined Gen. Aleksandr Lebed and the wild Vladimir Zhirinovsky.
Beyond corruption, political Russians have to deal with a wild card: the war in Dagestan. Even reformers who condemned the war in Chechnya are calling for Russian action to repel the Islamic fundamentalist invaders said to be helped by the terrorist financier Osama bin Laden. Wars create unexpected heroes and scapegoats and will affect the Russian elections.
What should America do to advance the cause of freedom in the coming Russian elections? Should we pull our investigative punch into Kremlingate lest ordinary Russians think we are abusing them when their country is down ?
We should butt out of their politics. We have shown we do more harm than good to genuine reform. At the same time, we should butt into their predators' thievery -- following every lead to help Russia recover funds spirited out by corrupt officials and Western co-conspirators.
If it embarrasses President Clinton and Yeltsin, or if it means we must wait six months for Communists to be replaced in the Duma so that Russia can ratify our arms limitation treaty, so be it. Both countries will be in business under new management in 18 months.
Yavlinsky's advice on what America should do: "Relax. You are still looking for partnerships with people who may be shown to be corrupt. Please -- just relax." 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico's Banks Adopt American Credit-Reporting Practices

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
The usual reason given for the failure of about a third of Mexico's bank loans since 1995 is soaring inflation.
With nearly all loans pegged to the inflation rate, which at times approached 100 percent, it was not long before many Mexicans owed more in interest than they had borrowed. So many borrowers merely walked away. 
 But bankers now acknowledge that even without inflation, touched off by peso devaluation, many of the loans would probably have gone bad.
A key reason was that bankers had made many of the loans with little data about the borrowers. The kind of nationwide, computerized credit reporting companies that had been standard in the United States for decades simply did not exist.
But now two of the biggest American companies, the Trans Union Corporation of Chicago and Equifax Inc. of Atlanta, are at work building files and computer systems in Mexico that will give bankers here the same instantaneous credit profiles that bankers in New York and Miami and Los Angeles take for granted.
Starting from scratch in late 1996, Trans Union, in a joint venture with Mexican banks, has compiled files on 25 million loans, representing most of the market, according to Trans Union. Equifax says it has 8 million files and hopes to have 20 million by this time next year.
While Mexico's economy has been recovering nicely, thanks to a surge in manufacturing and good earnings from higher oil prices, its banks are still limping along, collecting what they can on old debts and lending very little. The few mortgages that are being issued are at interest rates of nearly 30 percent, with credit cards charging more than 50 percent. Small and midsize businesses are starving for cash. Housing construction is down.
So the Government is eager to strengthen the banks. Just a few months ago, it made the credit reporting agencies a formal part of Mexico's financial system, for the first time mandating that bankers check out all prospective loans through one of the agencies. In the United States, credit reporting has been integral to lending for decades, but industry executives say that it is entirely discretionary.
Determined to inject discipline into lending in Mexico, the Government went on to require that, in the case of a bad credit report, a loan of say $100,000 or any other amount, could only be made if the bank were willing to set aside an equal amount in reserves.
It was a blunt sanction, that Federico Castro Rosas, the general director of BC Buro de Credito, the joint venture in which Trans Union is the largest investor, said would surely stop any lender in his tracks.
Like much of the rest of Latin America as well as Africa and parts of Asia, Mexico had gotten along for decades with very little credit reporting. There had been a credit reporting agency in Mexico -- at least in name -- starting in the early 1970's. But it was never really taken seriously and was eventually done away with. Banks and other lenders refused to share their credit information with the agency, and what little the agency could gather was fragmented, often outdated and considered unreliable.
"It was very poorly managed," said Ernesto Gomez-Gallardo, an executive vice president at Banamex, the country's largest bank.
Few felt an urgent need for better credit reporting, partly because, in Mexico as in many other developing countries, the banks lent to a fairly small circle -- either customers they knew or those referred to them.
But bank lending and the credit card business in Mexico exploded in the late 1980's and early 1990's as the banks were reprivatized after a decade of state control. Bankers who had paid high prices to get into the business were eager to put their money to work and began lending to almost anyone.
In those days, one banker said, "you just didn't check people's credit.
"There were questions on the application form," the banker said, "but the customer could lie and tell you he hadn't had any problems. And you would never know. The credit bureau wouldn't have the information."
After the value of the peso was cut in half in late 1994, inflation soared, and the banks and the Government recognized that big changes had to be made.
As one measure, the Mexican Association of Bankers deputized the five largest banks to begin talks with Trans Union, Equifax and the other industry giant in the United States, the Experian Corporation. Trans Union won the contest and three years ago began issuing credit reports as part of the joint venture with the banks. Equifax says it withdrew from contention and decided to go it alone before the banking association announced its choice. Experian is not doing business in Mexico. While Equifax has a few bank customers in Mexico, its greatest following so far has been among retailers. But it has its eyes on a stronger position with the banks. Equifax, the only one of the three companies that is publicly traded in the United States, had revenues in 1998 of $1.6 billion.
"The Mexicans are interested in competition," said Bill Phinney, a senior executive for Equifax in Latin America. "They want more than one player in their markets."
Both American companies have brought in sophisticated computer systems that blend information from several sources and, in seconds, produce reports on a person's debt history, the types and amounts of loans, the timeliness of payments and any defaults or repossessions. The companies charge corporations in both the United States and Mexico a negotiated fee for each report.
For both Trans Union and Equifax, the move into Mexico was part of a plan to expand from the saturated United States credit reporting market into Latin America and other parts of the world. "We see very good growth potential in Mexico," said Mr. Phinney of Equifax.
Lending has become a much more cautious and restrictive business in Mexico. And, the bankers say, it is a tough adjustment for many customers. "This is a big shock to Mexican culture," said Mr. Gomez-Gallardo. "If you have a bad loan or a default, you won't be getting credit. That is something new."
In the past, when one lender did not know what the other was doing, he said, "People didn't pay and nothing happened."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Fed Actions Aid Recovery Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices rebounded yesterday as traders covered short positions after the Federal Reserve took measures to insure there would be enough money in the banking system to counter any Year 2000 computer problems.
The market's tone improved and remained firm after Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, spoke at Grand Valley State University in Michigan but did not comment on interest rates, the economy or policy as expected. Remarks by other officials yesterday, including Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor, in Philadelphia and Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers at the New York Economic Club had little market effect and failed to put the market in a defensive stance. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 3/32, to 100 26/32. Its yield was unchanged at 6.07 percent.
Analysts said the market was also aided by the announcement of a Year 2000 program that would allow banks to use expanded forms of collateral for repurchase transactions within 90 days, which will add liquidity to the banking system. It eased concern that trading Treasuries or other fixed-income paper might be difficult at the end of the year. Some investors have had concerns the financial markets might freeze up, causing some to postpone selling until early next year.
Yesterday's sparse economic data were virtually ignored, showing that the market gave an inordinate amount of attention to the Fed news, said Andy Bischel, director of investing at Spare, Kaplan, Bischel & Associates in San Francisco. "The Fed is probably going to raise rates as soon as October," he said, "but in the meantime the market has been in and out discounting the increase."
July wholesale inventories rose nine-tenths of a percent, another hint that the change in business inventories in the third quarter could add noticeably to growth in the gross domestic product, some economists said.
Bond market participants have begun to focus on the scheduled release tomorrow of the Government's report on producer prices, or inflation at the manufacturing level, a key indicator of inflation.
However, the economic reports scheduled for release next week will play a role in determining whether the Fed will raise rates again at its meeting on Oct. 5, said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. "Market participants will certainly pay particular attention to retail sales, housing starts, industrial production, and capacity utilization, but most keenly awaited of all will be the C.P.I., the Fed's benchmark inflation measure."
A robust Consumer Price Index, coupled with retail sales data that indicate continued momentum in consumer spending, would create considerable consternation among Fed members and could prompt another increase, Mr. Fine said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Prices End Mixed as Traders Await a Key Inflation Figure

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday as investors remained cautious ahead of important economic data scheduled to be released tomorrow. Traders said a small rise in the Dow Jones industrial average was overshadowed by declines in other indicators and by market breadth, which was decidedly negative.
The Dow rose 2.21 points, or less than one-tenth of a percent, to 11,036.34. The Nasdaq composite index fell 28.52 points, or 1.02 percent, to 2,808.74, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 6.30 points, or five-tenths of a percent, to 1,344.15. 
 Declining issues outnumbered advancers 3 to 2 on the Big Board.
Although several people whose remarks often move markets spoke yesterday, none seemed to sway the market. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, focused on technology in a speech delivered at Grand Valley State University in Michigan and avoided any hint about the direction of interest rates.
In a speech to the National Association for Business Economics, Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor, said the nation's tight labor market threatened to fuel inflation but left it open whether the central bank would raise interest rates soon to counter that threat. Mr. Meyer -- widely seen as the Fed's most conservative member -- also said the central bank had no choice but to take into account the effect of higher stock prices on the overall economy when it sets interest rates.
Also yesterday, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers reiterated that a strong dollar was in the best interests of the United States.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the influential and bullish market strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, raised her 1999 earnings estimate on the S.& P. 500 companies and raised her target for the Dow industrials for 1999 to 11,500. Ms. Cohen said the new target was based on the higher earnings estimates, a continuation of modest inflation and a belief that bond yields appear to be peaking.
"It looked like the market reacted the most to Meyer," Barry Hyman, a strategist at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum, said. "He intimated that inflation is a concern even though it does not seem obvious right now."
Mr. Hyman said the market was looking for evidence that interest rates would not be raised a third time, and a key indicator of inflation will be the release of producer price data tomorrow. Analysts expect the report to show a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in August after a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent in July.
Ingram Micro tumbled 6, to 13 5/16, after the company warned of an earnings shortfall. The wholesaler of computer products and services said it expected to earn 10 to 14 cents a share in the third quarter. Analysts had been expecting 41 cents.
Global Crossing rose 5 1/4, to 25 9/16. Global Crossing, Microsoft and Softbank of Japan said they were joining forces to build a $1.28 billion telecommunications network in Asia. Frontier, which is being acquired by Global Crossing, jumped 8 13/16, to 45 1/8.
VF fell 3 11/16, to 31 1/16. The company said late on Tuesday that third-quarter earnings would slip 10 percent to 15 percent, compared with the period a year earlier. The company blamed weakness in sales at mid-tier department stores and in international sales of jeans.
Covance, which provides drug development services for the pharmaceuticals industry, fell 4 7/8, to 10 5/8. The company said it expected earnings for the third quarter and year to be below analysts' forecasts. Covance said that its clinical trial business was experiencing a slowdown and that growth in its laboratory business had leveled off.
IMRglobal fell 5 3/16, to 11 1/4. The company said late on Tuesday that it expected third-quarter earnings in the range of 12 to 16 cents a share, far below forecasts of 25 cents share. The company, which is involved in software and other services for business customers, said delays in the start of several large projects contributed to a slowdown.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Now Positive On Prospects ForEconomy

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 8

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, suggested today that the United States economy's expansion could continue, thanks to advancements in information technology.
The growth of such technologies as integrated circuits and improvements in software are among the developments that have "begun to alter, fundamentally, the manner in which we do business and create economic value," Mr. Greenspan said in the text of remarks in Grand Rapids, Mich. 
 That has bolstered productivity and shows few signs of slowing, he suggested. "Growth in output per work hour has accelerated, elevating the standards of living of the average American worker" because improvements in information technology have permitted changes in inventory management, distribution systems, customer service and other tasks, Mr. Greenspan said. That has "sharply reduced the degree of uncertainty confronting business management," he added.
Mr. Greenspan, whose last public comments, on Aug. 27, raised questions about whether stocks were inflated and started the Dow Jones industrial average on a 1 percent decline for that day, did not revisit the subject in today's text. He also did not discuss his views on interest rates, inflation or current economic conditions.
His speech was part of a lecture series sponsored by Grand Valley State University and the Gerald R. Ford Museum to commemorate the 25th anniversary of Mr. Ford's inauguration as President.
Mr. Greenspan served as chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers under Mr. Ford from September 1974 until Mr. Ford left office Jan. 20, 1977. Before and after his stint as chief administration economist, Mr. Greenspan was chairman and president of Townsend-Greenspan & Company, an economic consulting firm in New York.
The economy's expansion, now in its ninth year, has been marked by a growth of economic value that is "intellectual and impalpable," rather than symbolized by "large steel mills, auto assembly plants and skyscrapers," Mr. Greenspan said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
With Prices Up and Joblessness Down, British Raise Rates

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Britain's central bank raised a key short-term money rate today, for the first time in more than a year, in a pre-emptive move against inflationary pressure.
The quarter-point increase in the securities repurchase rate, to 5.25 percent, broke a series of seven modest rate cuts. Its timing was a surprise to many analysts; still, it came in a period of rising housing prices and relatively low unemployment. 
 The bank's rate-setting Monetary Policy Committee said in a statement, "Although inflation is expected to remain below the target of 2.5 percent in the short term, the committee concluded that a rise in interest rates was necessary to keep inflation on track further ahead, and that an early move could lower the level at which interest rates might otherwise need to be set."
British mortgage lenders responded by raising their base rates.
The move by the central bank also sent the yield on the 10-year Government bond 12 basis points higher, to 5.52 percent. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
The pound rose, too, settling here at $1.6209 and in New York at $1.6192, up from $1.6049 on Tuesday. Stocks moved lower on the news, closing down slightly less than 1 percent.
The Bank of England last increased the securities repurchase rate in June 1998 and has been cutting it since. Buthousing prices have now reached a 10-year high, rising 9.4 percent in August. The output of goods and services just increased more than it had in almost a year, and unemployment fell to 6 percent, one of the lowest levels in Europe.
But experts here had generally not foreseen a rate rise until at least November. "We certainly didn't expect it," said Robert Barrie, chief economist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Ellen van der Gulik, euro area economist at J. P. Morgan here, said she considered the rate increase appropriate even if surprising now. "This is almost a correction of the rate cut in June, which was unnecessary," she said.
Some analysts were not particularly impressed by the announcement. "It's not as if you can really work yourself up into a state about 25 basis points," Mr. Barrie said. "The real issue is where do you go from here?"
Michael Saunders, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney, said he tended to believe that today's rate increase signified a larger move by the bank's Monetary Policy Committee. "The M.P.C.'s hypersensitivity to real growth prospects, coupled with the likelihood that real activity will strengthen in coming months, means that the chance probably is better than even" of another increase "before year-end -- even though wage and price data probably will remain subdued," he said.
But Mr. Barrie disagreed. "I don't think we're at the start of anything substantial," he said. "Inflation isn't the real issue here. Growth is coming from areas where inflation is at its lowest."
Some analysts and business leaders suggested that the rate increase might erode British economic gains. "With wage levels stable and intense competition keeping prices down at home and abroad, the economy in under no significant danger," said Ian Peters, deputy director general of the British Chambers of Commerce. "The decision threatens to put a still tentative recovery into reverse."
Mortgage lenders changed their rates within hours of the announcement. Halifax P.L.C., the nation's largest, announced a 0.14 point rise in its variable mortgage rate, the most common mortgage here, to 6.99 percent, starting Oct. 1. Virgin Direct, part of Richard Branson's business empire, raised rates by a quarter of a percentage point, to 6.45 percent, as of Thursday. The Nationwide Building Society said it planned to hold its rate at 6.45 percent.
"This economy is having very strong growth," Ms. van der Gulik said. "The mood has shifted. This is just the beginning of more hikes."

HEADLINE: Bradley, Starting Campaign, Extols Small-Town Values

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: CRYSTAL CITY, Mo., Sept. 8

 BODY:
Returning to his hometown on the banks of the Mississippi River, former Senator Bill Bradley formally opened his campaign for the Democratic nomination for President today, pledging to fight racial strife, restore trust in government and spread the nation's prosperity to the most downtrodden Americans.
On a day when the dark sky rumbled threateningly but held back its rain, Mr. Bradley delivered a 30-minute speech that was a paean to small-town life, asserting that lessons learned in the classrooms and basketball courts here had prepared him to be a more humble, caring and selfless leader in Washington. 
 "Now, above all, is not the time for complacency," he said, standing outside his red-brick high school and before a crowd of more than 2,000 banner-waving residents. "I feel an urgency to seize this moment in history, to strengthen the weak and to challenge the strong to lead us into our full greatness as a nation."
To many Democrats, Mr. Bradley faces an uphill fight against his only rival for the Democratic nomination, Vice President Gore, who has built a formidable network of party supporters in seven years in the White House. But his campaign kick-off comes at a time when there are indications that Mr. Bradley is gaining steam. Mr. Gore's lead over Mr. Bradley, a former three-term senator from New Jersey and Hall of Fame basketball player with the New York Knicks, had narrowed to less than double digits in two polls of New Hampshire voters released in the past week. One was by a Dover, N.H., television station and the second by The Boston Globe.
Mr. Bradley's campaign has unsettled the Vice President's advisers, who say the former Senator has collected more money than they expected and assembled a talented staff. "He's gone through an important initial phase where he has clearly gotten himself in the game," said Geoff Garin, a Democratic pollster. "But there's a very big next step in putting the substance into his themes."
But whether Mr. Bradley makes a strong run at Mr. Gore will depend heavily on the way he manages the next phase of his campaign, when he will come under more intense public scrutiny and will be expected to release a more detailed agenda than he has been willing to do so far.
Mr. Bradley's relatively low-keyed campaign may have helped him avoid damaging controversy or criticism. But his aides say that in the next few weeks, he will begin releasing more detailed policy prescriptions. And those proposals, the aides hope, will lead to a more lively debate with Mr. Gore, who has studiously avoided engaging his Democratic rival so far, preferring to set his sights on the leading Republican candidate, George W. Bush.
In today's celebratory homecoming, Mr. Bradley avoided mentioning Mr. Gore, at least directly. But in describing his desire to help working families, he took what could be viewed as a veiled shot at the Clinton Administration, which has been attacked by some liberal critics as offering too many small-bore programs to solve big problems.
"We will do fewer things," Mr. Bradley said. "But they will be essential things, and we will do them more thoroughly."
Mr. Bradley will also try to differentiate himself from Mr. Gore on character issues, his aides say. Though his camp does not bring up Mr. Clinton's impeachment and repeated ethical travails, they sense that Mr. Gore will be hurt by his association with a scandal-plagued administration. Indeed, a poll published in The Washington Post today suggested that voters are tired of Mr. Clinton and are looking for a President who will take the country in a new direction.
With that in mind, today's event was intended to present Mr. Bradley as the antithesis of a polished Washington insider -- as he has described Mr. Gore.
From start to finish, there was an almost studied homeyness to the day. Many of the town's clapboard and stone houses had home-made "Bradley for President" signs on their trim lawns. The high school band that performed before Mr. Bradley's speech occasionally played out of tune. And at a reception for Mr. Bradley in the school gymnasium, home-baked cookies were served with iced tea.
Still, there was something paradoxical about the way Mr. Bradley's campaign sought to cast the day as a natural outpouring of support for a hometown favorite, while also trying to orchestrate it as a huge media event.
Throughout the morning, campaign officials wandered through the high school halls barking orders through portable radios and cell phones. Before the event started, aides distributed copies of Mr. Bradley's nostalgic description of Crystal City in his memoir, "Time Present, Time Past," along with a fact sheet noting the precise number of stop lights in town: five.
And at sunset, Mr. Bradley led reporters and town residents on a guided tour of his boyhood haunts, including the house where he was reared, the church where he worshiped, his father's bank and the local baseball fields.
(Mr. Bradley's parents are dead, but he still owns the family's house, as well as a 250-acre farm.)
But amid all the media management, it was also clear that Mr. Bradley has remained a revered figure here since he left 38 years ago.
"He could do it all on the basketball court, but he didn't try to do it all," said Ralph Boyer, 65, a retired teacher and basketball coach at the local Catholic school who saw Mr. Bradley play in high school. "And what made him a great ball player will make him a great President."
In his speech, Mr. Bradley described himself as a "small-town boy" who learned about hard work and discipline from his father and about honesty, courage and integrity from his mother, a school teacher.
In the Little League, he said he learned about racism when a black teammate was denied service at a restaurant. "Racism disturbed me then and still angers me now," Mr. Bradley said. "For me, the only thing deserving of hate is hate itself."
As President, Mr. Bradley said, he would try to redirect some of the nation's wealth toward reducing childhood poverty and providing affordable health care to working class and poor people.
"In so many ways, we have failed to use our prosperity to improve the well-being of all our citizens," he said. "Shouldn't we be fixing our roof while the sun is shining?"
But like many other candidates this year, including Mr. Gore, he also spoke of his desire to address the nation's spiritual yearnings, as well as its material needs.
"What we need in America is a deeper prosperity," he said. "Deeper in the sense that we have a prosperity that adds up to more than the sum of all our possessions; a prosperity that makes us feel rich inside as well as out."

HEADLINE: Auto Workers Choose Ford For Canada Contract Talks

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company will be the pattern-setting company in labor negotiations with the Canadian Auto Workers Union, the union announced today.
"We will get a good settlement," Basil E. (Buzz) Hargrove, the president of the Canadian union, said. "It is time working people in our nation got a pay raise." 
 Ford praised the move. "We're pleased to be the lead company," Donald J. McKenzie, the chief negotiator for Ford of Canada, said. "There are advantages to being the lead company in that you have the opportunity to fashion an agreement that is better suited to Ford of Canada's needs and the needs of its employees."
Richer pensions for current and future retirees is "our No. 1 priority," Mr. Hargrove said. In addition, he said the union would demand improved cost-of-living adjustments, expansion of four-day workweeks, better prescription drug coverage, tuition reimbursements and child care provisions. And he said the union wanted Ford, the General Motors Corporation and DaimlerChrysler A.G. to help insure that their suppliers remain neutral in drives to unionize those companies.
Mr. Hargrove noted that each of the three companies had earned spectacular profits over the last five years and that in the last six months, Ford had earned more than the others, with $4.3 billion in net income. "The issue isn't the ability to pay, it is about the ability to force the companies to share," he said. Workers deserve "to share in the incredible wealth that we helped produce with the auto companies," he added.
Labor experts predicted that unionized auto workers in Canada and the United States would likely get strong raises this year at all three companies. "There's more of an emphasis on pay than we've seen in recent years," said Harley S. Shaiken, a professor specializing in labor and global economic issues at the University of California at Berkeley, noting the recent, rich deal the Boeing Company cut with its union.
The Canadian union will first try to reach a deal with Ford, then plans to follow the industry tradition of demanding that G.M. and DaimlerChrysler accept its terms. Canadian labor contracts expire at midnight on Sept. 21, and Mr. Hargrove said he would call a strike if no deal was reached by then.
"There shouldn't be a work stoppage if the companies come to the table recognizing the contribution of our members," Mr. Hargrove said. The Canadian union has $60 million in its strike fund, which would support workers in the event of a strike.
Mr. Hargrove said the union chose to bargain first with Ford in part because the leader of the American union, Stephen P. Yokich, had narrowed his choices to G.M. and DaimlerChrysler. "I talked to Steve Yokich this morning and he told me it could be either one," Mr. Hargrove said, adding that Mr. Yokich indicated a decision would be made within a few days.
Industry and labor experts are betting the United Automobile Workers will name DaimlerChrysler as its lead company and will try to quickly reach a deal with the German auto maker, then will insist that G.M. and Ford accept those terms. The companies' three-year contracts with U.A.W. workers expire on Sept. 14.
A G.M. spokesman echoed his words. "Everyone would like to be first, but that's strictly up to the union, so we're waiting it out," the spokesman, Edd Snyder, said.
While Mr. Hargrove said the Canadian agreement would cover the traditional three-year time frame, the agreement between the United Automobile Workers is likely to go longer, industry and labor experts said.
DaimlerChrysler proposed a five-year agreement and Ford proposed a six-year deal with the U.A.W., according to a person close to the talks. A four-year agreement was the most likely, another person close to the talks said. In the United States, no auto labor contract has lasted longer than three years since the 1950's.
The issues at DaimlerChrysler are perhaps more straightforward for the U.A.W. than at the other two companies. Because of G.M.'s past poor labor relations and because of the company's size and complexity, the union has a host of national and local concerns to work through. And at Ford, historically strong labor relations have soured lately as the company considers spinning off its giant auto parts unit, Visteon.
At DaimlerChrysler, it mostly comes down to a matter of money -- raises, benefits improvements and the like. And one thorny issue -- whether Mercedes unionizes its factory in Vance, Ala. -- might be moved off the table if the U.A.W. fears it cannot muster enough support from the workers there.
Still, G.M. was pushing to be named the target. Last week, it offered the U.A.W. lifetime employment guarantees for workers with more than 10 years of seniority. However, Mr. Hargrove said he would not be likely to accept such a deal in Canada because the promise can be renegotiated later.
Despite the record auto industry profits, Mr. Hargrove predicted difficult negotiations. "Ford will bargain tough," he said. "In spite of all of the money they are making, they are still saying, 'We can't afford this.' "

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Bradley's Announcement of Candidacy

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Bill Bradley in Crystal City, Mo., as recorded by The New York Times:
We're at a special moment in American history, not just because we're on the eve of a new millennium but because our country and the world are changing at a dazzling rate. There are two billion more people in the world market today than just a decade ago. More of our jobs are dependent on exports than ever. 
 Interest rates here in Crystal City are set by millions of individual investors worldwide who every day render their verdict on the economic health of the United States. The nature of work itself is changing. The new global economy values knowledge above all, indeed capital follows knowledge.
In such a world, physical distance disappears. Life expectancy increases, national resources can be better preserved. The entrepreneurial spirit is once again pushing America forward.
But the positive effects of globalization and technological change are falling on us unequally. The economy soars, but some of us are slipping behind. Median family income seems stuck. Personal debt and bankruptcies are at an all-time high. One out of 5 children in America still live in poverty. And while kings and dictators come to this country for the best health-care treatment in the world, you and I both know that this care is not available to the 45 million citizens who have no health insurance at all.
Is this where we want to be? Is it our best self as Americans? The numbers tell us that we're living in a time of unprecedented prosperity. But what are we doing with that prosperity? After 10 years of a robust economy, are the important things truly better? A health-care system? A school, a civic life, a family life, our children's future?
In so many ways we have failed to use our prosperity to improve the well-being of all our citizens.
Shouldn't we be fixing our roof while the sun is shining? Shouldn't we be shoring up our foundation before the rain gets in?
Now, above all, is not the time for complacency. I feel an urgency to seize this moment in history, to strengthen the weak and to challenge the strong to lead us into our full greatness as a nation.
We're at the end of what's been called the American century. We started it as a minor power and we ended as the undisputed giant among nations. For the first time in human history, one nation can truly be a light into the future. We believe that the values of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness are not just American values but human values. But first we have to embody those values at home. . . .
The Dow Jones is at record height. But as Robert Kennedy reminded us, such numbers are not the measure of all things. They do not measure what is in our heads or hearts. They do not measure a young girl's smile, a little boy's first handshake, a grandmother's pride. They convey nothing about friendship or the self-fulfillment of helping a person in need. They tell us little about the magic of a good marriage, or the satisfaction of a life led true to one's own values. They can't comfort us when personal tragedy strikes, or supersede the pleasure of a job well done. They say nothing whatsoever, these numbers, about us being "one nation under God indivisible with liberty and justice for all." . . .
There are two kinds of politicians, maybe more. Those who talk and promise, and those who listen and do. I know which one I am. As President you must listen and consult, study and examine, pray and plan. But in the end you must be guided by the compass of your own convictions and do what's right as you're given to see that right and then trust that the people will understand.

HEADLINE: In Rubin's Shadow? Summers and the Dollar

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
In his two months as Secretary of the Treasury, Lawrence H. Summers has tried to leave no daylight between his policies and those of his predecessor, Robert E. Rubin.
Given that Mr. Rubin's approach was considered stellar both on Wall Street and in Washington, and that Mr. Summers was his deputy for four years, it seems a logical approach. And it was on full display yesterday when Mr. Summers made his first major speech in his new job, to the Economic Club of New York, and broke no new ground on domestic or international issues. 
 The question now, though, is whether an evolving economic situation and intensifying political pressures will allow Mr. Summers the luxury of leaving policy on automatic pilot.
The Clinton Administration faces a showdown with the Republican-controlled Congress in the next two months over how to apportion projected Federal budget surpluses. The Administration will have to make tough choices about how hard to push its free trade agenda, balancing the growing deficit against its desire to bring China into the world trading system and start a new round of trade liberalization.
And the White House will work to help keep the political deterioration and repression in Indonesia from derailing nascent economic recovery in the rest of Asia, while trying to defuse criticism from Republicans that it has turned a blind eye to Russian corruption.
In all these debates, Mr. Summers will be in the middle and will have considerable opportunity to put his own stamp on the job.
But the issue where he is most on the spot is in managing the Administration's policy on the dollar, which is shaping up as the first big test of his ability to step into Mr. Rubin's shoes.
Mr. Rubin's tenure as Treasury Secretary was marked as much as anything by his advocacy of a strong dollar, an approach that contributed to the economic prosperity and bull market of recent years by helping to keep import prices low and to attract a flood of capital to the United States from abroad.
Despite some doubts on Wall Street about Mr. Summers's commitment to keeping the dollar as strong as it has been, he has so far given no indication that there will be the slightest change in policy.
In his speech yesterday and in a separate interview, Mr. Summers repeated word for word Mr. Rubin's mantra that a strong dollar is in the interests of the United States, and said that policy would not be determined by short-term considerations.
"One of the secrets of our success has been that we have not tried to manage economic policy to the markets, but instead have focused on strengthening economic fundamentals," he said in the interview. "Certainly that is the approach I will take."
But when speaking generally about the process of emerging from Mr. Rubin's shadow, Mr. Summers suggested that while his goals remained the same, the course he will take to get there might have to be adjusted along the way. Events in the real world, he said, could ultimately force him to reassess the way he approaches all the big issues.
"The important themes and principles that have guided our policies -- fiscal discipline, international engagement, a commitment to making the economy work for people, managing government well -- those principles require constant new application as circumstances change," Mr. Summers said in the interview.
Circumstances are certainly changing in the economic backdrop for dollar policy. As a result, questions on Wall Street about Mr. Summers's commitment to a strong dollar are being joined by questions about whether it is possible or even desirable to keep the dollar strong -- through intervention in foreign exchange markets, higher interest rates or other tactics.
Mr. Rubin was able to keep the dollar strong over the last few years without much difficulty because the economies of most other big nations were weak or weakening, making the United States the logical place for investors to keep their money. Now, most of the rest of the world, including Japan and Europe, is rebounding economically -- attracting capital that would have been invested in the United States.
At the same time, the nation's trade and current-account deficits are rapidly increasing, creating an imbalance that many investors and analysts fear could eventually lead to a weaker dollar.
And with the trade deficit growing -- and the 2000 election campaign already heating up -- there is bound to be pressure from exporters and labor groups to fight the loss of sales and jobs to foreign competitors by weakening the dollar, which would make American goods cheaper to foreign buyers.
The dollar bought 111.08 Japanese yen in late trading yesterday, up slightly for the day but down from its 1999 peak in May of more than 124 yen to the dollar. After strengthening through the first half of the year against the major European currencies, the dollar weakened over the summer against the euro before leveling off again. Yesterday, it settled at $1.0595 to the euro, compared to its strongest level just over $1.01 in mid-July.
"The fundamentals do not line up for the dollar they way they did before," said Allen Sinai of Primark Decision Economics. "The question for Summers, from a market point of view, is whether what he says about the dollar, if he says anything at all, is credible against the reality of the changed situation."
Moreover, investors seem to be testing Mr. Summers, pushing the dollar down against the yen as if to dare him to back up his words with action and disprove their doubts about his resolve.
"Because of the influence of Rubin, Larry Summers has credibility," said David Hale, an economist at Zurich Kemper Investments. "But the dollar is a sensitive area for him. There are a large number of people out there who believe that in his heart of hearts, Larry Summers wants to devalue the dollar."
Mr. Hale said that some of the suspicions about Mr. Summers' resolve stemmed from a historical pattern in which Treasury secretaries who came from backgrounds on Wall Street, like Mr. Rubin, presided over periods of dollar strength, while secretaries from other backgrounds saw the dollar fall on their watch. Mr. Summers is an academic economist.
By this theory, those from outside Wall Street -- people like James A. Baker 3d, the Texas lawyer who served under President Reagan, and Lloyd W. Bentsen, the former Senator from Texas who was Mr. Rubin's predecessor under President Clinton -- are more sympathetic to arguments that a weaker dollar can help stimulate exports and protect jobs at home.
If the dollar is shaping up as a test of Mr. Summers's economic and financial acumen, dealing with economic policy toward Russia may prove to be the first big test of his ability to operate in a political minefield.
A Federal investigation into whether money from Russia was laundered through the Bank of New York has prompted criticism from some Republicans that the Administration, and the Treasury Department in particular, have not been tough enough in demanding that Government in Moscow crack down on corruption. With elections next year, analysts say the issue could well lead to pressure on the Administration to scale back Russian financial aid through the International Monetary Fund.
"To quarantine Russia, or to write it off as some have suggested, would I think be a potentially disastrous error," Mr. Summers said. "The policy challenge is to find a balance between being supportive of the Russian people, in whose support for market democracy we have an enormous stake, while at the same time protecting our own basic interests."

HEADLINE: THE CONTENDERS: Running Toward 2000;
Quayle, Seeking Vindication, Plods On With High Hopes

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: GOFFSTOWN, N.H., Sept. 7

 BODY:
By the time Dan Quayle made it to the Rotary Club breakfast here at 7:30 A.M., he had already finished two radio interviews and was bursting to offer this latest audience his distinctive conservative refrain: an embrace of family values, a call for a 30 percent tax cut and his lamentation over what he views as the dark spiritual legacy of the Clinton Administration.
But when the former Vice President concluded his remarks, he was met with another variation of the question he encounters at almost every turn these days: Why, given his weak showing in last month's Iowa straw poll, and the overwhelming signs of Republican support for Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, is Mr. Quayle staying in the race at all? 
 "They say it is over," Mr. Quayle said, displaying just a slight edge of frustration at hearing the question again, this time from a Rotarian. "It is not over."
"I plead with my party members, 'We need to have a serious debate,' " Mr. Quayle said, adding: "The Republicans are on the verge of saying to the Republican Party and the primary voter that we're going to have a coronation, that we're not going to have a serious primary. That would be most unfortunate, and it would diminish our chances in November."
Mr. Quayle, whose slingshot career has given him a glimpse of both the heights and the depths of American politics by the age of 52, appears to be back at the bottom of his political trajectory. Since his eighth-place finish in the Iowa straw poll -- only two candidates fared worse, one of whom did not even compete in the nonbinding contest -- some of Mr. Quayle's aides have quit for other campaigns, his old friends from the White House privately describe his Presidential ambitions as hopeless, and he is drawing small crowds. Even a signing for his new book in Boston on Tuesday that was advertised to last for 90 minutes petered out after 20, as the lunchtime line of autograph seekers dwindled away.
Yet, with poignant tenacity, Mr. Quayle perseveres, motivated by the political vindication he has pursued since he was selected as a Vice-Presidential candidate 11 years ago, and by the dogged belief in the possibility of success.
The candidate's schedule here on Labor Day was typical: He managed two television shows, a parade and two picnics, all before dinner. There is, it seems, no invitation that he will not accept. Labor Day morning found the former Vice President of the United States hustling down a set of stairs into a basement entrance to the Milford Town Hall, which was closed except for the cramped room serving as the studio for the local cable television show that was giving Mr. Quayle an hour of time.
For Mr. Quayle, the prospect of becoming the Republican nominee for President in 2000, as fanciful as that seems to many in his party, remains a realistic goal, if admittedly a difficult one. It is simply a matter of conservatives rallying around him as their ideological alternate to Governor Bush, Mr. Quayle said. And then, he continued, it is simply a matter of Mr. Bush's campaign collapsing, notwithstanding its continued signs of health.
"Eventually, the conservatives will have to take a deep breath and ask themselves this question: Who is the conservative candidate that is most qualified, and has the best chance of defeating George Bush and ultimately prevailing against Bradley or Gore?" Mr. Quayle said in an interview.
"Believe me, if I didn't think I had a good chance of winning -- why spend 18 hours a day, six, seven days a week doing this?" he asked. "There are other things in life. The moment I'm convinced that I can't win, then I won't be here."
There is little doubt, that he brings a strong resume to the race. He has far broader governmental experience -- he is a former Representative, Senator and Vice President -- than any of his opponents. Indeed, he was serving as Vice President to Mr. Bush's father when the younger Mr. Bush showed hardly a glimmer of interest in public service.
Alone among the conservatives in the race, Mr. Quayle has won election to public office. And he has a cogent ideological appeal that impresses his audiences.
Yet, that does not seem to be enough. As Mr. Quayle turns all his attention to this state and its first-in-the-nation Presidential primary, he is finding that his most daunting opponent is not Mr. Bush, but himself -- or rather, the frozen image of himself as a hesitant and intellectually slight figure that even Mr. Quayle acknowledges is the legacy of his Vice Presidency.
"The introduction that I had to the American people, that was totally unfair and is something that I have to deal with today," Mr. Quayle said, bristling at the memory. "The unfair, outrageous, false coverage. From Day 1, from the introduction, it was all BOOM -- totally, 100 percent negative."
Mr. Quayle is reminded of this more often than he would like. As he marched cheerfully along the parade route in Milford on Labor Day, Beverly Simpson, 75, met his smiling glance with a stern shake of her head, turning away as he sought to greet her. "I think he ought to drop out and let Bush have it," Mrs. Simpson said. "I don't think he is the man for the job. Mark my words -- I don't think he has the makings of a President."
Mr. Quayle's most enthusiastic supporters, after ticking off what they say should make him a particularly attractive candidate in this conservative state, acknowledge that his candidacy remains problematic.
"It's what I call the next-door-neighbor-people problem," said John H. Sununu, a former Governor of New Hampshire who is Mr. Quayle's biggest supporter. "They say, 'I really think he's great, but how are you going to convince my neighbor to vote for him?' And you talk to the neighbor and they say, 'I think he's great, but how are you going to convince my neighbor to vote for him?' "
Mr. Quayle suggests that the only way to counter the argument that he cannot win is, obviously, to win. Yet he acknowledges that there are people who will not vote for him because of the perception cited by Mr. Sununu, and seems flummoxed as he considers this contradiction of his political situation.
"Don't rely on others to go back 10 years ago, or whatever the case may be, to some false caricature that we know is totally not true," Mr. Quayle pleaded to listeners on WGIR-AM in Manchester on Tuesday morning. "Go with what's in your heart."
Through it all, the candidate shows no signs of flagging, offering an energetic and ideologically distinctive agenda that inevitably invites a comparison with the more general agenda offered by Governor Bush. Mr. Quayle supports a 30 percent cut in taxes. He advocates 12-year term limits for members of Congress or, alternately, a constitutional amendment that would stop the pensions and health-care benefits of lawmakers after 12 years.
But Mr. Quayle's overwhelming theme is a return to what he describes as traditional values. It is what has come to define his political views since he gave a speech assailing the television character Murphy Brown after she decided to give birth out of wedlock.
Americans, Mr. Quayle said, are understandably jubilant about the state of the economy and their material lives. "But ask them how are they doing inside," Mr. Quayle said. "Their hearts ache. They can see the cultural decline.
"We need to reclaim values that made America great in the first place," he continued. "Reclaim values like respect. Integrity. The value of faith. The value of freedom."
There is no question that Mr. Quayle's words have some appeal here. "I like everything he stands for -- family values," said Kevin Currie, 32, a forklift operator. "I don't think the press treats him fairly at all."
In pushing his quest for the Presidency, Mr. Quayle often suggests comparisons to another former Vice President who went on to become President, Richard M. Nixon.
But Mr. Nixon succeeded because he spent eight years creating a new image for himself; Mr. Quayle has resisted friends' advice that he do the same thing, arguing that to attempt that would be to affirm, in effect, an unfair caricature.
Indeed, Republicans who have advised Mr. Quayle over the years think that given the crowded current field, which includes several candidates who have Mr. Quayle's ideology without his history, it is unrealistic to think that he could succeed even if Mr. Bush were to fail.
"I'm afraid I think that's fanciful," said William Kristol, who was Mr. Quayle's chief of staff and is now editor of The Weekly Standard, a conservative magazine. "That's wishful thinking in the extreme. But I can see how he believes it. I mean, maybe it should be the case."
And these days, as Mr. Quayle makes his last stand in New Hampshire, it seems hard to quarrel with Mr. Kristol's assessment. As Mr. Quayle was stepping briskly around a turn in the Milford parade, he came upon a marquee. It was scattered with a jumble of letters, but one word, evidently a greeting for Mr. Quayle, stood out: "potatoe."
Mr. Quayle looked toward the sign, and then his gaze floated away as he turned to the other side of the street with a wave to the crowd, and quietly finished his march to a van waiting to take him to his next stop.
