HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Should Clinton embrace the China trade deal? Some say yes.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
GRAB it. So say many economists, referring to the bold trade deal that China offered the United States in April and President Clinton rejected in what many deem a serious foreign policy blunder. Mr. Clinton can reverse course when he meets President Jiang Zemin on Sunday in Australia.
China wants to enter the World Trade Organization in time for the group's next meeting in Seattle in November, when the member nations are expected to embark on a new round of world trade talks. But before China can join, it needs the approval of Mr. Clinton and Congress. So it offered huge "concessions" on nearly every front. 
 Concessions is the lingo of tradespeak. But the term is wholly misleading. China's promise to open its economy to foreign goods and investment would serve its own self-interest yet would be largely irrelevant to the economic fortunes of the United States. Some concession.
Critics make three arguments for rejecting the offer. Delay could achieve better terms in the future. The deal's nice-sounding terms are unenforceable. And China's entry into the trade group would flood American markets with cheap textiles and apparel.
But judging from an analysis of Daniel H. Rosen and his colleagues at the Institute for International Economics, the first criticism appears weak, the second misleading and the third misguided.
The precise terms of China's offer remain unpublished, though the Administration published a summary. The breadth of the offer is stunning. China would drastically cut tariffs to levels less than those of most United States trade partners. It would eliminate export subsidies, phase out quotas on industrial products and comply immediately with World Trade Organization rules for protecting foreign investors and intellectual property.
China also agreed to phase out regulations that restrict foreign companies from importing, exporting, wholesaling and retailing. The offer would permit foreign companies to buy substantial stakes in insurance and telecommunications companies. China also agreed to have its state-owned enterprises make purchases on nondiscriminatory terms, based solely on price, quality and other commercial considerations.
Jeffrey Schott of the institute said that these terms were "substantially more liberal than those the United States had hoped to get out of negotiations and substantially more liberal than those which a number of existing W.T.O. members, like India, currently adhere to. You can't say that the terms of the agreement don't measure up."
Greg Mastel of the New American Foundation, a prominent critic, says that the deal is deficient on telecommunications and financial services. He has a point. There is, for example, no firm provision to eliminate nonperforming loans from banks, which serve as disguised subsidies to state-owned enterprises. This omission raises questions about China's commitment to run its state-owned enterprises on a commercial basis.
Mr. Mastel also criticizes the deal because, he says, it cannot be enforced. China is not, he warned, "a rule-based society" that makes decisions in ways that can be monitored and challenged. He points to China's repeated violations of patent and copyright protections.
But here the Administration must ask, what is the alternative? In the absence of membership, China could continue many of its protectionist ways with impunity. But as a member, China is subject to the trade group's disciplinary process that has proven to be impartial and unflinching.
The United States would lose the right to impose unilateral trade sanctions against China once it joins the group. But the United States would gain international backing for sanctions so that every dispute does not turn into a bilateral foreign policy spat. Also, China would be responsible for meeting market-opening commitments that go well beyond anything the United States can now demand.
Critics point to the fact that as a member of the World Trade Organization, China would escape restrictions now in place on its exports of textiles and apparel to the United States. But Marcus Noland of the institute estimates that most Chinese sales here come at the expense of imports from other countries, not American manufacturers. Indeed, the institute estimates that American exports to China under the trade deal would rise by about $3 billion. Imports from China would rise by slightly more, so the overall effect on the $8 trillion American economy would be minute.
For the most part, the United States already provides China nondiscriminatory access. So why does China fight for admission to a club whose benefits it largely enjoys already? Prime Minister Zhu Rongji apparently needs the weight of international commitments to help overcome domestic opposition to his ambitious plan to drive his economy away from state controls and toward markets. That would seem to be an ambition that Mr. Clinton would want to propel rather than sabotage.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Canadian Auto Workers To Bargain With Ford First
Ford Motor will be the pattern-setting company in labor negotiations with the Canadian Auto Workers Union, the union announced. The union will first try to reach a deal with Ford, then it plans to follow the industry tradition of demanding that G.M. and DaimlerChrysler accept its terms.
The Canadian union said it chose Ford in part because the leader of the American union, Stephen P. Yokich, had narrowed his choices to General Motors and DaimlerChrysler. Industry and labor experts are betting the United Automobile Workers will name DaimlerChrysler as its lead company. Page C2. 

Greenspan Talks, but Not of Rates
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggested in a speech that the United States economy's expansion could continue, thanks to advancements in technology. But he did not discuss his views on interest rates, inflation or current economic conditions. C8.
 
Stocks End Mixed Ahead of Report
Stocks ended mixed as investors remained cautious ahead of the producer price index, which is scheduled to be released tomorrow. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.21 points, to 11,036.34. The Nasdaq composite index fell 28.52 points, or 1.02 percent, to 2,808.74, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 6.30 points, or five-tenths of a percent, to 1,344.15. C9.
 
Bond prices edged up as traders covered short positions after the Federal Reserve took measures to insure there would be enough money in the banking system to counter any Year 2000 computer problems. The yield on the 30-year issue was unchanged. C9.
 
S.E.C. Fines Van Kampen $100,000
The Securities and Exchange Commission censured and fined Van Kampen Investment Advisory $100,000 for marketing the Van Kampen Growth fund's hot track record without disclosing how its returns were actually obtained. The S.E.C. said Van Kampen improperly failed to disclose to investors that more than half of the fund's 1996 return of 62 percent came from hot initial offerings. The fund was able to buy these initial offerings while it had only a few hundred thousand dollars of assets and was closed to the public. Market Place. C10.
 
Britain Raises Key Interest Rate
Britain's central bank raised a key short-term money rate for the first time in more than a year in a pre-emptive move against inflation. The quarter-point increase in the securities repurchase rate, to 5.25 percent, broke a series of seven modest rate cuts. In response, the pound rose, settling in London at $1.6209 and in New York at $1.6192, up from $1.6049. Stocks moved lower, closing down slightly less than 1 percent in London. C4.
 
Delta Air Switches Ad Agencies
Delta Air Lines ended a two-month advertising review by dismissing its agency of two and a half years, Saatchi & Saatchi, and shifting its worldwide account to Leo Burnett. Trade publications have reported billings at $100 million. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.
 
Sony Backs Tivo Digital Format
The next generation of video recorders -- digital devices that save programs on a hard drive instead of on a video cassette -- received a lift when Sony announced it had agreed to make the device using a platform from Tivo, one of three competing designs. C6.
 
Credit Profiling Comes to Mexico
Two of the biggest American credit reporting companies, Trans Union of Chicago and Equifax of Atlanta, are building files and computer systems in Mexico that will give bankers there the same instantaneous credit profiles that bankers in New York and Miami and Los Angeles take for granted. C4.
 
Planet Hollywood Down but Not Out
Despite complaints about its food and difficulties attracting younger people and repeat customers, the Planet Hollywood restaurant chain can still flourish by closing unprofitable outlets and "going back to the basics," said Robert Earl, its chief executive. C8.

HEADLINE: Herbert Stein, Nixon Adviser And Economist, Is Dead at 83

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Herbert Stein, a free-market economist who used careful analysis and sharp wit to persuade the business community in the 1940's to rally behind the "unnatural" idea of using Federal budget deficits to regulate the economy, died yesterday at a hospital in Washington. He was 83.
The cause was heart failure, said his daughter, Rachel Epstein of New York City. 
 Most famous as a member and later chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under Presidents Nixon and Ford, Mr. Stein seldom let ideological purity stand in the way of what he thought was economic common sense.
He made news in the 1960's and 70's, but he made economic history in the 1940's. Mr. Stein served as an economist for the Committee for Economic Development for 22 years, starting in 1945. The committee, formed during World War II by executives and educators to study economic issues, adopted early on the idea, associated with John Maynard Keynes, of running deficits to moderate economic downturns.
Robert Solow, a Nobel Laureate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, applauded Mr. Stein's role in bringing the business community, a potentially hostile audience, behind the strategic use of deficits, a linchpin of economic thinking in the Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon Administrations.
"He convinced a powerful business lobby that there was no ideological reason not to pursue Keynesian fiscal policy," Mr. Solow said yesterday. Mr. Stein argued that while Government spending and revenue could be matched over the long run, it could be economically destructive during recessions to raise taxes or cut spending to eliminate deficits in the short run.
By now, this idea is commonplace. But it was an uncomfortable, heretical notion in the 1940's.
Mr. Stein, at the suggestion of Milton Friedman of the University of Chicago, served on President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers from 1969 to 1972 and as chairman of the council until 1974. During that time, he helped design Mr. Nixon's 90-day freeze of wages and prices and its aftermath -- an uncomfortable position for a conservative who preached the benefits of unfettered markets.
After he left Government, he became a professor at the University of Virginia and joined the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group. He gained more fame by writing pointed, often humorous columns for The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times and other large newspapers.
Because his writing often defended surprisingly liberal positions, he became known as the liberals' favorite conservative -- a tag line, Mr. Solow says, that made Mr. Stein cringe because he wanted his ideas to be applauded for their sensible, pragmatic underpinnings.
Mr. Stein came to what others perceived as contradictory positions because he followed the nonideological logic of the economist's tool box. He argued against those, including fellow Republicans, who focused on a relatively small number, the Federal deficit, when what they should be analyzing, in his view, was the entire composition of national spending. With that figure in mind, Mr. Stein argued that the nation could afford to spend not only more on the military, which he often favored, but also more to combat poverty.
Charles Schultze of the Brookings Institution praised Mr. Stein for refusing to give into fads. He understood that taxes depress economic activity, but he refused to follow those who fell in love with extreme versions of supply-side economics -- the notion, popular in the 1980's, that tax cuts would unleash waves of more work and investment. Mr. Schultze recalled a conference at which Mr. Stein punctured a speaker's faddish claims about the revolutionary effect of computers and the Internet by simply observing that the effect of those technological changes were not as great as that of the steam engine.
Mr. Stein was born in Detroit, received a bachelor's degree from Williams College in 1935 and a doctorate in economics from the University of Chicago in 1958. His most important academic work was "The Fiscal Revolution in America," published in 1969, which examined decades of American fiscal policy and its effect on the economy.
In addition to his daughter, Mr. Stein is survived by a son, Ben of Los Angeles, the host of the Comedy Central television quiz program "Win Ben Stein's Money"; a sister, Pearl Weiss, of Sarasota, Fla., and three grandchildren.
Mr. Stein was famous for making sensible economic points with wit and style. He frequently reminded Jeremiahs that "if a thing cannot go on forever, it will stop." His point was that economies adjust to growing trade deficits, accelerating prices and ballooning deficits and that to project that bad things will continue indefinitely makes no sense.
Cautioning against attaching religious significance to the deficit, Mr. Stein wrote: "I have consulted a concordance on the Bible. Apparently the world 'budget' does not appear in either the Old or the New Testament. The world 'balance' does appear about eight times, but never in connection with fiscal policy."

HEADLINE: Officials Urge M.T.A. to Build Full Second Ave. Subway Line

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
Calling on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to show the vision and foresight they said were needed to protect the city's future, elected officials urged the agency yesterday to seek enough funds to pay for a Second Avenue subway line running the length of Manhattan.
In August, the M.T.A. described alternatives for a Second Avenue line in its five-year capital plan. The most ambitious version offered by the agency, which critics called the stub line, would run under Second Avenue from 125th Street to 63d Street, where it would switch onto tracks now used by the N and R lines. 
 The original plan for a Second Avenue line from the Bronx to the financial district was scrapped in the 1970's because of the city's fiscal crisis. The Lexington Avenue subway line is the only one running north-south on the East Side, and trains are overcrowded to the point of being dangerous, riders' advocates say.
The authority also has plans for a Long Island Rail Road link to Grand Central Terminal, which would add about 17,000 passengers a day to the Lexington Avenue line, where rib-to-elbows rush hour rides are common. Gov. George E. Pataki, who controls the M.T.A., strongly supports that link. The M.T.A. is expected to present its five-year capital plan to its board of directors on Sept. 29.
At a press conference at City Hall, City Councilman A. Gifford Miller said, "If the subway represents the arteries of our city, the Lexington Avenue line is about to cause us a major cardiac arrest."
The Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields, spoke in favor of a Second Avenue line reaching from 125th Street to the Battery.
"Growth of jobs in Manhattan is directly tied to a good transit system," she said. "The need has never been greater. Our city's economic future indeed is riding on it."
Earlier yesterday, the Empire State Transportation Alliance, a new coalition of 46 groups as diverse as the Straphangers Campaign and the Automobile Club of New York, called for building the entire Second Avenue line.
Lew Rudin, chairman of the Association for a Better New York, said: "We're sitting on top of a new, exciting communications industry. How could we not move people to the Wall Street area and South Bronx, Harlem and Long Island City?" he said.
Bob Yaro, co-chairman of the transit coalition and executive director of the Regional Plan Association, said that by 2020, 350,000 more jobs are expected in the city. "We've essentially used up the transportation system built by our grandparents," he said. "New York avoids investment in expansion and improvements at its peril."
But Gary Caplan, the M.T.A.'s budget director, defended the shorter line when he testified before the City Council Transportation Committee. He said it would begin at 125th Street and then switch to existing, unused express tracks along the N and the R lines under Broadway, allowing riders to ride from Harlem to City Hall, through the financial district, then on to Brooklyn, without switching trains.
Mr. Caplan said extending the Second Avenue line south of 63d Street would create only an additional 1 percent reduction in crowding at the Grand Central stop on the Lexington Avenue line and 5 percent at the line's 86th Street station over the reductions the stub line would create, and would cost more than twice as much as the shorter line, which he estimated at $3.6 billion.
At the hearing, Councilwoman Kathryn Freed assailed the M.T.A.'s plan. "Maybe it is a first step, but it is an inadequate first step," she told Mr. Caplan, then raised the possibility of someone firing the M.T.A. and holding the Governor and Mayor responsible for transportation.
Mr. Gifford, who represents the Upper East Side, then asked Mr. Caplan, "Why isn't the M.T.A. saying there's not enough money? Why do you say we've got to come up with modest plans for modest resources? I believe more money needs to be raised. But where are you? Where is the M.T.A. when there's not enough money and we need more?"
Mr. Caplan replied, "We believe this is what can be funded."
In later testimony, Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer said the city must consider the consequences of doing nothing. "The economic loss due to traffic congestion exceeds $6.6 billion dollars annually within New York City," he said.

INDUSTRY: SIC4111 LOCAL & SUBURBAN TRANSIT; 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%);

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (97%);
